excerpts: Perbacco is a lovely Italian restaurant with an atmosphere of quaint traditionalism - a no hipster zone.
Between a party of three we had 2 appetizers, 3 entrees, a cocktail, 1/4 liter of white wine, dessert wine, coffee, and a dessert.
The bill with tip came out to a very reasonable $200.
perbacco.author: Amber M.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is a lovely Italian restaurant with an atmosphere of quaint traditionalism - a no hipster zone. Between a party of three we had 2 appetizers, 3 entrees, a cocktail, 1/4 liter of white wine, dessert wine, coffee, and a dessert. The bill with tip came out to a very reasonable $200. Everything was plated beautifully and the portions were pretty spot on. 

1. Hamachi crudo with clementine, hearts of palm. Very sashimi-like, ultra fresh fish. 

2. Seared octopus with black chanterelles and broad beans. One of our favorites. Extremely fragrant and multi-dimensional dish with the varying textures of the octopus and silky beans. 

3. Barley pasta "rags" with veal suco and black chanterelles. Another favorite. I'm guessing their housemade pastas are all a standout and have that unmistakable "toothsome" fresh texture. Just a tad salty. 

4. Suckling pig with brussell sprouts, chestnut spaetzle, persimmon. This meaty dish had different cuts of pork - mostly pork belly. Need I say more?

5. Butternut squash cannelloni on top of a bed of vegetables and black chanterelles - probably the most unimpressive thing we ordered. It was good, but almost too simple. You literally were served two crepe-like cannelloni's with pureed butternut squash.  

6. Almond semi-freddo with chocolate, pomegranates. Beautiful dessert with lots of playful bits and fruity things scattered on the plate. 

Great service, lovely meal!

excerpts: This was my second time at Perbacco, and I was just as impressed as my first time.
I arrived an hour or so earlier than my reservation, hoping that they would take my friend and me, but not expecting it.
perbacco.author: Miriam F.
perbacco.review:
This was my second time at Perbacco, and I was just as impressed as my first time. I arrived an hour or so earlier than my reservation, hoping that they would take my friend and me, but not expecting it. They had us seated within the next 20 minutes or so! 

Food: Incredible. It's an experience, not just calories you consume. The flavors, textures, and colors all complement each other. This food is definitely NOT something you can make at home. OH! THE TAGLIETTELE. get it. enough said. 

Service: Wonderful. Polite, respectful, timely.

This is great for a little date spot or a birthday dinner for a friend. Intimate.

excerpts: It's about time I review Perbacco.
Our sales team has eaten lunch here 6 times in the last 3 months.
I'm the food guy on my team.
I pick the restaurant and we go.
The food here is fresh and they serve you fast.
perbacco.author: Al G.
perbacco.review:
It's about time I review Perbacco. Our sales team has eaten lunch here 6 times in the last 3 months. I'm the food guy on my team. I pick the restaurant and we go. The food here is fresh and they serve you fast. (we always eat at the counter unless our boss is with us)

The apps we've all eaten: Little Gem salad, Burrata cheese, Marinated beets, Fritto misto of shrimp, Seared local squid, Vitello tonnato.  All equally delicious. My personal favorites are the seared local squid, marinated beets. 

Several of my teammates are major red meat eaters and love the hangar steak and the pork meatballs, that's all they every order. It's hard to go wrong with rare hangar steak.  Two of the guys are big pasta/carb eaters and have eaten: COUJETTE, AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN and the TAJARIN. I think the Tajarin in particular should be a little more al dente. 

In short, in the last 3 months, we've ordered everything on the lunch menu except for sides: turnips, cauliflower and the carrots.

It helps that the restaurant is 2 blocks away from us and it caters to the business crowd during lunch.

excerpts: This is my fourth time at Perbacco.
I make it a priority to have lunch or dinner there when I come to town because it's just the best Italian restaurant in the city.
perbacco.author: Mrs Cella S.
perbacco.review:
This is my fourth time at Perbacco. I make it a priority to have lunch or dinner there when I come to town because it's just the best Italian restaurant in the city. Period. 

The fresh, homemade gnocchi was out of this world, as was the beet salad and green salad. The chef's use of unique ingredient combinations (in just the right proportions) are one of the things that make this place so special. it's not your average Italian restaurant. 

Get lots of small plates to share because you're going to want to try everything.

excerpts: Throw back a Perbacco, allegesh beer, or hitachino beer and everything will be A - ok!
perbacco.author: Dub C.
perbacco.review:
If you are looking for spaghetti & meatballs don't come here. That's in the north beach. Don't get me wrong, I like spaghetti & meatballs. 
Things to get: Salumi misti, Raviolo, Seared octopus, 
Dry aged duck breast, Hamachi crudo, and Parpadelle. You can't go wrong with those items. Throw back a Perbacco, allegesh beer, or hitachino beer and everything will be A - ok!

excerpts: Perbacco seriously had the best pasta in San Francisco.
perbacco.author: Yuliya B.
perbacco.review:
Such a delightful experience! Perbacco seriously had the best pasta in San Francisco. 

Table cloth on the tables and romantic ambiance makes it a special place. 

You have to try their lamb pappardelle! Paired with 20 rows Cabernet, it tastes like heaven!

excerpts: I've been to Perbacco several times, granted perhaps 7-9 years ago.
I used to love it.
Tonight, the service was deplorable, the food was horrible....
what a waste of one of two nights in SF.
I could give numerous examples of the low quality of the food and service, but quite honestly, I don't even want to give this place any more of my time.
From start to finish it was just bad.
Really bad.
Sigh.
perbacco.author: Shawna M.
perbacco.review:
Ugh... absolutely awful! I've been to Perbacco several times, granted perhaps 7-9 years ago. I used to love it. Tonight, the service was deplorable, the food was horrible.... what a waste of one of two nights in SF.
I could give numerous examples of the low quality of the food and service, but quite honestly, I don't even want to give this place any more of my time. From start to finish it was just bad. Really bad. Sigh.

excerpts: I could see Perbacco working well for a date, business lunch/dinner, or a night w/
the girlfriends like me.
Just be aware that you might end up right next to a table full of bankers loudly saying "f*ck" every other word.
Otherwise, it was a pleasant experience!
perbacco.author: Ziyan C.
perbacco.review:
I could see Perbacco working well for a date, business lunch/dinner, or a night w/ the girlfriends like me. Just be aware that you might end up right next to a table full of bankers loudly saying "f*ck" every other word. Otherwise, it was a pleasant experience! Good service.

MUST-HAVES: Pork shoulder, Panna Cotta

* Free breadsticks & pesto - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#N7xbp6EedwBYIcAa-edZkw
Fantastic. Don't know how these little things can pack so much flavor, but they did. I only wish I could scoop more of that pesto dip w/ the breadsticks.

* Salumi Misti - 3 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#eixdC-amvYWxutfe1IOjGQ
(A selection of house cured salumi inspired by traditional piemontese recipes. $18/$28)
My friend wanted to get this. While the meats were good & there was tons of variety, I found this dish basically a way to stuff & bloat us so we couldn't enjoy the actual cooked entrees later. I also just noticed the immense price tag on this plate. There was also sourdough, breadsticks, & a preserve/jam that came w/ the meats. However, unless you are a cured meat fanatic &/or get some sort of immense pleasure out of it, I would probably skip this. Or at least go for the half portion.

* Roasted figs - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#eixdC-amvYWxutfe1IOjGQ
(w/ scidumin cheese, toasted hazelnuts, juniper cured lonza, white crane springs' greens. $13)
Really nice! Every ingredient was intense but it worked well. There was a cheese spread on the side (the texture was like hummus) - it looks innocent but is about 3x stronger than blue cheese. The greens were bitter, the figs fresh & sweet. But when you got it all in one bite, pretty close to perfection.

* Rabaton - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#5JemtEuuyFwJMI8eUnmtyA
Cross-section:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#zMdtKseG39sgLo41nhpI0A
(herb & spinach ricotta gnocchi, blu di langa fonduta, toasted hazelnuts. $13 half/ $18 whole)
My friends didn't like this, but I enjoyed it for being a unique gnocchi! The texture had a little more give than you'd expect, but was still soft. You can actually see pieces of the herb in each piece. The flavor of the white sauce was pretty strong, & it was very viscous. A pretty intense dish, but I liked it!

* Stracci - 3 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#AJqVXsFf24ratdhlRtheSA
(baladin beer pasta "rags", liberty farm duck ragu, brown butter apples. $14 half/ $19 whole)
I liked the texture of the curly thin pasta - soft, not too al dente which I don't usually prefer. However, I found the duck ragu to be too salty & thought it was just a big mass of ground meat in a thick sauce. Duck is so much better when you can feel the texture of the meat!

* Capicollo arrosto - 4 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#AW1MZnxmW-tv-4lWVPDojQ
Cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#R-umuC7Neuw4uOsveGoKBw
(slow roasted pork shoulder, roasted corn polenta, baby turnips, charred shallots. $24)
Fantastic. The pork was super tender & hearty. They kept the green stalks on the turnips & it was incredibly fresh & crunchy. The polenta was fantastic, probably helped by the fact that it had whole kernels of corn. That instance of sweetness in the savory dish was always a nice surprise. 

* Fingerling potatoes - 2.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#ZLC3E-B9-uJS7RextappyQ
(pan roasted in lardo w/ rosemary & garlic. $5)
Not impressed, but probably because my friend requested it to be made vegetarian, ie. no pig fat =(. This was dry & the skin didn't have a good crunch.

* Panforte - 2 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#4N_XTtBVvTVoeDdPC-WZ7g
(spiced nut & dried fruit cake. $3)
The entire reason I went to this restaurant was b/c my friend kept raving on & on about an Italian bread pudding dessert. I showed her the dessert menu & she said it was the panforte. I blindly ordered this & she must've chosen the wrong one! It was pretty bad, very dense - I like dense but this was too much! Like hardened jam. Only one of us liked it, but even she couldn't finish the last tiny bite.

* Rose geranium panna cotta - 4.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ#_5KAhclzY4UrdeyXe7q1OQ
(w/ raspberries, cocoa nib lime crumble. $9)
Props to our server for getting this order through, even though we were the last table at the restaurant & they were closing up the kitchen! This was fantastic, perfect soft texture, subtle flavors, plus the crumbles for added texture.

excerpts: Perbacco is legit.
perbacco.author: Dan I.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is legit. And coming from a full-blooded Italian who cooks his own serious Italian food, that's saying something. 

We started with the Burrata salad, which unlike most that has just tomatoes also had white corn and toasted almonds. It was a wonderful blend of flavors and the cheese itself was perfect -- not too soft/runny or too firm. 

For entrees, my wife and I split two pastas. One was the herb and spinach ricotta gnocchi with wild mushrooms ragu and snap peas. It was as good as it sounds -- rich mushroom flavor and soft, decadent gnocchi. The other was a pappardelle with a short rib ragu. The meat was so tender and created an amazing gravy. 

For dessert, my wife got an aged cow's milk cheese - testun al Barolo, beppino occelli. She went crazy over it. I, however, opted for a nice dram of grappa. And it was really lovely. 

So the food was spectacular. The space was also cool, sort of elegant but not stuffy vibe. The service, though, was only average. Our waitress wasn't particularly attentive and it took some time to get our bread at the start. Though that made the experience slightly imperfect, the food was good enough that I can't not give this place 5 stars.

excerpts: I pass Perbacco nearly everyday
and it's been high on my list for a culinary splurge.
perbacco.author: Amy Z.
perbacco.review:
Since I've become knocked up and Bridge and Tunnel, diners at these types of joints happen a lot less frequently then they used to. 

I pass Perbacco nearly everyday and it's been high on my list for a culinary splurge. Also recently saw it on Check Please where it received a very favorable review. 

The pricing is about what I expected and fair for the quality and level of service. I opted for the pappardelle with a side of Brussels sprouts. Both were brought out at the same time. My friend opted for the butternut squash ravioli with a side of sunchokes. Oh and the rolls with butter are amazing and worth every carb. 

We were both pleased with the pasta dish, but each of the veggie sides were severely overcooked. Mushy Brussels sprouts was a first for me and were void of flavor. We each barely ate half so I thought the server might question, but another of the staff took the dishes away without any question. When a couple of people are attending to the table, it makes it awkward to raise these types of issues. 

The strawberry themed dessert was amazing in presentation and taste. I'd like to return at some point and try some of the spring fare.

excerpts: I love that Perbacco offers half-dish portions too - was able to try 2 dishes :) "Farfalle" was good, but not mindblowing like Raviora.
Strawberry fields drink is yummy.
Service was awesome/friendly/helpful!
Definitely going back.
Like tomorrow.
perbacco.author: Deanna T.
perbacco.review: The "Raviora" is to die for!!!  Wowowow.  Best pasta I've had next to Ortolana in New Zealand.  Glad I don't have to fly back there to satisfy my pasta cravings.  I love that Perbacco offers half-dish portions too - was able to try 2 dishes :) "Farfalle" was good, but not mindblowing like Raviora. Strawberry fields drink is yummy. Service was awesome/friendly/helpful!  Definitely going back. Like tomorrow.

excerpts: The service at Perbacco is always great, whether lunch, dinner or after dinner drinks and desserts
but I'm never wowed by their food anymore.
My friends and I used to love their Papperdelle with meat cooked with horseradish
but apparently it's not on the menu anymore.
If you like mediocre food outstandingly served, topped off with a large bill at the end of your dining experience, go to Perbacco.
They won't give you what you bargained for.
perbacco.author: Jen L.
perbacco.review: Great service, bad food, low value. I was really happy that they had a booth available for two for a last minute lunch at 1pm. I was equally impressed by the attentiveness of the wait staff who got my drink order before I even had a chance to look at the menu and his attentiveness throughout our meal, filling water glasses and bringing us more bread as soon as we scarfed down the first pieces. Our food came out really quickly but we were quite disappointed with the overall quality, preparation and flavor. The Tajarin (handcut thin tagliatelle, 5 hour pork and porcini mushroom sugo) was like ramen topped with dry sloppy joe meat and the Polpette (meatballs over mashed potatoes and raisins) was a little sweet with too much cinnamon. We only liked the Brussel Sprouts but funny enough both the sprouts (cooked with duck fat) and meatballs (served with marinara and no cinnamon) are way better at Barbacco where the service is not as good! The service at Perbacco is always great, whether lunch, dinner or after dinner drinks and desserts but I'm never wowed by their food anymore. My friends and I used to love their Papperdelle with meat cooked with horseradish but apparently it's not on the menu anymore. If you like mediocre food outstandingly served, topped off with a large bill at the end of your dining experience, go to Perbacco. They won't give you what you bargained for.

excerpts: Perbacco is my go to place for business lunches.
When someone asks where I want to go for a business lunch, I say Perbacco, because it's 1/2 a block from my office at 101, and the pastas are consistently delicious.
My go to order is the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu.
Order that
perbacco.author: Christina L.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is my go to place for business lunches.  When someone asks where I want to go for a business lunch, I say Perbacco, because it's 1/2 a block from my office at 101, and the pastas are consistently delicious.  My go to order is the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu.  Order that and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.  

When I have the appetite, I like to start (and share) the Fritto Misto (deep fried medly of shrimp, I think calamari, lemons, and string beans served with lemon aioli); or when I'm not pregnant, the salumi misti (selection of house cured meats).

But, I should give fair warning that the I have been disappointed with the meat entrees.  Once I had some steak at an alumni lunch.  It was under-seasoned and overcooked.  Another time, I decided to go out on a limb and step out of my comfort zone, so I ordered the pork and hazelnut meatballs.  They were not good.  The pork with hazelnut and roasted pear combo was weird.  I couldn't get into it, and abandoned the dish for the free focaccia.

excerpts: I've always loved Barbacco, and for whatever reason, I never made it to Perbacco until now.
Between the two, I would say I probably still like Barbacco more, but Perbacco is a different experience and is worth trying.
perbacco.author: Marilyn H.
perbacco.review:
I've always loved Barbacco, and for whatever reason, I never made it to Perbacco until now.  It's kind of a more formal version of its sister restaurant, but the pasta prices aren't significantly more. 

They have a liquor license, but none of the cocktails stood out to me, and I thought wine better matched the meal.  They had many glasses by the glass with a good number of Italian wines.  I thought the glasses were a bit expensive.

Starters: 
1. Pan seared foie gras: with classic accompaniments of brioche (a toasted rectangle) and a cherry compote
2. Heirloom tomatoes: the tomatoes are in season, but the peach compote with the saltiness of the ricotta salata were awesome together. I used the house bread to soak up the rest of the sauce at the bottom 
3. House bread: free upon request; good flavor, reminded me of the acme baguette in flavor

Pastas: the 3 of us ended up doing 2 regular sized pastas and 2 appetizer sized pastas.
1. Gemelli: squid ink pasta with an octopus and shellfish ragu (shrimp, clams, mussels all out of the shells).  This was probably the lightest of the 3 pastas in terms of fattiness, and it was a good seafood option
2. Papparadelle: rich, super flavorful slow cooked short rib ragu, which wasn't overly fatty.  The grated horseradish was a really nice contrast.  This dish had tons of flavors going on 
3. Tajarin: I don't usually love thin pastas, but this one was so fresh and had tons of flavor with the porcini mushrooms and pork sugo.  It may have actually been my favorite 
4. Coujette: potato gnocchi (the pillowy soft kind but larger than usual) with a duck ragu and foie gras butter. Needless to say, this one was the heaviest one, so the light nature of the pasta helped. It was a bit rich for me, but it was one of the more interesting gnocchi dishes I've had in a while

Side:
1. Sugar snap peas: with pea tendrils and a minted pea sauce.  The snap peas were a bit oily, and I couldn't taste much of the pesto.  I would probably skip this one. We felt compelled to get a vegetable to counter the pastas..

Dessert: 
1. Citrus mint panna cotta: super smooth, very refreshing.  The mini white donut peaches and blackberries were super sweet, and the peach sorbet was a nice contrast to the panna cotta itself.  This was a really impressive summer dessert. We all thought we were full, but we had no problem finishing it in minutes 
2. Chocolates: for the table at the end (complimentary)

The bill ended up being less than we had expected since we mostly went for pastas.  If it were up to me, I would do just pasta and nothing else (fresh pasta is a weakness of mine). The server was very helpful when we were trying to portion everything out.

Between the two, I would say I probably still like Barbacco more, but Perbacco is a different experience and is worth trying.

excerpts: Once again, Perbacco does a beautiful job.
You can't go wrong by starting with a glass of their very find Prosecco.
Members of my party had the quail the short ribs and I had the scallops.
All were more than perfectly prepared very tasty and very fresh.
Since we were on a budget that evening we chose to drink wines by the glass.
They have a great selection of both domestic and Italian.
Even though we went to the prime time and they were very busy service was still up to par.
Without a doubt still one of my favorite Italian restaurants in all of San Francisco.
Enjoy!

excerpts: Loved our experience at Perbacco.
I rarely give 5 stars and in this case (although the food was also very good)
it was because of the excellent, attentive and friendly service.
When something was needed, staff was available.
When we wanted additional sides after the main courses were served, they quickly accommodated us.
The sommelier was available for recommendation, which I found necessary because the wine "book" was extensive, with too many choices.
perbacco.author: Shan H.
perbacco.review:
Loved our experience at Perbacco. I rarely give 5 stars and in this case (although the food was also very good) it was because of the excellent, attentive and friendly service. When something was needed, staff was available. When we wanted additional sides after the main courses were served, they quickly accommodated us. The sommelier was available for recommendation, which I found necessary because the wine "book" was extensive, with too many choices. We had seating upstairs and they fortunately have an elevator in addition to stairs, for the less-abled.

The dish I enjoyed the most was the agnolotti dal plin (small filled pastas in a delicious brown gravy), which I ordered as an entree size, to share with the table (you can order the pastas 2nd course size, which is smaller, or entree size). They were thoughtful to split the serving into two plates, so it was easier to share. Frankly, I could have eaten the whole thing myself (yum!), but I did want others to try it. The papardelle (with short rib ragu sauce) was excellent. I had the crepes (butternut squash, I think) which was very good (finger-licking), creamy and flavorful. Most of our table ordered the duck breast entree, which is not my cup of tea, so I cannot comment on how it tasted, but everyone cleaned their plates completely! Also loved the Brussels sprouts.

excerpts: I walk past Perbacco almost every day for work
perbacco.author: Hailey H.
perbacco.review:
FANTASTIC place - there are so many great Italian restaurants in the city and this is certainly one of the best. I walk past Perbacco almost every day for work and I'm so glad I finally stopped in for dinner! 

This place has truly elicious food and is a lot more welcoming/un-stuffy than you would think. The ambiance was definitely on the more formal side, but there was a nice mix of couples/families/and small groups of friends. The Rabaton (ricottta gnocci with mushrooms) was delicious- incredibly light and flavorful. Our waiter was incredibly attentive without being overbearing or hovering. 

A note on the portions: I avoided getting the smaller pasta portion for fear that it wouldn't be enough, and the larger size ended up being far too much food.

excerpts:
Why You Should Check Out Perbacco:

1)
Grazie Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Amy C.
perbacco.review:
Why You Should Check Out Perbacco:

1)  It is Italian mom approved (according to our Italian friend). 

2)  You will be ushered into an elegant, large, bustling, and VERY LOUD dining room with brick walls and horizontal mirrors.  

3)  If it is your birthday, you will be thoughtfully greeted by a handwritten birthday card. 

4)  Flawless service.

Your server will enthusiastically and sincerely wish you a happy birthday and the bussers will ask you if you are done before taking away plates promptly.

5)  You will have complimentary breadsticks, pesto, bread, and a really fantastic bit of butter.

6)  You will have an ample selection of cocktails and wine.  

I ordered the Fior d'Arancio which was a processo cocktail that basically tasted like a mimosa ($10).  J had a class of Pinot Noir which he enjoyed ($14).

7)  Fantastic Appetizers.

My favorite dish of the night was the freshly made Burrata Cheese.  It was atop a pile of basil sprinkled marinated cherry tomatoes and slices of ripe nectarines.  Summer in a bowl! ($14)

The Hamachi Appetizer was fresh and elegantly plated.  While I liked the kumquat, fennel, and olive oil drizzled on top, the salty and briny black olives overpowered the fish ($14).

8)  Pastas that are as good as they say!

I ordered two half portions as an entree.  Of the two, I preferred the pillowy soft Potato Gnocchi, with a rather salty Liberty Farm Duck Ragu, and some sliced cherries ($13).  

I also tried the Agnolotti filled with Porcini Mushrooms.  Although I liked the huge mushroom flavor of the Agnolotti itself, I didn't care for its cream sauce and toppings.  While the addition of blueberries and douglas fir needles on top was definitely creative, it didn't meld for me and I felt like I was nibbling on a Christmas tree ($12).  

J loves rabbit so he tried and devoured the Spinach Pasta "Rags" with Devil's Gulch Rabbit Ragu ($13).  

9)  Entrees

If you aren't a Carbivore like me, there are plenty of Entree options.  J tried the Wolfe Ranch Quail with roasted chanterelles and cipolline onions which he enjoyed ($27).

10)  Elegant Desserts

They surprised us with Brutti Ma Buoni Cookies on a plate with "Happy Birthday" prettily written in chocolate.  Although they are supposedly "ugly but good," these hazelnut filled cookies made of sugary sweet meringue were actually were not ugly at all!  

We also tried a Goat Cheese Mousse ($9) and a Chocolate Tasting ($10) but honestly I was too full to fully appreciate them. 

Grazie Perbacco!



AT38

excerpts: The bartenders at Perbacco are great people and know their food, wine and cocktails extremely well.
If you are lucky enough to eat at Perbacco while heirloom tomatoes are in season, ORDER THEM.
I have never had such wonderful varieties anywhere, and they will not serve a tomato unless it is at its ripe peak.
The basil, ricotta salata, olive oil and whatever other wonderful goodness they sneak onto the plate is all wonderful.
Their vitello tonnato starter is also a revelation - juicy, rosy and thin slices of roasted veal slathered with a tuna-anchovy mayonnaise.
perbacco.author: Steven H.
perbacco.review:
Quite simply, the best pasta I have ever had in the US.  I have been to this place 5-6 times over the last three years, and it just keeps getting better and better.  First, the service is wonderful.  I always come to SF on business and generally eat alone, so I sit at the bar and order from the regular menu.  The bartenders at Perbacco are great people and know their food, wine and cocktails extremely well.  

And oh, the food, the food.  If you are lucky enough to eat at Perbacco while heirloom tomatoes are in season, ORDER THEM.  I have never had such wonderful varieties anywhere, and they will not serve a tomato unless it is at its ripe peak.  The basil, ricotta salata, olive oil and whatever other wonderful goodness they sneak onto the plate is all wonderful.  Their vitello tonnato starter is also a revelation - juicy, rosy and thin slices of roasted veal slathered with a tuna-anchovy mayonnaise.  You must try it. 

Their pastas are the true star here, and frankly I have never ordered an entree as the pastas are just that sensational.  The tajarin with the 5-hour pork sugo, the ravioli filled with braised short ribs and porcini mushrooms and the recently added agnolotti filled with slow cooked pork and hazelnuts in a plum jus are each unique and memorable.  The gnocchi with the gorgonzola fonduta sounds heavy but isn't - the gnocchi are light as a feather and melt on the tongue.  The fillings and sauces here are not only perfect, but the pasta itself is a wonder.  Filled pastas sometimes have great flavor but the pasta turns out gummy - not here.  The pasta itself is always toothsome, light, perfectly cooked and delicious in its own right.

They have a very nice selection of reds by the glass.  The 2008 Langhe Nebbiolo is superb with any of the pastas mentioned above.  

The only dessert I have ever had here is the brown butter cake with pistachios.  In a word - YUM.  I hope to return here again and again for years to come.  It is always a terrific experience.  These people love to provide wonderful food and service - an art form.

excerpts: Perbacco is perfectly fine, but there are far better choices.
perbacco.author: Scott W.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is perfectly fine, but there are far better choices.  

Upon entering, there is very limited space to check in and wait for a table. You are crunched up against others waiting with people waiting and those at the bar. 

The decor is nice, yet bland. Dull. The highlight is a smart strip of mirrors that allow those facing the wall to seemingly look across the room. Nice touch. 

Service was fantastic. Our server knew the menu well, made great recommendations, was attentive but not intrusive. Five stars for her.  

We found the food to be very good but equally unexceptional. Nothing to write about.  Had we ordered the $65 truffle menu items, perhaps we would have been amazed.  

Prices are typical SF yet on the high side. My glass of wine was $18 or $20 and quite delicious. A quick check on my app showed a bottle at $28 retail. Ouch. Entrees are overpriced at around $28-30. 

Restrooms are near a kitchen area, down the stairs, and with communal sinks. Turn the wrong way and you see the underbelly of the beast. Unimpressive. 

Overall, this is a perfectly fine place. But, one can do much, much better.

excerpts: I'd read good reviews about Perbacco on Yelp, so I chose it for a business lunch... and it seemed everyone else had as well (super crowded).
While the decor is beautiful, the food is highly mediocre.
I ordered the quail with a side of fingerling potatoes.
The potatoes were awesome, but the quail was barely seasoned and inconsistently cooked (some overdone, some underdone).
The service was what you'd expect for a lunch place where executives dine in the Financial District of San Francisco.
My colleague and I were the only two people of color in the place, and the manager kept slowly walking past our table, which was a bit off-putting.
perbacco.author: Dom J.
perbacco.review:
I'd read good reviews about Perbacco on Yelp, so I chose it for a business lunch... and it seemed everyone else had as well (super crowded). While the decor is beautiful, the food is highly mediocre. I ordered the quail with a side of fingerling potatoes. The potatoes were awesome, but the quail was barely seasoned and inconsistently cooked (some overdone, some underdone). The service was what you'd expect for a lunch place where executives dine in the Financial District of San Francisco. My colleague and I were the only two people of color in the place, and the manager kept slowly walking past our table, which was a bit off-putting. Our server was nice enough.

I surely wouldn't return to this place for the food. Maybe drinks... and that's a big maybe based on that manager.

excerpts: I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about Perbacco and wasn't expecting that much because I've been to their sister restaurant next door, Barbacco, and thought it was okay at most.
However, I went here for a business lunch and knew this was a nice treat.
The fresh bread was delish and we loved the pesto sauce that the breadsticks were served with.
perbacco.author: Cat C.
perbacco.review:
I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about Perbacco and wasn't expecting that much because I've been to their sister restaurant next door, Barbacco, and thought it was okay at most.  However, I went here for a business lunch and knew this was a nice treat.  The fresh bread was delish and we loved the pesto sauce that the breadsticks were served with.  I got the Tarjian, which was handcut tagialette, 5-hour cooked pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.  

The pasta looked like ramen noodles (the 4 packs for $1 instant ramen kind)..they were pretty curly.  Pork sugo was plentiful though lacked deep flavors, and I didn't see any porcini mushrooms in there!  The portion was huge so I had leftovers.  We shared two orders of the brown butter brussel sprouts which were excellent.  

Service was excellent but the food didn't wow me.  Definitely better than the budget friendly sister Barbacco though.  3.5ish.

excerpts: I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone that wants amazing Italian.
perbacco.author: Delilah W.
perbacco.review:
Absolutely amazing dinner this evening.  Arrived early'ish at 6:30, had the Heirloom Tomato Salad and the Marinated Baby Beets as our appetizers.  So delicious!! I'd have to say I liked the Baby Beets, but my sister loved the Heirloom tomato salad, it's really difficult to say which was better, because they both rocked...

Main courses included PAN SEARED SCALLOPS, FARFALLE NERE, RAVIORA (my dish), PAN SEARED SCALLOPS, and PAPPARDELLE. (Sorry for the caps) just copying it from the menu because I don't want to hand type them.  Let me say they were all absolutely amazing :)

Finished it off with some amazing desserts, I got the Panna cotta which was heavenly.

I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone that wants amazing Italian.

Great job guys, we'll be back!! :)

excerpts: So they told me that I can wait at Perbacco's bar.
So I go in and order the usual $10+ drink.
It was a ginger ale plus ginger liqeur and some Jamison in there.
As I waited, I saw many groups all dressed up for a nice dinner.
perbacco.author: Ben H L.
perbacco.review:
Bar review only.  I was waiting for my group to arrive at Barbacco next door and I was early.  So they told me that I can wait at Perbacco's bar.  So I go in and order the usual $10+ drink.  It was a ginger ale plus ginger liqeur and some Jamison in there.  As I waited, I saw many groups all dressed up for a nice dinner.  I was actually dressed in semi-fancy garb despite the fact that my workplace dress code is casual.  

The bar folks were pretty nice but there was an absence of affordability in this bar in terms of food and drinks.  Then again, this place seems to be the high end luxury Italian dining sibling of Barbacco and lest I forget, I'm in the Financial District(palm of my hand hitting forehead).

 Hopefully I'll come back here and try their food.

When we first decided, I was ecstatic; I've been waiting to try the salumi misti for quite a long time after seeing it on 2012's 7x7 big eats list.
It wasn't until after the dinner when I found out that the same dish wasn't on 2013's list.
I absolutely understood why...it is way overrated!
For what its worth, the dish was good, but it was nothing that blew me out of my mind.
perbacco.author: Victor C.
perbacco.review:
A long loitering session in an SF parking lot after work ended up bringing my friends and I to Perbacco. When we first decided, I was ecstatic; I've been waiting to try the salumi misti for quite a long time after seeing it on 2012's 7x7 big eats list. It wasn't until after the dinner when I found out that the same dish wasn't on 2013's list. I absolutely understood why...it is way overrated! For what its worth, the dish was good, but it was nothing that blew me out of my mind. I also got a pasta dish with pork and horseradish...while you could taste the uniqueness in the dish, it didn't live up to my heightened expectations. 

Regardless of the food, the drinks and service made up for the experience. They made one of the best dark and stormy's I've had, and the waitress came to check up on us at just the right moments every time (don't you hate it when a waitress asks you how your table's doing right in the middle of everyone chewing?) For that, I rate this place a 4 star: High quality food that is good if you don't overhype it, and excellent drinks and service.

excerpts: Perbacco serves consistently tasty, carefully prepared, and refined entrees whether you are dining there for lunch or for a private party.
Lunch is like a fancier, more leisurely version of lunch at Barbacco, and requires more time to fully appreciate and digest the delicious courses.
My favorite menu items include the generous salumi misti platter, any version of the delicately prepared fresh pastas with a slow cooked neat ragu, and the complexly flavored meat stews.
I also enjoy the brown butter brussels sprouts.
Perbacco also excels at private parties.
My colleagues and I came here for a company-hosted party, and the meal was generously proportioned, perfectly paced, and well-executed.
Service was quick and responsive.
Perbacco's only drawback is that the service and atmosphere can feel a bit stuffy, which is quite relevant if you are looking to have a comfortable and casual meal.

Perbacco serves consistently tasty, carefully prepared, and refined entrees whether you are dining there for lunch or for a private party.  Lunch is like a fancier, more leisurely version of lunch at Barbacco, and requires more time to fully appreciate and digest the delicious courses.  My favorite menu items include the generous salumi misti platter, any version of the delicately prepared fresh pastas with a slow cooked neat ragu, and the complexly flavored meat stews.  I also enjoy the brown butter brussels sprouts.  For dessert, the gelati and panna cotta are reliably satisfying yet light.  

Perbacco also excels at private parties.  My colleagues and I came here for a company-hosted party, and the meal was generously proportioned, perfectly paced, and well-executed.  Service was quick and responsive.  Best of all, the private party menu did not feel like a quick and dirty version of the regular menu, which is sometimes the case when restaurants have to accommodate large groups.  

Perbacco's only drawback is that the service and atmosphere can feel a bit stuffy, which is quite relevant if you are looking to have a comfortable and casual meal.

perbacco.review:

This place was great.  Perfect service, great ambience, fantastic food. The charcuterie plate we had was one of the best I've had...

Great experience.  Next time I'm in SF, I hope to make it back...

excerpts: I cannot tell you how fabulous Perbacco is.
Spent Saturday dinner here for 20 year anniversary and birthday celebrations.
The day after, I feel like I am on some kind of wonderful drug
From now on, I will always order a pasta every time I come back to Perbacco, which will be very soon.
Thanks Perbacco for a beautiful evening.
perbacco.author: John M.
perbacco.review:
I cannot tell you how fabulous Perbacco is. Spent Saturday dinner here for 20 year anniversary and birthday celebrations. The day after, I feel like I am on some kind of wonderful drug /elixir hangover. 

The atmosphere and service are impeccable, and the food is sublime. I started with the fritto misto, and Mark had a salad with kumquats and cherries, which were both superb. The frito misto even had a thinly sliced fried lemon-a big surprise which I loved.

For mains, Mark had the plate of short ribs and tenderloin. The short ribs were flavored with red wine and melted in your mouth. My pasta with veal and mushroom sugo, well, I can't stop thinking about it, it was that good. From now on, I will always order a pasta every time I come back to Perbacco, which will be very soon.

Let's not stop here, moving on to dessert, I had the ricotta cheesecake with candied mandarines and rhubarb, and Mark had a dark chocolate mousse. There was a great selection of desserts, which makes me happy, cause I love a beautifully crafted and executed dessert. This is also the place for wine lovers. The wine list has a table of contents and is probably about 25 pages long.

This truly is one of SF's finest for Italian (or any other) food. This will  become our go-to place from now on for special occasions or just to grab a bite on Friday night. . Thanks Perbacco for a beautiful evening.

excerpts: Thank you Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Andy C.
perbacco.review:
Excellent, excellent service!

We sat at the chefs table and had a nice view of how the well run kitchen operated.  My favorite dishes were the pappardelle with short ribs and my wife's duck entree.  I just needed a bit of salt on my pappardelle dish, but other than that everything was excellent.

Our waitress was very knowledgeable about the menu and could not have been nicer.  This place was very welcoming and friendly, one of the best service experiences I've had.  We were visiting San Fran for the first time and our waitress gave us useful information about what was in the area and also tried helping us get a cab at the end of the night to our next destination.  As we were leaving, everybody from the wait staff, to the bartender, to the host thanked us with a smile for coming.

My party and I absolutely had a great and memorable experience. Thank you Perbacco!

excerpts: Thank you Perbacco staff.
You aim to please and we certainly departed more than satisfied.
Great place for a gathering of large groups especially when seated upstairs.
We all had a blast.
perbacco.author: A H.
perbacco.review: Stellar experience from start to finish.  Pappardelle with short rib ragu was everything I hoped it would be.  The horseradish finish was sublime and meat falling apart tender.  I ordered the halibut for my main and was impressed.  Nothing overpowered the delicate fish that was cooked to perfection.  My husband had the scallops and although they were tasty, the accoutrement was a tad on the fishy side.  Even the bread was something to return for served with fresh, sweet unsalted butter.  Fabulous beverage selection and impressive service.  I will definitely be back for more.  Thank you Perbacco staff.  You aim to please and we certainly departed more than satisfied.  Great place for a gathering of large groups especially when seated upstairs.  We all had a blast.

excerpts: I have never been to New York but Perbacco makes me think of what a restaurant would be like with power lunchers and women who lunch.
perbacco.author: Ciara G.
perbacco.review:
I have never been to New York but Perbacco makes me think of what a restaurant would be like with power lunchers and women who lunch. 

Cool, hip, elegant long space with attentive wait staff and down right delicious food. My Strawberry and Arugula Salad only had a few ingredients (white balsamic vinaigrette, red spring onions and ricotta salata) and it was so simply flavorful. The Risotto (roasted morel mushrooms, pancetta, spring onions, sweet english peas, parmesan) was the BEST risotto I have ever had. I think I am slightly still in a food coma from it and that was many-a-meals ago.

They start you off with thin breadstick crackers and a olive oil pesto dip. I was on the tired side so I went with an iced tea and fell in love when they served a mini carafe of simple syrup on the side. Napkins were folded on the table after every time we got up. You know how that extra touch of service gets me. 

I by all means had zero room for dessert but could not pass up the Warm Brown Butter Pistachio Cake filled with Vanilla Custard and topped with Cherry Compote. Heavenly, simply heavenly. 

A great lunch in a great city recommended by a great yelper (Kim D.)

excerpts: The guest of honor not only received a handwritten birthday note from Perbacco, her dessert plate also was inscribed with chocolate birthday wishes (and who wouldn't love that!?)
It's been years since I've had dinner at Perbacco.
Thank you, Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Kim N.
perbacco.review:
Amazing experience from booking the reservation with Jeremy to finishing with dessert and coffee. We were a party of five celebrating a birthday. The guest of honor not only received a handwritten birthday note from Perbacco, her dessert plate also was inscribed with chocolate birthday wishes (and who wouldn't love that!?)

Service was top-notch from everyone, not only Hank, the gentleman (truly) who served us. We were warmly greeted by everyone upon our arrival, and it was abundantly clear that the staff are well trained and are there to ensure we were happy and well taken care of. We wanted for nothing over the course of our evening. 

Now on to the food. Everything was delicious and some dishes were outstanding. Standouts include: fritto misto, escargot, octopus, scallops,  duck breast and roasted cauliflower cooked with anchovies. Yes, we ordered a lot of food!

It's been years since I've had dinner at Perbacco. After tonight's standout experience, it won't be so long until I'm back again.

Thank you, Perbacco!

I don't remember much about what we ordered (it was a long time ago!) but I do remember that we got this charcuterie plate with salami and different jams/pates with fruits, nuts, etc and it was amazing! On a separate note, the bathrooms are also really nice. it's like an open room (think of a rectangular room with 3 walls) with individual toilet stalls and a few sinks along one wall. And they play music in every stall..kinda cool.

perbacco.author: Anthony N.
perbacco.review:
***Perbacco is a good upscale Italian lunch spot; the portions are generous and almost all of their pastas and entrees are below $20***

Perbacco is a surprisingly big restaurant that sits right in the Financial District.  The restaurant has two floors and the first floor actually accommodates a lot of seating.  I like the dining room.  The low ceiling kind of gives it a more intimate feel and the dining room is contemporary and elegant (nice light colors throughout the room that do not clash).  The restaurant has a really clean and refined feel to it.

Perbacco gets busy at lunch.  Perbacco offers an upscale lunch with pastas and entrees that feature high quality ingredients.  Despite the fine dining menu, the pricing is not that bad.  Almost all of the dishes are below $20 and the portions are surprisingly generous.

For complimentary items, Perbacco features crispy breadsticks (maybe overly crunchy) and pesto.  They also offer just okay focaccia bread.

I started with the burrata, spring pea and artichoke salad.  The salad was garnished with mint, preserved Meyer lemon, and artichoke crema.  The salad was light and refreshing.  The burrata was creamy and the peas were nice and plump.  The artichokes were tender while the greens were fresh and had a nice fragrance to them.

It was a nice salad even though none of the elements (or the combined flavor combination) were that special or memorable.

I liked my pasta entrée more.  I had the agnoli di conglio, which was ravioli filled with devil's gulch rabbit.  The pasta was tossed with black chanterelles, braised greens and a rabbit jus (and then topped with grated parmesan by the server).  The pasta was very good.  It was nicely thick but not doughy and had a good flavor.  The filling was great--meaty and juicy.

I also really liked the sauce.  Pasta sauces can often just be salty (or just one flavor), but the rabbit jus here had several dimensions to it.  There were definitely salty notes, but the red wine flavor really came across and added a surprising and welcomed light sweetness to the dish.

For dessert, I had the almond brown butter cake that had a center of lemon curd.  The dessert was garnished with toasted meringue, pate de fruit, strawberries, strawberry sauce, and candied lemon peel.  I thought this was a nice dessert and much more refined than what I've had at several other Italian restaurants.

The brown butter cake was good and moist.  It had a good crust as well as a good flavor.  The lemon curd was also good--creamy and smooth.  I think it got baked a little too much because there was not as much curd in the center as I was expecting.

I thought the garnishes were good.  I really liked the toasted meringue and I liked both the strawberries and strawberry sauce (they were not too tart).

Service was okay.  The servers seemed to be working hard, but there did not seem to be enough staff.  Because Perbacco lists many Italian names/ingredients on their menu, many customers were (not surprisingly) asking a lot of questions.  And this kept the servers from being as attentive as they should be.  The food itself came out at a good pace.

As mentioned, prices are not that bad considering you can easily go with just one item here (and most of their menu is below $20).

Perbacco is a good upscale lunch spot.  It gets quite busy and it is easy to see why.  Their upscale lunch features a lot of good food and the atmosphere is nice and very welcoming.  I also like nearby Michael Mina and Wayfare Tavern for an upscale lunch, but Perbacco might be the best value of the three.

Parking in San Francisco is difficult.  There are several parking lots and parking structures nearby.  You can also find metered street parking along the street adjacent to the Ferry Building.

perbacco.review:
This place is fabulous - perbacco!!!

I brought my family here for dinner. Combined we had the pesce crudo, the seared scallops, one of the fish dishes and the mushroom risotto with bone marrow. All were tasty and flavorful. I couldn't have asked for a better dinner. 

For desert we tried three items - I can't remember what they were called, but all three were divine. DIVINE. 

Drinks were great - I had the buddha hand infused vodka cocktail - highly recommend!

The prices are reasonable. The service was fantastic. My family already decided that we'll be back.

excerpts: I've always been a huge fan of Barbacco, so it was difficult making the reservation for Perbacco instead this time.
At the price point that Perbacco is at, I'm completely blown away by the quality of their food and service.
I'm already planning my next trip and I can't wait to be back!
perbacco.author: Sunny H.
perbacco.review:
My new SF obsession. I've always been a huge fan of Barbacco, so it was difficult making the reservation for Perbacco instead this time. However, I'm so glad I did because it surpassed all of my previous expectations.

Our whole experience from start to finish was absolutely great. As some others have mentioned, service could be slightly improved due to the at times inattentive servers. However, we also dined like it was a three course meal and they continuously replaced our dinnerware so I'm not complaining.

The meal begins with complimentary bread crackers with a chimichurri sauce which was a great touch. We decided to order three things to split: the herb and mushroom ricotta gnocchi, risotto, and duck breast. My first bite into the gnocchi was heavenly - I've never had such rich gnocchi that melted in my mouth before. The risotto was also extremely flavorful with hints of apple and mushroom. Finally, the duck breast was cooked to a perfect medium rare with a really interesting peach salad on the side.

I would highly recommend each of the dishes we ordered. At the price point that Perbacco is at, I'm completely blown away by the quality of their food and service. I'm already planning my next trip and I can't wait to be back!

excerpts: Perbacco was an incredible dining experience for me and the rest of my group.
Like many people, I too have been to my fair share of Italian restaurants both in the US as well as when I lived in Florence a few years ago--
Perbacco certainly knows what they are doing.
I say this because I haven't been to the restaurant in over a year and still remember the tagliatelle w/ pork sugo I ate.

The service was great, and the ambiance at Perbacco is understated and elegant.
Keep up the great work, Perbacco (and Steffan!)
perbacco.author: Elizabeth M.
perbacco.review:
I ate here well over a year ago, and just today saw a video on Eater SF with the Chef reading his bad reviews from around the internet (oh internet, you are truly hilarious) so felt compelled to write this long-overdue review.

First of all-- people who are whining about the lack of chicken options on a menu (Italian restaurant or elsewhere) should eat at KFC. When making reservations at a restaurant, don't you typically do your due diligence (ie check the website or menu) beforehand, to set proper expectations?! People are funny.

Anywho, I digress. Perbacco was an incredible dining experience for me and the rest of my group. Like many people, I too have been to my fair share of Italian restaurants both in the US as well as when I lived in Florence a few years ago-- Perbacco certainly knows what they are doing. I say this because I haven't been to the restaurant in over a year and still remember the tagliatelle w/ pork sugo I ate. This was after a delicious antipastO/salumi platter and coupled with a delicious bottle of Sangiovese. The service was great, and the ambiance at Perbacco is understated and elegant.

Keep up the great work, Perbacco (and Steffan!)

excerpts: Perbacco has been around for a while, and while it's no longer the hot new thing in town, it still remains one of SF's finest restaurants.
I've been here several times for lunch and dinner, and I've been hooked since the first time I went.
Before Perbacco, I'd always scoffed at Italian dining out as being a thoroughly heavy, carb-loaded, gut-busting Olive Garden/Buca di Beppo-like experience.
Weekday lunch at Perbacco is a total power scene, with lots of business deals being discussed everywhere.
If confidentiality and discretion are a concern to you, the tables downstairs might feel a bit intimate and closely spaced.
Yet overall, the atmosphere is loud and lively.

Dinner at Perbacco can run from semi-formal to business casual, with younger professionals sticking to the bar and well-dressed, reservationed older folk sitting down to an intimate dinner before a night at the theater.
perbacco.author: Vincent L.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco has been around for a while, and while it's no longer the hot new thing in town, it still remains one of SF's finest restaurants. I've been here several times for lunch and dinner, and I've been hooked since the first time I went. Before Perbacco, I'd always scoffed at Italian dining out as being a thoroughly heavy, carb-loaded, gut-busting Olive Garden/Buca di Beppo-like experience. I never knew Italian cuisine could be so inventive, light, and refreshing without making you feel as if you've added 20 pounds of gut and booty ballast.

Weekday lunch at Perbacco is a total power scene, with lots of business deals being discussed everywhere. If confidentiality and discretion are a concern to you, the tables downstairs might feel a bit intimate and closely spaced. Yet overall, the atmosphere is loud and lively. Not so much so that you have to shout to be heard by your companions, yet just enough so that you likely won't be overheard by the tables next to you.

Dinner at Perbacco can run from semi-formal to business casual, with younger professionals sticking to the bar and well-dressed, reservationed older folk sitting down to an intimate dinner before a night at the theater. 

I didn't have a reservation the last time a friend and I went for dinner, but we still managed to get accommodated immediately by having table settings placed on the last remaining empty bar table up front. Everything from the salumi platter, veal, hanger steak, to a cheese platter struck the right "balance" for almost any attribute you could imagine - whether unique flavors, the "magnitude" of the flavors, "lightness" vs. "heaviness," and even portion size/value.

Overall, a memorable and truly positive dining experience that makes you feel lucky - and proud - to be in such an amazing city.

excerpts: Perbacco used to be a reliable restaurant for good Italian food.
Now, they mix things up a bit with surprise special events; keeping diners on their toes.
Shortly after we were seated, a server behind my wife slammed a heavy silver tray into her head so hard it immediately brought tears to her eyes.
No apologies, just a comment that "that was weird."
Now that's what I call guerrilla dining.
A new approach to an exciting dining experience.
Decent food rounded things out.
The randomness continues in the kitchen too, with dirty pots and pans strewn around the floor.
You never know when someone needs to slip and fall for added excitement.
Sommelier poured the initial taste to the wrong person.
Maybe she took a blow to the head too.
Dining room was partially full all night on a Saturday.
I'm guessing not enough people have subscribed to this new level of dining adventure.
Are you up to the challenge?

excerpts: I enjoyed Perbacco a lot.
Food was all excellent -- hightly recommend the rock shrimp misto, the braised short ribs, & the stuffed quail.
(Stuffed quail was hands down the winner -- fantastic!)

In any other city (except maybe New York or something), I'd probably give Perbacco half a star more--the food was all very good, but I have had so much food in SF, and so much Italian food, that has utterly blown me away, so the bar is really high.
There was nothing at Perbacco that I felt rose to the "foodgasm" level, which has kind of become my standard for rating something five stars.
perbacco.author: Angela B.
perbacco.review:
I enjoyed Perbacco a lot. Food was all excellent -- hightly recommend the rock shrimp misto, the braised short ribs, & the stuffed quail. (Stuffed quail was hands down the winner -- fantastic!) We had a lovely endive salad as well.

Service was excellent, with two somm-type-people walking around to help with wine selection. The woman who helped us with wine knew her stuff, & directed us to a perfect match based on our food, preferences, & price point. The rest of the service was excellent as well--the server did a great job of explaining to us exactly how everything was prepared so that we knew what we were getting.

We split the brown sugar gelato for dessert, which was very good. (I had a hard time deciding between that & the salted caramel. Now I really want to try the salted caramel!)

In any other city (except maybe New York or something), I'd probably give Perbacco half a star more--the food was all very good, but I have had so much food in SF, and so much Italian food, that has utterly blown me away, so the bar is really high. There was nothing at Perbacco that I felt rose to the "foodgasm" level, which has kind of become my standard for rating something five stars.

The only other drawback was the noise level. We were lucky enough to be seated upstairs, which was definitely quieter than downstairs, but it was still a bit loud. (Which....seems to be par for the course in SF.) There were also a couple of very loud (possibly intoxicated?) tables near us, which didn't help.

BUT, overall, totally worth a trip, and while I might not go out of my way to eat here again, I would happily go along if someone else suggested it.

excerpts: After scouring Yelp for a couple weeks for the perfect Italian restaurant to have my Birthday dinner, I finally settled on Perbacco.
I had heard great things about it, and the Yelp reviews were off the charts.
perbacco.author: Hayley H.
perbacco.review:
After scouring Yelp for a couple weeks for the perfect Italian restaurant to have my Birthday dinner, I finally settled on Perbacco.  I had heard great things about it, and the Yelp reviews were off the charts. When we entered the restaurant I was given a Happy Birthday card...that was a nice touch!  

One of the deciding factors in my decision was that the Salumi Misti was on the Big Eat, so naturally, my family started off with one of those.  I have never been a big fan of salumi plates in general, but thought I would try each kind. They were good, but because salami is something that I'm not a particular fan of, one time was enough.  We also ordered that Burrata with sweet corn and cherry tomato crudo.  I work at a cheese shop and know my burratas...this one wasn't curdly (the death knell of mozzarella's) and the cherry tomato crudo was flavorful.

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ztL8KI0ed0snCiK88ZUfNw?select=zJqYLy_4xU2ZEeACMkntuw

For my main dish, I had the Pappardelle with braised short rib ragu.  I was a bit disappointed that the sauce tasted like Thanksgiving gravy...I was expecting something more earthy and meaty.  Aside from that fact, the portion size was perfect and the pasta cooked to perfection.  

Dessert was good...so good that my family of 3 ordered 4 and finished every last bite.  I had been dreaming about the doughnuts. They came out warm, in a bag, with a nice "Happy Birthday" chocolate stencil on the plate.  The citrus wasn't overpowering, but enough to taste. The Butter Pistachio Cake was good as well. There was some filling in it...almost custard like.  The Burnt Carmel Gelato is to die for...and I've been to Bi-Rite, so don't even try to compare the two!  It was topped with coarse salt which added an addictive crunch to the creamy concoction. By far, my favorite dessert was the Chocolate Torrone.  It had chunks of hazelnuts in it and was served with blackberries on the side...extremely refreshing and a chocolate lovers dream.

excerpts: but we didn't have a reservation and thankfully Perbacco had a table for us.
perbacco.author: Chyng H.
perbacco.review:
We originally tried to go to their sister restaurant next door but we didn't have a reservation and thankfully Perbacco had a table for us. 

I had the steak tartare and the pappardelle. The steak tartare was delicious, it had grated horseradish on top which gave it a great kick without being overwhelming. The pappardelle was served with a shortrib ragu, the ragu was so tasty, it had a sweetness and the spring onions cut right through it. This was hands down the best pasta dish at our table! 

Our friends at dinner also ordered the cauliflower side dish and it was served on top of this delicious sauce of some sort! Definitely a great side dish to have. 

The service was great, atmosphere was nice. Only thing was my glass had lipstick stains... And I wasn't wearing any lipstick!

excerpts: Craving tartare and seafood - I knew Perbacco has good veal tartare
perbacco.author: Gloria H.
perbacco.review:
Craving tartare and seafood - I knew Perbacco has good veal tartare so we headed there.  

We took one of the pub tables near the window by the front.  We were greeted quickly by the host with wine list and menu.   

What we had:
Maker's Mark on ice - $9 - for hubby
Timorasso - $12 - crisp, just as I wanted

Jewel box of citrus marinated abalone and shrimp, sea urchin over shrimp panna cotta - $15 - wow, genius!  The panna cotta was rich, creamy with an intense shrimp flavor.  The shrimp was sweet with just the right hint of citrus, which helps with the rich panna cotta.  

Tartare of pastured veal, black truffle lardo crostino - $14 - always good.

excerpts: We agreed that Perbacco seemed like a fantastic choice and rushed over to satisfy our growling bellies.
Regardless of the waiter with the attitude, our meal at Perbacco was delightful.
From the elegant atmosphere to the perfectly cooked cuisine, we were glad that we had made our dinner reservation there.
perbacco.author: Alison C.
perbacco.review:
My brother and I were trying to decide on a restaurant for our final dinner in San Francisco, and, as usual, it was taking us hours to finalize a selection.  By the time we had even narrowed down our options, it was pretty late into the evening, so we figured it would be best to dine somewhere near our hotel.  We agreed that Perbacco seemed like a fantastic choice and rushed over to satisfy our growling bellies.

We walked into the elegant dining room, which was quite expansive and extremely packed.  We were seated at a comfortable table and presented with a lengthy wine list.  My glass of 2008 Alto-Adige, Müller Thurgau was crisp and delicious.  Fabulous bread also helped tide us over as we awaited our meal.  

After gazing around at the neighboring tables, we started salivating over the decadent pasta dishes.  Each creation was offered in full or half portions, but we decided to split the larger plate as our starter.  There did not seem to be a poor choice among the bunch, as they were all exquisite and unique.  We settled on the Pappardelle, which was tossed with a short rib puree.  The dish was earthy, savory, and comforting.  My duck entree was equally fabulous.  The meat was lean and perfectly cooked.  I actually exclaimed that it was the most well-prepared duck I have ever tried.  

Unfortunately, our spectacular meal was tarnished by snippy service.  Our waiter was extremely refined and professional, to the point where I contemplated if he disliked us.  He seemed extremely put out all evening, which made us hesitate with our requests for additional bread, and so on.

Regardless of the waiter with the attitude, our meal at Perbacco was delightful.  From the elegant atmosphere to the perfectly cooked cuisine, we were glad that we had made our dinner reservation there.

excerpts: I would recommend Perbacco for a business lunch because I like the noise level (medium) and I love the interesting menu that always requires me to ask several questions.
Creative menu!
perbacco.author: Julie W.
perbacco.review:
I ordered the 5-hour pork sugo with tagliatelle noodle and a porcini mushroom sauce.  DELICIOUS!  

The portion size was perfect, I ate the entire dish for lunch, and I forgot about the surrounding business meetings taking place around me.  The dish was not salty, which I had expected with the 5 hour title but it was so nicely seasoned.  The pasta did not take over the sauce because the noodle is so thin -- perfect.  I rarely order pork but would order this dish again, for sure.

I then ordered the pear gelato, and the flavor is brow-raising.  yum.  They make their gelato in house, and the two soft cookies are nice companions to the dessert.  I was glad I didn't pass on the dessert for a nice change.

I don't remember the server, unfortunately, but I will say that the details were all there.  No mess ups on our order, and our check arrived quickly enough for us to have a one-hour lunch despite the bustling business.  

I would recommend Perbacco for a business lunch because I like the noise level (medium) and I love the interesting menu that always requires me to ask several questions.  Creative menu!

excerpts: Being that I just went to Flour + Water, I have to say Flour + Water's pasta is better however the overall experience was better at Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Andy W.
perbacco.review:
Great service, fantastic meal.

We came here to celebrate a birthday and as soon as we were shown to our table, we found a card on the table. They took the time to write a nice message along with the bday wish. Very nice touch.

The salumi misti platter was pretty cool. There were about 10 varieties on the platter. They explained what each one is and how it was prepared.

We also had the fritto misto, roasted octopus, and raviolo. They were all good, not great.

We went with the Tris pasta tasting ($19/pp). It was pretty hard to understand from just reading the menu. It's basically, a pasta sampler platter for each person. Everyone at the table will get the same platter with the same three pastas. It's basically reverse family style. The table agrees to 3 pasta dishes and the kitchen will divide it evenly for each person. When the platters come out, each person will have 3 varieties on their own plate. It was pretty cool and pretty good. 

Being that I just went to Flour + Water, I have to say Flour + Water's pasta is better however the overall experience was better at Perbacco. In terms of service, appetizers, desserts and drinks.

When it was time for desserts, the kitchen sent us a gift, it was meringue cookies. I usually don't like meringue but these were amazing. They were delicious!  We ordered the caramel gelato and panna cotta. Everything came with cookies and they were really the standouts of the night.

All in all, a wonderful experience.

excerpts: Perbacco has made a major come back into mine.
In the end , Perbacco has not missed a beat.
They still churn out some of the best Northern Italian cuisine in all of San Francisco.
Great night out with two really great people and my wife course.
perbacco.author: Rene C.
perbacco.review:
Like a long lost love who comes back into your life. Perbacco has made a major come back into mine.

It has been a while since I've dined here, honestly I cannot even remember when it was but it has been at least a year. I've always enjoyed some amazing meals here, but started to take it for granted and just knew that at some point I would be making a return visit. And last night was exactly that. A true sublime reconnection. A night that for the first time in years, I would actually clean my plate.

A group of four, 6:15 reservations and cocktails in hand we were ready to party and be treated to huge meal that would rival Thanksgiving. And yes, in my opinion we did order way too much, but when 99.99 percent of the menu offerings sound absolutely delicious what are you supposed to do? 

Marie and my wife are fans of beets. Markus and I hate those stupid things so we got the burrata and heirloom tomato starter. Our appetizer was amazing, but I must admit those beets looked awfully tasty, and was tempted to pry one of those away. So as of right now, I am officially still president of the "I hate beets" club, but on my next visit I am going to take a chance and put one of those purple slimy things in mouth and see what happens. 

Four mains to share,

1. Pork shoulder with polenta and turnip. Good? YES! and I am now a former member of the "I hate turnip" club.

2. Risotto with wile mushrooms. My favorite of the evening. Complex flavors with a hint of Gorgonzola. The cheese was not on the menu description, but it was there i just know it.

3. Gnocchi with toasted walnuts. Mixed reviews at the table, but I thought they were perfectly executed. 

4. Tajarin,  tagliatelle noodles with a rich pork sugo sauce. This has always been a staple here and it always found a way to our table. But last night it missed the mark. There was no problem with the pork sugo sauce, but the problem is that there simply wasn't enough of it. May not be part of the future rotation.

Two desserts to share.

1.Gelato with sea salt. So good we fought over the last bite

2. Gianduja. Dark chocolate, hazelnut and praline bar. Also served with a sea salted gelato. OMG! Yes, it was amazing.

Cheese course to share.

1. La Tur. One of my all time favorites, creamy goat cheese. Try it with honey.

2. CAPRIAGO, BOHEMIAN CREAMERY, SONOMA (had to copy and paste that). Made a nice compliment to the La Tur, a hint of nutty (think softer Parmesan).

Wine, a $45 dollar bottle from sardinia that was a bargain.

Dessert wine, PAYS D'AUGE, 6 ANS D'AGE, ADRIEN CAMUT. At $16 a glass it isn't cheap, but deep dark and delicious. Would get it again in a second.

In the end , Perbacco has not missed a beat. They still churn out some of the best Northern Italian cuisine in all of San Francisco. Great night out with two really great people and my wife course. I cannot wait to make a return visit.

4 1/2 stars.

excerpts: Largely replicating the dining path of the day prior due to convenience, lunch amongst the power brokers on Tuesday saw me seated at a hightop near the front of Italian stalwart Perbacco.

Ostensibly a modernized take on Piemontese and Ligurian cuisine from Nordic chef Staffan Terje the first thing that struck me upon walking in was the impressive size of the restaurant and the seemingly 1:2 ratio of servers to tables assuring that each and every diner is never for want, a particularly good thing for keeping the water and bread basket clean in such a busy space and all the more so when my server, Christopher, explained to me that most plates could be ordered in half portions thus opening up my options substantially.
Clearly the sort of place where a lunch could be leisurely or fit within the typical lunch hour

it would not be long after my focaccia arrived that the first of two pastas would come, in this case the rich and earthy stracci, and close on its heels three of my favorite things all on one plate; tender gnocchi, supple duck, and sweet cherries - a 'best of' dish on a trip with many and good enough that I actually requested a second demi-portion that arrived fifteen minutes later - a decision I'd regret only slightly when I realized there were at least four desserts I wanted to taste, instead limiting myself to the truly fascinating sweet mushroom donuts filled with green strawberry jam...plus a scoop of intense caramel gelato flecked with smoked sea salt rounding out a truly excellent lunch.

excerpts: Awesome night at Perbacco celebrating my sister's elopement.
We sat in the upstairs private dining area and had our own little area that over looked the kitchen...
What a treat.
Our 2nd course was Perbacco's specialty meat platter, with lots of varieties of pate, salamis, prosciutto and more.
The meat plates were eaten up quickly.
After the meat we had the salad course.
It was a simple salad with delicious tomoatos, grapefruit and nuts.
Perbacco was more than accommodating to our small wedding party of 14.
perbacco.author: Danielle B.
perbacco.review:
Awesome night at Perbacco celebrating my sister's elopement.  We sat in the upstairs private dining area and had our own little area that over looked the kitchen... What a treat.  We all started off with some excellent Italian Red Wine (to die for actually)... and the mushroom risoto balls, along with the yellowtail with radishes and other delicious accoutrements.   

Our 2nd course was Perbacco's specialty meat platter, with lots of varieties of pate, salamis, prosciutto and more.   The meat plates were eaten up quickly.  After the meat we had the salad course.  It was a simple salad with delicious tomoatos, grapefruit and nuts.  What a wonderfully light salad to start off the pasta dish.  

For the pasta we had the gnocchi with mushroom cream sauce, and a risoto with a delicious white wine sauce.  The pasta dish was amazing.  I am not a huge pasta fan, but it was great.  The entree we had a choice between duck and seabass and I had the seabass.  It was done perfectly.  What a great piece of fish.

To top it all off we had a nice dessert along with tea, coffee and more wine.  Perbacco was more than accommodating to our small wedding party of 14.

It was truly a lovely evening.

excerpts: Expectations are everything, and mine were high for Perbacco.
It's one of a few places in SF that's been on my list for several years after multiple people recommend it and after reading strong reviews and learning about the pedigree and style here.
perbacco.author: J S.
perbacco.review:
Expectations are everything, and mine were high for Perbacco. It's one of a few places in SF that's been on my list for several years after multiple people recommend it and after reading strong reviews and learning about the pedigree and style here. So my wife and I finally had a chance to go this week for a casual dinner outing. 

The ambiance is lovely and the service is really top notch. The waitstaff was friendly, helpful, and present. Our main waiter was definitely a pro -- good stuff. I'll say the menu is fantastic as well, although the pastas and mains were largely meaty. There were plenty of creative and delicious sounding choices, especially on the appetizer list. However, before I got to the main menu, I started with the wine list. Lovely collection, but the wine prices were incredibly pretentious. I know there's a lot of markup for restaurant wine and they need to make some money here, but this list and the prices are bordering on the ridiculous. 

We ordered an Italian wine at the lower-to-mid range of prices. As expected, it was drinkable, but mediocre (actually, appalling for the price, but whatever -- I don't think we would've found better value in a different selection since it was all overpriced).

As for food: our apps were nice, especially the frito misto, but nothing spectacular. And sorry, but the mains were just so-so. I had a squid ink cavatelli with octopus and urchin that sounded amazing on paper, but just didn't come together for me on the plate. It was tough, unloved, and the entire dish, bland. I am a very low sodium user -- many dishes that would pass the normal palette taste too salty to me. But for the first time in recent memory, I actually had to salt my restaurant food here. In the end, sensing my dissatisfaction, our waiter took a few dollars off the bill and added some complimentary cookies to our dessert order. 

Which brings me to the highlight of the meal: dessert. Again, the menu was great -- good choices and quite creative. We ordered the salted dark chocolate bonet. It's was huge, and very yummy -- almost redeeming the rest of the meal! My wife commented that we should just come back here for dessert only sometime when we have that late evening hankering for some yummy sweets. 

And indeed, I'm not likely to go back soon except maybe for dessert, unless someone tells me I hit a bad night or I picked the wrong menu items. Too many other great places to eat around here, and way better things to spend my money on than a so-so meal.

excerpts: If you cannot get into Perbacco, then make a reservation next door at Barbacco (sister location)  Another excellent choice

perbacco.review:
This place is great.  Group of 7 for dinner on a Saturday night

First, service is simply outstanding.  If you want to be pampered, then make a reservation.  This place really knows how to take care of their customers

Food is outstanding.  Everything we ordered was great.  Roasted  cauliflower and  radicchio salad appetizer was crazy good.

Dessert - Almond Brown Butter Cake.  This is an eye rolling, lip smacking, get your moan on type of dessert.  Look at the ingredients - there is nothing to not like...

Get on down here

TIP:  If you cannot get into Perbacco, then make a reservation next door at Barbacco (sister location)  Another excellent choice

excerpts: perbacco was a great experience.
i came here the other night after wanting to come here for years!
