excerpts: perbacco:  thank you
perbacco.author: Bill L.
perbacco.review:
Came here during the week of Jan 19th.  this old favorite continues to perform very well.  we had pasta and hanger steak and dessert.  left the place smiling as the food was outstanding and service was very attentive.

perbacco:  thank you

excerpts: I've been dying to try Perbacco, so I subtly suggested (subtle as a sledgehammer) that we make a reservation for a weeknight.
perbacco.author: Jennie K.
perbacco.review:
Holy moly.

(The great irony here is that the pricing is rated $$$, but it was $20 CHEAPER to dine here than a few recent, disappointing meals at other SF establishments.)

"Payday dinner" is my +1's excuse to celebrate the time-honored tradition of being paid for working at a real job.  I've been dying to try Perbacco, so I subtly suggested (subtle as a sledgehammer) that we make a reservation for a weeknight.  

Decor: upscale, warm, and lighting that hides the onset of wrinkles and grey hair, allowing you and your date to fool yourselves (with the aid of a cocktail or two) into believing you're not rapidly marching right out of your late-20's.

Service: friendly, attentive, and helpful (when asked which of 3 dishes he would recommend).

Food:  I had the duck with polenta, green strawberries, ginger jus, and rhubarb agrodolce.  It was presented artfully and tasted like god intended: the fatty duck with crispy skin was balanced by the sweet and tart strawberries and rhubarb.  If the +1 had asked me to marry him that night I would have been insulted that he was competing with the duck.

+1 had the short rib sugo, served over papardelle with grated horseradish.  Also excellent - the very definition of elegant comfort food.  

We shared the veal appetizer, which was thinly sliced and served with an albacore/lemon sauce, capers, and microgreens (I think).  This was, as you might imagine from the rest of the review, also delicious.

Portions were generous--enough so that between the complimentary crostini, crusty bread with butter, the appetizer, and the entree, we had leftovers to take home.  Two tiny dessert bites were served with the check, and off we went into the windy spring night.

But don't YOU go, because then it will be even harder to get a reservation at a reasonable hour.

excerpts:
Luckily Perbacco was able to deliver.
We started with the vitello tonnato, a veal dish almost prepared like a beef capriccio but slow cook. 
The thinly slice veal and the arugula with flavor of lemon and caper was a delightful mouthful experience.
We also order the brown butter brussel sprout that was very flavorful but over powering with butter.
My entree was the quail which was another delightful experience.
perbacco.author: YC L.
perbacco.review:
Yum yum yum......
This was an impromptu decision to meet up with parental's friend.
So respectable and tasty was essential...
Luckily Perbacco was able to deliver.
We started with the vitello tonnato, a veal dish almost prepared like a beef capriccio but slow cook. 
The thinly slice veal and the arugula with flavor of lemon and caper was a delightful mouthful experience.
We also order the brown butter brussel sprout that was very flavorful but over powering with butter.
My entree was the quail which was another delightful experience.
The red wine butter flavored the mushroom and quail perfectly.

Our waiter also recommended a 2009 Skewis, Ridly Vineyard, Anderson Valley Pinot Noir which complimented our meal very nicely.

Overall a great dinning experience and I will be back.....

excerpts: I loved Perbacco and can't wait to go back!
perbacco.author: Michelle T.
perbacco.review:
This was one of the best meals I've had in SF ever.  What a wonderful place!

Firstly the decor is beautiful -- it has a sleek modern look without seeming cheesy or overdone. It's comfortable and elegant and clean.  

Secondly the food was incredible.  I had the rabbit leg with cherries and mashed potatoes which was potentially one of the best dishes I've ever tasted.  Also really enjoyed the salumi misiti which was quite large - I would recommend it for a group of 3-6 people.  The short rib ragu was delicious, as was the truffle polenta  ravioli.  The egg yolk in that dish was incredible. 

I loved Perbacco and can't wait to go back!

excerpts: I took my best friend to Perbacco last night for her birthday.
The dining experience started out good, we opened a bottle of wine and had the beef carppacio as a appetizer.
It was full of flavor and even came topped with a quail egg.
Next we ordered the tagliatelle.
It looked like ramen noodles with a pile of meet sauce on top.
The sauce and noodles did not go together at all, and i have never seen tagliatelle like this.
We decided to try something else and the waiter recommended the truffle risotto
so we went for it.
The rice was crunchy and the over all dish had no flavor.
When I asked for the bill I was shocked that the risotto was 65 dollars!
I payed anyway and sat in the restaurant waiting for them to bring out something, anything with a candle to say happy birthday to her, but it never happened.
This made me upset because I had let them know it was her birthday when we got there.
I wasn't going to say anything
but I was unhappy and wanted to let the manager know.
When I told him everything he said the food how was sapposed to be this way.
He ended up saying he would take the risotto off the bill and the credit would go back on my card
but I still have yet to get the refund.
I am new to yelp and this horrible experience inspired me to create a account.
This place is far from authentic Italian.

excerpts: The website defines Perbacco "an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.
I am pretty sure they strive to have every guest "perbacco" this place to all they know (and they should).
perbacco.author: Kerina J.
perbacco.review:
The website defines Perbacco "an Italian word to accentuate positive comments." I am pretty sure they strive to have every guest "perbacco" this place to all they know (and they should). 

This is Italian food at its best. I have been here for lunch and for dinner, and have been extremely impressed both times....although I wish they served the foccacia at dinner. So olive-y and lovely (see what I did there). I've had the beet salad, risotto, and the papadelle. Such layers of flavor on all the dishes!

Service is fantastic. Very attentive, friendly, and knowledgeable. I put my napkin on my seat when I went to the restroom, and when I returned a new one was put at my place setting (!). My water glass was always filled. The waiter also knew the wine list very well.

The prices range from $15-$30 for entrees, but they are so worth it. I could not dine here all the time, but how I wish I could.

excerpts: Located in the Financial District, Perbacco gets a lot of business-dinner folks, but it'd be just as good for sharing comfort food with someone you love.
The best part of our meal was the vitello tonnato, the best version of this dish I've had, with the rich yet bracing tuna sauce perfectly married to the succulent and rare slices of veal.
The pastas are homemade and awesome.
Two starters, two pastas and two glasses of wine came to just under $100.
perbacco.author: Cecilia L.
perbacco.review: This upscale Northern Italian joint shows off the rich, hearty foods of Piedmont, and for a reasonable sum. Located in the Financial District, Perbacco gets a lot of business-dinner folks, but it'd be just as good for sharing comfort food with someone you love. The best part of our meal was the vitello tonnato, the best version of this dish I've had, with the rich yet bracing tuna sauce perfectly married to the succulent and rare slices of veal. The pastas are homemade and awesome. Two starters, two pastas and two glasses of wine came to just under $100.

excerpts: I had been to Perbacco a couple times over the last two months
and I totally forgot to write a review -
wow
* Pastas (to be honest, I can't remember what they were, I think one was a tagliatelle, yum, Perbacco knows their pastas, we ordered 2 pasta dishes to share for a party of 4 before our entrees)
If there are scallops on the menu, you MUST get these - this was a big hit both times I visited Perbacco
And the sides are lovely -
I had the baby carrots and the brussel sprouts - totally great combo with the pastas and scallops
perbacco.author: Maile N.
perbacco.review:
I had been to Perbacco a couple times over the last two months and I totally forgot to write a review - wow, I must've been really out of it because that never happens!  

Most memorable from my meals here were the:

*SALUMI MISTI - A SELECTION OF HOUSE CURED SALUMI INSPIRED BY TRADITIONAL PIEMONTESE RECIPES:
SALSICCIA DI BRA / TESTA IN CASSETTA DI GAVI / SALAME AL NEBBIOLO / SALAM 'DLA DUJA / PANCETTA STESA
LARDO DI CAVOUR / SALAME COTTO D'ASTI / SALAME TORTONESI / SALAME CUNEESE / LARDO REALE (wow, what a great selection of meats, I tried everything and loved the classic salumis, but it gave me a real appeciation for all the other types, especially the good and fatty ones!  Both times I came here, we ordered the smaller platter which is perfect for 2-4 people)
* Pastas (to be honest, I can't remember what they were, I think one was a tagliatelle, yum, Perbacco knows their pastas, we ordered 2 pasta dishes to share for a party of 4 before our entrees)
* If there are scallops on the menu, you MUST get these - this was a big hit both times I visited Perbacco
* And the sides are lovely - I had the baby carrots and the brussel sprouts - totally great combo with the pastas and scallops
* Their mixed drinks are classy without being too sweet or syrupy

I came here with a friend once and for a work dinner another time, and both times we had lovely service that was nicely attentive and patient.  A very nice dining experience.

excerpts: Perbacco is fantastic.
I loved everything about this place.
The vibe, the service and mainly the food.
perbacco.author: Sunil R.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is fantastic. I loved everything about this place. The vibe, the service and mainly the food. A friend who is a regular was able to get us a table at short notice which was nice. 

We were a big party and tried a lot of dishes and they were all divine. The beef short rib stood out for me since it was so tender and flavorful.
I am not much of a seafood but my friends were raving about the selection of some pretty rare fish as well. Feels good to hand out a 5 star review after a while!

The pasta was delicate and the the pork was amazingly rich and lovely.
perbacco.author: Suzanne J.
perbacco.review:
The challenge was three nights and two full days in San Francisco, and attempting to find some new dining experiences mingled with old favorites. 

 We found recommendations for Perbacco on the SF Chowhound board and knew we had to have dinner here, as the pasta selections were especially noteworthy on the menu when reviewing.   He began salad prepared with marinated root vegetables, beautiful golden beets and a tasty vinaigrette.  I opted to skip the traditional appetizer menu and start with the small portion of the handcut tagliatelle with five hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.   The pasta was delicate and the the pork was amazingly rich and lovely.  If I close my eyes I can still taste it.  

For our mains, I opted from the risotto with black chanterelles, smoked pancetta, swiss chard and parmigiano reggiano, was fabulously rich and the pancetta was perfect.  He opted for the pappardelle with short rib ragu and roasted cipollines.  The short rib was braised perfectly and all of the house made pastas were melt-in-your-mouth good.  I almost didn't want to share, but what can you do? 

Everything here was amazing, honestly.  We enjoyed the fact that we could order a wine by the half liter (rather than a bottle between the two of us, sometimes) and our server made a well matched pairing to both of our dishes.   

Another SF restaurant that makes me want to move to the city in a heartbeat.

excerpts: Fantastic experience - thank you Perbacco!
The food was great and the service impeccable!
My partner and I dined at Perbacco on New Year's for our anniversary.
We had 8:15pm reservations and were promptly seated in a corner booth on the first level.
Since it was NYE, the restaurant full, and many of the tables arranged in close proximity to one another, we were prepared to sit closely amongst others.
We were nearly completely sold from the beginning when our server handed us a 'Happy Anniversary' card on behalf of Perbacco.
Throughout the night, our server also paid extra attention to ensure we enjoyed ourselves - the ideal amount of attention and privacy.
From the server to the hostess, each employee we encountered congratulated our celebratory event, which we didn't really expect, and therefore could not help but be thankful and impressed.
Also, as it was NYE, Perbacco served complimentary seasoned lentils.
All were great.

My favorite was the Beet Salad - the red and yellow beets were fresh, slightly sweet, and cooked perfectly with just the right amount of Castelmagno cheese, microgreens, and chestnut crumble accompaniments.
The Fritto Misto, nicely paired with their lemon aioli, was satisfying & filling - great starter for big eaters.
For my entrée, I ordered the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu and my partner had the Garganelli with Duck Ragu.
We were pretty full after the appetizers, but still managed to finish both pastas (small size).
Each pasta dish was cooked a nice al dente and the ragus both wonderfully, rustically flavorful.
perbacco.author: Catherine C.
perbacco.review:
Fantastic experience - thank you Perbacco!  The food was great and the service impeccable!  My partner and I dined at Perbacco on New Year's for our anniversary.  We had 8:15pm reservations and were promptly seated in a corner booth on the first level.  Since it was NYE, the restaurant full, and many of the tables arranged in close proximity to one another, we were prepared to sit closely amongst others.  To our pleasant surprise the corner booth had access to the festive atmosphere, but at the same time added privacy and extra wiggle room.

Service: Top Notch - Five Stars!  We were nearly completely sold from the beginning when our server handed us a 'Happy Anniversary' card on behalf of Perbacco.  Throughout the night, our server also paid extra attention to ensure we enjoyed ourselves - the ideal amount of attention and privacy.  From the server to the hostess, each employee we encountered congratulated our celebratory event, which we didn't really expect, and therefore could not help but be thankful and impressed.  At the end of the evening the restaurant also provided complimentary cookies & chocolates with 'Happy Anniversary' etched in chocolate.

Food/Drink:  Delicious!  We started with two Negronis on the rocks - they were superb.  For appetizers we split a Beet Salad and the Fritto Misto.  Also, as it was NYE, Perbacco served complimentary seasoned lentils.  All were great.  My favorite was the Beet Salad - the red and yellow beets were fresh, slightly sweet, and cooked perfectly with just the right amount of Castelmagno cheese, microgreens, and chestnut crumble accompaniments.  The Fritto Misto, nicely paired with their lemon aioli, was satisfying & filling - great starter for big eaters.  For my entrée, I ordered the Pappardelle with Short Rib Ragu and my partner had the Garganelli with Duck Ragu.  We were pretty full after the appetizers, but still managed to finish both pastas (small size).  Each pasta dish was cooked a nice al dente and the ragus both wonderfully, rustically flavorful.  The horseradish in my Short Rib Ragu cut the richness of the ragu well with its pungency and zest.  

Overall:  A great special occasion restaurant - we would not hesitate to return!  The service was outstanding and really made the whole night exceptionally special.  The bar area also seemed like a nice spot to grab a drink or a spontaneous bite.

excerpts: The first time I went, I ordered a $90 dinner just for myself, because I wanted to try the best that Perbacco--ranked third in the city by some--had to offer.
Octopus and beef tongue salad, white truffle and oxtail risotto (off their seasonal white truffle menu), and tahitian sea salt caramel ice cream rounded up my order.
I have but one word to say: SALT.

It wasn't just that there was too much of it, to the point that I was actually gagging in the restroom before my end-meal cup of coffee, but the food itself was so tasteless that even if the only flavor available to the palate was not salt, one would have been disappointed.
perbacco.author: Joshua R.
perbacco.review:
Sure, it's rated highly. Sure, lots of people think they enjoy it. But honestly, I've never had such a rampant disregard for my tastebuds at these prices in my entire life. The first time I went, I ordered a $90 dinner just for myself, because I wanted to try the best that Perbacco--ranked third in the city by some--had to offer. Octopus and beef tongue salad, white truffle and oxtail risotto (off their seasonal white truffle menu), and tahitian sea salt caramel ice cream rounded up my order. I have but one word to say: SALT. It wasn't just that there was too much of it, to the point that I was actually gagging in the restroom before my end-meal cup of coffee, but the food itself was so tasteless that even if the only flavor available to the palate was not salt, one would have been disappointed. It was clear that the restaurant had confused subtlety with blandness.

I spoke to the owner when I was at barbacco (which oddly has far superior food--and the same chef), and he offered me a second chance, on the house, to enjoy the food. I took him up on it a couple months later. This time, I ordered a gamut of delicacies and staples, from rabbit to a simple salad. I once again have a single word: SALT. The guy next to me at the restaurant returned his spaghetti and meatballs (as well as every other dish but the wine), and when we spoke I discovered that he had traveled for the last 40 years while with the Navy, tasting and loving cuisine from across the globe. When he left, the bartender shook her head sadly at me and said "some people just don't have a refined enough palate to recognize delicious food, you know?" Oh contraire.

My mother is a caterer and I absolutely adore salt for its restorative properties to most every meal. In this case, not only was it overused to an extreme degree, but it wouldn't have helped even if it had been sprinkled with the restraint of a starving farming family saving its salt reserves to give in blocks to its two tiring horses. In other words, the chef couldn't mask the tastelessness of the food with his liberal salting, no matter how hard he tried.

excerpts: We were completely stuffed leaving Perbacco, but it was an all-around great dining experience - really delicious food, great wine and top notch service - can't ask for more than that!
perbacco.author: Erin L.
perbacco.review:
Had dinner here last week and from start to finish it was one of the better meals I've had in a long time.  The sommelier was so nice and helped us pick a wonderful bottle of champagne and a really great bottle of wine.  He listened to what we wanted and suggested affordable bottles (he didn't automatically go for the most expensive bottles on the list) that both ended up being really good.

Our server was also great - he knew the menu well and answered all our questions like a pro.  He also struck that perfect balance of anticipating our needs and handling them before we had to ask, but not being at all intrusive.  I was really impressed with the service.  

For food, we had the Pesce Crudo (big eye tuna) which was pretty good, although I enjoyed my husband's Piastra Roasted Octopus even more (tender and flavorful).  We also had the Tajarin and Papardelle pastas, which were both good -- I particularly liked the papardelle - really rich, delicious and meaty!  For my entree I had the seared scallops - they were awesome!  I'm kind of particular about the texture of scallops and I like it when they are firm, but tender, and these scallops were cooked perfectly - the tiniest bit of crunch on the outside and nice and tender on the inside.  They also came in this garlicy sauce that was delicious!  My husband had the beef short rib -- he said it was good, but not the best he's ever had.  

For dessert we had the "ugly, but good" cookies and the caramel/sea salt gelato.  The cookies are really light and airy with hazelnuts in the middle and the gelato had a creamy, delicious caramel flavor with bits of sea salt in it - I thought both were outstanding.

We were completely stuffed leaving Perbacco, but it was an all-around great dining experience - really delicious food, great wine and top notch service - can't ask for more than that!

excerpts: Romantic dinner at Perbacco, yes, please!
perbacco.author: Megan P.
perbacco.review:
Romantic dinner at Perbacco, yes, please! 

We arrived for our reservation a couple of minutes late so we needed to wait about five for our table.  The table was tucked in a quiet corner so we could sit caddy-corner instead of across from each other, another plus.  

Being foodies we tend to order two dishes for every course of the meal and share them.  Perfect way to taste a vast amount of menu.  

We started with the roasted baby beets & strawberry arugula salad.  The beets were roasted to bring out each type of beets delicate flavor.  The arugula salad was tangy yet sweet at the same time.  A plate of trotter cakes were sent out as well.  Trotter is exactly what you are thinking, piggy feet.  The meat was shredded and fried inside a pressed cake, surprisingly tender and sweet.

The next course was pasta.  We shared the tasting for two.  Our two were potato gnocchi with duck ragu and ligurian pasta with pesto sauce.  The gnocchi were light and airy.  They were tasty little pillows drenched in a rich duck ragu.  The ligurain pasta was a nice contrast with the bright pesto sauce.

The main courses were sea bass and duck with stone fruit.  The sea bass's skin was crispy and the flesh just flaked apart.  The duck tasted great but was a little hard to break down to eat.  

The last course was the best, thanks to pastry chef Suzanne LaFleur.  We had the honey panna cotta, with fennel pollen and honeycomb.  The panna cotta had a luscious texture that made it move like it had a mind of its own.  The flavor was clearly honey without being over powering.  The honey comb which accompanied the panna cotta was crispy and a wonderful compliment of textures.  

We also had the gianduja, which is a dark chocolate and hazelnut prailine bar, which is served with a caramelized cocoa nib gelato.  Where the panna cotta was delicate, this was the opposite rich and imposing.  The flavors of hazelnut and chocolate were meant to be together.  Pastry Chef LaFleur marries them in a way that punches you in the face with flavor.  Each bite is better than the last.

Overall an amazing meal, but the last course was the best.

I was looking forward to a very nice working lunch with a co-worker and Perbacco was so pleasant.  We had reservations for 1230pm and were seated immediately.  I heard that Perbacco made their cured meats well, so of course I was eyeing their salumi misti platter.  They make their salumi in-house: seasoned, cured, rested, grounded, and then magic!  Actually, I find that I'm not soo crazy about cured meat, but it was still great to experience the pork backfat and parts mixture.  :)  

The waiter was absolutely patient with us as we took our time ordering and still chatted away about work.  We even brought our pens and notebooks out to write notes about our upcoming meetings.  They didn't rush us and returned twice to ask us if we would like to order our entrees next.

The Pappardelle was so delicious!  Wide ribbon noodles with short rib ragu!  This dish inspired me to look for a good pappardelle and slow-roast pork recipe.  I will report out on the results soon.  On the otherhand, my friend's sole was a little dry.  

This is a place to impress as the FiDi lunch crowd appeared in suits and ties.  I would love to return and also try the burnt caramel gelato dessert that others have been yelping about with a glass of wine.

A good little selection of cocktails, I also love seeing whiskey and ginger beer together in a drink.

perbacco.review:
3 words: Mmmm.... Meat platter. Perbacco has all the makings of a good restaurant. We arrived early and posted up at the bar for drinks. The bar area also has a few booths, perfect for eating at the bar. A good little selection of cocktails, I also love seeing whiskey and ginger beer together in a drink. I had a drink with a mixture of gin, champagne and elderflower, very yummy!

We were seated in the upstairs portion, which was like a loft-style area. Cute table, but apparently near an exit and it was pretty chilly up there.  Now to the wine list, a bit disappointing with a limited number of reasonably priced wines. We ended up 2 carafes of wine, which were still about $35 each. But that was all forgotten when the salumi platter came out! There was oodles of house-made meats and awesomeness. I ordered the pappardelle, with great freshly made noodles, short rib and the perfect dash of horseradish. I also tasted the roasted pork shoulder, which was simply divine!

Service is always pleasant, although the Irish server we had at my most recent trip was above and beyond, so friendly and attentive without being invasive, she was absolutely fantastic. 

I love that they make their pastas fresh in house, you can certainly tell the difference. Service at the bar is not as warm as tableside but hey, if I'm wearing a suit jacket at a bar, I should be able to take it as well as I can dish it out.

perbacco.author: A. L.
perbacco.review:
**I am strictly gluten-free, so my review is from the perspective of someone with this need.**

I was treated to a delicious birthday dinner at Perbacco by the fabulous Jeff W.

PROS: Perbacco is what every "$$$" restaurant should aspire to achieve!  The staff hit that sweet spot of being attentive and also aware of when to hang back.  The menu, from top to bottom, was mouth-watering; we had a difficult time choosing  antipasti and entrees because each sounded incredible.  

A gluten-free woman of Italian descent, I usually end up with a sad salad when I venture into an Italian restaurant.  Not so at Perbacco -- the menu is not pasta-centric (although there are several pasta dishes offered for normie foodies), and the chef accommodated my gluten intolerance effortlessly.

CONS: None; however, be prepared to dine alongside pretentious middle aged folks who become louder as they consume more wine.

excerpts: I left Perbacco quite unimpressed after some high expectations going in.
While the wine here was quite good, I had a first time rabbit experience with devil's gulch rabitt in spiced red wine sauce that did not go quite too well.

One was a bit chewy with some substance, the other was like a dry chicken breast, and the other piece was a soft bland piece of meat either way undercooked or way overcooked.
Either way, there was no flavor to the meat (maybe I just got a bad rabbit or they just got the most recent roadkill from Golden Gate Park)

:D

Perbacco has an energetic atmosphere and the interior isn't quite as refined as the food
perbacco.author: Shauna F.
perbacco.review:
Excellente!

My best friend and I decided to treat each other to a fabulous meal as our Christmas present.  I did my due diligence and Perbacco seemed to have the perfect combination of mouth-water inducing menu, BART accessibility for adult beverage consumption and atmosphere.

We arrived about 45 minutes ahead of our reservation, intending to get a drink.  To our delight, we were seated immediately at an excellent table.  Our service was pleasant, informative and unobtrusive throughout.   

Excellent (and strong!) drinks in hand, we started with the hamachi crudo with citrus and the burrata with jerusalem artichokes.  The burrata and the artichokes were fantastic.  The hamachi was good but lacked a bit of acidity and flavor in general.  The lightness was a good foil for both the burrata and the pasta that was to come.

We chose to do the three pasta tasting.  I was *super* bummed that the risotto is not an option (risotto with duck, butternut squash and caramelized onions, you are on notice for next time!).  We made a quick decision to add the agnolotti dal plin which was fantastic.  I'm always blown away at how such a small filled pasta can have the most intense flavor.  I had the same experience at Cuoco in Seattle. Our other pasta selections were the tajarin (nothing special, sad to report) and agnoli with rabbit which was almost as fantastic as the agnolotti.   After sopping up the sauce with their lovely bread, I was shocked to have enough room for dessert.

I'm a complete sucker for all things salted caramel so their burnt caramel gelato with sea salt was a no brainer.  It was SO delicious.  Perfect consistency and flavor.  It was served with wonderful pine nut cookies that had a texture and flavor reminiscent of marshmallow.  Delicious!  We also had the sformatina - a chocolate mousse cake that was quite tasty.  Amazing with the caramel gelato.  :D

Perbacco has an energetic atmosphere and the interior isn't quite as refined as the food but I can see how that would be appealing to the happy hour, work crowd.  We had a wonderful experience and I would certainly return.

excerpts: You're unquestionably going to enjoy Perbacco more fully if you go with the intent to splurge--it's worth it.
perbacco.author: Amanda R.
perbacco.review:
Gluttony alert.  
On a recent visit to San Fran I whipped out my trusty Yelp app and searched for a nearby Yelp-certified place to rest my tourist feet and feast.  What a find.
My gent and I are bar people in the sense we love to dine at the bar even when fine dining.  The perspective is more authentic to us, and the views are always more fun.  People watching, interacting, etc.  We began with the tuna appetizer, which was exquisite, delicate and balanced.  For our second course we chose the gnocchi with an incredible, creamy, veal ragu.  Little pillows of pure love.  Finally, we enjoyed the short ribs with polenta and black truffle.  The flavors were so deep, so succulent, a definitive win.  
I certainly love my vino, but am admittedly far from a connoisseur.  Thus, we placed faith in our server/bartender to recommend wines for each course- best decision we could have made.  His choices were positively incredible, enhancing each dish to a greater level.  And his service impeccable. You're unquestionably going to enjoy Perbacco more fully if you go with the intent to splurge--it's worth it.

perbacco.author: Ed U.
perbacco.review:
A good Italian restaurant does not necessarily translate into checkered tablecloths and candles melting into the necks of empty Chianti bottles. It should be like a classic Sophia Loren movie circa 1963 when she was at her most lusciously lascivious...stripping in front of a hormonally charged Marcello Mastroianni...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7E4ukdZXHew

Perbacco is not quite Sophia. It's more like Mario Batali in a g-string. Ewww...scatch that. Maybe Gina Lollobrigida wearing a bodice in a B-movie. Perbacco actually bills itself as northern Italian with a touch of Provence. I guess that means Neapolitan pizza and eggplant parmigiana are out of the question here. That's OK because the menu does look pretty good.

I had the $17 Grilled Lamb Tagliata topped with a mint salsa verde and accompanied with a warm butter bean salad. Delicioso. I had a taste of my dining companion's $16 Pappardelle in a Braised Short Rib Ragu with golden chanterelles and sprinkled with parmigiano reggiano. Really delicioso. I made a mistake. Can we switch? No? Damn. But I did start with a no-brainer, the $8 Roasted Red and Golden Beets with arugula and castelmagno cheese in a white balsamic vinaigrette. Very good if a bit skimpy.

I went yesterday for lunch with the recruiters who helped me land my new job. We could barely hear each other since the noise level is fairly unbearable, and the space feels a bit cramped despite the handsome decor. The hostess is a bit snooty, but I can see why since the army of self-important, white-collar drones who come here seem to be pushing a stick up her... Anyway, I like Perbacco, just didn't love it. Maybe I'd feel differently if I went for a Saturday night dinner.

FOOD - 4 stars...nicely turned northern Italian dishes, the pappardelle is a standout
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...it's all very nice and cosmo-trendy in a loft way but so damn crowded and loud at lunchtime
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...nice waitress but the hostess holds a stick without the use of her hands
TOTAL - 4 stars...really for the menu

perbacco.author: Saminda W.
perbacco.review:
Beth and I went to Perbacco with high expectations and were generally disappointed.  Almost so that I didn't want to even write about it.

Like many SF restaurants in this mid-level space, Perbacco has all the requisite qualities to be an outstanding find:

    * Striking design: 6K square-foot historic brick warehouse space with bold modern accents such as vaulted ceilings with blond wood beams, glass mirror wall panels that attempt to open the space up further, and marble-topped bar that extends the length of the main hall
    * Robust menu: Several dozen regional Italian dishes that cause your mouth to water
    * Equally impressive wine menu

But the food.  Meh.
 
We tried several dishes, starting with the herb ricotta gnocchi with roasted wild mushrooms and the potato gnocchi with duck ragu (the former was weak, the latter was a'ight) and then the beef short ribs and duck sugo (again, former was poor, the latter was good).  Service was so-so, friendly but nothing to write home about.

For the price and vibe, the food should be so much better and so I relegate Perbacco to the realm occupied by the many dozen SF restaurants that are long on style and short on substance.  So don't worry Perbacco, you won't be lonely in exile.

excerpts: Perbacco has been on my to try list for awhile now
and I finally decided to make reservations here to celebrate my up coming birthday.
We sat down and the team at Perbacco was so nice, they even had a birthday card for me!
perbacco.author: Juliane N.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco has been on my to try list for awhile now and I finally decided to make reservations here to celebrate my up coming birthday. Easy and fast with opentable and you get points. 

Parking was easy and when we entered the restaurant, I was just staring at the open kitchen in the back. The decor and the workers here are so friendly! We were greeted by the hostess right away with a smile. 

We got seated up stairs, which is a more intimate dining area. It's out from all the bustling noise downstairs and I liked it more up stairs because the tables are not as together as the ones downstairs. We sat down and the team at Perbacco was so nice, they even had a birthday card for me! I think that is how a business should be run. 

The menu looked great, lots of options, vegetarians and meat eaters. 

Started with:
Hamachi ($12)-It came with four think slices! Fresh and so delicious! Had lemon zest on top and red chile? I didn't care for that but it was still really good without it.
Fritto Misto of Rock Shrimp ($11)- The shrimp was fried to perfection! It was all shrimp. There was also fried green beans, olives, and fennel, served with a lemon aioli. MmmmMMmm. I miss that already!

Entree:
Recommended by our awesome waiter, Sr. Juan, Pappardelle ($16.00)- It tasted like homemade pasta, which I think really was homemade, with duck, and some kinda ragu, forgot. It was really good too. Finished it pretty fast!
Grilled Ribeye steak ($29.00)- Grilled JUST the way I LOVE IT. It was awesome. i only wish they served with with a side like fingerling potatoes or something. The plate looked empty. I didn't care for the butter served on top, AT ALL though.. It tasted kinda like something was molding. Bad after taste. But I finished the steak so that means it's good!

Dessert:
Pear bread pudding ($8.00)- It looked more like a muffin without the paper on the bottom served with vanilla gelatin and mandarin marmellata. Looks can be deceiving! The pear bread pudding was really good. Good flavor of the pear you can taste the custardness of the pudding. Make sure you get a scoop of the bread pudding with the vanilla. Taste so yummy!

Service and food is excellent! Service actually was OUTSTANDING! From hostess, to waiter, to bussers!

**Tip: If you're sitting on the top floor and need to use the restroom located in the basement, there's a elevator so you don't have to walk all the way around the restaurant!**

perbacco.review:
I had a business associate in town from Chicago. He wanted martinis and appetizers and someone suggested Tadich Grill. I really want to like Tadich but can't see the appeal so I was not very happy. After one round of small warm martinis (standing, constantly being asked to move) there, we moved the party to Perbacco. 

Perbacco is the un-Tadich. Take that however you want. We've all been to Tadich a hundred times so you know what I mean. Tadich is uber-traditional and claustrophobic. It's heavy food served by heavyhanded servers. It's expensive. 

Perbacco is none of that. Well, Ok. It is expensive.

Perbacco was equally crowded but seemed airier and much friendlier. We commandeered a table next to the window and ordered a round of larger, colder, better martinis. This was more like it. Our server was friendly, full of great suggestions and always there when we needed her. The Italian wine list was good but would have benefited from a Super Tuscan or two (La Parrina is nice~). We ended up with a couple of rounds of martinis, a bottle of wine, several rounds of appetizers (the cured meats and the stuffed dates were fabulous) and dessert.

I think some of that too new, too hip, too trendy attitude that kills cool places in this town is starting to melt away into something still hip but comfortable and friendly.

perbacco.review:
T r e n d y
S m o o t h
V i b r a n t

I had just polished off only a half of the beer at Schroeder's and the pancake we had consumed between the three of us just did not cut it.  I mean, how am I suppose to support a pancake arranged on a dish Denny's level of style and presentation?

My good friend's friend was visiting from AZ for work and since I had missed connecting with her for several years, I had to delay my dinner plans with J and met at Schroeder's.  R volunteered Perbacco and since I had never been, jumped at the chance of trying a new place, plus to possibly review and check out the interior of the establishment.

First, let me state that I am all about interiors and ambiance.  I believe this truly enhances the eating process and Perbacco did an excellent job of this.  The establishment is a sleek and modern rendition of Northern Italian hospitality, echoed in the use of warm neutrals and lighting floored firmly by the rustic brick wall behind the bar.  Good thing I was in my suit, because 99% of the people here were in coats, and it must have been the destination spot for all the good looking people in suits from the Financial District.

R ran into a friend of his standing at the bar, who apparently knew the staff and the owner, and fantastically procured a banquette for us when one opened up.  Since I had already ruined my slight alcoholic tolerance earlier at Schroeder's, I declined to partake in anything special here, but did elect the Navarro Pinot Noir Juice, priced beautifully at $5.  They presented this in a wine glass and suddenly, people thought I was sipping some Pinot.  Brilliant.

Once seated, I was too busy checking out the interior and distracted by the group of suits behind us making loud discussion about an X-box game I had played in earnest (Gears of War, come on now!) but my dear friends ordered items off the menu upon the advice of our server, who was actually quite learned with the items listed and he advised that we start off with several of the appetizers (personally, they all looked quite appealing to me.)

T h e O r d e r

SALAME - NOSTRANO / FINOCCHIONA / SANGUINATO / TOSCANO / SALAME COTTO D'ASTI

A fantastic platter for the virgin to antipasti and all cured vivid meats.  Arranged artfully, the meats were arranged by type and came accompanied with little pieces of crostini as well as a sweet honey type marmalade and little gherkins.  R's special Perbacco friend questioned the use of forks, so I used my fingers to select pieces of the Toscano/Nostrano/Finocchiona (I'm a sucker for these extreme rush of tastes piqued by the curing process, the wine-garlic-herbs mix) slices gingerly and nibbled on the very rich and salty meat.

HAMACHI / SHAVED FENNEL / BLOOD ORANGE ESSENCE / OLIVE OIL

Exquisite and thick slices of the buttery hamachi, topped with shaved fennel, olive oil and slices of jalapeno peppers.  A beautifully textured piece of a gourmand's dream.  Remember to redip the hamachi into the olive oil for smooth transfer of senses.

BURRATA CHEESE / MARINATED FRIARELLI PEPPERS / WHITE ANCHOVY / ARUGULA

Resembled a little bag of fresh mozzarella, but the burrata cheese was milky smooth on the outside with a slight ricotta texture on the inside.  A mild tasting cheese, collecting a bit of the cheese in addition to the bitter arugula and the savory peppers and anchovy brought a fresh burst of a combination of tastes in my mouth.  Exquisite.

FRITTO MISTO OF ROCK SHRIMP / GREEN BEANS / OLIVES / FENNEL / LEMON AIOLI

Not the surprising course of the bunch.  Think tempura style, but the Japanese version offering a bit more on the crunchy and less oily side.  However, I was in love with the little fried balls of rock shrimp.  The lemon aioli was slightly bland, perhaps in due part that the lemon flavor was a little too mild for my tastes.  I ended up dipping it into the sweet marmalade that accompanied the cured meats plate. Fried green beans were not too entertaining, but anything fried tastes good these days.

This impressive display of vibrant textures as well as bursting flavors and the expert melding of greens and peppers to fold rather than diminish existing surprises to our palate.  The dinner was made even more enjoyable with Umberto Gibin, the part owner, assisting in the deliver of our plates.

I had to leave early from this wonderful presentation to meet up with a coworker, but will return to partake in the entree portion of their menu.

It's been a while since I've been impressed with artful Northern Italian fare and with the surprise introduction enhanced by the excellent service, Perbacco has restored my faith.

"So" he said. "I tried to make reservations to Benu, but it was impossible, they're full for the night."

Instantly  the image that popped up in my mind was Buca Di Beppo and I was secrety praying, "nooo, I hope it's not like a Buca Di Beppo!"

AND IT WASN'T! It was a very beautiful and romantic restuarant. Everyone was nicely dressed, the host and hostess looked gorgeous and the waiters were well presented too. Soon after we informed the hostess of our arrival, she quickly seated us at our table. Then our waiter quickly came to our service with the menu and the wine list. After a generalized recommendation of wine from our waiter, we ordered a bottle of 2007 Giacomo Conterno Barbera d'Alba to share. (GREAT CHOICE for those who prefers a fuller bodied wine) 

After scanning the menu for some time, we decided to opt out on the main entrees and to just share serveral appetizers, a side, a pasta and a dessert to end. 

Appetizers:
PESCE CRUDO- Big Eye tuna, cuttle fish, uni w/ an olive vinaigrette.

CARNE CRUDA- Veal tartare w/ truffled lardo crostino

*Forgot the last appetizer we ordered, but it was a crab cake mixed w/ mashed potatoes and topped with artichokes.) We could have done without that one.

On the side:
SAUTEED WHITE CORN- w/ thyme, onion and chanterelles.

Pasta:
TAJARIN- tagliatelle w/ pork sugo and porcini mushrooms 

Dessert: 
FIG LEAF PANNA COTTA

AMAZING and I was VERY impressed! Wine was great, appetizers were devoured, pasta was flavorful and the dessert.... THE DESSERT, I literally rolled in my seat laughing after each bite. It was so delicious! Another great choice, recommended by our waiter. 

5 stars for the wonderful dining experience.

Perbacco? Prebacco? PERFECTO!

This place won't jump out at you but is rather hidden amongst the giant skyscrapers in the Financial District but right when you walk inside, you know you've entered the Palace of Fine Dining.

Came with a group of 6 with lunch reservations at around 115PM. Once we entered, we were promptly seated after a wait of a few minutes. I don't know what it is about Perbacco....maybe it's been I've never eaten lunch at such a nice restaurant before...but I felt like I was Leonardo DiCaprio walking down that spiral stairwell, getting ready for dinner like a King. 

Might I say that the customer service is superb? They were very attentive but not too attentive (if you know what I mean). 5 stars for that.

Before your food comes out, they start you off with these crispy breadsticks dipped in this pesto sauce. Delicious. I could not get my hands off them. I truly believe you can tell how good a restaurant is going to be based on what type of bread they serve you. 

And for the food? I ordered the Pan Seared Hanger Steak. I can still picture the overall pinkness of the insides, while the outsides were seared to perfection. Couple that with some greens...best lunch ever.

Room for dessert? Oh hell yes. Get the Bonet (chocolate custard). Get the Bonet. Get the Bonet. That's all I gotta say.

Job well done, Perbacco. Job well done.

excerpts: Like me in the sack, Perbacco started off strong and withered away to utter disappointment as the night went on.
perbacco.author: Quinn S.
perbacco.review:
Like me in the sack, Perbacco started off strong and withered away to utter disappointment as the night went on.

One thing that never disappointed was the service; second to none in San Francisco!

The wine list is great too.  Quality, diversity, and decent pricing. Above all else, not a lot of bullshit text.  Direct and to the point is just how I like it!  We started off with a lambrusco to cut the fat on some amazing meats.

The Salumi plate is remarkable.  All house-made meat, there was a wide array that satisfied a table of 5 hungry drinkers.  I can't begin to describe the wonders on that fleshy platter, so just go in an order one for yourself.  I'll probably be found at the bar soon enough with a crossword puzzle, a cocktail and a big plate of these meats. 

Appetizers were really good as well. The mixed fried stuff was tasty, but seemed to be entirely beans and shrimp, and if I had any complaint, it was a minor one that the aioli was a tad too tangy.  The trotter cake was above reproach and I wish I had gotten more than 2 small bites.

The pasta is 99% house made and also contains 99% of the salt in the Pacific Ocean.  I can only imagine what it would have tasted like if I had accepted the offer of grated cheese over the salt.

Entrees were really really rough.  The duck breast was fine but not impressive, while the little piece of confit or whatever it was tasted like someone had poured an entire bottle of cheap pumpkin pie spices over it.  It was no more enjoyable than chewing a mouthful of cloves.

The veal was a fantastic example of poorly executed sous vide.  The mushy meat was well seasoned, but the texture made it miserable to eat.  Even the brussels sprouts, which I have enjoyed here in the past, tasted like they had been doused in sand.

excerpts: perbacco is the updated 21st century version of italian.
gone are the heavy cheese loaded entrees, replaced with well crafted pastas and entrees.
one saturday night, with plenty to chatter about, a few friends and i happened to congregate here.

perbacco.author: helen l.
perbacco.review:
perbacco is the updated 21st century version of italian. gone are the heavy cheese loaded entrees, replaced with well crafted pastas and entrees. one saturday night, with plenty to chatter about, a few friends and i happened to congregate here. we were not disappointed. the delicious offerings, well designed, contemporary ambiance, and very reasonable prices (entrees in the mid $20's, pastas in smaller/larger portions under $20) were just what we needed to help us unwind.

while the shortrib ragu w/pappardelle was quite good, and a classic, I am on the fence regarding the desserts. the panna cotta was delightful. delicately infused with orange zest, plated with candied kumquats or oranges, and paired with morsels of orange granita. but i dislike panna cotta in general so one bite was enough. instead, my dessert of choice, bread pudding, came out dry and bland. it was quite a disappointment, topped only with some creme and white chocolate drizzles.

definitely a good place to catch up with good friends over a glass of wine. the upstairs mezzanine area would be an ideal setting for a beautiful birthday dinner, or a group event.

excerpts: I had a really great lunch last week here with my advisor from work, and I think the best advice I can give to Perbacco is keep up the good work!
Perbacco is a distinctly regional Italian restaurant, which I truly love.
Of all the flashy places in the Financial District that can impress visually, I think Perbacco is one of the better in actually serving quality cuisine that is well thought out.
I'll try and find an excuse to be back soon.
perbacco.author: David W.
perbacco.review:
I had a really great lunch last week here with my advisor from work, and I think the best advice I can give to Perbacco is keep up the good work! :) Perbacco is a distinctly regional Italian restaurant, which I truly love.  You will not find Tuscan, Sicilian, or Italo-American cuisine here, but rather classics of Northwestern Italy, done well!

I had the side of **brown butter brussels sprouts with capers, shallots, and parmigiano reggiano** as a starter, and these were reallyyyy tasty.  There were some crispy bits, but for the most part it was a smooth blend of all the flavors, and the capers and parmigiano really added to this side dish.

My main dish was the **quadrati d'anatra** which were agnolotti (like ravioli) with duck, and an orange-rosemary arrosto sauce over them, sprinkled with hazelnuts.  It was very tasty, and reminded me a lot of the agnolotti I had in Torino, but with the brightness of duck and orange flavor instead of the darker beef and red wine flavors.

We were also both curious about the **Tajarin** pasta, which were handcut tagliatelle with "5-hour pork sugo."  This dish was surprising in that it is so very simple --just a plate of tagliatelle with a generous splash of sauce in the center-- but it was no less exciting than the other dishes.  Definitely more of a "comfort" dish, with a delicious pork red sauce.

Of all the flashy places in the Financial District that can impress visually, I think Perbacco is one of the better in actually serving quality cuisine that is well thought out.  I'll try and find an excuse to be back soon.

perbacco.review: coming in after hidden vine sip...finally dinner....eight:thirty pm on a tuesday and restaurant full...lively and staff busy...reservations and seated upstairs...dim lighting...thin crispy breadsticks and sweet dip snacking...browsing wine and bottle of j pinot gris at $thirty-six to start...family style order of mix and match...slivers of tasty tender octopus $thirteen...wonder how long they massaged the octopus?...quite tender and sweet octopus deliciousness...small salumi meat platter quite loaded for smaller sizing $eighteen...slivers of salty meats and small sweet tangy pickles complimenting....perfection with another bottle of wine...brought a bottle and no corkage charged...taste of summer fruits in september $fourteen...wedges of sweet soft peaches piled with leafy greens...succulent!...garganell, pappardelle and risotto marvelous...$fourteen, $thirteen and $fourteen prospective...great mix of full flavor small plates...finishing with animals..tender well sauced short ribs $twenty-six fork tender beef...pork shoulder $twenty-four tasty and saucy...gulp of wine and finishing...barbera coppo $fourty-eight?...must be a wine ordered...stomach full and a lush with wine....check please!...roughly $two-hundred-eighty for dinner and wine for five...$fifty-six per person...perbacco perfect date or group restaurant...small plates and large plates to share, eat and enjoy...

excerpts: Even though I was disappointed with my meal, I might be willing to give Perbacco another shot.
The pasta left me hope that I might actually be able to enjoy something in the future.
perbacco.author: Annalynn C.
perbacco.review:
Friends and I had dinner here on a Tuesday evening and the place was packed.  We had reservations and were promptly seated when we arrived.  Service is hot and cold at this place.  It took a while before our waiter inquired about what we wanted to drink. 

However, after we ordered our appetizers it didn't take long before they arrived.  We ordered  Hamachi (yellowtail) with blood orange essence, shaved fennel, and orange oil, and ligurian salt cod with potato gratin and crostini.  The Hamachi was good, but it was difficult to savor the fish because the orange oil and essence were too overpowering.  As much as I love Hamachi, I don't think I'd order this particular dish again.  The salt cod was too salty for my liking.  Even with the crostini and bread sticks, I was still unable to enjoy it.

After a somewhat disappointing appetizer, I looked forward to my seared tuna entree; but that, too, was disappointing.  The tuna was seared alright, but the portion of the tuna that was uncooked was still frozen!  I should've followed my friends' lead and tried their pasta, instead.  I had a bite of the pasta and preferred it to my fish.  Try the Pappardelle, you won't be disappointed if you eat red meat and like mushrooms.

This place was batting 0 for 2, so I decided to pass on dessert.

The interior is modern and comfortable.  

Even though I was disappointed with my meal, I might be willing to give Perbacco another shot.  The pasta left me hope that I might actually be able to enjoy something in the future.

excerpts: Instead of bread, Perbacco serves breadsticks with pesto.
I ordered beef short rib with pappardelle pasta which I didn't enjoy very much.
I didn't like the horseradish shavings on top and the ragu pasta didn't mix in well with the sauce.
My sister ordered pesto gnocchi which was quite dense.
perbacco.author: Cindy H.
perbacco.review:
My sister and I were seated in this packed rectangle area that was quite noisy. All the tables were close enough that you can hear other people's conversations. 

Instead of bread, Perbacco serves breadsticks with pesto. I ordered beef short rib with pappardelle pasta which I didn't enjoy very much. I didn't like the horseradish shavings on top and the ragu pasta didn't mix in well with the sauce. My sister ordered pesto gnocchi which was quite dense.

excerpts: I hosted my engagement party dinner at Perbacco and with a few weeks notice got a table for a large party (had to put down my credit card to secure).
Given the long wait on a secured reservation, I felt like Perbacco could have offered us drinks, or even water, as we stood around awkwardly in the doorway.
perbacco.author: Wendy T.
perbacco.review:
I hosted my engagement party dinner at Perbacco and with a few weeks notice got a table for a large party (had to put down my credit card to secure).

That night we arrived on time and the hostess tells me that the party at our table has just paid the bill and should be leaving soon. Sure, no big deal. Our large party stood around waiting for about 25 mins to no avail.. Finally the previous party left and the hostess seated us. Given the long wait on a secured reservation, I felt like Perbacco could have offered us drinks, or even water, as we stood around awkwardly in the doorway. I almost wanted to leave and go next door to my fav restaurant Tadich Grill!

Otherwise it was a great night. We started out with the salumi misti for the table, which was excellent. There were so many selections on the plate and they were all delicious. Everyone had an appetizer of some sort - the rock shrimp misti was especially delicious and large compared to the appetizer-sized pastas everyone else ordered. All entrees were fantastic - specifically the pork shoulder and the scallops.

After dinner, a few of us had desserts or drinks and they brought us a plate of the "ugly but delicious" cookies on the house. Definitely delicious :)

I'd come again just for the salumi misti!

excerpts: Perbacco gets an extra star for having a full bar with imaginative drinks, no conversation competing music and equal food.
The highs at SPQR might have been a bit higher in a dish or two, but this was a strong meal in a much better environment.
Oh, it was half the price too.
perbacco.author: Jon W.
perbacco.review: My direct comparison (fair or not) is my 4 star review of SPQR the night before. Perbacco gets an extra star for having a full bar with imaginative drinks, no conversation competing music and equal food. The highs at SPQR might have been a bit higher in a dish or two, but this was a strong meal in a much better environment. Oh, it was half the price too.

excerpts: Thank you, Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Rene D.
perbacco.review:
Just as delicious as I remembered! Lunch was fantastic:

PIASTRA:  seared local squid w/ corona bean puree, preserved lemon, chili and arugula 
TAJARIN - hand cut tagliatelle covered with their famous 5-hout pork sugo and porcini mushrooms

Also splurged and ordered a wine flight of reds from the Piedmont region: Verduno / Dolcetto d"Alba / Coste Sesia / Colli Tortonesi / Roero
Service? Professional and attentive as always. 

God, it was just the right to have a windy, chilly afternoon. Thank you, Perbacco!

excerpts: I went to Perbacco for lunch a few weeks ago
and it was a fabulous experience.
The salumi misti lived up to the hype in my opinion, and was actually quite filling when paired with warm bread.
The piastra seared local squid was my favorite dish - ultra tender and bursting with flavor.
perbacco.author: Claire C.
perbacco.review:
I went to Perbacco for lunch a few weeks ago and it was a fabulous experience. The salumi misti lived up to the hype in my opinion, and was actually quite filling when paired with warm bread. The piastra seared local squid was my favorite dish - ultra tender and bursting with flavor. Duck ragu 7-pepper pasta was also tasty and perfectly cooked.

Service was friendly and on point and the prices were reasonable for the FiDi location and the quality. I shall return!

excerpts: Perbacco held it's own.
We got the last reservation and the place was still pretty full.
I had a great blood orange cocktail.
We tried 3 half orders of pasta, all house made and outstanding.
We had a grilled octopus dish which was great .
We finished with the rabbit which we loved as well.
perbacco.author: Michael H.
perbacco.review: This was our last dinner in sf and it landed in valentines day. It had some tough competition as our previous meals were at frascati, gary danko and spruce. Perbacco held it's own. We got the last reservation and the place was still pretty full. I had a great blood orange cocktail. We tried 3 half orders of pasta, all house made and outstanding. We had a grilled octopus dish which was great . We finished with the rabbit which we loved as well.

excerpts: This was somehow my first visit to Perbacco, and I will definitely be back.
The pork shoulder and duck were both phenomenal!
Not as impressed with the sea bass, but everything else (burratta, crab cakes and even the breadsticks) were delish.
Our waitress Tiffany was also incredible - very knowledgeable, friendly and helpful!
perbacco.author: Megan S.
perbacco.review: This was somehow my first visit to Perbacco, and I will definitely be back. The pork shoulder and duck were both phenomenal! Not as impressed with the sea bass, but everything else (burratta, crab cakes and even the breadsticks) were delish. excerpts: We visited Perbacco for dinner on a Tuesday night in October.
We were seated in Alana's section and will forever ask for Alana whenever we return.
We ordered way too much food for two (and Alana warned us that it was a lot), but we wanted the full Perbacco experience.
perbacco.author: Cecily J.
perbacco.review:
We visited Perbacco for dinner on a Tuesday night in October.  We were seated in Alana's section and will forever ask for Alana whenever we return.  She was very attentive but allowed us time to enjoy each others company, provided detailed, accurate answers to all of our questions, and recommended wines and dishes that far exceeded our high expectations.  

We started with a fish crudo, which was fresh & flavorful, and a duo of pasta - DELICIOUS.  We then shared two entrees - quail & duck.  Both were cooked perfectly.  We also shared two sides - brussels sprouts & white corn.  We ordered way too much food for two (and Alana warned us that it was a lot), but we wanted the full Perbacco experience.

We have enjoyed fantastic service at many wonderful restaurants across the country, but Alana gave us a truly exceptional experience.  We look forward to seeing her again when we return to SF soon.

excerpts:
We chose Perbacco after searching Yelp for a restaurant that a) was within walking distance, but b) wouldn't cause poor Nate's feet to blister anymore than they already had due to our full day of walking San Fran. 

We called Perbacco, made a reservation for 7:30pm, and got ready to go.
perbacco.author: Sarah C.
perbacco.review:
Part of my San Francisco weekend included fancy dinner out on the town. We chose Perbacco after searching Yelp for a restaurant that a) was within walking distance, but b) wouldn't cause poor Nate's feet to blister anymore than they already had due to our full day of walking San Fran. 

We called Perbacco, made a reservation for 7:30pm, and got ready to go.

We arrived and were seated right away. It was a Saturday night, and the place was PACKED. So glad we made a reservation!

Since this dinner out was part of my Christmas present, Nate let me pick everything we would be eating that night. YES!

We started with the Roasted Pear Salad with caramel vinaigrette, gorgonzola crema, and candied hazelnuts. So yummy; sweet, yet savory.

Next course I chose the Tortelli Di Ciapin-Abe - Pasta filled with roasted sunchokes with sage butter, hedgehog mushrooms, and radicchio. I was expecting Tortellini noodles, which I adore, but it was more like Ravioli. Still very, very good.

For our main course, I chose the Liberty Farm Duck Breast with Roasted Pears, Butternut Squash Passato and Antica Formula Duck Jus. I have never had duck before, but OH! This was SO good. The meat was tender and flavorful. I absolutely loved it!

Dessert was the Burnt Caramel Gelato with Vanilla Sea Salt. This was what most of the reviewers were raving about, and I didn't even need to look at a dessert menu after reading all about it. And it was AMAZING!

The service was great; our glasses were never empty, and someone was always clearing or bringing out a dish. Warm bread = icing on the cake.

This was seriously one of the best meals I have ever had (top 5 for sure) and was one of the best restaurant experiences too.

excerpts: I just looked at my list of reviews and see that I never updated Perbacco.
I am ashamed of that because my experiences before and after my previous review were always great.
Their service is really impeccable and their menu is just to die for.
I love it all.
I live up the street from the restaurant and it's a great place for a late dinner with it's cozy interior and storefront window where lights spills out onto the dark sidewalk.
Small tables near the bar, larger tables beyond, plus a full second floor.
A great place for a special celebration meal, a date, or, heck
ANYTIME
you want beautiful food.
perbacco.author: Karen S.
perbacco.review:
Oh, my.  I just looked at my list of reviews and see that I never updated Perbacco.  I am ashamed of that because my experiences before and after my previous review were always great.  Their service is really impeccable and their menu is just to die for.  I love it all.  I live up the street from the restaurant and it's a great place for a late dinner with it's cozy interior and storefront window where lights spills out onto the dark sidewalk.
Small tables near the bar, larger tables beyond, plus a full second floor.  A great place for a special celebration meal, a date, or, heck ANYTIME you want beautiful food.  I've dined during the White Truffles season as well as through the rest of the year.  

Barbacco, next door, is under the same  ownership and serves lunch only, in a more casual atmosphere, also providing take-out meals.

excerpts: I took my ex to Perbacco for his birthday last month.
Gee, aren't I a doll?
Anyway, he cooks at Pizzaiolo in Oakland, so
after checking Perbacco's menu I thought it would be compatible with his taste in food.
perbacco.author: Joanna M.
perbacco.review:
I took my ex to Perbacco for his birthday last month.  Gee, aren't I a doll?  Anyway, he cooks at Pizzaiolo in Oakland, so after checking Perbacco's menu I thought it would be compatible with his taste in food.  Me, I'm more of a French foodie, but it was his day.

Neither of us were disappointed, and he is a big snob. The house-cured salumis were fatty fantastic, I had the duck, which, flavored with quince compote, was the best duck that I've ever had (ooh I see someone else has said the same thing.)  The angelotti were perfect, and I finally warmed up to panettone!

Our waitress looked exactly like the actress who played Juno (i.e. short and young), but she didn't have any of Juno's saltiness.  She was purely sweet :)

excerpts: I had been to Perbacco for lunch five years ago and it was upscale, and precise in food preparation and presentation, so I suggested we go there.
There was a crisp urban feel about the restaurant when I last visited.
Perbacco  was packed on a Monday night  most folks appeared not to be  locals, perhaps they were all part of the 20000 convention members.
The service was attentive, although our waiter noted but did not ask about our half eaten main courses.
The starters of a fritto (which was not cooked hot enough) and a tartar which was fresh  were passable, but half way through the main courses my friend said, "Room service was better!"
I had the stuffed quail which was over cooked and tasted steamed and was on a mess of greens with both some kind of creamy sauce and a sauce of poultry,
It was all gooey.
His "nettle lasagnetta" was also gummy, thick with little taste of nettle and only a slight resemblance to lasagne
perbacco.author: maria B.
perbacco.review:
It seemed like a good idea at the time....A friend who is a wonderful cook was in SF at a meeting , and he said, "I'm so tired of working on my presentation and having room service let us go out to dinner." I had been to Perbacco for lunch five years ago and it was upscale, and precise in food preparation and presentation, so I suggested we go there.  There was a crisp urban feel about the restaurant when I last visited. Tonight it just felt noisey, crowded and  very ordinary.

Perbacco  was packed on a Monday night  most folks appeared not to be  locals, perhaps they were all part of the 20000 convention members.   The service was attentive, although our waiter noted but did not ask about our half eaten main courses.
The starters of a fritto (which was not cooked hot enough) and a tartar which was fresh  were passable, but half way through the main courses my friend said, "Room service was better!"  I had the stuffed quail which was over cooked and tasted steamed and was on a mess of greens with both some kind of creamy sauce and a sauce of poultry,  It was all gooey.  His "nettle lasagnetta" was also gummy, thick with little taste of nettle and only a slight resemblance to lasagne and he said it had "specks of meat in it". 

I wonder what has happened here I certainly will not go back, but perhaps it was Monday and the chef was off  --oops I mean away--certainly the chef was off.

excerpts: At Perbacco, most of these things definitely applied certainly, but really, it was the little things that impressed me the most, such as when our server offered us tastings of wines-by-the-glass when we asked for recommendations to go with our courses.

Unlike Aqua, though, Perbacco lacks a bit of warmth and mystery and seems designed more for the high-end expense account power lunches and dinners of FiDi denizens rather than intimate tete-a-tetes with a crush du jour.
perbacco.author: Claudine C.
perbacco.review:
We take many things for granted in this food-crazy city: that the meal will be delicious, the service impeccable and the surroundings fabulous.  At Perbacco, most of these things definitely applied certainly, but really, it was the little things that impressed me the most, such as when our server offered us tastings of wines-by-the-glass when we asked for recommendations to go with our courses.

As for the food...

Hamachi with preserved lemon and chili peppers -- 4 large slabs of raw hamachi, drizzled with olive oil.  I felt the dish could have used a bit of acid, but the peppers were not overly spicy and the preserved lemon added a bit of pleasant bitter tang.

Roasted Octopus - octopus tentacles, fingerling potatoes and haricot verts salad. Couldn't get enough of this dish - note that unfortunately one gets only about 4 tentacles of the most perfect and tender-roasted octopus...

Risotto Milanese - listed on the menu as a "saffron risotto / slivered foie gras / nettle puree"
We ordered the large portion, and servers brought out 2 split and vrey generous servings for each of us.  It's presented to you rather dramatically with the shocking yellow saffron rice surrounding around 3 very thin slices or medallions ("shavings") of foie, and a tiny quenelle of nettles.  Each individual component tastes just ok on its own, but once you mix the lot together (smear the already- melting foie around with the nettles and gooey rice), the taste is orgasmic.

As for entrees, the boy chose the monkfish with wild mushrooms, beans and truffle butter -- I could smell the truffles as I sat across the table from him.  I opted for the milk-braised pork shoulder with polenta and savoy cabbage.  My dish was not exactly the prettiest to look at, but the meat was utterly tender and bursting with good porky flavor and the polenta rich and cheesy.  The boy's monkfish was also fabulous - perfectly cooked and firm and redolent of that singular earthy-heady truffle scent. Oh - and our side dish of roasted brussels sprouts - also fantastic...

Did we have dessert? I believe the boy had a chocolate covered creme brulee served with crisp mini cannolis -- 2 desserts in one... I was absolutely stuffed and nibbled at the edges.

I'm not a big fan of the design inside -- like Aqua next door, the small entrance belies the cavernous, long interior with high soaring ceilings and clean, minimalist lines.  Unlike Aqua, though, Perbacco lacks a bit of warmth and mystery and seems designed more for the high-end expense account power lunches and dinners of FiDi denizens rather than intimate tete-a-tetes with a crush du jour.

excerpts: I just had a lovely lunch at Perbacco.
I've been there before, but never taken the time to review it.
It has been on my list for business lunches for awhile now, but it is always hard to get a quick reservation
perbacco.author: Katharine A.
perbacco.review:
I just had a lovely lunch at Perbacco.  I've been there before, but never taken the time to review it.  It has been on my list for business lunches for awhile now, but it is always hard to get a quick reservation and I end up going elsewhere.

Today I had planned ahead.  Everything from the food to the service was superb.   I started out splitting a 1st course of heirloom tomato salad.  It is right on the cusp of the season, but these tomatoes were out of this world.  Flavorful and delicious, and topped with cheese and a sprinkle of balsamic.

We went with our great waiter's pasta choices for our 2nd course--Trofie (pesto, potato, veggies) and an Angolotti dal Plin.

For dessert we has chocolate mousse and gelato.  Glad I saved room!

The portions were perfect for lunch.  Satisfying, but not overwhelming.

I sat downstairs this time and it was great for business conversation.  Not too loud, not too quiet..  Good atmosphere and pretty full for a 1:00 reservation.

excerpts: So after the "Tequila + Chocolate" tasting at TCHO, a group of us (14? 16? I actually lost count -- blame the tequila!) went to Perbacco for dinner.
There is a private dinning room upstairs -- in sort of a loft, overlooking the kitchen.
Perbacco was wonderful -- I can only speak for what Lynn and I had, but the appetizers were wonderful:

I have the Carne Cruda di Vitellone (a tartare of veal, served with truffled lardo crostini), that was just amazing, while Lynn had the Roasted Octopus & Poached Wagyu Beef Tongue, served with golden potatoes, celery hearts, and salsa verde (
perbacco.author: Jason L.
perbacco.review:
So after the "Tequila + Chocolate" tasting at TCHO, a group of us (14? 16? I actually lost count -- blame the tequila!) went to Perbacco for dinner.  There is a private dinning room upstairs -- in sort of a loft, overlooking the kitchen.  What a great room!  

Perbacco was wonderful -- I can only speak for what Lynn and I had, but the appetizers were wonderful:  I have the Carne Cruda di Vitellone (a tartare of veal, served with truffled lardo crostini), that was just amazing, while Lynn had the Roasted Octopus & Poached Wagyu Beef Tongue, served with golden potatoes, celery hearts, and salsa verde (and she's still raving about it 24 hours later!).

We both opted for pastas as our entrées . . . Lynn chose the Rabatòn (truffle and herbed ricotta gnocchi with wild mushroom sugo) that was delicious, while I devoured the Pappardelle with rabbit ragú, chanterelle mushrooms and braised radicchio . . . 

A wonderful evening indeed . . .

excerpts: My husband and I just went back to Perbacco to celebrate  our wedding anniversary.
This was my husband's first visit and and he was in awe of this place.
It was just incredible.
The food was excellent.
The service was over the top.
Our server was very attentive and you could tell he enjoyed his job.
I had said that this place was a special occasion place, but after dining there tonight, we will be back soon.
We are definitely fans!!!
