perbacco.review: My husband and I just went back to Perbacco to celebrate  our wedding anniversary. This was my husband's first visit and and he was in awe of this place. It was just incredible.  The food was excellent. The service was over the top. Our server was very attentive and you could tell he enjoyed his job. I had said that this place was a special occasion place, but after dining there tonight, we will be back soon. We are definitely fans!!!

excerpts: I reluctantly accepted -- we never ate dinner before 7 when we were growing up, but seven people at Perbacco?
I understood it was tricky.
If it hadn't been for that insulting first table assignment, I'd have given Perbacco 5 Stars.
The table next to the swinging kitchen door may be alright to assign to walk-ins, but NOT to guests with (2-week) reservations travelling from out of town for a birthday dinner.
(Che bruto!)
perbacco.author: Saskia Fiona S.
perbacco.review:
Birthday Festa

My brother generously offered to bring me here for my birthday. We're Italian and have travelled in Italy since we were little. Anyway, my boss had brought me here for my birthday also, and I was so excited to see Vitello Tonnato on the menu.  When I told my brother how good the food had been, he offered to bring my family there on a Saturday night to celebrate my birthday. 

So I phoned for reservations (7 at 7) but they didn't have anything available at  7. Would 5:30 be oK?  I reluctantly accepted -- we never ate dinner before 7 when we were growing up, but seven people at Perbacco? I understood it was tricky.  My brother and his family live out of town, but we live in the City, so we agreed to make the sacrifice and eat way early. 

The staff had kindly asked if we were celebrating anything when I made the reservation.  I let them know that it was my birthday.  They assured me that detail would be noted on our reservation.  At the appointed hour, We arrived on time .... And were escorted upstairs and seated RIGHT NEXT TO THE KITCHEN DOOR. I was horrified. When I commented, sotto voce, "Oh ...  Right next to the kitchen", I was insulted by the "hostess" who said, "It's not the kitchen".  When I asked what it was, she said it was the stairs.  I tried to let it go but the longer we sat there, the worse it got.  There was a constant parade of waiters in & out. Then the odors started. I don't know what they were cooking in those "stairs" but it became too much. Thankfully, our designated waiter noticed me fanning the odor away and offered to check about another table. Our new table, despite being close by, proved to be a tremendous improvement. We were able to concentrate on the food, which was as it should be. 

We had the Vitello Tonnato, an old family favorite, and the Salumi Misti, Pappardelle, Gnocchi, and Risotto. The Gnocchi were a huge hit with the children. And our (new) waiter, Rocco, was fantastic. He was not only impeccable, suggesting perfect wines to accompany our meal, but he was absolutely adorable with the children.  

If it hadn't been for that insulting first table assignment, I'd have given Perbacco 5 Stars. The table next to the swinging kitchen door may be alright to assign to walk-ins, but NOT to guests with (2-week) reservations travelling from out of town for a birthday dinner. (Che bruto!)

excerpts: The one thing I have to add to the 865 preceding reviews of Perbacco is that Joe Montana eats here.
That's right, Joe Montana, the legendary 49er.
I have to confess, I was caught off guard by how handsome and fit he is at 54 - um WOW!
perbacco.author: Rebecca O.
perbacco.review:
The one thing I have to add to the 865 preceding reviews of Perbacco is that Joe Montana eats here. That's right, Joe Montana, the legendary 49er. I have to confess, I was caught off guard by how handsome and fit he is at 54 - um WOW! Starstruck Rebecca O. in da hou-ouse! 

While that was the obvious highlight of our dinner here, I did actually enjoy the food. My ricotta gnocci with mushrooms entree was good, but not special, but my husband's short rib pappardelle (rhymes with R Kelly), was heaven on a plate! I would definitely go back for that dish in a heartbeat. I was equally excited about the salted caramel gelato I inhaled for dessert. I'm really in love with salted caramel ice cream situations these days.

The dining room acoustics are noisy, so it's not the best choice for folks that are looking for a quiet, intimate ambiance. However, we were able to get a last minute reservation on a week night.  Plus, street parking was an absolute breeze, because the Financial District empties out at night. Bonus points awarded for ease of use. 

Bottom line, people - if it's good enough for Golden Joe, chances are high that you will like it, too!

excerpts: Apparently Perbacco knows how...
perbacco.author: Debbie C.
perbacco.review:
How do you wild harvest warm chocolate cake? Apparently Perbacco knows how...

Very fancy smancy place to go for lunch with coworkers.  I enjoyed my three course business lunch. I made sure I brought my table manners since I was eating lunch with my boss and my boss' boss. Luckily there were no major mishaps although I think I accidentally dropped some fritto misto on the floor (shhh! don't tell). 
 
I definitely recommend the fritto misto of rock shrimp / green beans / olives / fennel / lemon aioli for the starter. For the main I got the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vitellone, the waitress said it was a signature dish. My taste buds appreciated her recommendation. I wish I hadn't ordered the dessert though. Don't get me wrong it was goooood but so decadent. The wild harvest warm chocolate cake put me over the edge and into a food coma. I wanted a nap the rest of the work day.

excerpts: I have eated at Perbacco several times and each time it is beyond delicious.
The risotto is always a treat, great service and a nice wine list all make Perbacco a place to come back to!
perbacco.author: Michele K.
perbacco.review: I have eated at Perbacco several times and each time it is beyond delicious.  The risotto is always a treat, great service and a nice wine list all make Perbacco a place to come back to!

excerpts: Nothing but "perbacco" for Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Linda L.
perbacco.review:
Nothing but "perbacco" for Perbacco.

I totally judged this place because it's in the financial district.  Sorry.  I was wrong.  The crowd seemed a little b&t/touristy/weird/douchey, but not so much so that it was distracting or that the service was catered to that.

Our waiter was helpful, knowledgeable, and attentive without being overbearing, and the other service was also excellent.

The food was all good, and some really great.  One of the highlights for me was the raviolo.  The egg yolk inside was cooked perfectly to create a slow ooze when you cut in to it, and the truffles and yolk, and spinach all worked together magically.  The brussel sprouts with capers in brown butter were so beautiful together I almost cried.  

Delish, I'll totally go back.

excerpts: Just thinking of our dinner at Perbacco is making my mouth water!
perbacco.author: Kelly K.
perbacco.review:
Mmm... Just thinking of our dinner at Perbacco is making my mouth water! Overall, this was a wonderful restaurant with friendly service, amazing food and a great atmosphere. 

You have to try the "tris" of pasta. It's basically a trio of pasta samples, and every single one I ordered was delicious. It was some of the most unique pasta I have ever had. Since the pasta was a bit filling, our group just split a couple entrees, and the duck was oh so tasty!

Did I mention you can bring your own wine too? (2 bottle max.) This is the perfect restaurant to go to for a special occasion.. although I also heard they have a good happy hour. We can't wait to go back!

excerpts: We cannot recommend Perbacco more highly!

perbacco.review: Through private dining manager Stephen Lee we booked the Barolo Room, the wine "cellar" located on the mezzanine floor.  We were only 12 guests but the room would easily accommodate more.  Mr. Lee was a pleasure to work with, efficient and to the point, a simple email was all that was needed to communicate.  We had our own private waitress, an Irish girl named Emer, and she was a delight.  She "read" the room correctly and struck a nice balance for us.  This was a wedding luncheon.  She kept the champagne and wine glasses filled...  The food was spectacular!  This place is fit for "foodies," and we will return as regular diners in the future.  All of our guests felt the same way.  We cannot recommend Perbacco more highly!

perbacco.author: Roy N.
perbacco.review:
* I'm back!!!  Apologies to all my good friends here that I temporarily lost touch with on Yelp.  The past few weeks have been absolutely crazy and my father's health has deteriorated greatly in so many ways.  He was hospitalized for ten days and is home now, but his dementia, alzheimer's, and poor health has been quite a test for us all.  On a good note, I used some of this hospitalization time as an opportunity to treat my poor saint of a girlfriend who hasn't had a night out in ages (since my dad ordinarily cannot be left alone and has to be watched all the time now, we normally cannot go out together at the same time at night).  If we weren't visiting him at the hospital, we were out and about, dining and drinking.  He is home now so things are back to normal and we absolutely can't get out or get away together at night now, but during that little time we had off, I really tried to make those nights special for her and show her how much I appreciate her and everything she does.  Thanks to Perbacco, I was able to.  Anyway, on to the review!

The review:

As everyone knows, I have always loved Perbacco and as such, it only seems logical that this meal turned out to be the most memorable of all the nice dinners and lunches that my girlfriend and I had together recently.  She has been so wonderful to me and my dad and with him temporarily hospitalized, I finally had the opportunity to take her out to dinner, something that has been absolutely impossible otherwise.  

Upon walking in the door, was happy to see that Carla was working behind the bar (nice new haircut!)...she really makes the place and was fantastic as always.  The hostess and people working the front desk were really great too.  As always, the service from everyone we came in contact with was fantastic too.    

Some places just always feel right every time I go there and Perbacco is one of them.  From the moment I walked in, I felt elated and at home in the uplifting environment.  This for me has always been the hallmark of a great restaurant...it's hard to describe, but in a nutshell, it's the convergence of setting, food, decor, and first class service/attitude (in a good way).  It's not just about location either, it's about a place with synergy that is run right and excels in so many ways.  Lake Park Bistro in Milwaukee overlooking Lake Michigan and Flagstaff House in Boulder, CO share a similar magic for me, every time I walk in.

In addition to the cocktails and then wines, we shared an appetizer of Vitello Tonato - slow roasted veal, lemon and albatore sauce, capers and arugula. She then had the Pappardelle which was wide ribbon pasta ribbons, slow-cooked short rib ragu, roasted cippoline, and grated horseradish. I had the Tajarin which was handcut tagliatelle, 5 hour cooked pork sugo, and porcini mushrooms.

The waiter we had, Brett, was first-rate and he really added to the experience.  Extremely professional, yet at the same time, genuine and real, he had the calm manner of a seasoned professional and his efforts made for an exceptional dining experience.  When I inquired about available roeros, he instantly suggested a special off-menu Trinita nebbiolo roero ($98) that turned out to be the perfect complement to our meal.  

For our main course, she had the Beef Short Rib Stracatto with root vegetable passatina, braised escarole, and honey glazed cipoline and carrots. I had the Striped Bass with wild mushroom and Jerusalem artichoke ragout and truffle jus. I specifically asked for no side of spinach and they were more than happy to accomodate.  Looking back, I just realized that I forgot to order the additional side of fingerling potatoes with lardo we wanted, but just as well, we were stuffed anyway. We then had a really nice valpolicella dessert wine (nice!!!) and then she had the Bonte, a wild harvested chocolate custard with whipped cream and amaretti. I had the Sformatino, a carmelized milk chocolate mousse with dark chocolate glaze, cocoa almond streusel, and creme inglese. No complaints here...it was a pricey, but most memorable dining experience for both of us, especially for her as it was her first time here. 

One of my friends, upon hearing that I spent $300 on dinner for two here took a look at the online menu and was surprised that I spent so much.  I explained that we had some nice wines and that when there are as many outstanding items on the menu, it wasn't hard to do at all.

Perbacco...just the mere mention of  the name gives me a warm feeling and makes me dream of heavenly Italian food, celestial pastas with slow cooked sauces, and fine wines in a tasteful, romantic setting.  Special thanks to our server, Brett, and Carla at the bar for a most memorable dining experience.

excerpts: Prior to my girl date earlier this week, he asked me why my roommate and I had chosen Perbacco.
Because, silly boy, they supposedly have this fantastic salumi misti plate.
After explaining to him that the plate was essentially high-end salami, he perked up.
And the thing is, everything about the food at Perbacco is excellent.

Whether it was the roasted asparagus and pear salad appetizers, or the complimentary breadsticks, or the pappardelle with short rib ragu, or the rabaton gnocchi with mushroom sugo, my roommate and I were constantly wowed.
You bring that sexy acquired Australian accent of yours, and I'll bring the salumi misti from Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Devon S.
perbacco.review:
A little over four months ago, my boyfriend moved to Australia for an extended sabbatical. The land down under has proven to be a clever minx, and she has seduced my boy. Seduced him good. Between Skype dates and care packages full of Cholula and refried beans, I've often wondered how I'll ever convince him to come home early.

Prior to my girl date earlier this week, he asked me why my roommate and I had chosen Perbacco. "Because, silly boy, they supposedly have this fantastic salumi misti plate." After explaining to him that the plate was essentially high-end salami, he perked up. I had the man hooked, as he loves his salami.

And you know what?

I've found the way to lure him back home. The salumi misti plate is fantastic and full of delicious salty meats and briny cauliflower and pickles and sweet quince jelly. It was everything I had hoped it to be, and it is definitely something I will share with him when he gets home.

And the thing is, everything about the food at Perbacco is excellent. Whether it was the roasted asparagus and pear salad appetizers, or the complimentary breadsticks, or the pappardelle with short rib ragu, or the rabaton gnocchi with mushroom sugo, my roommate and I were constantly wowed. Everything about the service was perfection, as well, and even though the ambiance is decidedly business-happy-hour, there were a number of couples enjoying intimate dinners around us.

So boyfriend, since I know you follow my reviews even though you're 7.5k miles away: Come home soon. You bring that sexy acquired Australian accent of yours, and I'll bring the salumi misti from Perbacco.

excerpts: Bottom line, Perbacco left a bitter taste in my mouth, quite the opposite of the expression of pleasure and surprise, as their namesake alludes one will feel after dining here.

perbacco.author: H T.
perbacco.review:
We came here for dinner on a Saturday night - the restaurant itself is ok - being in the financial district it has more of a business like feel than a romantic one (it can get pretty loud to the point of being unable to hear the person sitting next to you). Nevertheless, we were seated upstairs and ordered a bottle of wine and appetizer (a single raviolo with ricotta and spinach $12). If you ask me, that's an expensive raviolo. The had complementary sticks of bread that were unique and innovative and the pesto fresca dipping sauce which accompanied it was pretty good. 

For my entree, being a vegetarian and not wanting gnocchi, I had a limited selection to choose from - I  I had the raviora 'd cosse - pasta filled with roasted butternut squash, sage brown butter and toasted hazelnuts ($16). This entree was way too sweet for my liking and I was left with a meh feeling from it.  I was hoping the dessert would save the night. For dessert we did a three cheese platter of capriago, caprino di riforano, and the cuise sotto foglie di tabaco. I wasn't wowed by any of these unfortunately.  We topped off the night with the Hazelnut Budino which really saved the night. Honestly, if I came back here I wouldn't even bother with the actual food, just the budino! 

What really turned me off from this place was the service. It was slow and unattentive. What was even worse was the annoying couple sitting next to us who were making fun of one of the other guests - to top it off, they started talking to our waitress about the guest and to my shock, she joined in on the discussion! I found this to be appalling and very unprofessional at any restaurant, let alone one that's attempting to be "upscale".

Bottom line, Perbacco left a bitter taste in my mouth, quite the opposite of the expression of pleasure and surprise, as their namesake alludes one will feel after dining here. My advice, if you want good italian in SF, travel to north beach, and if you want a romantic, upscale meal in SF, try a Michelin, - do yourself a favor and leave out Perbacco.

excerpts: I stopped in for a late night dinner around 9:30 on the promise from my friend that Perbacco would offer a fine meal.
perbacco.author: Jason L.
perbacco.review:
I stopped in for a late night dinner around 9:30 on the promise from my friend that Perbacco would offer a fine meal.

The dining area was still packed with a healthy dinner crowd, full of the energy of the financial district's finest. We ordered a bottle of the Peter Paul pinot noir as I perused through the difficult-to-pronounce menu items. 

I decided on the Tajarin, not knowing what it was, but the phrases" 5-hour" and "pork" together sounded delicious. What arrived before we could finish our first glass of wine was a beautiful dish of long, stringy pasta (similar looking to ramen if I may be so bold) with a neat covering of thick pork ragu sauce. 

If you're a foodie (and I don't claim I am), the first bite tells all. To me, if it makes my eyes close as I savor the flavors in my mouth, this place is getting at least 3 stars. As it turned out, the Tajarin pasta was cooked perfectly - a bit al dente to make it springy and pleasantly chewy. The thick, melt-in-your-mouth pork ragu sauce added a most excellent compliment to the pasta. I had to exercise diligent self-control as to not hork down the plate of pasta and lick the plate, as I was on a date of sorts.

Though a bit on the pricey side (one plate of pasta, a bottle of wine, and dessert) came out to a little over $100, it's definitely worth your splurge fund when you feel like you deserve a heart-warming pasta treat.

perbacco.review:
I've been to Perbacco quite a few times and it has generally been at least very good.  Last night it was better than that.  The food was outstanding.  Given that it's so easy to forget an older standby with so many new places opening, I figured I should up-date.

First off, the service and the welcome at the door were both what you would and should expect from a good restaurant.  But for me, it's always the food.

When a salad of arctic snow peaches, spring porcini mushrooms, spring lettuces, with a stone fruit vinaigrette arrived I was a bit disappointed.  It looked a bit plain with slices of peach and mushroom over greens.  One taste disabused me of my concern as the peaches were sweet, the lettuces perfectly pristine and the mushrooms spot on.  

Tagliatelle with five hour pork sugo was all that pasta should be: perfectly al dente with a sugo that had depth of taste.

Black sea bass was perfectly seared and sweet.  The morel mushrooms that came with the fish were wondrous and the sweet pea passatina beneath the fish was nice as well.

All in all a lovely meal and a reminder not to forget places like Perbacco.

After the briefest moment of silently determining whether they would seat us, we were placed at a table as far away from the other still-lunching customers as possible.  They needn't have worried --- Ruby has been dining at posh establishments since birth, and needed only to have a basket of good bread and butter and a refreshing drink put in front of her to quell the grumpiness (kind of like her grandmum ...  ;-)

While I very much look forward to revisiting Perbacco with a grown-up the next time I'm in the city so that I can indulge in starters, sides, cheeses and wines (six yr olds have tiny tummies and short attention spans), I have to say that what we did eat was plenty memorable:  we shared a plate of trout fillets with wild shrooms and - genius - jerusalem artichokes as our starch. excerpts: Me lovies some Perbacco anytime, any day.
perbacco.author: Jessica C.
perbacco.review:
Me lovies some Perbacco anytime, any day. 

The girls and I love coming here for a special occasion or no occasion at all because it frankly serves any purpose. You have a convention, work day, cultural event, or because you're thirsty, just come by! The northern Italian cuisine is my preferred regional cuisine when it comes to Italian and you won't leave dinner feeling like you just loaded up on carbs before a marathon. Clean, bright and rich flavors on just about every dish. 

Say yes to the roasted octopus and poached veal tongue app, roasted beet salad w gorgonzola bombolino, arugula and strawberry salad, pastas of Agnolotti and Pappardelle with ragu feature of the day and pistachio pana cotta  - when they have it. If they ever have octopus/squid anything for an app - get it!

We love this place mainly because Mark works the bar and we prefer just to eat at the bar as well since we love the ambiance. Mark always provides honest recommendations, excellent service and good company to all. Did I mention there are purse hooks as well? Always a winner. Although this place gets loud, it works in your advantage if you go on an awkward date probably. 

P.S. Come Tuesday, Wed or Fri nights when Mark is working. Yes they take reservations for the tables not the bar and $10 valet out front if you can't find parking.

perbacco.review:
Perbacco was just not for me. Nothing against the restaurant or the food but it just wasn't my kind of food or my kind of atmosphere. What I liked I loved, but to describe what I disliked would require this analogy: To those who hate brussel sprouts, no matter how you cook it, you're not gonna like it. That was how I felt about the dishes I disliked. 

I apologize that the rest of my review of the dishes don't include names; I had a hard time reading the menu as there were so many things I didn't understand on the menu in one line. For those of you who don't come to these type of restaurants often or if you dont' have culinary experience, heed this warning: you will have a hard time reading the menu too. Words like passatina and passato frequent the menu often and I still don't know what they mean. I felt like I needed a dictionary or an italian-english translator to decipher the menu. Just what are they trying to prove -.- Anyways...

Food: We shared appetizers and pasta dishes and there were dishes that stuck out to me. First was this plate of fried food. It had string beans and what I thought was calamari but my boyfriend's dad said it was fried shrimp. It had the right texture and a great taste. 

Second were these pasta noodles with short rib ragu. The noodles honestly tasted like soupless ramen noodles but the lamb ragu had a great strong flavor. 

Third was the gnocchi. It was the first time i've had gnocchi so I"m not sure how they are supposed to taste but it wasn't my cup of tea. It had a mushy texture and a forgettable taste. Anyone want to tell me if gnocchi is supposed to be mushy?

Fourth was the main entree I ordered. Duck breast whatever. It was really juicy but the taste was also forgettable.

Fifth was the hazelnut cookies. Again weird texture. Half the table liked it and half the table didn't. I wasn't that big of a fan. It was as chewy as nougat is which I think is kind of weird for a cookie.

Sixth was the chocolate mousse which I thought was the best part of the night. The chocolate wasn't overly sweet, it was actually pretty perfect for me. Satisfied my sweet tooth but didn't make me reach for the water cup. 

Seventh were the breadsticks. It's actually the first time i've ever had those thin hard crunchy breadsticks, like you see in italian restaurants on television all the time. I thought the flavor was great and it was even better when you dipped it in the sauce. 

Service: GREAT. We were seated promptly at our reservation time. We were asked if we wanted to hang our coats up in the closet. The waiter was very knowledgeable and was able to give me recommendations for drinks and for the main entree. Our waters were constantly refilled and when we got up to go to the bathroom, our napkins were refolded for us. 

Unfortunately, I've had great service and great food at other restaurants so Meh is as good as this review is going to get. 

I would give this restaurant another try because supposedly they have a different menu daily so maybe different dishes will prompt me to give a better review. But I don't think I'll be coming here unless my boyfriend's family wants to give this place another try.

Tina

excerpts: My never-ending quest to find an Italian restaurant comparable to Delfina finally led me to the entrance of Perbacco (read: a very nice gentleman finally offered to take me there) - one of Bauer's 100 best of the bay, and generally known to have a reputation for delicious, sophisticated Italian in the City.
Equipped with 7x7's "Big Eat SF" list (not to mention an appetite big enough to eat the world), and having researched their signature dishes, I was ready to tackle Perbacco head-on.
But, as I always say in these reviews, my bottom line is the food, and unfortunately the word that comes to mind when I think of Perbacco's menu is "inconsistent."
I feel that one of the pitfalls of offering such an extensive menu is that some dishes are simply not going to be at the same level as others.
Such was the case at Perbacco; while their specialties certainly deserved their rave reviews, the rest of our meal left me wanting more.
perbacco.author: Kelsey E.
perbacco.review:
My never-ending quest to find an Italian restaurant comparable to Delfina finally led me to the entrance of Perbacco (read: a very nice gentleman finally offered to take me there) - one of Bauer's 100 best of the bay, and generally known to have a reputation for delicious, sophisticated Italian in the City. Equipped with 7x7's "Big Eat SF" list (not to mention an appetite big enough to eat the world), and having researched their signature dishes, I was ready to tackle Perbacco head-on. 

I'm not going to lie, I definitely went into the night with certain expectations of how everything should play out. And, in terms of atmosphere, those expectations were filled as soon as I walked in the door. The lively, modern, refined atmosphere instantly appealed to my "city chic" preferences. And, the open kitchen not only let me catch a glimpse of what was going on behind the scenes, but let me flirt with the chefs (with my eyes of course!) on my way down to the restrooms. Unfortunately, I don't think they noticed...

The service was on point as well - there when we needed it, helpful in answering our numerous questions, friendly, even complete with a sommelier to help us find our way through their extensive list. No complaints.

But, as I always say in these reviews, my bottom line is the food, and unfortunately the word that comes to mind when I think of Perbacco's menu is "inconsistent."  I feel that one of the pitfalls of offering such an extensive menu is that some dishes are simply not going to be at the same level as others. Such was the case at Perbacco; while their specialties certainly deserved their rave reviews, the rest of our meal left me wanting more. 

**Exception: the bread sticks were buttery, perfectly crispy, and downright dangerous. Be warned that they serve bread sticks AND bread, so it's easy to fill up before the main course has even arrived!

As for appetizers, the SALUMI MISTI offered a variety of meat selections in sizable portions, however, it wasn't mind-blowing. Let's not kid ourselves here - it's sliced meat on a plate. Sure it's delicious, but it doesn't take a premier restaurant to serve it (and, I'm a bit spoiled by having Lucca down the street from my house). And, while the VEAL TRIPE was perfectly cooked, the composition of the dish was a bit uninspired and lacked seasoning. 

Since, as I said, I was ready to eat the world, we tackled 3 pastas - the AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN, the TAJARIN, and the RABATON. There was nothing especially memorable about the latter 2 - both were executed well, but I wasn't impressed by the flavors. When I eat ricotta gnocchi, I want to think I'm eating a cloud, and the Rabaton fell short of cloudliness. However, the Agnolotti (a dish they are known for) was everything I could've wanted and more. As soon as we dove into that dish, our lively conversation came to a dead silence - there was no room for words in the face of that rich, complex flavor. This was one of the top 5 pasta dishes I've had in the City, and if I was ever to go back, would be the only thing I'd need to order to feel completely satisfied. 

With so many choices on the menu, I'm sure everyone can find something that makes their heart sing. However, for me, I want any and every selection I make to inspire me to jump on a table and start declaring my enduring love (don't worry, it's only happened 2-3 times). While my overall experience was solid, my quest to find sensational Italian food in San Francisco must continue.

excerpts: Not to be confused by the Sanrio character Pochacco (for all the little asian girls out there), Perbacco is one of my new favorite restaurants just because how can you reject something that loves you so much?
perbacco.author: Jen Y.
perbacco.review:
Our office Christmas party was off the meat rack. Let me tell you why.

My boss had this crazy idea to do our annual White Elephant exchange at the restaurant. I was hesitant because that game can get really loud; not to mention potentially lasting for several hours. Our entire night from beginning to end was amazing starting with the staff who were all super accommodating with everything from where to put our unopened presents to discarding our leftover wrapping paper to extra bags for take-home gifts. Rock stars they are -- totally on the ball making sure we were comfortable and taken care of the entire time. 

I'm kinda upset about something though. Nobody warned me that I would be fist-pumping during my meal. It started out a slow fist-pump but gradually sped up with each dish put in front of my face. 

Not to be confused by the Sanrio character Pochacco (for all the little asian girls out there), Perbacco is one of my new favorite restaurants just because how can you reject something that loves you so much? 

And trust me, I'm totally feelin' the love...

excerpts: Came to Perbacco for lunch with a few of my co-workers.
Much more of a fan of Perbacco than its sister restaurant, Barbacco.
The set up is interesting.
When you walk in, the restaurant looks somewhat small, but it opens out into a large dining room in the back.
I like the decor...pretty simple and clean.
The homemade breadsticks with pesto are a delicious little snack while you're waiting to order.
I ordered the roasted chicken with polenta, and it was very good.
It had a lot of mushrooms in it (a little too many for my taste), which is why I wouldn't say it's fantastic.
Next time, I'll order it without the mushrooms.
The service was great!
I would look away for two seconds and turn around and my iced tea would be refilled.
The food literally came out in five to ten minutes.
They were really on top of their game!

excerpts: I had been to Perbacco a couple of years ago for lunch and wasn't terribly impressed.

I'm so pleased that Perbacco is right around the corner from my work.
This is definitely going to be my go-to spot for special occasion lunches in the future.
perbacco.author: Julia N.
perbacco.review:
I had been to Perbacco a couple of years ago for lunch and wasn't terribly impressed. It wasn't that it was horrible, it just wasn't memorable enough at the time for me to really care enough to go again. 

As time passed and all my friends and coworkers raved about Perbacco time and time again, I decided it was time to give it another go. I am SO glad that I went back again because my experience was simply lovely. 

The brussel sprouts were fantastic; the beets were scrumptious and the butternut squash ravioli's were the probably the best I've had. They were drizzled with a butter sage sauce and the squash was so creamy. I would go back JUST for that dish. 

Since it was my mother's birthday we decided it a dessert was definitely in order. The olive oil chocolate cake/mousse, even though I was slightly skeptical (olive oil?), was unbelievably good. We split one but quite honestly I wanted the whole damn thing to myself! 

I'm so pleased that Perbacco is right around the corner from my work. This is definitely going to be my go-to spot for special occasion lunches in the future.

excerpts: Located conveniently 5 minutes away from my work, Perbacco surpassed my really high expectations.
Perbacco, you've earned a special place in my stomach.
perbacco.author: Jeff N.
perbacco.review:
This place is amazing.  Rounding out to one of the best lunches I've ever had, my experience consisted of 3 appetizers, a pasta main dish, and cafe latte.  

Located conveniently 5 minutes away from my work, Perbacco surpassed my really high expectations.  With classy, yet modern decor inside, and hip, knowledgeable, yet, not pretentious wait staff, I can see this being one of my favorite Italian spots to go to.

Starting off with a slow roasted veal carpaccio in a lemon/tuna sauce, I was impressed right off the bat.  Not being a huge fan of veal or capers in general, I was pleasantly surprised by how tender and flavorful (without the typical vealish gamey taste) this dish was and how well it went with the sauce.

Fried rock shrimp was the next order of business, where there wasn't too much batter, or too little shrimp with each bite.  This also came in a lemon sauce (aioli) as well as some other fried bits.  Definitely couldn't complain about this dish.

The seared squid on a bed of arugula was the last appetizer that was demolished.  I especially enjoyed how the arugula nor the salted squid overpowered the other.  There was a very delicate balance in this dish that made it juuuuuuust right.

For my main, I had the langaroli with braised short rib.  This was a decision I had my server make for me when deciding between this, the tagliatelle and the parpadelle (all of which I'm convinced are amazing).  She mentioned that it was new on the menu and that it was a good choice, so I went with it.  In the end, who can really complain about pasta filled with braised short rib.  There were some bites that may have bordered on being too salty, but the succulence of the short rib brought it all back.  Of course, the pasta (smaller ravioli like) was perfectly al dente, and the portion was just right....assuming there is a correct portion after eating 3 appetizers.

To top it off, I had to deny the creme fraiche panna cotta and settle for a latte, as I still needed to be functional at work.  And, to one up themselves again, the latte came with extra foam and milk if we desired.  WHO DOES THIS?!

Perbacco, you've earned a special place in my stomach.

excerpts: Perbacco's breadsticks are oh so addictive.
It's crunchy and greasy, and would definitely cause a dent in your strict diet.
But who cares.
perbacco.author: Ange L.
perbacco.review:
The breadsticks and salumi misti plate were enough to give this place five deserving stars.

But the goodness doesn't stop there.  The posh sister to Barbacco next door (http://www.yelp.com/biz/barbacco-san-francisco#hrid:KQWnDd9VEnGb6QZQhbcyKw), it was definitely less cacophonous, more refined, less family-style small plates, more white tablecloth and fine china.  

Both are great, in their own way. 

Perbacco's breadsticks are oh so addictive.  It's crunchy and greasy, and would definitely cause a dent in your strict diet.  But who cares.  Goes really well with everything on the salumi misti plate, from the cured pancetta, cheese and lardo.  

For the entree I had the pork shoulder, slow roasted and tender.  The serving was generous and, I'm no wine connoisseur but the server's recommendation of a glass of 2010 Kerner (GENEROUS pour!) was probably the best that I could've asked for, as a pairing. 

Definitely on the list as my go-to Italian.

excerpts: Perbacco does not have any beers on tap, unfortunately.
perbacco.author: Megan L.
perbacco.review:
The boyfriend was working in SF for the week and I had class at the UCB Extension building near the Embarcadero BART. We decided to have a dinner date on a Wednesday before I headed to my 6:30pm class and I chose this place for its proximity to the BART station. We planned to meet at 5; I arrived at 4:45pm. I was told by the hostess that they did not start dinner seating until 5:30. The hostess politely inquired if I were looking for Barbacco, which, for its convincingly similar name, must be a frequent source of mix-ups. I was not; and decided to grab a bar table in the corner near the front window to wait for my bf to arrive. It was pretty empty around 5pm but I am glad I snagged that table when I did, because the FiDi after-work crowd filtered in soon after. The bf arrived at 5:15; by 5:30, the entire bar area was crowded to the point of an almost-uncomfortable capacity. 

We asked for menus so that we could choose our main dishes and put in our orders so that we could start our dinners as soon as possible. The menus for the night had not even finished printing yet, but our waitress was kind enough to bring them over as soon as they were ready, around 5:25. We ordered our mains and decided to start with the salumi plate. The salumi plate was all that it is hyped up to be in these reviews and more - the fatty selections were incredibly flavorful and decadent. 

I had the duck breast and the bf had the rabbit. These were both presented on our plates in two distinct preparations, which was refreshing as not only did it showcase the chef's abilities, but also we were able to experience our duck and rabbit in more than one way each. This was a refreshing take, as it was more interesting to my palate to be able to taste my duck in different textures and tastes that were overall complementary to each other. 

The wine list is extensive and solid. I was pleased to discover a sizeable selection of rieslings. I had a very good $12 glass of riesling, but the name of it escapes me. My bf had a bottled anchor steam. Perbacco does not have any beers on tap, unfortunately. 

Our impromptu dinner date meal cost us about $90 before tip. Definitely not a place to frequent on a regular basis, but definitely nice for an after-work pick-me-up or a celebration once in awhile.

Pros:
-Very solid and satisfying Italian main dishes 
-Beyond decadent salumi plate
-Extensive wine list
-Helpful and attentive waitress (despite the unyielding crowd)
-Proximity to Embarcadero BART

Cons:
-Very, very loud - the acoustics in the restaurant are not suited for comfortable across-the-table talking (not suitable for a first date, for sure!)
-The elbowing FiDi after-work crowd 
-Not being able to get dinner seating until 5:30 (I would appreciate being able to sit by 5pm for dinner)

perbacco.author: Andrea L.
perbacco.review:
Dining at Perbacco was in the pipeline since Piccolina P.  highly recommended it to me only a couple of weeks ago. What most interested me in this establishment is that they serve typical dishes from Piemonte  (my home region in Italy) but with a Californian touch.  Pointless to say that I had great expectations (and some fears too).

As a great start, we got homemade grissini with a typical flavourful parsley-based green dip (Bagna Verde) that Piemontesi normally use as sauce for veal tongue or boiled veal meat.

The menu itself is rather interesting: I particularly like the possibility of combining two or three different pasta dishes (I wish more Italian restaurants offered such a possibility, since I often have hard times in deciding which promising homemade pasta to pick).  No chance I could have missed this heavenly possibility. After a good looking and flavourful appetizer with raw yellowtail, shaved porcini and celery, our main choice fell upon the following pasta trio:

1- herb Maltagliati with lamb ragu', peas, ricotta di pecora and mint: excellent pasta, overkilling sauce with too much on it. I honestly find ricotta and lamb (despite its nicely melting-in-mouth texture, by the way) a rather weird combination, but I liked the mint (exactly the opposite as my gf ...);

2-agnolotti al coniglio with vermouth based sauce and fruit mustard:
those agnolotti were a real pasta masterpiece and the sauce was original, even though the reduction didn't fully kill the alcoholic taste. Forgivable sin, though, that didn't affect too much the marvellous resulting dish.

 3- tajarin (typical Piedmontese taglierini) with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini: if you wonder  why letting the sugo cook for 5 hours, this dish gives you a convincing answer. What a fantastic taste! Again, another delicious pasta.

Desserts were good (but not exceptional) and they came in huge portions:  
1- buttermilk panna cotta with a lemonish taste, raspberries and a touch of fruity granita;
2- ricotta mousse, a lemonish cake (I can't recall the name) and Lambrusco marinated strawberries. 

Good wines and beers (I got a Piedmontese Menabrea) too.

Perbacco offers a seriously good deal considering both quality and quantity (the real surprise, in my opinion) for the price you pay.  Thanks Piccolina P.: this place really deserves a visit (or two or three ...).  

Pasta lovers, here you can find "pane per i vostri denti" (literally: "bread for your teeth").

4.5 stars.

perbacco.author: Regina C.
perbacco.review:
first, i want to say that this place is perfect for dinner right before heading to the Punchline for a comedy show. it's only about a block or so away. so Guys, (nudge, nudge) make a reservation for Perbacco and then get tickets for some stand-up comedy and you've got yourself a pretty damn good date. you are so very welcome for planning out your next courtship! 

as a chinese, it's always a plus when you find yourself with free things. at Perbacco you not only get the standard bread with dinner, but you also get breadsticks. already winning, Perbacco! haha. 

we got the papardelle with short rib ragu which was as good as a well made fresh pasta could be. nothing stand out, but definitely had an appreciated simplicity. we also had the short rib entree and the scallop entree. both were cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor. 

definitely a place to return to.

excerpts: And then my firm had this year's holiday party at Perbacco.
The choices were steak, chicken, or butternut squach ravioli.
I should have gotten the ravioli.
I had chicken, and it was pretty well cooked but a piece of grilled chicken is still a piece of grilled chicken.
Nothing too fancy.
The steak was cooked rare.
Too bloody for many people to be able to enjoy.
perbacco.author: Su K.
perbacco.review:
Maybe I haven't had the right dish here yet. I've been here twice and both times I was disappointed. 

I came here for lunch with a couple of friends. The food was acceptable, but my plate of fish looked very lonely. It didn't come with friends of veggies or even sauce. It was just a lone cooked whole fish. I don't know about you, but I can't eat just fish. Maybe it's because I'm Asian, I need my starch and veggies. Maybe I was expected to order them seperately? $23 seems a lot for a plate of lone piece of meat.

And then my firm had this year's holiday party at Perbacco. The choices were steak, chicken, or butternut squach ravioli. I should have gotten the ravioli. I had chicken, and it was pretty well cooked but a piece of grilled chicken is still a piece of grilled chicken. Nothing too fancy. The steak was cooked rare. Too bloody for many people to be able to enjoy. People who got ravioli seemed to enjoy their dish the most. 

The dessert was apple pie - like thing with a dollop of cream. It was mediocre at best.

Maybe I should give it a third chance?

excerpts: We came here a month ago, and Perbacco was a last minute decision after a girls' night out turned into date night.
The only thing I would say about Perbacco was that it can get loud at times and it's hard to have a conversation when the tables are so close together.
Other than that, the food was delicious.
I'd come back any night for dinner.
perbacco.author: Amy N.
perbacco.review:
I love the urban feel of this restaurant. We came here a month ago, and Perbacco was a last minute decision after a girls' night out turned into date night. It was totally worth the change in plans. 

We ordered the dishes recommended by other Yelpers - the salumi misti, the Tajarin, three sides of fingerling potatoes with rosemary and garlic, brown butter brussel sprouts and broccoli di cicco. That was way too many dishes for two people, but nonetheless delicious. The Tajarin dish was my favorite. It's hand cut tagliatelle pasta with 5-hour pork sugo and porcini mushroms. YUM. I wiped out everything. 

The dish pacing was really good, and we didn't feel rushed at all. The only thing I would say about Perbacco was that it can get loud at times and it's hard to have a conversation when the tables are so close together. Other than that, the food was delicious. I'd come back any night for dinner.

perbacco.review: Enjoyed the ambiance. Good service...great cocktails & local wines...ok food. Was excited about the fresh pastas but, wasn't blown away...You have to try the Burnt Caramel, Salted Gelato though. Things were a under-seasoned (my pasta & main course). Overall, my food experience at Perbacco was ok...nothing to write home about. In my opinion, a bit overpriced for food that was just ok.

excerpts: Lucky us, we strolled through the doors of Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Brittney G.
perbacco.review:
It was my birthday. Reservations made at another place fell through, so we were on a hunt for something in a pinch. Lucky us, we strolled through the doors of Perbacco. 

It was 7 p.m. The host told us they were booked solid. Just as we were about to ask how long we'd wait, a man came over and looked at the host board. He clicked his tongue. "We can seat you right now," he said, and whisked us off.

Happy birthday to me!

As we walked to our cute table for two in the dining room, we walked past the slick and sexy bar and a GIANT flower arrangement near a veritable sea of cheese selections. Oh, yes.

The service was impeccable. The wine menu was intimidating.

Overall, a wonderful experience, though I have to say for such stellar service at the door, luminous ambiance and an attentive waitress, I expected the food to blow me away. Don't get me wrong it was terrific, but it didn't dazzle me the way the rest of the experience did.

All told, this was a fantastic birthday spot. Happy to have found it.

What I really enjoy about Perbacco is the use of local, fresh, in-season ingredients; the constantly changing menu selections;
Next up: Perbacco's new younger sibling, Barbacco.
perbacco.author: Sarah S.
perbacco.review:
I work directly across the street from Perbacco, so I've had many occasions to dine, lunch, and happy hour at this fine restaurant.  

Yes, it's a noisy space.  So if you don't do noisy, don't do Perbacco.  My hearing is still 100%, so this does not bother me.  Also, the din is considerably less during the lunch hour, when the FiDi brass haven't taken over the bar (yet).

What I really enjoy about Perbacco is the use of local, fresh, in-season ingredients; the constantly changing menu selections; the fact that I can get dishes with rabbit in them; the class-A service; and the lovely presentation.  

Definitely order some of the salumi as an appetizer; you will not regret this!  

Next up: Perbacco's new younger sibling, Barbacco.

excerpts: I admit, I was a little turned off when I first entered Perbacco.
We were early for our reservation and the hostess at the front was quite rude to us.
There was no offer for a drink or a seat at the bar - which was empty.
If it hadn't been for the rave reviews, and the fact that I've been seeking an authentic italian restaurant in the area, we would have ended up at Tadich next door.
The ambiance was a little stuffy, but the food definitely made up for it.
We tried a variety of pastas, all of which were outstanding.
For our main dishes, we paired the risotto with the short ribs.
The short ribs were so tender, I could cut it with a spoon.
They also had us in and out just in time to make it to our show.

So, I'm happy to report that Perbacco still rates 5 stars for both food along with friendly and efficient service.
I look forward to my next dinner here.
perbacco.author: IQuack D.
perbacco.review:
My first dinner here was when my good friend took me here for my birthday last September. We both decided that we'd like to return, so it was my turn to host,  and both the food and service remain top quality.

It's a waste of time to describe every item because everything prepared here seems to be outstanding. Be sure to share a pasta item because the pastas are superb with intense flavors in reduced sauces that you're unlikely to make at home. 

We both had the sea bass main course which was excellent and served on greens with turnips and mushrooms and.........well, try it and you'll agree that the selection of ingredients couldn't be better.

We had an Italian red wine which was very smooth and perfect with fish or meat.

Perbacco isn't for cheap eats--you get what you pay for in this world. But the money you spend here is for the best food of its kind. 

So, I'm happy to report that Perbacco still rates 5 stars for both food along with friendly and efficient service. I look forward to my next dinner here.

excerpts: Perbacco does it with aplomb!
so ... we went next door to Perbacco (actually to Barbacco, it's sister restaurant, but left because Barbacco did not have a full bar
and I REALLY wanted a martini).
Perbacco is an upscale Italian restaurant.
perbacco.author: Mark P.
perbacco.review:
Being right next to the Tadich Grill (a San Francisco  landmark), takes guts.  You have to be sure of your restaurant, because you are competing with one of the fine all time restaurants in this restaurant crazy city.  Perbacco does it with aplomb!

So we were going to go to Tadich, but the wait was 45 minutes and we were hungry, so ... we went next door to Perbacco (actually to Barbacco, it's sister restaurant, but left because Barbacco did not have a full bar and I REALLY wanted a martini). Perbacco is an upscale Italian restaurant. We were a party of four and we had the full restaurant experience.

I had the raviolo (one big one) with an egg yolk in the center and an amazing pappardelle with braised short ribs.  Both were very well prepared and quite delicious (warning, consuming undercooked egg yolk can be hazardous to your health, but ... oh ... so ... delicious too).

The bartenders know how to make a classic martini too. Thank you.

And the service was exceptional, as they went out of their way to take care of us (and I can be a handful).  Patient, courteous, and very customer friendly with excellent food.  What more could you ask for.

excerpts: If you don't mind shelling out the money, give Perbacco a try!
perbacco.author: Angela L.
perbacco.review:
What a great place! I came here recently to celebrate the end of a project with a principal. It is definitely the place to go in FiDi for a power lunch as I kept seeing droves of men in blazers come in. The atmosphere definitely felt power-lunchy, which is appropriate for FiDi. 

We started with the pan-seared octopus, then had the pappardelle with short ribs, then ended with the salted caramel gelato.  I was afraid I wouldn't like the octopus, but it was actually really delicious. It was not too fishy and the olives were a perfect compliment to the octopus flavor. The pappardelle noodles were obviously freshly made and the short rib meat basically melted in my mouth. The salted caramel gelato was admittedly not as good as bi-rite, but still a good end to the meal. The cookies that came with the ice cream were also really good. 

In total, the meal was around $100; which is admittedly on the expensive side for lunch. Perhaps, it would be better to come here for dinner. There were intimate booths that I could be really conducive to a date. If you don't mind shelling out the money, give Perbacco a try!

excerpts: I think Perbacco is a very good restaurant, the service is always attentive, the atmosphere is very nice, the menu is interesting....
I would have given it a 5-star
if it wasn't that the dishes are a little too heavy.
Don't get me wrong
: I love Italian food
and I know gnocchi, pasta,

risotto aren't light, but I think here it is particularly heavy maybe due to too much butter or cream in the recipes... possibly combined with the fact that they serve a delicious slice of focaccia, drenched in olive oil, which pretty much fills you up before you even get your meal.
I never heard of anybody not liking their food at Perbacco, but everybody always feels very bloated when leaving.
Some people love this, others don't and would prefer a more balanced menu.
perbacco.author: OcchiDiGatto S.
perbacco.review:
I think Perbacco is a very good restaurant, the service is always attentive, the atmosphere is very nice, the menu is interesting.... I would have given it a 5-star if it wasn't that the dishes are a little too heavy. Don't get me wrong: I love Italian food and I know gnocchi, pasta, risotto aren't light, but I think here it is particularly heavy maybe due to too much butter or cream in the recipes... possibly combined with the fact that they serve a delicious slice of focaccia, drenched in olive oil, which pretty much fills you up before you even get your meal. Each dish is unique and full of flavor, but very rich. 

I never heard of anybody not liking their food at Perbacco, but everybody always feels very bloated when leaving. Some people love this, others don't and would prefer a more balanced menu. Thus, I can only give it a 4 star. 

PS: I would recommend the agnolotti with rabbit, and most of the pasta or gnocchi dishes, but today I had the Risotto with Figs, Prosciutto and Burrata and, while the first bite was amazing, by the second bite I was overwhelmed with too much sweetness and too much richness.... I wish it were a little more delicate.

FOOD: very good
SERVICE: very good and attentive
ATMOPSHERE: modern, happening, loud especially at lunch, busy bar at entrance, white tablecloths.
VALUE: good
BEST FOR: business lunch or dinner; birthday/occasion celebration; date; dinner with friends; long lunch with friends.

excerpts: This is almost as good as the homemade pasta I ate in Sicily...so the bar is high and Perbacco has met it.
perbacco.author: Kathleen E.
perbacco.review:
Yummy!!
This place is amazing. I had the pappardelle w/ short rib ragu. This was by far one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had. I could have eaten this all day and everyday.
This is almost as good as the homemade pasta I ate in Sicily...so the bar is high and Perbacco has met it.

excerpts: While I thought I was making a reservation at BARBacco where I'd dined a few months back, I was pleasantly surprised when I arrived at PERBacco and realized my mistake and that I would be dining at the more established big sister restaurant.
perbacco.author: Sean M.
perbacco.review:
Checking in at the end of our evening dining at this Italian restaurant in the Financial District I yelped, "OMFG! Perfect service, perfect meals to share, and perfect company to enjoy this A+ dining experience!"  I'd be hard pressed to recall a better evening of dining out than what I experienced last night, which was a tie with Zuni Cafe back in the spring so I guess my two favorite restaurants just now happen to be in San Francisco.

Working out here in the Bay Area as frequently as I have been of late I seem to go through fits and starts.  Some trips I'm all about going back to the places I've tried and liked, but some trips are like the last two weeks when every new experience seems to unfold some hidden gem that I'm just discovering for the first time.  Writing this just now I can't gush enough about how much I love this city so forgive me if you detect more than a whiff of hyperbole.

Meeting up with a former work colleague whom I've not seen in about six years and her beau, it was on me to choose the restaurant since she'd only moved to town (from New York City) just two weeks ago.  Needless to say she wanted something on par with what she'd grown accustomed to in New York.  While I thought I was making a reservation at BARBacco where I'd dined a few months back, I was pleasantly surprised when I arrived at PERBacco and realized my mistake and that I would be dining at the more established big sister restaurant.

First the service: I wish I'd gotten my waiter's name so I could rave about him personally.  As happened at Zuni Cafe, he let us take our time as we were so busy talking we'd barely perused the menu after ordering a couple of drinks.  Since we were all three newcomers he took great pride in explaining the menu and insisting that everything on the menu is special when one of us asked if there were any specials.  Indeed he was right as every dish on the menu had allure, especially the homemade pastas and house cured charcuterie.  When we noticed that we could order two or three pastas to share for the table, he recommended we get two salads to start, two pastas, and two entrees.  

We had no trouble choosing the two salads, one was roasted beets on a testa (head cheese?) remoulade and the other roasted figs with burrata, arugula and a balsamic glaze. The pastas all looked great and I might have wanted a filled ravioli or gnocchi but we had the papardelle with beef ribs and the the molto Italiano strand pasta with pesto and crushed cherry tomatoes.  Given that all of the pastas are made on the premises I'm sure there was no going wrong. And rather than serving the the dish family style, we were each given a plate with a portion of each.  The papardelle was certainly my favorite and I guess I had a taste for beef that night because we also ordered the beef rib straccato.  No one is a bigger fan of red meat braised in wine than yours truly.  I love making it at home and I love eating it when I go out.  This version came not just with a bread crumb crust but a bone marrow bread crumb crust.  Perfecto!

For the second entree we were to share, our waiter pulled a delightful trick I've never experienced at another restaurant before.  Since we couldn't decide among the salmon, the duck or the rabbit, he said let me surprise you. We were all somewhat taken aback by the proposition, but of course he promised that they were each excellent.  That we went along with his suggestion is testament to his overall competence as a waiter and how deftly he orchestrated a gratifying experience.  And of course he chose a bottle of Italian red close to the flavor profile of our consensus wine of pinot noir that would have gone with any of the three but again seemed extra special because he chose it for us.  I'm not sure how he came to decide on the duck for us, but I couldn't have been more pleased even though I was hoping for the rabbit.  What was especially delicious was the the accompaniment of roasted apples and brussel sprouts that made for such a succulent complement to the duck.

It's rare that service and meal are so perfectly combined in one evening.  Part of the magic was of course catching up with an old friend in a setting new to both of us. But our waiter took the pulse of our table and just made sure we'd have a wonderful evening.  I only wish I could give more than 5 stars for this spectacular night!

excerpts: I would consider Perbacco your typical FiDi business lunch or fancy dinner spot.
We chose Perbacco because the menu was scrumptious!
What we hadn't realized was that Perbacco is a really nice restaurant with fancy, well-heeled patrons, and beautiful decor.
I give Perbacco 5 stars because it serves delicious food without any pretension.
I am absolutely returning to Perbacco when I'm feeling in the mood for a beautiful sit-down dinner with excellent service and delectable food.
perbacco.author: Kira K.
perbacco.review:
I would consider Perbacco your typical FiDi business lunch or fancy dinner spot.  I would not normally consider it as a place where you'd have a casual dinner date with your sisters and your new baby niece...

My sisters, one of whom had a baby very recently, and I wanted to get together for a nice dinner.  We chose Perbacco because the menu was scrumptious!  What we hadn't realized was that Perbacco is a really nice restaurant with fancy, well-heeled patrons, and beautiful decor.  I felt a little embarassed trying to fit my 3.5-month old niece at our table, because the high chair wouldn't work with her car-seat, but the host and the servers were really accomodating and we managed to make the baby comfortable in a regular chair.

Not a single person stared at us in horror, which was really surprising, even when my sister started to breastfeed!  I give Perbacco 5 stars because it serves delicious food without any pretension.

The food was beautifully plated, and just plain yummy.  We had:
- salumi 'nduja platter (with soft, spreadable salumi, which was different but still delicious) - $8
- roasted beets and arugula salad - $10
- roasted octopus salad - $12
- burrata chese/heirloom tomato/arugula salad - $11
- tajarin (handcut tagliatelle and pork sugo) - $16
- pappardelle with short rib ragu - $17
- brown butter cake for dessert, and a complimentary Italian chocolate plate
*Total dinner tab plus a Chimay was just under $100 not including tip.  How much more reasonable can you get?!?

Everything we had was simply delicious, and I would order it all again, though I'll likely venture to other items on the menu because there are so many!  The burrata cheese app was especially noteworthy, as it just melts in your mouth.  I also love how our server automatically separated the pasta onto three dishes so we didn't have to divvy up the portions ourselves.  I really would consider this a fabulous value for your money, as we all left stuffed and incredibly happy.

I am absolutely returning to Perbacco when I'm feeling in the mood for a beautiful sit-down dinner with excellent service and delectable food.

excerpts: EUREKA.. Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Kurt P.
perbacco.review:
Wife and I crawling the private galleries on Geary and we gets the rumblies. ( I dunno, Irving Penn does that to me).
Now what to do? Surrounded by a million choices. Mina's new place?Benu? Wexler's? Rose Pistola? cab up to Zuni? . We were hoplessly perplexed n couldn't decide which direction to go.

BOOM! we suddenly decide Italian.

hmm... Italian in San Francisco. Didn't narrow things much.

When wifey beams me and says, "hey whattabout that place you were telling me about  down financial district way. bocco, bococo, perboco."

EUREKA.. Perbacco! 
Radiologist pal o' mine raves about the place.

We arrive early and sit at the bar. 
Beautiful place. Warm lighting, exposed brick, comfortable stools.
All good after a long walk 'cross town.

I order a cocktail (don remember what it was but damm good) my wife an Alto Adige Pinot Bianco...fabulous.

we spend the next 2 hours sipping, munching, laughing with some of the best food and wine we've had in months. 

Didn't make many mental notes so....I must return to see what else they conjure.
Don't miss an opportunity to check 'em out.

Excellent service, superb wine list, fabulous food.

excerpts: I had a very random encounter with Perbacco on St. Patty's day.
We were at the block party and I wasn't about to spend 30 minutes standing in line to use a porta-potty.
Being somewhat familiar with the area I knew there were a handful of restaurants in the area.
That is how we stumbled into Perbacco.
One thing led to another and we found ourselves with some new St Patty's plans, dinner at Perbacco.
The food was great, it had a cozy and sophisticated vibe and the people sitting at the bar were friendly and social.
Overall, it ended up being a great night!

After taking care of business we decided to sit down and have a drink. The bartender was nice and whipped up some good Manhattans and we were content. excerpts: That said, the disappointment over the main courses was such that I couldn't give Perbacco more than a couple of stars...so many better options I would rather visit as opposed to giving this another try. :-(
perbacco.author: J C.
perbacco.review:
I have to admit, I was sincerely disappointed.

I had heard such great things about this place and was excited to meet a friend for dinner here. The short rib pasta came highly recommended so I was excited to try.

I started with the roasted beet salad and it was delicious. Mandarin oranges were a nice touch to the overly sweet red beets. My friend's salad of Fall fruits looked something like an ambrosia salad. She seemed to like it though.

We ordered the short rib pasta, noting that they had changed the menu from pappardelle to langaroli (fancy name for ravioli). I didn't realize that would have such a huge impact. The photos on Yelp of the Papardelle showed what appears to be shredded short ribs but when they switched to ravioli they essentially pureed it with mushrooms. The result was a filling that reminded us of wet cat food. It really wasn't very good.

For the desserts, we had the toffee cake and the chocolate pudding. Both were great, a very nice way to forget about our horrible entrees.

Our server was very nice and even removed one of our desserts after accidentally forgetting to put in the order. I also loved the casual atmosphere.

That said, the disappointment over the main courses was such that I couldn't give Perbacco more than a couple of stars...so many better options I would rather visit as opposed to giving this another try. :-(

excerpts: We went to Perbacco for lunch and the place was packed.
I would say that the noise level was high and that the service was slow.
perbacco.author: Sailing A.
perbacco.review:
We went to Perbacco for lunch and the place was packed. I would say that the noise level was high and that the service was slow.  The waiter/busboy were very nice but the kitchen was slow in turning out the dishes.

Other than that, the food was superb.  We had the focaccia with the pesto paste while waiting for our appetizer and it was very good.  The grissini were nothing special and the focaccia could have used a little less oil but otherwise everything was fine.

And, did I mention it is so nice to be eating in a restaurant with a white tablecloth instead of just on a table?

The appetizer was awesome, vitello tonnato.  It can be a heavy dish but the chef put the sauce on the side so you could add or substract as much as you needed. I think he even put some anchovies in the sauce to give it a kick and it was a great idea, in my opinion.

We had the duck risotto, excellent, and the taglierini with pork ragu.  The pasta was so fresh that you could smell its freshness as soon as the plate touched the table.  It seemed homemade.  The sauce was on top of it and really complemented the fine, delicate pasta.

We did not try dessert, although we were tempted by the panna cotta, and did not try the wine but we are sure, they were excellent.

We will be back!

excerpts: So, the online dictionary tells me that perbacco means "wow!"

Good food, good ambience, good service...

Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Linda C.
perbacco.review:
So, the online dictionary tells me that perbacco means "wow!" 

Was pretty impressed by this place.  Mind you, this comes from someone who doesn't think much of Italian food (usually prefer a good dumpling to ravioli).

The place is small-ish but gives off a good vibe.  Tall ceilings give it a roomy feel.  Tables are close enough to not feel impersonal, and there's just enough noise to give you an excuse to lean in and get closer to your dinner companion.  There were a lot of suits around, which made it a little stuffy looking, but overall quite a nice ambience.

We were in their upstairs private dining room.  It's a small space surrounded by windows from which one can watch the hustle and bustle of the ground floor. 

                                                                                 ****** Food ******

Amazing:
- Rabbit Agnolotti with Truffled Sugo D'arrosto: these were GOOD.  They're little tiny pillows of pasta stuffed with a very good filling and a delicious sauce.  Comes in a small or large plate.  Get the large - it's not that big and everyone will want to taste some.
- Mousse dessert: WOW.  I don't usually like mousse, but this thing has great presentation and then an unbelievably airy texture.  Definitely the dessert to get!  

Solid:
- Seared Local Sea Bass: Was a little firmer than expected, but the combination of corn with some sort of a lemon-y sauce and asparagus was well done.
- Goat cheese and mint ravioli: this was interesting.  Both the mint and goat cheese are subtle, so it actual tastes better than it sounds.
- Fig-leaf scented panna cotta: Was decent as far as panna cotta goes.  Hard to appreciate it after tasting the mousse (see above).

Other: Pappardelle, Prather Ranch Sirloin Steak, Roasted Octopus were all supposedly decent.  Monkfish was the miss of the evening.

                                                                               ************************

Overall? Good food, good ambience, good service...

Perbacco!

excerpts: Like many other Yelpers, I was lured to Perbacco by the siren song of its salumi plate.
Our waitress gave a great wine recommendation (Perbacco has a HUGE selection of Italian wines)  and weighed in on their many popular entrees and appetizers.
Perbacco hand-makes all of their cured meats, and I've honestly never tried anything like some of the pates and sausages that emerged with our plate.
perbacco.author: Amanda F.
perbacco.review:
Like many other Yelpers, I was lured to Perbacco by the siren song of its salumi plate. I can now rest easy with the knowledge that, according to 7x7 magazine, I only need to try 94 more dishes before laying claims to a life fully lived. 

The decor is modern and somewhat understated, although the tables are a little too close together, and I definitely felt like the diners either side of us were privy to a little too much information. The wait staff were very attentive and knowledgeable of the menu - which was absolutely ENORMOUS. Our waitress gave a great wine recommendation (Perbacco has a HUGE selection of Italian wines)  and weighed in on their many popular entrees and appetizers.

I, however, ignored most of those recommendations and decided to go freestyle. We started with the salumi plate, obviously, which was pretty incredible. Perbacco hand-makes all of their cured meats, and I've honestly never tried anything like some of the pates and sausages that emerged with our plate. Top marks, and if I'd been smart about things, I would have left it at that.

My appetizer was a watermelon salad with basic and queso fresco - which was tasy, but by no means extraordinary. I was HUGELY disappointed by my appetizer of home-made gnocchi with Early Girl tomatoes and cheese - the potato was incredibly dense and the tomatoes seemed a little too sweet and lacking in flavor - enormous bummer, because simple gnocchi/tomato dishes are my absolute fave. I left all but a bite on my plate. Donny S. was similarly underwhelmed by his pork dish cooked in milk - a dish the waitress had recommended.

We finished by sharing the olive oil chocolate cake - which was tasy, but not as 'push-the-envelope' as it sounds. The cake was a gooey fudgy sponge-type thing, and the ice cream was basically vanilla flavored with a little hint of olive oil. I think had it just been "chocolate cake with ice cream" I wouldn't really have noticed the olive oil.

So three stars - for the decor, service, and salumi. I'd probably come back here for a drink and an appetizer, but save my dinner money and take myself somewhere a little tastier.

excerpts: Perbacco may be my favorite restaurant in SF, and it's lucky that I'm not around there often because I'd want to go back again and again and again.
Everything about Perbacco is lovely.
I can't wait to go back
perbacco.author: Gracie B.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco may be my favorite restaurant in SF, and it's lucky that I'm not around there often because I'd want to go back again and again and again. 

I went back last weekend with a certain someone before the symphony.  He has a fondness for cured meats and 7x7 said that the salumi plate is a must try.  So we decided to split the salumi, a salad, a pasta entree, and 2 sides.  This was the perfect amount of food.  

Everything was, of course, delicious.  The salumi was some of the best I've had.  The salad was not remarkable, but quite good. The butternut squash ravioli was so good that I regret sharing.  And the sides of braised romano beans and roasted fennel were fab.

Everything about Perbacco is lovely. I can't wait to go back

excerpts: I took my friend to Perbacco for her birthday.
She has dined here a few times, this was my first
and it was fabulous.
My friend and I shared the Fritto with Rock Shrimp appetizer with seasonal beans, olives, and fennel.
I'm not a huge fennel fan but this dish was lightly battered and all the flavors came together.
I enjoyed eating my entire share of it.
My friend ordered the Market Salad - seasonal mix greens and I ordered the Heirloom tomato salad with basil; very tasty.
For our entrees, my friend ordered the Petrale Sole and I had the Butternut Squash Ravioli with sage brown sugar.
For desert we shared the Burnt Caramel and Tahitian sea salt gelato; very good if you like a salty and sweet combination.
The atmosphere was nice, very busy with business lunch parties.
Over all I was impressed with everything.
I will recommend this restaurant to friends and collogues.
