We shared a half-carafe of Sangiovese, which I'll never order again.
Highly acidic, it wasn't so much the quality of the wine as it was the server who made me regret our choice.
I gather he disapproved of our selection as he spilled  quite a bit of it when he poured my friend's glass.
Ok.
Maybe it was an accident.
My friend poured the remaining glasses himself, rather than tempt fate by having our server  . . .
pour more.

That was fine until the very end of the meal when, after expertly scraping grissini crumbs from the white linen tablecloth, he picked up my glass and turned it upside down right next to my friend's elbow.
There was a trail of red wine dribble almost touching my friend's sleeve.
They traded glances and then . . .
He does it AGAIN!
with my friend's glass.
We just stared at the two little red rivulets and then my friend asked, "What's going on with this guy?
Is he mad at me?
He did that on purpose, didn't  he?".
I had to admit that it certainly looked lthat way.
Three splash-downs, and all on *his* side of  the table.
perbacco.author: Lucia M.
perbacco.review:
This ristorante reminded me of a place I loved in Perugia when I lived there. I met an old friend there, he treated me to lunch for my birthday. It was an idyllic 2 hours. The grissini were fresh and crisp -- didn't try the other bread. We shared appetizers:  Vitello Tonnato and Antipasti Misti. Both were very good. It was the one and only time I've ever had Vitello Tonnato outside Italy or my own home and it was very good. The vitello was sliced like prosciutto, which was unusual, but it  did taste delicious. Our entrees were the hangar steak (with Vidalia onions!) and the roast chicken served on a bed of polenta. I ordered the latter as I was craving decent polenta and it did not disappoint. My friend graciously shared some of those eXquisite onions and a bite of hangar steak and I'll go with this entree next time if it's availabe. We topped off the meal with a delicious chocolate delicacy that had a hint of espresso. I can't recall the name of this concoction, it was like a creme brulee or a heavy mousse, and it was absolutely divine. 

I'd have scored Perbacco a perfect 5 if it weren't for the uneven service. We shared a half-carafe of Sangiovese, which I'll never order again. Highly acidic, it wasn't so much the quality of the wine as it was the server who made me regret our choice. I gather he disapproved of our selection as he spilled  quite a bit of it when he poured my friend's glass. Ok. Maybe it was an accident.   My friend poured the remaining glasses himself, rather than tempt fate by having our server  . . .   pour more. That was fine until the very end of the meal when, after expertly scraping grissini crumbs from the white linen tablecloth, he picked up my glass and turned it upside down right next to my friend's elbow. There was a trail of red wine dribble almost touching my friend's sleeve.  They traded glances and then . . . He does it AGAIN! with my friend's glass. We just stared at the two little red rivulets and then my friend asked, "What's going on with this guy? Is he mad at me? He did that on purpose, didn't  he?". I had to admit that it certainly looked lthat way. Three splash-downs, and all on *his* side of  the table. We'll definitely make sure we have a different server next time. 

But even with that dodgy waiter, the food made our meal a wonderful reunion.

excerpts: Such was my experience at Perbacco.
Two years ago, I had a wonderful dinner at Perbacco - the service was phenomenal, the ambience earthy yet contemporary, and the roasted duck divine.
For two years I have been trying to get back to Perbacco, and finally had my chance last night.
perbacco.author: Sherry N.
perbacco.review:
Sometimes second chances don't live up to great first impressions.  Such was my experience at Perbacco.  Two years ago, I had a wonderful dinner at Perbacco - the service was phenomenal, the ambience earthy yet contemporary, and the roasted duck divine.  For two years I have been trying to get back to Perbacco, and finally had my chance last night.

The service was still excellent, however, I found the food to be seriously lacking in flavor.  The arugula and pear salad was drizzled very lightly with a rich gorgonzola sauce (I would have preferred a little more), and it seemed like there was all of two tablespoons of arugula on the plate.  The roasted pears were so-so; for such a savory salad, they would have done better to caramelize the crust on the pears a bit more.  With so little salad on the plate, it becomes almost essential for every morsel to literally burst with flavor, and this salad did not.

I also ordered the sea bass in a saffron broth.  I could not taste the saffron at all.  But the biggest disappointment - I did not recognize the fish as a sea bass.  I had imagined a thick, moist slab of meaty fish, but the sea bass had the texture of a mahi mahi,  It was served with the skin, but the skin was neither flavored nor crisp, so I could not understand its purpose on the plate.  The entree came with fingerling potatoes.  Again, I had imagined roasted buttery little nuggets, but these were sliced thin and boiled in the broth.  I was completely underwhelmed.

My husband had the lamb, which I thought had some good flavor.  But the medallions were so small - after excluding the bone, there was all of three bitefuls in each of the two medallions.  And at nearly $30 for the entree plate itself, I think the restaurant could have done a little better than that.  There was a glimmer of hope - one of our dining companions had the beef shortrib, which seemed to have been perfectly cooked; he did not even need his knife to slice it.

We had a flourless chocolate torte and chestnut/honey ice cream for dessert.  The chocolate torte was rich in flavor, but they missed the mark on the ice cream.  My first bite left me initially wondering if the ice cream was rancid.  It was only after I had thought about the aftertaste that I recognized the unusual raw sweetness as honey.

I may have just been there on an off night.  And, as I mentioned, the service was still very professional, friendly, and attentive.  I will not be in as much of a rush, however, for a third impression.

excerpts: For my entree, I ordered the tajarin, a dishfrom the Piemonte area of Italy for which Perbacco is known.
The handcut tagliatelle resembles wavy ramen and 5-hour cooked pork sugo
was a like ground beef poured in the center of it.
Although it looked rather eh, the texture was al dente and quite good.
The sugo was nice but a little bland and after pretty heavy.
It would have been nice to get some veggies or crunchy nibbles to balance the heavy starch and meat.
I remember getting the agnolotti dal plin the last time ... but can't remember if I enjoyed it or not.
perbacco.author: F. P.
perbacco.review:
I had lunch yesterday with clients and hadn't been here in years since ... well, frankly, another business lunch.  It's that kind of place where I think if it was located elsewhere but FiDi, it would be a much more attractive place.

I mean, don't get me wrong.  The decor is beautiful and service is quite attentive.  But you look around and everyone looks like they're on a business lunch with their button-downs and fake smiles.

It's a shame because the food really is good.  The breadsticks with pesto are a nice touch and the warm focaccia that follows is amazing (although it will leave your hands quite oily).

For starters, the beet salad was excellent (but a bit small in size).  The client had the heirloom salad which looked amazing.  If I was only with friends, I could just reach over and ... doh!

For my entree, I ordered the tajarin, a dishfrom the Piemonte area of Italy for which Perbacco is known.  The handcut tagliatelle resembles wavy ramen and 5-hour cooked pork sugo was a like ground beef poured in the center of it.  Although it looked rather eh, the texture was al dente and quite good.  The sugo was nice but a little bland and after pretty heavy.  It would have been nice to get some veggies or crunchy nibbles to balance the heavy starch and meat.  I remember getting the agnolotti dal plin the last time ... but can't remember if I enjoyed it or not.  Everyone else at non-pasta entrees which looked much more complex (the hangar steak, the halibut) but also looked like what you might be able to get at other restaurants.

I may have to come back (maybe for a weekend) when the suit & tie crowd is far, far away and try another pasta dish soon.  Or I'll probably soon forget how the tajarin tasted (much like the forgotten agnolotti).

excerpts: Perbacco is top notch for food, service and atmosphere for happy hour, date or celebration.
Amazing Italian wine list that your sommelier will help you make heads or tales of.
The cheeses and cured meats make a perfect starter for the table as you flip a coin to help decide your courses from a fresh and varied menu.
Offering of small pasta for primi is perfect and I chose the ragu with duck.
Outstanding!
Others in the group enjoyed gnocchi and risotto.
Loyal followers will question my sway from the risotto.
It was tempting but a ragu like Momma makes, that's the best.
This was better but don't tell Mom.
The sea bass looked like a winner for my main
but I went with the pheasant and was not disappointed.
Amazing presentation, great service
and although we've never been here before, we were treated like regulars.
I will be back for a drink at the bar and dinner with friends.
Perbacco, I thank you.

excerpts:
Perbacco is a superb dining experience in every way! 
The service is spot on, not too much hovering and not unavailable, lovely!
The food is delicious and I always enjoy the beet salad and the pastas are varied and always sumptuous!
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, where I have lived and dined for 25 Years!

excerpts: I've heard good things about Perbacco and I was fortunate enough to have a friend invite me along for a last-minute dinner.
perbacco.author: Bernadette A.
perbacco.review:
I've heard good things about Perbacco and I was fortunate enough to have a friend invite me along for a last-minute dinner.

The staff was easygoing and personable. We were seated at the chef's table a few minutes after our arrival. That's when the fun started! We could see all the action going on in the kitchen.

The best part about our dinner was the service and company. I had the raviolo as an appetizer which was sublime. The risotto was just OK and a little too al dente for my taste. Not to toot my own horn but there was a general consensus that my mushroom risotto is much tastier! =)

I don't remember much about dessert but after downing 3 gin & tonics, who would? Fortunately I had that little area around the chef's table to jog off the liquor. =)

I would come back to try the other items on the menu. Seems like a great place to meet up with friends after work!

excerpts: It was so bad, I did not care to write a review, but last Thursday my opinion of Perbacco changed for the better.....
My first true test of my discipline was at Perbacco when I did not order wine.
I would give Perbacco a try if you have not been.
If you did not have the best experience, give it another try, as I did.
perbacco.author: Christopher W.
perbacco.review:
I had a negative experience here two years ago that involved wine, drama, and a ruined shirt. It was so bad, I did not care to write a review, but last Thursday my opinion of Perbacco changed for the better.....

I started a liver cleanse diet seven days ago, meaning no alcohol for fifteen days. My first true test of my discipline was at Perbacco when I did not order wine. Throughout the evening, only one person had wine, totaling $8.00.

For meals, I started with fresh, grilled asparagus with a beautiful hollandaise sauce. For my second course, I shared a papparadelli pasta with short rib meat on top. Both dishes were memorable. 

What made this restaurant stand out to me was:

1.) The waitress treated us like we ordered there best champagne instead of one glass of wine and tap water.
2.) They split the pasta without charging an additional fee.
3.) The meal was only $59.00 for three of us, which is the least I have ever spent for three people in adulthood in San Francisco.

I would give Perbacco a try if you have not been. If you did not have the best experience, give it another try, as I did.

excerpts: I was in San Francisco visiting family and my aunt suggested Perbacco.
This place is amazing!
The restaurant is very well done in every regard
but I think was impressed me
most was the overall feel of the building.
The interior design is modern and original, and just feels good.
I love it when things are designed well.
The menu is extensive and delicious, with enough options for vegetarians.
The staff was great as well.
I got a chance to meet the owners and they were very cool and intelligent people.
Perbacco is the  kind of place you could go on almost any occassion.
I definitely owe my aunt one for showing me this place.
Definitely my kind of place.
Overall, I had about as good of a time at a restaurant as is possible.

excerpts: The head honcho of the office suggested Perbacco.
Luckily, we made reservations because it was pretty packed on Thursday night.
perbacco.author: Patra I.
perbacco.review:
One of my clients was in town for a conference, so my boss wanted to take them out to dinner.  The head honcho of the office suggested Perbacco.  Luckily, we made reservations because it was pretty packed on Thursday night.  There were alot of people at the bar enjoying their cocktails, and all the tables were full.  

I arrived 10 minutes early, but the client was even earlier.  They were already seated upstairs, so I had to entertain them until my boss arrived.  It can get pretty loud in the restaurant, so sometimes I would just nod my head and smile and pretend like I knew what they were talking about.

Once the boss arrived, we decided to order a bottle of wine.  The sommelier recommended two reds.  The client picked, but I can't remember the name....it was something Italian.  It was more of a full bodied wine, and once it had a chance to breathe, it was really good.  

I ordered the Seared Sea Bass and my boss had the Grilled Prather Ranch Sirloin Steak.  I think the clients got the Grilled Berkshire Pork Chop, some seared ahi tuna dish, and a veal dish.  My sea bass was delicious.  It was in a tomato stew with shrimp, mussels and clams.  Since we didn't order any appetizers, the portion was a tad bit on the small side for me.  All of the other dishes looked really good, but I couldn't exactly say, "hey..let me try some of that."  

The service was great.  Our waitress was quite attentive and made sure we always had everything we needed.  Our water glasses were always full, and our wine always topped off.  

If you need to use the restroom, find the elevator and head to the basement.  Its quite an interesting journey.  You exit the elevator from the back, and then you walk to a room with 4 doors.  Two M's and two W's.  Behind each door is a toilet and a sink, but there also sinks outside as well.  Kind of weird.  

With all the budget cuts and layoffs, I haven't had a free meal on the company in a while, so it was a great treat to dine here.  I'll definitely be back to try other dishes on the menu.

excerpts: I went to Perbacco for the first time last week to celebrate with a few coworkers.
Let me start by saying that the food here is excellent.
The olives and salted almonds were incredible.
The bread was fantastic.
If you do try Perbacco, I highly recommend the spiced almonds and olives - they are real treats!
perbacco.author: Heather S.
perbacco.review:
I went to Perbacco for the first time last week to celebrate with a few coworkers. Let me start by saying that the food here is excellent. The olives and salted almonds were incredible. The bread was fantastic. My gnocci were exceptional. 

I do have to knock off one solid star for the service. While the wait-staff weren't out-right rude, I noticed that we did not receive the same level of service as some other customers sitting near us. It was kind of a disappointment.

If you do try Perbacco, I highly recommend the spiced almonds and olives - they are real treats!

excerpts: it was at Perbacco.
Co-worker had the Paparadelle with Short Rib Ragu...and literally sopped up every last bit of the sauce with his bread.
I had the Truffle-herb ricotta gnocchi w/ caramelized onions and wild mushrooms.
It was delish!
perbacco.author: Kelly K.
perbacco.review:
Business lunch with the boss...always good...but even better b/c it was at Perbacco.  Co-worker had the Paparadelle with Short Rib Ragu...and literally sopped up every last bit of the sauce with his bread.  I had the Truffle-herb ricotta gnocchi w/ caramelized onions and wild mushrooms.  It was delish!  Perfect pairing of flavor from the onion and mushrooms with the  creamy-fluffiness of the gnocchi.  

Didn't get to have appetizer or dessert but will have to back and try the strawberry salad, and the brown butter cake with apricot.  yum!

excerpts: We were great customers for 2+ hours, and, though, most places want to nickel and dime you for a drink, at Perbacco you almost want to pay double in order to get prompt attention for a second glass of wine!   ....
A friend of mine did not like her cocktail, and it was complimentarily replaced...
no hassle,
so, perhaps they aren't greedy on their liquor margins.
Bathrooms, strangely, were downstairs and a maze to find.... guess you don't want to order too much raw meat, or, get plastered on the cocktails.
perbacco.author: Em H.
perbacco.review:
Ate at the bar; food- excellent; service- eh (keeps me from providing a 5 star rating)

Some friends of mine ordered a couple cheeses- hard and soft-  recommended by a staff member; each was amazing and nuts (almonds), raisins, and a jam comes with... delish..  raisin nut bread was also brought but not quite enough.  It must be a commodity because when we asked for more to spread the cheese only a baguette was provided.
The Piastra Roasted octopus (octopus appetizer) was a MUST HAVE.  I have not had such great octopus since Bodrum, Turkey, where it is part of the common cuisine.  It came with a thin veal tongue tartare which was an absolute great accompaniment (for an at home version, use corn beef).
The salumi misti was a large appetizer which a great variety of meat... not sure what I ate (lardo was included)..be adventurous is all I can say!!
Now... for such a busy place it was difficult to get a bartender's attention!!   We were great customers for 2+ hours, and, though, most places want to nickel and dime you for a drink, at Perbacco you almost want to pay double in order to get prompt attention for a second glass of wine!   .... A friend of mine did not like her cocktail, and it was complimentarily replaced... no hassle, so, perhaps they aren't greedy on their liquor margins.
Bathrooms, strangely, were downstairs and a maze to find.... guess you don't want to order too much raw meat, or, get plastered on the cocktails.

excerpts: Had a wonderful dinner at Perbacco tonight.
The main dining room is lively (and noisy) but very festive.
I had the sea scallops with caponata - dee-li-cious
but I wish there more of them (only 4 scallops).
My friend had the truffle-infused fusilli, which was very tasty.
The best thing we ate was the grilled butternut squash with brown butter and pomegranates -
WOW, this dish was amazingly rich and tasty!
Our waiter was really friendly and efficient - a good combination.
And the whole bill was under $100 for 2 people with drinks.
Really good value for a great meal.

excerpts: Perbacco met my expectations.
The service was non-pretentious and the dishes were mostly tasty.
perbacco.author: Ankur P.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco met my expectations.  The service was non-pretentious and the dishes were mostly tasty.  The flavors didn't blow me away but price-wise, it was fairly reasonable.

I'd probably try somewhere else before coming back.

excerpts: I absolutely loved Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Alison V.
perbacco.review:
I absolutely loved Perbacco.

I sat at the bar with my Dad and Sister for a Stella Artois (poured perfectly) since we were early for our reservation. The salume platter was amazing.

After being seated, we were promptly given San Benedito water, which is the same water I obsessed over while I was in Italy. It is the best. I love that they have imported Italian "aqua frizzante".

I started with the beet salad with vinegarette, DE-LISH.

I had the grilled pork chop, which melted in my mouth. The bed of fennel it rested on was delightful as well.

A tad pricey, but totally worth it. I too BART into the City and only had to walk a block from Embarcadero BART. Very convenient. They have valet too, which is quite important.

Bomb.

excerpts: we each had a cocktail, and i had the perbacco which had ketel one citron and meyer lemon in it.
it tasted light, but apparently it had a lot of alcohol in it
perbacco.author: Helen T.
perbacco.review:
this place is pretty packed on a thurs night.  we had a reservation for 8 pm and were seated pretty promptly.  before ordering, we were brought breadsticks w/ pesto dip.

we each had a cocktail, and i had the perbacco which had ketel one citron and meyer lemon in it.  it tasted light, but apparently it had a lot of alcohol in it, b/c it hit me later!

after ordering, we were brought gigantic rolls, which i happily ate b/c i was starving,  we didn't have to wait long for our food to arrive though.  we got the strawberry and arugula salad, the beet salad, and the crudo to start, and they were all good.  the portions were pretty small, so we finished these up quickly.

we then each ordered the small portions of the pasta.  i got the pappardelle w/ short rib ragu, and my hubby got the meyer lemon ravioli w/ asparagus.  i LOVED the pappardelle, and the short rib just melted.  the small sized pastas were more than enuf, since we also got the brussel sprouts w/ capers and the honey roasted carrots on the side.  both veg sides were a good size, so by the end, we were stuffed.  

however, how can we leave w/o dessert?  we just shared the burnt caramel gelato w/ sea salt and a couple cookies w/ sunflower seeds on the side.  it was the perfect ending to a yummy meal.

excerpts: Make your selection, and give instructions on where and when to deliver to Perbacco for your dinner evening.
Call Perbacco and make them note the florist delivery.
Order dinner and enjoy Perbacco's delicious menu items.
Have a sentimental, romantic conversation.
Have a card ready in which you've expressed your love, and possibly a gift to be served with dessert.
perbacco.author: Danny H.
perbacco.review:
Update: February 2011: Still 5-star quality food and service! Unbelievable!

Previous review:

A friend recommended this place to me for Mother's Day dinner for my wife. I have NO regrets. Okay, fellas, here's a recipe to put that smile on your woman's face:

1. Make reservation. Request a seat on the second level, in the back. the front near the bar area can get really loud.

2.  Browse Rossi & Rovetti's website. They're a premium, highly regarded florist in San Francisco.  Make your selection, and give instructions on where and when to deliver to Perbacco for your dinner evening.

3. Call Perbacco and make them note the florist delivery. Call back two more times later (a couple days before the dinner, and then again on the day of) to CONFIRM everything is scheduled as you want.

4. Take her to dinner. Forget street parking. Pay the money for valet and save yourself some stress. On the side confirm with the waiter/waitress that the flowers are in position BEFORE you are taken to the table.

5. Watch her reaction and rejoice your credit card was put to good use!

6. Order dinner and enjoy Perbacco's delicious menu items. Have a sentimental, romantic conversation. Have a card ready in which you've expressed your love, and possibly a gift to be served with dessert. The rest, gentlemen, I leave to your imagination.

Quality of Food: A+
Quality of Service: A+
General layout and setting: B+

excerpts: I will not go back to Perbacco again!
perbacco.author: Randal P.
perbacco.review:
I heard so many good things about this place and when I went, I was very, very disappointed.   

I spent a lot of time in Italy during my youth and this isn't the food I had grown to love.

The service was horrendous!  I'm a senior citizen and I felt out of place in this restaurant.   

I try to instill humor in my reviews, but there wasn't anything funny about my experience.  

I will not go back to Perbacco again!

The owner contacted me after reading my review.   I had blocked owners from contacting me, but he circumvented this by using his quasi-private yelp account.   

I find this unacceptable.  The owner of this establishment shouldn't get bent out of shape over a one star review.   It's part of business.  It's part of life.

The guy has yelp envy...

excerpts: I came to Perbacco for to satisfy a Friday night Italian craving.
The menu was a little overwhelming as several options sounded right up my alley.
The waiter was really helpful in providing some guidance as he claimed that the raviolo shouldn't be missed.
The soft pasta enveloped a luscious, rich filling of truffled-polenta, egg, and corn-truffle butter.
Definitely not a dish for the faint of heart.
It was quite good, but I wouldn't say it couldn't be missed.
The same doesn't hold for my entree, however, the seared sea scallops.
The scallops were delicious, perfectly seared and the celery root puree was amazing.
It was an exceptional dish and if it's offered the night you happen to come in I highly recommend it.
The ambiance was nice, although I would say the tables were a little too close for my taste, or maybe the person next to me just doesn't know how to use an "inside voice.
My meal didn't shake up to be classic Italian
but it did stand out as a fantastic experience.
I highly recommend Perbacco.

The waiter was really helpful in providing some guidance as he claimed that the raviolo shouldn't be missed. excerpts: The likelihood of disappointment was high, but Perbacco really pulled through.
I think two aspects of their menu are really worth highlighting - the salumi and the pasta.
The salumi might be cured on site, and if not, it's freshly sliced and there are several options every night.
The pasta is freshly made and there are many, many unique options that don't involve words like Bolognese or manicotti.
They have a (seemingly) new addition to the menu where you can do a pasta tasting for the table.
It worked out wonderfully -
This time, my drink (the eponymous Perbacco) was good, but nothing to swoon over.
perbacco.author: Erika H.
perbacco.review:
My second meal here followed many, many months of lusting to go back.  The likelihood of disappointment was high, but Perbacco really pulled through.  I think two aspects of their menu are really worth highlighting - the salumi and the pasta.  The salumi might be cured on site, and if not, it's freshly sliced and there are several options every night.  The pasta is freshly made and there are many, many unique options that don't involve words like Bolognese or manicotti.  They have a (seemingly) new addition to the menu where you can do a pasta tasting for the table.  It worked out wonderfully - we got 3 small pasta servings each which was basically the portion equivalent of an entree. 

The wine list is great and my Barbera did not disappoint.  There are probably 20 nice types of wine by the glass in addition to the numerous bottle choices.  When I came here the first time, I had such outstanding cocktails that they could have been reason enough to come back.  This time, my drink (the eponymous Perbacco) was good, but nothing to swoon over.  I think it was a blip, so no poor marks on that account.

Go here!  It's really, really great.

excerpts: Perbacco is an Italian restaurant in the financial district which has a reputation for 'authentic/traditional' Italian cuisine.
perbacco.author: Rob H.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is an Italian restaurant in the financial district which has a reputation for 'authentic/traditional' Italian cuisine.

I ate there on Tuesday evening and the place was packed. Since we didn't have reservations, there was a 20-30 minute wait and we decided to sit at the bar.

There were several people 'behind' the bar but only 1 bartender. It took about 10 minutes for the bartender to 'acknowledge' us and another 5-10 minutes to get drinks. Terrible bar service, hint: hire another bartender.

The waiter was much more prompt and I never had an empty glass. I ate the grilled prather ranch sirloin steak dinner with the grilled torpedo spring onion, arugula and gorgonzola butter. Ate the steak which was average and left the veggies/filler. 

Personally, I have had better Italian and felt this place was a little over rated. Maybe waiting 20 minutes at the bar for a drink left a bad taste in my mouth but I wouldn't recommend this restaurant.

excerpts: I love Barbacco next door, so I took someone from work to Perbacco for dinner (same owners).
perbacco.author: workingstiff f.
perbacco.review:
I love Barbacco next door, so I took someone from work to Perbacco for dinner (same owners).   Unfortunately, it was not that great.

Reasons: our waitress forgot about us and was borderline obnoxious when she did come over; wood fired octopus was tough and lacked flavor; pasta was hard on top from sitting under the heat lamp too long.

excerpts: Went to Perbacco for a work event and was generally pleased by the food.
perbacco.author: Melissa D.
perbacco.review:
Went to Perbacco for a work event and was generally pleased by the food. We had a set menu and 4 courses, and for my main I ended up with the beef short ribs stracatto with the sweet potato puree which was much better than I anticipated. 

However, one of the salads/courses prior, there was a beet salad that I really wasn't a fan of-- while it was pleasant, it was a touch too sweet and I could have passed on it. 

For our appetizer though, they presented us with an absolutely amazing shrimp and calamari duo, which was perfect-- the seasoning on the seafood was absolutely perfect. 

Dessert was sort of molten chocolate cake, which was served with a dollop of creme, but really ought have been served with ice cream instead, because the cake was SO incredibly rich. 

All in all, the food was great, and the short ribs were surprisingly good (I am normally not a short ribs person, but didn't want the scallops), and will likely come back for the normal menu another time with friends.

excerpts: Part Italian, part business exec--Perbacco is a rare combination of decadent Italian wine/food and men in suits brokering deals.
perbacco.author: Britt M.
perbacco.review:
Part Italian, part business exec--Perbacco is a rare combination of decadent Italian wine/food and men in suits brokering deals. Love the exposed brick and modern design in the bar area, as it really adds to the vibe.

The salumi, risotto with scallops, and appetizers like the crispy pig's trotters are some of my faves (mmm...). Wine pours are generous, martinis less so (they seem to come in small-ish glasses--then again it IS straight vodka) and service is extremely well-trained and competent. 

You'll never be wondering where your entree is, why your water glass isn't full, or where that next glass of wine is. If you're a dine and dash type person, you'll love it.

With that said, if you're on a romantic date or out with a good friend who you'd like to linger with, I'd suggest a seat at the bar or another establishment just because this isn't a 3-hour, European chat and linger type of place. Not that they rush you exactly, but courses tend to come out fairly fast and close together and the atmosphere is not one in the dining room that encourages you to stay and talk for hours. The various servers and food runners clear silverware, plates, etc between courses so if you order multiple items they come by quite frequently which can be a little invasive. It's really the perfect place to come with coworkers though--I'd bring my boss here in a heartbeat.

Food and wine is fab...love the bar area...a little "meh" about the dining room in terms of design.

excerpts: I will probably give Perbacco another try, some day.
perbacco.author: Brenda G.
perbacco.review: I had the sole, was cold, had to send it back. It came back in under 5 minutes, nice and warm but it wasn't that great.  My friend had some kind of ravoli and liked it.  I was not impressed with the restaurant as a whole.  We were seated in the large alcove section near the back that was pretty full.  It was very warm and a little uncomfortable after a glass of wine.  (Granted it was before Christmas and it was obvious a lot of people were there for a holiday lunch, as was I).  The service was impeccable and that is why I gave 3 stars.  I will probably give Perbacco another try, some day.

excerpts: Perbacco was a bit of a disappointment.
I think part of this is because we had a spectacular meal at Babbo in NYC recently and thought this might be similar.
perbacco.author: Bleep S.
perbacco.review:
Tried to make a reservation on Open Table the day of dining. Could only get 2:30 and 9:45, so called the restaurant directly and got a reservation for 7:45. No Open Table points but, oh well. We arrived way early and were seated immediately, upstairs. Very nice! It is noisy up there and the lighting is eerie. Skinny bread sticks and olive oil basil dip are on the table. The skinny bread sticks did not taste good. Ordered a delicious beer from the Piedmont region of Italy. Best Italian beer I've ever had. We also ordered a bottle of Italian sparkling water. Rolls (Acme..delicious) and butter (sweet cream..yum) arrived...so good. We ordered the 3 pasta sampler as an appetizer...AGNOLOTTI DAL PLIN FILLED WITH ROASTED VITELLONE AND SAVOY CABBAGE / SUGO D"ARROSTO,PAPPARDELLE - WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / GRATED HORSERADISH, and another pasta filled with butternut squash and garnished with nuts. All the flavorings for the pasta were delicious. Unfortunately, the pasta was a bit mushy. The guy ordered SEARED SEA SCALLOPS / WILD MUSHROOMS AND SAVOY CABBAGE / RED WINE BUTTER..and was told there would be 4 scallops. There were three and we were told that was because they were unusually large. They were large? What do the small ones look like? They must have the diameter of a bottle cap. We ordered two vegetables on the side:BROCCOLI DI CICCO / BAGNA CAÔDA BUTTER and GARLIC...wonderful...a hint of anchovy butter,PAN ROASTED FENNEL / MEYER LEMON / OLIVE OIL..very nice. Perbacco was a bit of a disappointment. I think part of this is because we had a spectacular meal at Babbo in NYC recently and thought this might be similar. This is not at all fair, I know...two different places.

Easy access from Embarcadero BART...moderately priced.

excerpts: Perbacco is a festive place to please the palette and take a little vacation in the middle of the work day.
One of my favorites I keep returning to in the Financial District.
perbacco.author: Nicky D.
perbacco.review: Perbacco is a festive place to please the palette and take a little vacation in the middle of the work day. One of my favorites I keep returning to in the Financial District.

excerpts: To make it up to me she took me to Perbacco for lunch a few days later.
I've heard mixed reports on Perbacco but based on my one lunch there I quickly added it to my list of favorite new restaurants.
There was a ton of great options on the menu
so we ended up splitting three appetizers (grilled squid, house made salumi plate and burrata) and one pasta (the gnocchi)
Everything was fantastic!
And portion size was huge...

The little things really stood out at Perbacco-the complimentary dessert, the biscotti that came with my coffee, the three different cookies served alongside the gelato, super friendly service from our waitress and the manager on duty who stopped by our table to check in.
I will definitely be back soon to try dinner at Perbacco.
perbacco.author: phil h.
perbacco.review:
I finally had my Sixteen Candles moment.  No, not sitting on a table kissing Jake Ryan (although he was quite dreamy, sigh) but my mom forgot my birthday!  Ok, she was out of town at the time but they do have phones in Canada, right?  So the next day I call her and don't say anything...we talk for a few minutes and she hangs up without a word. Five minutes later she calls back and starts singing Happy Birthday (a family tradition) and then apologizes over and over.  To make it up to me she took me to Perbacco for lunch a few days later.

I've heard mixed reports on Perbacco but based on my one lunch there I quickly added it to my list of favorite new restaurants.  There was a ton of great options on the menu so we ended up splitting three appetizers (grilled squid, house made salumi plate and burrata) and one pasta (the gnocchi)  Everything was fantastic!  And portion size was huge...we were stuffed and had a bit of each leftover to take home.  

To round out the meal our waitress brought out a trio of gelato (including a fantastic salted caramel) on a plate that had "Happy Birthday" spelled out in chocolate.  Hey, at least our waitress didn't forget my birthday.

The little things really stood out at Perbacco-the complimentary dessert, the biscotti that came with my coffee, the three different cookies served alongside the gelato, super friendly service from our waitress and the manager on duty who stopped by our table to check in.  I will definitely be back soon to try dinner at Perbacco.

excerpts: It's been almost a year since I last ate at Perbacco, but it is an excellent, elegant spot for lunch or dinner in the Financial District.
Summer bean salad with heirloom tomatoes was excellent.
Main course was the beef short rib, which was cooked perfectly, tasty and tender.
I don't remember what dessert was
(cheesecake?)
but it was delicious.
Excellent California cuisine in a great location and a great interior.
Service was good: attentive without being rushed.
Prices are very reasonable given the quality of the food and service.
Definitely need to go back.
perbacco.author: Charles W.
perbacco.review: It's been almost a year since I last ate at Perbacco, but it is an excellent, elegant spot for lunch or dinner in the Financial District.  Summer bean salad with heirloom tomatoes was excellent.  Main course was the beef short rib, which was cooked perfectly, tasty and tender.  I don't remember what dessert was (cheesecake?) but it was delicious.  Excellent California cuisine in a great location and a great interior.  Service was good: attentive without being rushed.  Prices are very reasonable given the quality of the food and service.  Definitely need to go back.

excerpts: Perbacco is definitely suitable for business type lunch venue.
Everyone is wearing suits and talks quietly which I can appreciate.
perbacco.author: Cathryn C.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is definitely suitable for business type lunch venue.  Everyone is wearing suits and talks quietly which I can appreciate.  Service is very good, the servers, bread folks are quite attentive to your needs.  

I'm only giving it 3 stars because after 2 visits, there really isn't much to say about the food.  Everything seem to taste like mushrooms - the desserts aren't exactly fantastic either.  I would say their Gnocchi is cooked to perfection but the flavor lacks something - maybe they can grate more cheese on top or spice it up a bit.

This place has fantastic wine selection and cocktail menu - so if you're in the mood for some apres work drinks, this place isn't too bad.

excerpts: Last year, soon after I wrote my 3-star review, the proprietor of Perbacco, Umberto, messaged me to apologize for the service and to thank me for the positive comments I had on the food.

Finally, the food is so different than what you normally find at high-end SF restaurants, even other high-end Italian restaurants, that I think Perbacco can be a destination restaurant for out-of-towners.
It's so much more interesting than Gary Danko's, for example.
And the prices are very reasonable (we had probably two too many dishes + 3 bottles of wine, and it came out to $95/person).
perbacco.author: Veronica S.
perbacco.review:
Last year, soon after I wrote my 3-star review, the proprietor of Perbacco, Umberto, messaged me to apologize for the service and to thank me for the positive comments I had on the food. He said he hoped I'd be back and to make sure to introduce myself when I did.

Well, I did return - 12 months later. I'm not the type to to call in favors so I didn't seek him out when I arrived, but he made a point to find me. He sat our party of 7 at the chef's table, where we ended up dining for almost 4 hours on a Monday evening. Service was impeccable this time around, and food as delectable as my previous trip. 

We wanted to do family style, so we ordered several apps (would recommend the squid, pork pate, and veal tartare) and let the server decide how we'd mix 'n match our pastas and meats for our entrees. 

He brought us a "pasta tasting", which I would recommend if you have 4 or more people. It came out to 1.5 portions of 3 pastas, and they plated each pasta for us individually. It's the best way to eat pastas really, because a full portion of one just isn't as fun as trying a little of 3. The best one was the agnolotti with veal -- absolutely delcious.

We shared 4 "meats" (seared ahi, duck, pork,  beef short ribs). All were wonderful, but I especially liked the duck (hands down, the best duck I've ever had). The beef short ribs was also very, very good. 

But what impressed me the most was that Umberto made that initial effort after my first review, and stayed true to his word when I came back. He didn't need my business -- the place was packed on Monday night. But you can tell he truly cares about his patrons and their experiences; the excellent food and service was an added bonus.

Finally, the food is so different than what you normally find at high-end SF restaurants, even other high-end Italian restaurants, that I think Perbacco can be a destination restaurant for out-of-towners. It's so much more interesting than Gary Danko's, for example. And the prices are very reasonable (we had probably two too many dishes + 3 bottles of wine, and it came out to $95/person).

excerpts: Perbacco is everything I'd want in an expense account lunch (especially if it is someone else's expense account we're utilizing!).
Looking over the other selections of pastas and main courses, I can only foresee more visits to Perbacco in the future, be that for lunch or in the evening.
Not just a nice addition t the Fi-Di, the place is a pleasure for all of San Francisco.
perbacco.author: Nish N.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is everything I'd want in an expense account lunch (especially if it is someone else's expense account we're utilizing!). It's a sleek but warm and inviting space, perpetually boisterous with a clientle that exudes success, and that was even without me checking up the equally busy second floor. 

Our waiter was efficient but friendly, and our food arrived almost too quickly after ordering (is there such a thing as fast food fine dining?). That said, my Tajarin pasta was a culinary marvel of flavors:  handcut tagliatelle with a 5-hour pork sugo over it, porcini mushrooms, divine. The three of us split the gelati misti - a trio of chocolate, hazelnut and caramel with vanilla sea salt - for dessert.  

Looking over the other selections of pastas and main courses, I can only foresee more visits to Perbacco in the future, be that for lunch or in the evening. Not just a nice addition t the Fi-Di, the place is a pleasure for all of San Francisco.

excerpts: Fortunately, since I only ate 8 bites total at Perbacco
Sorry Perbacco, can't do it.
perbacco.author: Janney B.
perbacco.review:
P- Prompt service (Our resos were for 6:15 and they sat us at 6:00)

E-Eager bread man who kept appearing all magician-like and bringing additional sourdough rolls.

R- Really gross pear/gorgonzola salad.  Duck was very fatty.  Fortunately, since I only ate 8 bites total at Perbacco I am a little less fatty.

B- Be back?  Moi?  Nah.. third time wasn't a charm for this place.

A- Actually, I did like the rolls...

C- Can't justify $100+ for sourdough though. So no, I won't willingly return.

C- Crap! Carbs DO have a way of calling my name in that sweet, sweet way.

O- Okay, I'm not coming back.  Sorry Perbacco, can't do it.

excerpts: Well, in actuality, this little piggy *me* went to all the way to Perbacco and had some suckling piggy served with a blood orange and arugula salad.
What can I say?
I'm a sucker for finger suckling good piggies.
And this piggy was very tasty.
Tasted like buttery textured ham.
Why did I order this though?
I just had ham for Easter dinner and pork loin and bacon last night.
Oh yes, because I dine on swine and love to fork the pork.
perbacco.author: Christina S.
perbacco.review:
This little piggy went to market. 
This little piggy stayed home.  
This little piggy had roast beef.  
This little piggy had none.  
This little piggy cried "Wee! Wee! Wee!" all the way home. 

Well, in actuality, this little piggy *me* went to all the way to Perbacco and had some suckling piggy served with a blood orange and arugula salad.  What can I say?  I'm a sucker for finger suckling good piggies.  And this piggy was very tasty.  Tasted like buttery textured ham.  Why did I order this though?  I just had ham for Easter dinner and pork loin and bacon last night.  Oh yes, because I dine on swine and love to fork the pork.

excerpts: Perbacco = Little Italy in New York but really in San Francisco
perbacco.author: Sue L.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco = Little Italy in New York but really in San Francisco

This ristorante boasts a grand brick wall that welcomes local San Franciscans to New York and feeds them as a French person residing in Italy would. Their dishes are amazing! I hear the pasta is out of this world, however, having come here for a private dining event, I was only able to select from the filet mignon or sea bass. The filet was superb, the mash potatoes were a tad on the salty side, and the chocolate volcano cake melted in my mouth. 

After 3 hours of eating and mingling, my private dining party and I went back downstairs, walked past the large brick walls and left New York. We opened the doors leading outside and were greeted by cable cars...

excerpts: Far be it from me not to order homemade pasta from Perbacco when The Pasta Gods are obviously beckoning......
perbacco.author: Katherine N.
perbacco.review:
So, Today was my second time visiting this charming place.

I walked in late in the afternoon for lunch as is my style.

It's 3pm and the hostess is so sorry to say that they stopped serving lunch at 2:30. 

I really didn't want to stay for the bar menu......When Saint Maria (manager) comes up to me and scoops me up and away to the bar and asks me if I'm willing to order Pasta . .....I can still order off the lunch menu for about the next five minutes because the Pasta Chefs were still there......

Far be it from me not to order homemade pasta from Perbacco when The Pasta Gods are obviously beckoning......

AND,.....There were a lot of pasta dishes to decide upon Thankfully.

 So I chose a Ravioli Style pasta filled with Chard (Spinich Family) and Riccotta with Olive Oil, and Butter and Nuts....it melts in your mouth .

Maria had it herself that day and recommended it and I think it's what bonded us at the end of the afternoon...along with girl talk of course !

Isn't it funny how good food does that with people, you start talking about the food and then everything else flows.

First, There is no substitute for fresh homemade Pasta. The flavor of their Pasta is rich and tasty and so easy to eat.  I don't know the recipe and I'm sure they'll never tell me  !

Second, Their ingredients are Fresh and True to their flavors.

Third, I think it's safe to say their Chef knows what he's doing and don't ask me his name.

Eating at the bar this afternoon was a really lovely way to celebrate becomming a Elite Yelper.

I'm just around the corner from this place and I'll be back.

Oh, The waitstaff are so professional and efficient. They can't do enough for you.  I Love That

Along with being a bit hot !

excerpts: , so we made our way over to Perbacco right next door.
Two people were missing, but that's not Perbacco's fault.
perbacco.author: Nancy M.
perbacco.review:
I just had a fabulous dinner!

Tadich Grill right next door was bursting at the seams as we sauntered in a 7;!5 on a Thursday night., so we made our way over to Perbacco right next door.  This place was super busy too, but they offered us a bar table at the front right away where we could order from the full menu - right on! 

It had been a long and stressful week at work, and it wasn't over yet.  I should have been at the office, getting things done, but my very good friend was coming up specifically to see us.  How could I resist?  I think it was the best decision I could have made.

We were celebrating some very important and happy milestones, so we decided to go all out for dinner.  We ordered a lovely bottle of Syrah wine to share amongst the three of us, well, rather, the two of us, since one of my friends wasn't drinking.  For starters we had the prosciutto and melon and the sea scallops.  The melon was a strange and yet oh so perfect accompaniment to the prociutto, and the sea scallops, though raw (much to my surprise - I didn't really read the menu carefully) were excellent.

For dinner I had the saffron risotto with braised beef cheeks - WOW!  The saffron risotto was exquisite, so flavorful, and the meat was extremely tender, that everything melted in your mouth in just the right way.  I tried some of the ribs, which were also quite tender.  One thing I have noticed about this place on this occasion, and on a previous visit here, is that they leave a lot of the fat on their meat.  Does this make it more tender? Flavorful? I personally don't like the fat to remain on my meat, but that could just be me.  The halibut was tasty, but a bit dry.

Dessert was delectable!  I am a big fan of dessert, so I was really excited when I got to order what I wanted, then got my companions to order the other two items that I wanted to try. :)  I had the peach and raspberry cake with peach ice cream, all of which was excellent; however it came with this intriguing (and yucky) champagne jello type substance.  I like champagne, and I like jello, but those are two things that didn't mix well on my plate.  I got to try the chocolate torte - overwhelmingly chocolatey, but good, just make sure to order some milk or something.  I think the winner though, was my friends plum crostini.  He complained that it was too sweet, but if you ask me it was perfect.  

Tonight was perfect.  Well, almost.  Two people were missing, but that's not Perbacco's fault.  :)

excerpts: I took out a home equity line of credit before going to perbacco, and still couldn't take the price vs food ratio.
I was so hungry after leaving and spent so much money
it was pathetic.
I am not calling perbacco pathetic but I am saying they need to step up.
Just thinking of perbacco makes me want to go some where else and eat.
perbacco.author: Ellis D.
perbacco.review:
I took out a home equity line of credit before going to perbacco, and still couldn't take the price vs food ratio. I was so hungry after leaving and spent so much money it was pathetic. I am not calling perbacco pathetic but I am saying they need to step up.

Great wine list Umby! good food and ambiance but for crying out loud I am a slim guy height weight proportionate and left thinking of the taco truck in fruitvale. Just thinking of perbacco makes me want to go some where else and eat.

excerpts: My date dropped me at home after having dinner at Perbacco.
I took my shoes off and marched straight to the kitchen for chips and salsa.
Perbacco is good for business not for pleasure( unless you're dabbling in infidelity).
perbacco.author: R M.
perbacco.review:
My date dropped me at home after having dinner at Perbacco.  I took my shoes off and marched straight to the kitchen for chips and salsa. I swear I'm not one of those dainty date eaters either.    

The cuisine was much more about flavor and quality than quantity.  

SERVICE
The service was fine. Maybe a little too attentive actually.  The server would come over and ask how the first bite was? and the 5th,10th.,15th...It went on like this for four courses. 

AMBIANCE
The tone of the restaurant was very stiff.  It kind of launched me back into childhood. I could practically hear my mother whispering, "Nadja stop wiggling at the table.  Where is your napkin? Chew with your mouth closed, Don't pick your nose".

I looked around at one point and saw a sea of 'blue hairs'.
Blue hairs on business dinners, blue hairs with buxom blonde's they had no business being with, blue hairs with blue hairs....

Perbacco is good for business not for pleasure( unless you're dabbling in infidelity).

excerpts: What does any of this have to do with Perbacco?

We started with some bubbly in the loin while watching the princess open her mountain of gifts (including a Law and Order coloring book) before hailing a cab to meet the rest of the party downtown at Perbacco.
It was a great night and Perbacco played a huge part in that.
Total Party All the Time.
perbacco.author: Thadd L.
perbacco.review:
Have you heard the track 'make it rain?' by Lil' Wayne?  It is money, only eclipsed recently by that Akon song 'I wanna love you.'  Anyway, if you haven't heard it basically the phrase basically means 'throw around so much money that there is a storm of cash blowing around the room.' Or... as defined by urban dictionary...

"Term used in strip clubs, it defines when you in da club, with a stack and you throw the money up in the air at the strippers, and the effect is that it seems to be raining money on to the strippers."

I really don't think that you need to be in 'da club' though, as I saw one of the line backers in the super bowl game pantomiming 'make it rain' after his teammate made a touchdown... What does any of this have to do with Perbacco? Nothing.

Except for the fact that some partners in crime and I made it rain (figuratively) on our friend (the beautiful, charming and captivating) Melissa H. earlier this week.

We started with some bubbly in the loin while watching the princess open her mountain of gifts (including a Law and Order coloring book) before hailing a cab to meet the rest of the party downtown at Perbacco.

We arrived a little before the time of our reservation and lucky for us our table was already set and ready to go so we didn't have to squeeze into the happening (read: crowded) bar. We started with some cocktails from the signature menu... well... the women did... I wasn't turned on by the liquor combinations that were available so I stuck to the martini... the chicks did like their drinks though.

When the rest of our party arrived one of our friend Bobby quickly snatched up the wine list and bought a wonderfully tasty bottle of champagne.  Good thing I love that stuff.

I will not go into exactly what was ordered but I dare say that there wasn't an unloved plate in the bunch.  Standouts included the huge plate of Salumi that included one of the better pates I have consumed along with some really interesting spicier meaty blasts.  Also, I am very happy that we decided to get the 5 hour pork ragu pasta dish.  It was exactly how I love my ragu... meaty and rich... it was also a good idea to split this at the table as eating a pasta course and protein course here would send you into a food coma that might last until your NEXT birthday.

Let's see, this is getting long... the pork entre is freaking killer.  The gelato was amazing and the cheese course was stinky. All in all I think that this place will be somewhere that I return about every year, it is on the spendy side and there are too many other restaurants that demand my attention throughout the year.

It was such a wonderful night that I hate to bust balls on anyone but our waiter in training was nothing to get excited about... I loved it when the super cute waitress came by from time to time recommending wines and talking about the food.  Not only was she easy on the eyes but she knew her stuff... the other guy would have been great at a funky place in the mission but looked like he lacked fine dining chops.

It was a great night and Perbacco played a huge part in that. Total Party All the Time.

excerpts: (tm Dynamite) to a potential-teaming partner lunch at Perbacco with enthusiasm, having been past it several times and peeked longingly at the menu.
You can tell me all day about your "synergistic services" and "high-quality technical products,
perbacco.author: Gretchen T.
perbacco.review:
I love my job. I have a view of the Bay out my office window, work with super smart and hard-working staff, I ride my bike to work, I reside directly above three pubs, and am across the street from a wine bar and a Peet's Coffee. 

Typically I run along the Embarcadero at lunch, where I can shake off any angst and pound out knotty client or personnel problems. I look forward to my run and only sparingly accept business lunch meetings. But I said heck yes (tm Dynamite) to a potential-teaming partner lunch at Perbacco with enthusiasm, having been past it several times and peeked longingly at the menu. You can tell me all day about your "synergistic services" and "high-quality technical products," so long as I have a plate of house-curred meats and hand-blown mozzarella (don't ask me what that means, it just tasted like fresh-squeezed heaven) in front of me!

I will nod and grin and appear engaged for over an hour if you then bring out the BEST Ligurian tuna salad (Italian version of the nicoise) I have ever set taste buds upon. Prepared with veggies and giant beans (no lettuce even, to distract) and a hunk of delightful, light-colored tuna seared to perfection; I wiped a tear when it was finished. The desserts look great (strawberry panna cotta, oh man), but after eating the slab of mozzarella nearly on my own, I decided to pass and have a cappuccino breve, which was a treat in and of itself. The service is also excellent (and flirty--is this to lend to it's Italian authenticity?!). Yes, folks, this is all in a days work--it does not suck to be me. 

I am also requesting that the green-eyed boy go back with me for a leisurely, decidedly non-work-related dinner so I can try the wine as well!
__________________________________________________

Back for dinner and was not dissapointed! Took all of our server's recommendations (sea bass with quail egg, pork chop, beet greens, Swansons Merlot) and enjoyed every last bite.

excerpts: Last night was night one of my wife's SF Birthday celebration, so we BARTed in, went to the Cornell exhibition at SFMoMA, had a lovely cocktail at Seasons, the Bar at the Four Seasons, and then on to Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Cheesemonger Jeff D.
perbacco.review:
Last night was night one of my wife's SF Birthday celebration, so we BARTed in, went to the Cornell exhibition at SFMoMA, had a lovely cocktail at Seasons, the Bar at the Four Seasons, and then on to Perbacco.   

I had been here only once before, at a wine luncheon in the private room, so couldn't really comment on service, decor or menu.

First the positives:
It's really lovely and refreshing to see that an upscale restaurant is finally letting Hispanic workers do more than deliver bread and refill water.  Hispanic workers run most of the restaurants in the country (look in the kitchens and see who's making the food).  Our server was hispanic, as were most of the runners and servers were in the room.    About time.  Bravo!

The pastas are great - well seasoned, balanced with deep, deep flavors.  Carol had the Papardelle with Short Rib Sauce - wow! - and I had the Agnolotti with Bunny and Truffles - also very good, but they were really Agnolotini or Gnocchi sized, but I'm probably just splitting hares (sic).  

The wine list is very well chosen and fairly priced.   Kerner (a fairly obscure Riesling cross) from the Alto Adige by the glass ?!?!   Well aged Barolos in half bottles?!?!  Nice.   

Now the negatives.  
The room is ugly.  Tables butted up against columns, concrete, brick, shiny surfaces.  The designer for the space should be whipped with a pappardelle!!  And it's ungodly loud.  

Wine service could have been a little more attentive.  The pours were too large for the glassware, and not done with any flair.  Also, Barolo shoudn't be served in Pinot Glasses, but that's minor....

The salad was fine - boring really. But, the lettuces were sopping wet from not having been dried, which made the vinaigrette overbearing. 

The "signature" fritto misto was tired - the lemon slices were too thick to eat, and the batter was waay too dough-y to appreciate the interplay between the succulent rock shrimp and the crunchiness of the green beans.   Needs a rethink.

All in all 3 stars.  We won't be back

excerpts: Because at Perbacco, ordering carefully is the key to dining success.
Perbacco has only been open like a month, so maybe in time every item on the menu will be incredible, but for now there are great heights as well as some duds.
My ideal dinner there would consist of the following: Salumi, most of which they cure themselves -- maybe you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear but you can make wonderful salumi out of it!
Then the freakin' agnolotti, which descends from heaven on a cloud -- everybody else is writing about the agnolotti
so I don't need to reiterate, just get some.
Then two desserts, the gelato trio and the panna cotta -- in particular, the caramel gelato is not to be believed.
perbacco.author: Ian G.
perbacco.review:
The best meal in a long time

So why do I only give four stars for such a great meal?  Because at Perbacco, ordering carefully is the key to dining success.  Perbacco has only been open like a month, so maybe in time every item on the menu will be incredible, but for now there are great heights as well as some duds.  My ideal dinner there would consist of the following: Salumi, most of which they cure themselves -- maybe you can't make a silk purse from a sow's ear but you can make wonderful salumi out of it!  Then the freakin' agnolotti, which descends from heaven on a cloud -- everybody else is writing about the agnolotti so I don't need to reiterate, just get some.  Then two desserts, the gelato trio and the panna cotta -- in particular, the caramel gelato is not to be believed.  Breadsticks throughout the meal, and a glass of vanilla bean mint lemonade, and that is nearly a perfect meal as you will find in SF.

Contrariwise, their risotto was avearge, the skate was dull, the short-rib stracotto was tender but boring, the artichoke soup was nothing special, and the beet greens were just too oily and salty.  Fortunately no one is forcing you to order these dishes!  Just stick to the winners.  The staff was great and the decor is too.  If I drank wine I'd probably praise that as well.

excerpts: Perbacco actually got even pricier now that i see they've removed the sandwich option from the menu.
perbacco.author: dan h.
perbacco.review:
one of the classier and pricier lunch options in the downtown area.  it makes total sense that it's within a few steps of aqua and tadich grill - two other classy and pricey options.  Perbacco actually got even pricier now that i see they've removed the sandwich option from the menu.  that pretty much did away with the only lunch option on the menu for less that $17!  

but anyway, if you have a client or you're just looking to splurge a little, head over here and you can enjoy a stellar plate of pasta or a nice piece of fish or meat - for about 22 bucks.  i had the pappardelle pasta with short rib ragu.  very nice.  interesting flavors and well prepared and presented.  my friend had a glass of wine and the soup and the salad which apparently were excellent.  the service is friendly and good.  the overall decor is really beautiful and thank goodness we got in without a wait.  people must take lunch late downtown SF these days because there was no wait when we arrived at 12:15pm but an hour later, when we left, there was quite a line of people waiting to be seated.  so get there before the rush!

PERBACCO!

perbacco.author: Natasha S.
perbacco.review:
Update: 6-1-07

PERBACCO!  Truly!  WOW!!!!!  One of my absolute FAVORITE places now.  And I owe it all to one of my Absolute Favorite People in the whole wide world (AFP).  Ever eat with someone whose recommendations are consistently flawless?  I'm so lucky!  I have!  And I got to do that at Perbacco!

I KNEW I ordered wrong before (see below).  This time, we relied on the know-how, recommendations and talents of one of the hawtest, friendliest, knowledgeable, talented bartenders around.  His name is *drumroll* SCOTT.  Wait, did I mention he was talented AND hawt?  Scott conjured up some seriously yummy and original cocktails.  And per his suggestions, we got to partake in some of the best food I've had in a  long LONG time.  And for that I am truly truly grateful.  

PERBACCO!

Must Gets: 

-SALUMI MISTI, including a generous portion of pate topped with a fruit compote relish.  Amazing selection of varying flavors and textures.  I can't say I have a favorite, since all of them were excellent and exceedingly fresh.  And so different.  Served with a couple of slices of toasted bread, their famous breadsticks and a few cornichons.  I can't stop thinking about the salumi! 

-CHEESE.  Scott recommended a huge hunk of soft cheese topped with a generous helping of lovely, flavorful black truffle oil.

-PISTACHIO CAKE with a vanilla custard filling and fresh cherry compote.  HOLY MOTHER OF GOD, this is ONE OF THE BEST DESSERTS I'VE EVER EATEN.  The cake and filling were not overly sweet.  The cake itself was amazingly fresh, perfect texture and divine fresh pistachio flavor.  A miracle in a cake.  That's what I'm calling it from now on. 

Perbacco makes you re-think your notions of food and good food.  The dishes are flavorful and inventive and seriously take the dining out experience to The Next Level.  Not many places can achieve that.

PERBACCO!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
12/27/2006 3 star rating

This is a "Nothing was really bad, but . . . ?" aka "I really wanted to like this place" review.  Just OK.  I read rave reviews on this place and was desperate to try their papardelle w/ braised short ribs and the salumi.  So maybe my expectations were too high.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things.  Actually, most of my stars are for the stellar service and accommodation by the hosts and the servers, who really go out of their way for you, i.e., quick, efficient, friendly, helpful but not wanting to join you for dinner service.  Plus the place is rather spacious.  

Cocktails are alright.  We had the pearlini and the rosmarino.  Alright, not stellar.  Not wanting to make you want more :(.

Eats -- hamachi, shrimp (appetizer) and risotto.  Other than the hamachi, which was simple and fresh, the other dishes were not partic. inspired.  I really really want to like this place.  So,  I think I have to go back again and get the short ribs.

Expense aside, it's a greasy, butter-dependent place.  I expect a high-end Nor Cal restaurant to do better than rely on those kinds of crutches. 

I also think that Perbacco is NOT a good place for a business lunch.  It's taken as long as 3 hours to get in and out of there, even when we weren't going for the leisurely route.  More often than not, the wait staff was less than helpful.  I think this place wouldn't do such a brisk business if there were a lot of other good lunch spots in the Fi-Di.

excerpts: I had the Perbacco cocktail to start.
perbacco.author: Sam D.
perbacco.review:
Really loved this place.  Am usually averse to painfully trendy places, but the service was excellent, food was amazing and the cocktails were fab.  
The menu is a little hard to get thru.  It's all typical Italian fare, but they try to make it sound more fancy-schmancy.  But the wait staff was very helpful, and it was soooo worth it to figure out the menu.

I had the Perbacco cocktail to start.  Yum!

Appetizers - heirloom tomato salad was good, but not terribly special.  the rock shrimp was breaded and fried much like calamari - very light breading, etc.

At this point I needed another beverage.  I perused the limited list of wines by the glass.  For an Italian place, they had no Pinot Grigio!!! But the waiter made a great comparable recommendation.

Main course - I got the veal and cabbage ravioli.  If you love any pasta stuffed with any food product as much as I do, you'll be a happy camper.  Yes, the cabbage part sounds bizarre, but in fact, it added the perfect crunch to it. 

Dessert - I'm usually hell bent on having something chocolate, but I'm glad I broadened my horizons.  The warm pistachio cake is possibly the best dessert I've ever had.  Moist cake with just enough nuts to add crunch and cold ice cream to balance the warm cake.

Cheese - yes, this was a dining event based on the number of courses we had.  How can you go wrong with a cheese dish.  The goat cheese was the best one.

excerpts: Perbacco has a great atmosphere.
perbacco.author: Yvette M.
perbacco.review:
Yum.  This place has great food, great service, and a great atmosphere.  I need to go back!

If you feel like being fabulous...Perbacco has a great atmosphere.

excerpts: Once we were seated, we were shown to Perbacco's private dining room--unexpected and very nice!
Floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the kitchen which was a great treat for those interested in behind-the-scenes of a great restaurant.
Not only did the evening impress our sophisticated out-of-towners, but also our more demanding local foodies, and me who probably had the highest expectations for Perbacco which I know well.
Truly one of the great dining experiences I've had in SF--which says a lot!!
perbacco.author: Brent E.
perbacco.review:
Every meal I've had here has been excellent, but I want to relay one particularly great experience.

My family and my wife's family was in town for the Christmas holidays, so we booked a reservation here for 9 people for the day after Christmas--a nice break from our own cooking.

We waited a few minutes at the bar and ordered aperitifs, which were served with wonderful friendliness by the bar staff. Once we were seated, we were shown to Perbacco's private dining room--unexpected and very nice! Floor-to-ceiling windows overlooking the kitchen which was a great treat for those interested in behind-the-scenes of a great restaurant. Our families are a boisterous group, so it was good to have our own space and not worry about interfering with others around us. 

We were served by several people, and each one was professional and a pleasure to interact with. Our families area boisterous lot, with most a type-A personality that can be difficult to deal with, but the staff was incredibly adept at dealing with us throughout the evening. One of my major concerns about taking two families out for dinner alleviated!

We ordered their fantastic salumi platter for the table, and when it arrived we were told that the chef decided to give us two platters that contained everything he offered rather than two platters with duplicate items. Wow. Not only great food, but great consideration in thinking about optimizing our experience. Not surprisingly, we had a great time sampling and comparing everything served--a wonderful start.

We had some real wine connoisseurs at the table, and the sommelier  showed up and dealt with three people simultaneously making demands on his wine list. He handled us adeptly and we ended up with some incredible wines: some that he recommended given our food orders and a description of the kind of wine that we liked, and some varietals that we specifically pointed that we wanted to try.

Most of the table was from out of town but had sophisticated palates, and they were all impressed with what they were served. The dishes were served simultaneously, not easy to do for a table of 9, and really done to perfection. The quality of each dish was truly amazing--one or two great dishes out of nine is expected, but the number of incredible quality dishes was truly amazing. I was so happy that my out-of-town family was ecstatic over the food they were served--as were the in-towners! And I can't overstate the quality of service that we received.

It was my wife's birthday and they brought out a nice dessert for her, but subtle and no crass "happy birthday" celebratory motions that would not have fit with the mood.

Not only did the evening impress our sophisticated out-of-towners, but also our more demanding local foodies, and me who probably had the highest expectations for Perbacco which I know well. Truly one of the great dining experiences I've had in SF--which says a lot!!

excerpts: I had a lovely leisurely lunch with a friend on my day off at Perbacco.
The service was stellar and warm with all the Italian accents floating around.
The space is comfortable, yet upscale--not at all pretentious.
We started with a really nice cheese topped with truffle served with a nice toasted bread.
For my main course I had the papardelle with pork ragu.
It was delicious, and just the right size portion to satisfy my hunger without giving me the stuffed pasta feeling.

excerpts: Does that mean that Perbacco is on par with Taco Bell?
No.
perbacco.author: Hannah Q.
perbacco.review:
Major disappointment.

I haven't reviewed Taco Bell because I don't eat there, but if I did, I'm sure I'd be giving it a max of two stars. Does that mean that Perbacco is on par with Taco Bell? No. I just hold them to different standards, and in both categories ("fast food" and "finer dining"), both establishments fall dramatically short of satisfaction. 

FOOD - not so much. 
1) Salad - I got a salad that had a strong citrus element, with slices of grapefruit, I believe. The fruit slices had lots of internal skin, meaning that I had to pick at it and rip is apart to make it satisfactorily edible, and there were SEEDS left in it, which, in my book, is inexcusable. Maybe that's just my tastes, but.. you're a restaurant that's attempting to create good food and give it a decent presentation... don't lay it out so that your customers have to finish the basic prep work for you when the food hits the table. 

2) Main - buckwheat pasta
I ordered a pasta dish that normally comes with prosciutto, but  had them skip the ham. It tasted good, but came with slices of potato (??!??!?@??!?) in it. I'm sorry, but if I'm ordering a CARB-BASED entree, I really don't need extra starches tossed in. It made no sense. 

CHOICES - 
As I recall, there was literally ONE vegetarian option on the menu for entrees and most of the desserts were laden with alcohol, which I detest. Unfortunately, you couldn't request an alcohol-free version, since it was cooked in. 

PALATE DOMINATION
I think what left the worst impression on me, regarding the food, was that the menu seemed dominated by one palate that was very particular - really rustic meat oriented. There were plenty of choices on the menu, but they all seemed to come from the same vein of culinary style, one that, as a pregnant woman, I clash with. Even the fish was unworkable for me at the moment. It seemed like the head chef created this menu to please his or her whims, without considering the varied tastes of their clientle.

The customers shouldn't have to hunt the menu to find what they can "settle" with and then have to have modified in the kitchen. Ideally, a good menu should offer a few options for a variety of types of palates. 

ATMOSPHERE: 
1. UNBELIEVABLE NOISY - great for after work drinks and apps, wind-down socialization. Horrendous if you want to have actual conversation at your table. 

2. CIGARETTE SMOKE - We were seated on the third floor, yet somehow cigarette smoke wafted up and emanated around the dining room for a good 20 minutes. Given the location of the front door versus the staff area in the basement, I'm thinking it's a lot more likely the smoke came from a staff member having a smoke break, rather than someone out front. The bottom line is that a staff member on the third floor should have noticed and immediately had the situation addressed. 

SERVICE
This is a pet peeve... If I'm eating at a relatively fine-dining location, I want my service to be unnoticeable.*** The ideal is minimal interaction with the table, getting orders, etc, and then seamlessly refilling waters, beverages, delivering food, removing empty plates in a way that is unremarkable. 

Sadly, our waitress was of the "hey folks, welcome to my show" mentality, so we had constant interruptions from her that were wholly unnecessary - interrupting us in mid-sentence to inquire if we wanted more to drink, if we were DONE with our food that we were still eating, etc. Ridiculous. Also, it was all delivered with an overly engaging, disruptive and peppy attitude, like she was inserting herself into our dinner company and trying to join our table. 

The rest of the staff was equally bad - the busboys literally hovered near the table to try to swoop in the moment a fork was set down. 

They seemed to be rushing us to turn the table, but we were by no means lingering and wasting time. 

Bottom line - major disappointment. I will NOT be going back, even if someone else is footing the bill. 

***I worked for many years as a waitress in a variety of restaurants, from fine dining to pizza joints. As a waitress, I enjoy the chit-chat and casual attitude of slinging pizza, but I also deeply appreciate appropriate deference in a nicer establishment.

excerpts: Calling Perbacco a day ahead for reservations will most likely end with a late, late dinner and after eating here last week, I understand the reason why.

perbacco.author: Jason A.
perbacco.review:
Calling Perbacco a day ahead for reservations will most likely end with a late, late dinner and after eating here last week, I understand the reason why.  

Located two doors down from some stiff competition, Aqua, they follow the new wave of SF restaurants where the interior is a mix of modern and old San Francisco.  The service is accommodating as expected from a restaurant of this caliber and the setting is a little loud, but still intimate for those couples out there.  

The food is California Italian cuisine with seafood being the standout and a well prepared Pork Chop.  Try not to miss the grilled squid appetizer that is paired up with beans and drizzled with olive oil.  Also the Tuna Crudo is a nice light and refreshing way to start your dinner with glasses of champagne of course!  If you're a corn lover like me, the side of corn is a perfect compliment to any dish, especially the pork chop that is well flavored and is enjoyable to the last bite.  Desserts are spectacular, especially the Nuvola (a macaroon filled with lemon curd surrounded by raspberries).

Perbacco is a wonderful addition to the San Francisco dining landscape, bringing dishes that will tease you enough to come back for more.
