excerpts: I believe in second chances and I errored with Perbacco.
My first visit was after an exhausting day's work with girlfriends.
We had just finished a long, food-less seminar and arrived for dinner hungry.
We placed our order and - needless to say - devoured our breadsticks while waiting for our first course.
We asked for more and were given a cold, hard stare like we asked for the waiter's first-born.
perbacco.author: Kelli F.
perbacco.review:
I believe in second chances and I errored with Perbacco.  My first visit was after an exhausting day's work with girlfriends.  We had just finished a long, food-less seminar and arrived for dinner hungry.  We placed our order and - needless to say - devoured our breadsticks while waiting for our first course.  We asked for more and were given a cold, hard stare like we asked for the waiter's first-born.  Although a decent meal, the service was steely cold and unfriendly that night.  

So I returned for the cocktail hour with a business colleague on a Monday.  I walked in and inquired where I could sit (bar, dining area, etc.?).  The hostess gave me the meanest look ever, as if I had interrupted her busy afternoon.  I made an attempt engage her and she wouldn't "lighten-up".  Again, I felt like I was stealing her first-born child.  Disappointment is putting it lightly.  Management needs to work towards improving the staff quality and let me remind them - the customer comes first.

excerpts: My dining experience at Perbacco was good, not poor nor outstanding, but merely good.
Like any other S.F. restaurant at it's level, Perbacco has the requisite hostess, decor, tablecloths, silverware and attentive waiter with an accent.
perbacco.author: Jenny K.
perbacco.review:
My dining experience at Perbacco was good, not poor nor outstanding, but merely good.

Like any other S.F. restaurant at it's level, Perbacco has the requisite hostess, decor, tablecloths, silverware and attentive waiter with an accent.  You can check those off the list.

Now, for the food:

1. (appetizer) Yellowfin Tuna Crudo - tasty but my dining companion found a bone in his piece.  Erh, the only explanation I could come up with was I don't recall Italians being known as sushi chefs.  It was also a bit fishy.  The good thing about this dish is the taste and texture of combining watermelon cubes with the fennel and tomato.  Amazingly inventive!

2. (entree) Garganelli - excellent flavor and juicy rabbit meat.  Definitely a winner among the risottos.

3. (entree) Beef Short Rib Stracotto - tender and flavorful but could have used a bit more flavor.  The mushrooms were a great touch but I didn't understand the purpose of having peas mixed in.  Perhaps for color?

4. (dessert) Red Plum Crostata - the crust was a bit soggy but the plum made a great contrast to the basil gelato.  The basil is potent.  Take small bites.

Overall, this is a nice restaurant for little occasions.  Despite what you might think walking in, this is a fairly large restaurant.  For a place where I was hoping to catch a casual dinner, it was a bit extravagant.  However, the prices are very reasonable for the quality and they have a good Italian wine selection to pair with the food.  The crowd's a bit stuffy (i.e. lots of suits whose hawk eyes follow any females walking through the room...ladies, if you're looking for that sugar daddy...) but the bar area's great to get some quick after work drinks and appetizers.

Delfina was mentioned during the meal. Yep, next time, Delfina.

excerpts: And frankly, Perbacco's entrees are its weakest link.

The pork shoulder al latte turned out to be an unappetizingly symmetrical chunk of pig --- plated like Lean Cuisine on a small oval dish --- that lacked the cut-it-with-a-fork tenderness that's the hallmark this traditionally braised dish.
And again, the sides were laughably meager.
Sadly, we doubt we'll take another stab at dinner at Perbacco.
We can envision returning for a plate of salumi at the bar, alongside one of their well-made cocktails... especially the Rosmarino.
And certainly, if friends suggested we meet at Perbacco, we wouldn't decline.

But for the price --- dinner both times hovered near the $200 mark for a full complement of food but minus any blow-out wines or other additions --- we can't afford the gamble of another hit-and-miss meal.
perbacco.author: anita c.
perbacco.review:
Our initial visit left us disappointed but convinced that the food was worthy if you steered clear of so-so main courses in favor of pastas. We decided that the colossally amateurish service we experienced was what prevented us from having the sort of night that we'd gush about. But after a second visit with significantly better service but much worse food, we just can't join the chorus of praise.

All through both meals, we noticed, over and over again, problems of size and intensity. Too much, not enough, too much, not enough... like some practical joke played by the kitchen at our expense.

First, the overkill: On our initial visit, we loved the burrata appetizer, but quickly tired of its unctuous, truffled intensity. A strongly flavored salad was another tastebud-killer: All the components hung together well, but by the time he was halfway through, the richness of chestnut honey, gorgonzola, and hazelnuts was just exhausting. On our return trip, a beet-and-arugula salad offered just too much of the same flavors, over and over, without relief.

Next, the underwhelming flavors: Although the feta-like Castelmagno cheese on that same beet-and-arugula salad provided too much salt, the beets themselves were nearly flavorless. On our second visit, a pasta didn't appear to have any salt in the dough, and had been dressed with unsalted butter. A cauliflower soup was perfectly velvety but didn't actually taste like cauliflower.

And then, unpredictable portions: We loved the tajarin (hand-cut tagliatelle) with pork-and-porcini sugo as a middle course on our first visit, but an entre portion that we ordered on our second visit was only a smidge larger. Similarly, the sides accompanying all three main courses we ordered (over the course of 2 visits) were so skimpy that you wished the chef would just offer his entrees a la carte and be done with it.

And frankly, Perbacco's entrees are its weakest link. The pork shoulder al latte turned out to be an unappetizingly symmetrical chunk of pig --- plated like Lean Cuisine on a small oval dish --- that lacked the cut-it-with-a-fork tenderness that's the hallmark this traditionally braised dish. And again, the sides were laughably meager. (Could there be anything cheaper than corn mush and cabbage?)

Both times we opted for gelato for dessert. Presented in adorable ceramic dishes made to look like partially crushed Dixie cups, the flavors ran the gamut from delightful (fleur de sel caramel) to overwhelmingly unpleasant (pistachio).

Sadly, we doubt we'll take another stab at dinner at Perbacco. We can envision returning for a plate of salumi at the bar, alongside one of their well-made cocktails... especially the Rosmarino. And certainly, if friends suggested we meet at Perbacco, we wouldn't decline. But for the price --- dinner both times hovered near the $200 mark for a full complement of food but minus any blow-out wines or other additions --- we can't afford the gamble of another hit-and-miss meal.

excerpts: I think I'll take him to lunch at Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Christine T.
perbacco.review:
My new favorite restaurant.  LOVE that it is so close to work.  

I dream about their Tagliatelle w/ 5-Hr pork sugo...  mmmmm....!  Heaven on a plate!  Can it get better than this?!  Um, I don't think so!  (Well, certainly not at these prices!)

The bread stick thingies are SO good!  Please just leave them at the table and keep bringing us back some more!

I need another excuse to go back...  and soon!  ooohhh..  I need to "pay" my tax guy....  I think I'll take him to lunch at Perbacco!

excerpts: Perbacco is definitely not a peanut shells kind of place, and its nice to be spoiled sometimes!
perbacco.author: Jessica R.
perbacco.review:
I have been here for various work lunches, and am impressed by the food and the decor. Not being "wine'd and dine'd" much outside of work, this place lets me get my "high maintenance fix" with out having to admit it to my friends.  

The cured meat plate is great, their grilled chicken tasty, and the caramel gellato with sea salt is my version of "heaven." Service is good, they hand write out a "Happy Birthday" card to the customer if you tell them ahead of time, and write out in chocolate sauce on a dessert plate! 

I can't review the upstairs seating area, but if you have a large party you should definitely reserve the "chef's table" I tried too for a lunch we had on Thursday, but the hostess didn't have 5 people confirmed on the reservation and there for gave the table (that I specifically requested) away to another party (hence 4 stars- your screw up should not mean I look dumb to my colleagues). 

I am not a high maintenance girl... sure I would love to be taken out to a nice restaurant on a date, but peanut shells on the floor are okay by me!  Perbacco is definitely not a peanut shells kind of place, and its nice to be spoiled sometimes! :)

excerpts: I know Perbacco is richly historic, but I was not impressed.
There are so many fabulous places to visit other than here, to say the least.
perbacco.author: Gina G.
perbacco.review: I know Perbacco is richly historic, but I was not impressed. There are so many fabulous places to visit other than here, to say the least.

excerpts: Perbacco has an excellent wine menu and they go to town on their imported (DOP) Italian cheese's --
I cannot get enough of their Burratta (Buffalo) cheese.
perbacco.author: Colleen B.
perbacco.review:
4 and 1/2 stars. This is an excellent place to dine in the heart of the financial district, and lucky for me -- right around the corner from work! The atmosphere is warm, inviting and sophisticated and the service is attentive and friendly. 

I have dined here on many occasions and always enjoy my meal. Today I had braised beef with polenta and cipolini onions, it was cooked to freaking perfection. I also shared a butterscotch pudding with my dining companion - it was *eyes roll to back of head* good. 

Perbacco has an excellent wine menu and they go to town on their imported (DOP) Italian cheese's -- I cannot get enough of their Burratta (Buffalo) cheese.

excerpts: , Perbacco is the perfect downtown spot for after dinner drinks, a client lunch, or dinner with friends.
perbacco.author: Melissa W.
perbacco.review:
Everything is good here, but the real fun lies in the Salumi.

After we received a personal tour of the 'meat locker', I was even more intrigued by the house cured meats and had to try each one. 
We found the favorite to be the Salumi Misti - since it's a sample of everything it pretty much covers it.
And the Hamachi Crudo - should not be missed.

A slam dunk since opening, Perbacco is the perfect downtown spot for after dinner drinks, a client lunch, or dinner with friends. Chef Terje knows his stuff...so you can't really go wrong no matter what you order.

Did I forget to  mention the seamless design by CCS?

excerpts: Perbacco is still quite trendy, and the bar can get a little intense on weekend nights.
If you want a quiet place to take a close friend, this isn't it.
I've been to Perbacco previously but wasn't familiar with the menu of the cuisine of Piedmont / Liguria.
This time I ordered what people suggested to me and found the whole dining experience absolutely amazing.
Also the service was excellent and the wait staff very well informed about the menu.
I would say that this is one of the best restaurants in the City.
perbacco.author: Tony G.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is still quite trendy, and the bar can get a little intense on weekend nights. If you want a quiet place to take a close friend, this isn't it. It is also somewhat expensive. 

HOWEVER if you know what to order and don't mind the noisy atmosphere, the food here is truly wonderful and immensely satisfying. Like many of the other reviewers, I would recommend the salumi plate as a first course.  My guest and I had the the burrata cheese which was distinctive. For the main course we had the beef short rib stracotto and maiale al latte (braised pork shoulder) which were both perfect. It's hard to describe them in any other way. We also had the recommended Italian wines which were married well with our meal. 

I've been to Perbacco previously but wasn't familiar with the menu of the cuisine of Piedmont / Liguria. This time I ordered what people suggested to me and found the whole dining experience absolutely amazing. Also the service was excellent and the wait staff very well informed about the menu. I would say that this is one of the best restaurants in the City.

excerpts: I highly recommend Perbacco.
The chef is a genius!
perbacco.author: Terri V.
perbacco.review:
Seeing less than 4 star reviews surprises me because first time was a charm for me. Chic two story setting with a mezzanine overlooking  the spacious modern beautiful bar scattered with tables adorned with white clothes. Lovely wine list. Incredible Piemonte Northern Italian specialties. 
We began with the raddicchio & chicory salad with hard-boiled egg. Then enjoyed several vegetable sides including brown buttered brussel sprouts with capers and shallots, fingerling potatoes in rosemary and garlic.  A fascinating unique albacore tuna ragu on large pasta tubes both were delicious. I had a difficult choice between the 5 hour pork sugo or the short rib ragu on papparadella and decided on the latter. Juicy, tender and succulent short rib in a beautiful ragu and homemade papparadella. Paradisio!...or however they say it in Italian!
I highly recommend Perbacco. The chef is a genius!

excerpts: Perbacco is still learning about this message.
Over a month ago I made a reservation for our wine tasting group to go to Perbacco, we heard good things about their food and wanted to taste Chianti Classico's.
When making the reservation for our group of 6, I explained to the hostess that we would be bringing 6 bottles of wine and would likely buy one or two.
She explained that there was 20 dollar corkage and a 2 bottle limit.
I told her this was a no go
and she paused and said we will work it out for you.
That afternoon I received a phone call from Umberto, the owner of Perbacco who apologized for what happened.
He asked if there was anything they could do to make up for the situation, he was very professional and respectful, and I appreciated that.
I said no, we had moved on.
I am sure that the sommelier at Perbacco has great wine knowledge and is a good person
but he needs to realize that when a commitment is made to a customer, it must be kept, not challenged.
Frankly, the host should never have transferred the call to him in the first place.
perbacco.author: Jules K.
perbacco.review:
This is a long story that starts with frustration and ends well.

I read that restaurants are having a hard time attracting business and are working hard to make their customers happy.  Perbacco is still learning about this message.

Over a month ago I made a reservation for our wine tasting group to go to Perbacco, we heard good things about their food and wanted to taste Chianti Classico's.  When making the reservation for our group of 6, I explained to the hostess that we would be bringing 6 bottles of wine and would likely buy one or two.  She explained that there was 20 dollar corkage and a 2 bottle limit.  I told her this was a no go and she paused and said we will work it out for you.  I told her great and the group was ready to go tomorrow.

So today I get a call from the host, he says there is a note here that you want to bring 6 bottles; we have a 2 bottle limit.  So I explain my conversation.  Instead of saying OK, he says, you have to talk the sommelier.

The sommelier got on the phone after a long hold and told me there was  a 2 bottle limit.  I told him what happened.  He told me OK, if we made a mistake then we will waive the policy but added that he wants to sell his wine to his customers and let me know that he was not happy about our coming with our bottles.  I even asked him to come over that evening and share a glass with us and sell us a Chianti of theirs and he blew me off.  He made it clear that I had to convince him to let us into their restaurant.

The more i thought about it after I hung up the more irritated I became.  And then I picked up the NY Times dining section (does anyone else miss the Chron food section on Weds?) and there was an article on how restaurants are becoming more hospitable to their clients!  Here is a link:  http://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/04/dining/04note.html?_r=1&ref=dining

That did it,  I cancelled and will stay in the East Bay.  And when I callled to cancel they didn't really seem to care.  Hope their business holds up, they are not working to attract new customers in these funky times and that does not make sense.  Not to mention blowing off a 600 dollar check.

That afternoon I received a phone call from Umberto, the owner of Perbacco who apologized for what happened.  He asked if there was anything they could do to make up for the situation, he was very professional and respectful, and I appreciated that.  I said no, we had moved on.  He has emailed me as well.

That same evening I attended a great panel discussion on the life of MFK Fisher  and it reminded me once again that the love of food and company and wine are great passions that drive our lives. She was also someone who told it as like it is.

I am sure that the sommelier at Perbacco has great wine knowledge and is a good person but he needs to realize that when a commitment is made to a customer, it must be kept, not challenged. Frankly, the host should never have transferred the call to him in the first place. That is what customer service is about, keeping your promises and empowering your staff.

And a final note.  The next evening the owner, who knew where we would be eating in the East Bay after our conversation, went out of his way to buy us a bottle of Proseco before our meal.   That was exceptional and for that alone, the rating goes to a hopeful two stars.

excerpts: I've been remiss in not writing a review of Perbacco despite the fact that it is my FIRST-choice FiDi restaurant for client lunches, networking lunches, and sneaking-away-from-my-desk-for-a-treat lunches HANDS DOWN.

It cracks me up that so many well-suited biznessfolks are always milling around the entrance during the weekday lunch-hour, and the fact that many of them are turned away because, due to the quality of its service and food, tables at Perbacco are hard-won without a reservation beforehand.
It's hard to have 5 stars on every occasion, but that's been my experience with Perbacco.
Highly recommended!
perbacco.author: wildhippychile d.
perbacco.review:
I've been remiss in not writing a review of Perbacco despite the fact that it is my FIRST-choice FiDi restaurant for client lunches, networking lunches, and sneaking-away-from-my-desk-for-a-treat lunches HANDS DOWN. It cracks me up that so many well-suited biznessfolks are always milling around the entrance during the weekday lunch-hour, and the fact that many of them are turned away because, due to the quality of its service and food, tables at Perbacco are hard-won without a reservation beforehand. Which is why I ALWAYS remember to make a reservation, because it's not to be missed.

They've added a few new delicious menu items as of this week (10/28/09), and may I say that if you have ANY interest in risotto, you should try the new risotto with braised ox-tails entree! It was so flavorful, rich and creamy, and thankfully, my lunch companion and I split the dish because it was a huge portion. I also thoroughly enjoy the cool red and yellow beet salad appetizer, which they've just re-vamped with a new plating drizzled with (what I believe is) cilantro-infused oil, tossed with lovely pieces of fennel, and sprinkled with a creamy bits of goat cheese.

5-stars, and I go often, people. It's hard to have 5 stars on every occasion, but that's been my experience with Perbacco. Highly recommended!

excerpts: Perbacco for me is a 5-star restaurant but the service makes the experience a 4-star.
I look at several items with particular focus 1) ingredients 2) preparation 3) plating 4) environment 5) service and 6) wine list.
perbacco.author: Jaime Patricio M.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco for me is a 5-star restaurant but the service makes the experience a 4-star.   I look at several items with particular focus 1) ingredients 2) preparation 3) plating 4) environment 5) service and 6) wine list.   When these items are not working together the experience is un-even.  

  
The service element was off from the beginning.  When I arrived I checked in with the host to my departure I was completely surprised and disappointed.  Disappointed with the hosts - the first host asked me to "relax" in a very crowded bar.  There was no where for me to "relax."  Another host queries if I have been helped; I replied yes and then I am asked to check in again.  This was a sign of what was to come.

  
The wait staff was less than friendly--even chilly.  Hardly excited about menu; was not willing to allow me to see which wine I would like the best by agreeing to my request for a splash.  When I get a splash I am always satisfied with my choice.  We were having a hard time deciding what to eat; little guidance or suggestions were made.  

  
The food was quite different from the service.  The food was beautifully executed such an opposite experience to the service.  We began with the Ahi Tuna--the Ahi was perfectly fresh; even the olive oil was superb; gently drizzled; in my opinion it is easy to over use olive oil--that olive oil just a touch of lemon--so little of a touch that you may not detect it.  The other first plate was a salt cod fritti - four large spheres of slightly spiced salt  cod--a completely abundant dish.

  
My stripped sea bass was a beautiful masterpiece of green abundance; pieces of olive complemented the sea bass.  There two large slices of potato--I was completely filled but the potatoes were so compelling.  When I am full I stop; I kept going and enjoyed each morsel as if I would never eat these potatoes again.

  
The food portion, even by, San Francisco standards were generous I had only wished my pour of wine was as generous.  Over all I will go back even in spite of the service.

excerpts: Just went for a standard "business lunch" at Perbacco.
perbacco.author: John H.
perbacco.review:
Really...after 103 reviews, do you need another??

Just went for a standard "business lunch" at Perbacco. I recently read Josh Sen's review in San Francisco Magazine, so was interested in going. 

The highlight was the bread sticks....oh so addictive. I think I had a Ligurian fish soup next but, can't say for sure. Okay, that's too harsh. It was pretty good and I'm a sucker for anything that says aioli in the description. I had the lamb sugo pasta with classic" mint and peas.  Watching my weight sore, I skipped dessert and slammed down a double espresso and admired the art on the walls before stepping out into the dreary rain.

This is a competent restaurant built for a bustling business lunch crowd. Not as pricey as Aqua next door...and not as good, but good enough and a clear upgrade from the Gold Coast which was there before.

excerpts: Lunch with a client led me to Perbacco for the first time.
I wouldn't recommend it for a business lunch-
we were there for over 2 hours (a shared app and entrees only) and there is a loud din.
Hence, Perbacco looses one star.
perbacco.author: Jenni D.
perbacco.review:
Lunch with a client led me to Perbacco for the first time.  I wouldn't recommend it for a business lunch- we were there for over 2 hours (a shared app and entrees only) and there is a loud din.  Hence, Perbacco looses one star. 

Everything else was excellent. The service, while slow, was friendly and informative. The atmosphere is modern and comfortable. We started with the grilled octopus salad. They divided it neatly into two portions without being prompted... very much appreciated. The octopus was tender while firm and had a delicious marinade that was both tangy and spicy.  I'd go back just for this dish.  For entree I chose the goat cheese gnocchi. The lunch portion was very generous. The gnocchi were soft but not at all gummy. The goat cheese infused every bite and left a rich, salty flavor in my mouth. The presentation was beautiful also. Another winner. While I did not glance at the wine list (business lunch!) I'm convinced they have excellent wine service, as I saw a somellier taking care of another group a few tables away.

excerpts: A strangely hard texture.. frustratingly difficult to eat and not helping my opinion of Perbacco.
perbacco.author: M P.
perbacco.review:
With really no expectations coming in, I was pretty disappointed.  For a Saturday night, the restaurant was deserted.  Waiters were standing around chatting because they didn't have enough people to wait on.  Restaurant has 2 stories with different atmospheres - upstairs is a bit more private, downstairs is open and has a bar.  

They serve breadsticks and a olive-based salsa as you are looking at the menu.  I started with the bean soup, which was nothing special.  Tasted like something you could get at Pancho Villa.  I had a taste of the Bartlett Pear Salad, which was a better appetizer option but still somewhat bland.  I had the Monkfish for my main course, and it was horrendous - unpleasant rubbery texture, in a tomato-based sause.  The Risotto was much better.  In an effort to wash the taste of my meal away, I ordered a desert  -- the Lemon Semifreddo.  A strangely hard texture.. frustratingly difficult to eat and not helping my opinion of Perbacco.  My date's Panna Cotta was much better.  

Maybe it was a series of bad choices on my part, but maybe not.  I don't think I would come back here unless they completely re-vamped the menu.

excerpts: Earlier this week, I had the pleasure of visitng Perbacco for the first time.
I have heard very good things and looked forward to this evening.
The culinary team of Perbacco did a fantastic job of bringing her vision to  our plate.
Vegetable dishes were executed beautifully.
perbacco.author: Emanuel B.
perbacco.review:
Earlier this week, I had the pleasure of visitng Perbacco for the first time.  I have heard very good things and looked forward to this evening.  This was a special event in the restaurant as it was an Italian interpretation of a traditional Jewish feast for Passover.  

First, the dining room- sleek and stylish though quite loud.

Second, the service- first rate.  Our server was attentive and thoughtful touching our table in just the right away.

Now, the food- this was a temporary menu developed by Joyce Goldstein who formerly operated Square One.  The culinary team of Perbacco did a fantastic job of bringing her vision to  our plate.  Vegetable dishes were executed beautifully.  We also had great veal and lamb stew as our main courses- also beautifully executed.

I enjoyed the experience and would consider going back.

excerpts:
but my friend really liked it
Perbacco - very refreshing, citrus vodka with a splash of amaretto
House

champagne - solid
Wine
I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone in FiDi!
perbacco.author: Susan L.
perbacco.review:
This is a solid 4.5 star restaurant, bumping up to 5 because it's Friday. The entire experience was flawless from start to finish. We went an hour before our reservation to grab drinks at the bar. While the bar was PACKED, the bartender saw me squeezing my way towards him and patiently waited. 

Drinks:
Mojito - I hate mint but my friend really liked it
Perbacco - very refreshing, citrus vodka with a splash of amaretto
House champagne - solid
Wine - we really enjoyed our bottle of Dama Montelpulciano and it was cheap!

At 7pm on the dot, our table was ready for us. The restaurant gets pretty loud, which is where they lose the half star. We were upstairs where I thought it would be quieter, but there was a private party in the room behind us and you could still hear the riff raff from the bar. 

Food:
Breadsticks w/ pesto - awesome!
Bread - fresh!
Fritto rock shrimp starter - good, wide assortment of freshly fried stuff, great for sharing
Pappardelle - awesome flavor, homemade pasta was perfectly done and made the dish!
Pork chop - thick, meaty, and juicy
Tajarin - again, homemade pasta melted in your mouth! simple, tasty.

The dishes were just the right size, well for me anyways. At first glance, you wonder if there's enough pasta but by the end, you feel great. Service was impeccable and our waitress gave us great recommendations. I thought the prices were extremely reasonable - with appetizer, pasta, and bottle of wine, we all came out under $40 each. I would highly recommend Perbacco to anyone in FiDi!

excerpts: Perbacco is a stylish restaurant, although somehow more Manhattan than San Francisco in its style.
Its relatively narrow entranceway belies the large dining room that unfolds over two levels towards the back of the long space that it occupies.
The front of the restaurant is dominated by a long, classic cocktail bar, where dinner is also served either at the bar itself or in one of the booths directly opposite.
The main seating areas - a large, open ground floor space with a mezzanine overhang - lie beyond the bar area.
The cheese board is worth the visit by itself, and Perbacco boasts an excellent list of predominantly Italian wine.
The well-dressed, convivial proprietor greeted diners with warmth
and (on this evidence, justified) pride.
A great place - we'll be back!
perbacco.author: Dom B.
perbacco.review:
This gem was recommended to us by numerous people who've experienced its delights over the last few years.  We checked it out on a Friday evening in spring, when it buzzed with contented diners, most of whom - to my surprise - didn't look like they'd just left the office. 

Perbacco is a stylish restaurant, although somehow more Manhattan than San Francisco in its style.  Its relatively narrow entranceway belies the large dining room that unfolds over two levels towards the back of the long space that it occupies.  The front of the restaurant is dominated by a long, classic cocktail bar, where dinner is also served either at the bar itself or in one of the booths directly opposite.  The main seating areas - a large, open ground floor space with a mezzanine overhang - lie beyond the bar area.  The space has a high ceiling, with a tall exposed brick wall (another Manhattanesque touch) opposite the mezzanine level.  

It's deceptively big, with the main section of tables tucked away under the mezzanine, out of the view of the bar area.  The conversation buzzes, but the space seems neither noisy nor crowded.  If I have one criticism of this beautifully designed space, it's that there are a few support pillars that obstruct the tables that are close to them.  Our - otherwise nice - table for two was next to one of them and it was a bit of an encumbrance both to the dining experience and the service.  But no big deal.

The food is mostly excellent - standard rustic Italian fare with lots of enticing, ingredients-driven dishes.  We split a fritto misto to start with - a delicious mix of shrimp with fried olives, fennel and beans, before moving onto pasta.  The Tajarin with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms was delicious and perfectly sized.  The parpadelle with short rib ragu and grated horseradish didn't quite deliver - the horseradish slightly overpowering the ragu.  The cheese board is worth the visit by itself, and Perbacco boasts an excellent list of predominantly Italian wine.  The well-dressed, convivial proprietor greeted diners with warmth and (on this evidence, justified) pride.  A great place - we'll be back!

excerpts: Because I like pasta so much and have really enjoyed Perbacco's in particular, I haven't sample much in the way of main-course meats, and I've been too full for dessert as well.
perbacco.author: Tara M.
perbacco.review:
Overall, very good, despite a few issues. I've been here twice so far, and the food is quite good, the service mostly so, and the ambiance is pleasant.

On our first visit, we were seated promptly, but on our second visit, we had to wait for a good 20 minutes beyond our reservation time for our table for four -- yikes. Not so good. Our waiter on our first visit was a man who displayed the essence of professionalism; on our second visit, we were helped by an Italian woman who, while not super-polished, was lively and opinionated and made us chuckle (not necessarily a bad thing). She seemed to know her wine, too. Still, a little less levity, a little more gravity would've been nice.

Appetizers are big, particularly the fritto misto and the grilled calamari, and they're excellent. Mmm, squid. The mixed salumi plate is fun, even if you're not a cured meat aficionado -- I enjoyed tasting the different types of salami, prosciutto, etc. Pastas are top-notch, too, although there's an unfortunate tendency for noodles to clump together. This is somewhat understandable with the tajarin since the noodles are so thin, but it's not excusable with the wide papardelle. Because I like pasta so much and have really enjoyed Perbacco's in particular, I haven't sample much in the way of main-course meats, and I've been too full for dessert as well.

I'll be back -- the food is wonderful. I wouldn't rate this place above Delfina, as I've heard some might, but it's a go-to option. They need to work on de-clumping the admittedly tasty pasta.

excerpts: 6 of us co-workers plus 1 new possible new hire went to Perbacco for lunch to get to know each other a bit.
perbacco.author: Jamie W.
perbacco.review:
6 of us co-workers plus 1 new possible new hire went to Perbacco for lunch to get to know each other a bit. 

The menu was a bit of a challenge to figure out - words not in my vocabulary had me asking the very knowledgable and friendly waiter about what this and that was.  I settled on a garden salad and a grilled ham with salsa verde and some kinda veggie as my meal.  The lamb was excellent - very good flavoring.  The salad ... was a salad (shrug).

The dessert was the most memorable item I ordered. It was a pear and apple bread pudding with some fresh whipped cream on the side.  Yummmmmmmmy!!!!  It was very tasty!!!  If I could just come here for a dessert after a movie at the Embarcadero, it'd be just right.

excerpts: I wanted to come back and update my review for Perbacco.
I went back to this restaurant last night (2/24/2007) and wanted to tell you that the place is bustling and the food is still amazing.
I also have to say that the one negative I had listed in my previous review is no longer there.
In the previous review, I had mentioned that the lighting was too bright for a dinner experience.
Well, not only did I notice that the lighting was 100% better
but Umberto, one of the 2 owners of the restaurant spoke to our table and told me that the restaurant's first few weeks had an issue with the dimmers not being installed.
perbacco.author: Ingrid P.
perbacco.review:
***UPDATED*** - 2/25/2007
I wanted to come back and update my review for Perbacco.  I went back to this restaurant last night (2/24/2007) and wanted to tell you that the place is bustling and the food is still amazing.  I also have to say that the one negative I had listed in my previous review is no longer there.  In the previous review, I had mentioned that the lighting was too bright for a dinner experience. Well, not only did I notice that the lighting was 100% better but Umberto, one of the 2 owners of the restaurant spoke to our table and told me that the restaurant's first few weeks had an issue with the dimmers not being installed.  Once the dimmers were installed, the lighting was corrected.

As for food, last night I had the Burrata Cheese with arugula and black truffle - amazing!  The Beef Short Ribs with Celery Puree - tender and smooth, and a chocolate torte with caramel sauce and hazelnuts - divine.  

10/31/2006We had dinner here 2 days after it opened and it was great.  The food and service was truly well thought out.  Our waiter was attentive and courteous and the food was sublime.  Their wine list is amazing - great Italian section.

We started with a red wine from the Langhe region of Italy - very good.  For appetizers, we had the Prosciutto san danieli and the crudo viteloni (spelling?).  The crudo (Veal tartar basically) and the prosciutto melted in our mouths.  The we split the sirloin with a reduced sauce made from marrow - it was great.  We ended with the chocolate tart - also very good.

The only thing that I did not like was the lighting in the place.  I prefer more intimate lighting for dinner and this restaurant was all lit up - a bit too bright for me.  

Overall - it was a wonderful dining experience.

excerpts: It really should be simple not to over-stir a classic cocktail like the Martinez, especially at a place like Perbacco.
I left disappointed in that respect, however, the service was great
and so was the food
, so ill be back to see if they've fixed this Martinez situation...
perbacco.author: Zack H.
perbacco.review: Let me start by saying that the food would probably have garnered four stars but the cocktail I had was 2 stars at best and seeing as how I had 2 of each, Ill split the difference with 3 stars for the review.  My Martinez (which I ordered twice in hopes of it improving) was beaten so badly it was hardly recognizable on both occasions.  It really should be simple not to over-stir a classic cocktail like the Martinez, especially at a place like Perbacco.  I left disappointed in that respect, however, the service was great and so was the food, so ill be back to see if they've fixed this Martinez situation...

excerpts: Run do not walk to Perbacco - but wise to check if you can get a ressie.
Not always easy.
There is a reason why they are always packed.
It is delicious, tasteful and fresh - each ingredient can be tasted -
is not overdone - is not underdone - everything is made with thoughtfulness.
I've been here several times - maybe 10 since they opened in
Oct. Finally, I brought my husband - who hails from Torino - and is very very very picky about Italian restaurants in the U.S. and
S.F. He loved it.
Found the food to be fresh, perfectly flavored and authentic.
He even remarked that many of the ingredients that were utilized tasted better here than in Italy.
Could be. . .
perbacco.author: laura p.
perbacco.review:
Run do not walk to Perbacco - but wise to check if you can get a ressie. Not always easy. There is a reason why they are always packed. It is delicious, tasteful and fresh - each ingredient can be tasted - is not overdone - is not underdone - everything is made with thoughtfulness. 
I've been here several times - maybe 10 since they opened in Oct. Finally, I brought my husband - who hails from Torino - and is very very very picky about Italian restaurants in the U.S. and S.F. He loved it. Found the food to be fresh, perfectly flavored and authentic. He even remarked that many of the ingredients that were utilized tasted better here than in Italy. Could be. . .

excerpts: So, when I stumbled into Perbacco after a few drinks on a Saturday night, I was not prepared to be astounded-
I just wanted to carb load and check out the wine list.
JOKE'S ON ME because I was BLOWN AWAY by the gnocchi with chanterelle mushrooms.
It was seriously a religious experience.
Everybody around me ordered the pappardelle and they were making the same mmMMMMMmmm noises as I was, so I take that as a positive sign.
I also sampled the raviora- CRAZY GOOD (pomegranate seeds all up in my pasta, what an unexpected love story!).
Service was good, wine was fantastic.
My only complaint was that I was not totally into my caramelized white chocolate bar, which I think has more to do with my taste than the actually bar itself.
Overall, it was a very memorable experience and
until I return, I shall dream about the chanterelle mushrooms.
perbacco.author: Margaret L.
perbacco.review: I'm gonna be real with everyone here: I am an Italian food snob. My ability to be impressed by Italian fare has been numbed by a handful of extended stays in Italy throughout my life, and consequently I tend to avoid trendy Italian places with high price tags because there are so many ways that my pasta dish can result in an underwhelmed MEH from my palate (I know I sound insufferable; bear with me). So, when I stumbled into Perbacco after a few drinks on a Saturday night, I was not prepared to be astounded- I just wanted to carb load and check out the wine list. JOKE'S ON ME because I was BLOWN AWAY by the gnocchi with chanterelle mushrooms. It was seriously a religious experience. Everybody around me ordered the pappardelle and they were making the same mmMMMMMmmm noises as I was, so I take that as a positive sign. I also sampled the raviora- CRAZY GOOD (pomegranate seeds all up in my pasta, what an unexpected love story!). Service was good, wine was fantastic. My only complaint was that I was not totally into my caramelized white chocolate bar, which I think has more to do with my taste than the actually bar itself. Overall, it was a very memorable experience and until I return, I shall dream about the chanterelle mushrooms.

excerpts: This review is for Perbacco's pris-fix Passover meal on 4/22.
I was so excited to get an email from a friend regarding Perbacco's exclusively kosher-for-Passover meal for last night.
Three of us booked a table and had a lovely evening.
Now, anyone who knows about kosher-for-Passover food knows that it's REALLY hard to have a full course, delicious meal.
Passover food is just blah
, there's no other way to explain it.
Perbacco did their very best and worked with what they had to produce a pretty good meal.
The night started off with two small pieces of matzoh and a very thick harroset (I feel like there were figs in there...).
Then I had artichoke soup (non-dairy based)
bland
but once I added salt I enjoyed it more.
We also shared (family style) grilled eggplant, marinated zucchini and duck liver, 3 of 8 choices.
I had the chicken entree; drenched in fresh tomatoes, onions and olives.
Super tastey.
The entrees were accompanied by grilled fennel, a mashed-potato type side (again, no dairy...) and another lettuce based thing that is escaping me.
I was impressed at how Perbacco pulled this off
Thanks, Perbacco!
I'll be back for my non-kosher meal very soon.
perbacco.author: Meredith R.
perbacco.review:
NOTE: This review is for Perbacco's pris-fix Passover meal on 4/22.

A+ for effort! I was so excited to get an email from a friend regarding Perbacco's exclusively kosher-for-Passover meal for last night. Three of us booked a table and had a lovely evening. Now, anyone who knows about kosher-for-Passover food knows that it's REALLY hard to have a full course, delicious meal. Passover food is just blah, there's no other way to explain it. Perbacco did their very best and worked with what they had to produce a pretty good meal. The night started off with two small pieces of matzoh and a very thick harroset (I feel like there were figs in there...). Then I had artichoke soup (non-dairy based) ---- bland but once I added salt I enjoyed it more. We also shared (family style) grilled eggplant, marinated zucchini and duck liver, 3 of 8 choices. I had the chicken entree; drenched in fresh tomatoes, onions and olives. Super tastey. The entrees were accompanied by grilled fennel, a mashed-potato type side (again, no dairy...) and another lettuce based thing that is escaping me. Finally for dessert we were served (family style) caramelized strawberries (heavenly), a sponge cake (very good) and an almond pudding (not very good as it can't really be pudding without milk...).

The service was impeccable and the whole staff was very knowledgeable about each dish and choice provided. I was impressed at how Perbacco pulled this off and I am thankful that they catered to the Jewish community on a night that is truly different than all other nights.

Thanks, Perbacco! I'll be back for my non-kosher meal very soon.

excerpts: Thanks Perbacco!!!
We will be back!
perbacco.author: Kristen V.
perbacco.review: After my last visit with my fiance wasn't all that great, the manager responded to my yelp review and asked if we would come back.  With over 1000 reviews, he really didn't need to do that, which made it mean that much more.   We returned last night for a very nice dinner.  Service was excellent, food was delicious, and we had a great booth in the corner of the restaurant.  Thanks Perbacco!!!  We will be back!

excerpts: Can't believe I've missed out on Perbacco for so long.
Love the design of the restaurant- open, modern yet warm.

The bar area is perfect for waiting for your table and sharing wine with friends (I never felt cramped and the bartenders were very friendly- going out of their way to suggest and pour samples of wine

I was with a couple who has been to Perbacco many a time and it was clear they loved and felt very at home at the restaurant- chatting with the somalier, asking the waiter to add a little extra of some ingredient to a particular dish, etc.
perbacco.author: Sonia S.
perbacco.review:
Can't believe I've missed out on Perbacco for so long. Love the design of the restaurant- open, modern yet warm. The bar area is perfect for waiting for your table and sharing wine with friends (I never felt cramped and the bartenders were very friendly- going out of their way to suggest and pour samples of wine I may like even when the bar was pretty crowded). 

My group of 4 sampled a few appetizers and main courses- all were superb. I was with a couple who has been to Perbacco many a time and it was clear they loved and felt very at home at the restaurant- chatting with the somalier, asking the waiter to add a little extra of some ingredient to a particular dish, etc.

The raw fish was amazing (try the hamachi with jalapeno) as were all the dishes we ordered. I would list everything we tried, but I don't think you can go wrong.  The desserts were equally impressive- we had a caramel/seasalt gelato (huge serving) and a cheese plate...sublime.

I really love this place.

excerpts: But for $2 out-the-door of the liquor store, don't buy a High Life at Perbacco.
All in all, Perbacco has good food/drink, good service, good atmosphere, and interesting people to watch.
perbacco.author: Syd V.
perbacco.review:
We had a lovely experience:

Boy brought me here to celebrate the ending of a long week. What a shweetie. Our server (Claire) was really nice and never left us waiting for anything -- my (3) Peronis came one after the other, while boy chose a half liter of the Syrah. We like drinky.

I had the herb roasted gnocchi. It was THE best gnocchi I have ever had and I eat a lot of gnocchi -- I love love looove gnocchi. Gnocchi gnocchi! The dish was full of melted cherry tomatoes. They were like little explosions of flavor. THE greatest flavor explosions on Earth. Oh, man. So good.

Anyways, boy had the ahi steak and a plate of the crudo, which he said was d-e-l-i-c-i-o-u-s. My pear and arugula salad was quite good as well. The desserts looked delicious, but my belly so full that if I ate anymore I would've needed to be rolled home.

We had the corner booth with the best view in the house, so it was easy to people watch. We especially enjoyed watching the 2 Japanese businessman with the two scantily dresses call girls. One of the girls downed her champagne with each glass and kept staring at herself making fish faces in the mirror above the bench seats. That was weird, yet very entertaining.

The only thing I thought was strange was that they had Miller High Life on the menu and I think it was priced at $5. But for $2 out-the-door of the liquor store, don't buy a High Life at Perbacco.

All in all, Perbacco has good food/drink, good service, good atmosphere, and interesting people to watch.  A++

excerpts: Perbacco is always solid, from meats (salumi plate) to the pasta to the service.
Great place for a work dinner or otherwise.
perbacco.author: Sherrick M.
perbacco.review: Perbacco is always solid, from meats (salumi plate) to the pasta to the service. Great place for a work dinner or otherwise.

excerpts: Funnily enough, I had my first Perbacco experience last week, and I have to say, I have never been compelled to write any review on yelp for any restaurant-
I mainly use yelp as a way to surf the city for new restaurants, not to pretend to be a critic.... however
, I had such an amazing experience that I truly felt moved to let everyone know about it!!!!
Perbacco, if you have lost this guest, you have gained one in me!!!
The chef of Perbacco should be handed an award for the amazing food I tasted that night.
Rubicon, Bix, Aqua, I apologise-
Perbacco is THE best restaurant in SF...
Thank you so much Perbacco, for enhancing my night!!!!
perbacco.author: judy b.
perbacco.review:
Wow. Funnily enough, I had my first Perbacco experience last week, and I have to say, I have never been compelled to write any review on yelp for any restaurant- I mainly use yelp as a way to surf the city for new restaurants, not to pretend to be a critic.... however, I had such an amazing experience that I truly felt moved to let everyone know about it!!!! .... That being said, finding"KIM D"s review below HAS INFURIATED me into taking a moment to address it:

Kim, You are "confused." There is never any excuse to demean anyone with a child. Even if they are loud, or in your eyes, out of line. To each his own. I cannot believe you would fault the restaurant or it's staff for another persons behavior anyway......

Besides- what would the alternative be? To turn families away and have them write scathingly negative reviews about it on yelp??? Perhaps people with children have a little more patience and perspective than you... Perbacco, if you have lost this guest, you have gained one in me!!! So ciao bella, Kim- Please don't procreate.

that being said.... I sat at the bar, and although crowded, was fun and lively! I was never wanting for anything for the entire time I was there. The bartender- Scott- was proffessional and lovely. He suggested amazing pairings of wine with our meal..... And our meal!!!! Oh! The chef of Perbacco should be handed an award for the amazing food I tasted that night. Rubicon, Bix, Aqua, I apologise- Perbacco is THE best restaurant in SF... Thank you so much Perbacco, for enhancing my night!!!!

excerpts: The menu at Perbacco spoke to me in a way I'd been searching for.
Thank you, Perbacco, for giving me hope that there is romance out there for me (albeit in the form of a superb italian eatery, but romance none the less).
perbacco.author: Jaimey W.
perbacco.review:
The menu at Perbacco spoke to me in a way I'd been searching for.  Upfront, romantic and kind, straightforward - as if knowing what I was thinking:

House Cured Swordfish...
Summer Peach Salad with Marcona Almonds...
Strip Loin Steak with Heirloom Tomato Panzanella...
Pan Roasted Fennel...

It's almost overwhelming that I found love so right and so pure.  Thank you, Perbacco, for giving me hope that there is romance out there for me (albeit in the form of a superb italian eatery, but romance none the less).

excerpts: Perbacco has good breadsticks.
perbacco.author: Gracie-C Y.
perbacco.review:
I like breadsticks.
Perbacco has good breadsticks.
That's all I gots to say.

Well, not quite all I gots to say.
This place got a lot a buzz recently from a lot of people.  After sampling the fare, I have to wonder why.  
Maybe wifey and I are getting jaded and cynical from eating out too much.  Maybe our expectations are too high.  Maybe we're just whiney snobby  gourmands who like to toot our own horns.  After all, wifey's been on a rage booking us for 2-3 restaurants per week.  This blistering pace has left me exhausted and weary.  At this point, the  only way a restaurant's gonna get a rise outta me is if unicorns serve the meal and buxom strippers dance in the background... that's not weird, is it?

The food here is pretty straightforward.  I found the entrees fairly standard.  Like others, I think the pastas are worth investigating if you decide to try this place.  Also, the salumi and cured meat samplers are nice.  I had a duck mortadella that would make a grown Italian paisano weep.

Remember to try the breadsticks.
They keep a big bin of them on the way to the bathroom.  I got greedy and grabbed a handful of them on my way to the john.  It helped pass the time.

excerpts: I'm very up in the air about Perbacco.
I LOVE the space.
It's beautiful; big bar, high ceilings, boothes, exposed brick, quiet upstairs dining area, open kitchen area.
It really is an amazing space.
And it's much bigger than I had expected.
I just wan't
perbacco.author: Lauren M.
perbacco.review:
I'm very up in the air about Perbacco.  I LOVE the space.  It's beautiful; big bar, high ceilings, boothes, exposed brick, quiet upstairs dining area, open kitchen area.  It really is an amazing space.  And it's much bigger than I had expected.  I just wan't THAT impressed with the food.  

I enjoyed the beet salad to start with, but its pretty difficult to mess up a basic beet salad.  My boyfriend had the slow roasted veal appetizer and it was nothing like we had expected.  There just wan't any amazing flavor to it.  A very weird combo with the tuna sauce as well.  And it's cold!  Not a favorite whatsoever.  I wouldn't recommend it.  

For my main entree I had the paparedelle.  I definitely liked the dish, but it wasn't anything special.  It is rare to find a short rib ragu, but nothing really stood out to me.  It tasted like short ribs.   I feel like my boyfriend could have made it for me.  He had duck tortiloni, which again, was nothing special.  Duck being as gamey as it is, really needed something extra flavorful to make taste really good.  It was just ok.  

We had two veggie sides, the fingerling potatoes and the cornona beans.  The fingerling potatoes were amazing, but thats just because fingerlings are amazing.  The corona beans were alright, but I guess I was really looking for some green beans or broccoli which wasn't an option.  I would have liked to see more "green" options for sides. 
  
Overall the service was great.  Our SERVER was really sweet and had great recommendations.  She paired wine for both of our dishes and was all around very friendly.  The "manager"? was quite annoying though.  He gradually walked around the entire upstairs checking in on every table.  I don't know how often he checked on everyone else, but he interrupted our dinner THREE times to ask how everything was, sparked random conversation and made recommendations when we hadn't asked for advise.  I could have gone without him.

I think it would be a really fun spot to go for some after work drinks and apps with some friends and sit down in the bar area.  But if I were going on a nice date and really wanted to be impressed by the food, I'd probably choose somewhere else.

excerpts: Each year I attend the special dinner event at Perbacco for Passover.
This year I invited my children to join the fun and we were not disappointed.
Joyce Goldstein, premier chef and author, oversees the dinner this one night.
The owner is always gracious and attentive to the packed house.
Everything was fantastic.
Look forward to enjoying dinner throughout the year at Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Gerry C.
perbacco.review: Each year I attend the special dinner event at Perbacco for Passover. This year I invited my children to join the fun and we were not disappointed. Joyce Goldstein, premier chef and author, oversees the dinner this one night. The owner is always gracious and attentive to the packed house. Everything was fantastic. Look forward to enjoying dinner throughout the year at Perbacco!

excerpts: I don't know how Perbacco could get any better...
My "sexy hombre" brought me here for my BDay dinner
and I fell in love...with the food, the wine, the service and the desserts!
perbacco.author: Jennifer L.
perbacco.review:
I don't know how Perbacco could get any better...My "sexy hombre" brought me here for my BDay dinner and I fell in love...with the food, the wine, the service and the desserts!  "Yay"!  

Upon arriving, we did have to wait a bit for our table, because the original table he requested was not yet available so we stood around the bar for a drink.  Yum.  I started off with the Prosecco with organic strawberries.  What a perfect and bubbly way to begin a meal!  

When we were finally seated, they sat us in a cute little corner table, slightly away from everyone, but still in the midst of all the action.  Very romantic.  Nice alternative!  

Once we were settled, the hostess presented a hand-written Happy Birthday Card, such a sweet touch!  Then, our cute server came and introduced himself to us...Very sweet and very personable from the start!  I looked at Sexy Hombre and said "Where are we?  Are we still in San Francisco?"  

Okay, onto the food.  
-Pesce Crudo: Wonderful tastes of Albacore Tuna, Watermelon, Celery, Chili and Cherry Tomatoes.  Squeezing everything into one spoon and devouring it whole, you get a variety of flavors, that pair surprising well together!
-Carne Cruda: Veal Tartare (I know...poor baby lamb!) quail egg (love quail eggs!) and truffle atop toasted bread.  Oh lord...I think Sexy Hombre had a few moments...I know I did!
-Agnolotti: My Sexy Hombre may need to translate again what was in it, but I will say that it is A MUST!  So much flavor coming out of such a little pocket of pasta!   
-Parppardelle: With Quail Ragu and teeny tiny little mushrooms...It was good, but the Agnolotti shoved it aside and took first place on my palatte!  

Now, on to my favorite!  Dessert!
-Glass of Vin Santo: See the below description of how "Ridiculous" this wine is!
-Semifreddo: It's like a cross between a creme brulee, and an ice cream cake.  Have a bite and take a sip of the Vin Santo.  "Ridiculous".  It's so ridiculous that Sexy Hombre was enticed to use profanities to describe how (again) "RIDICULOUSLY DELICIOUS" it was!
-Chocolate Gelato with a side of Toffee: This was on the house, which made it that much yummier!  I don't know if I've ever had Chocolate Gelato THAT good!  The cute server, originally from Boston (love him!), told us about the rarity of the chocolate...I can see why.  Oh, don't let me forget to tell you about the Toffee.  Be careful, it will stick to your teeth, but let it marinate in your mouth to form a caramel consistency.  Take another sip of the Vin Santo and there goes my "RIDICULOUS MOMENT"!  I literally had to pause for a moment and wonder if this was real.  It was.  

Thank you a million times, Sexy Hombre!  Definitely a night to remember...I heart Bday dinners!

excerpts: Fun tidbit - according to the restaurant's website, "Perbacco" is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.
perbacco.author: Brittany M.
perbacco.review: Order the Tortelli di Zucca - Pasta filled with Roasted Butternut Squash, Sage Butter, Rapini and Hazelnuts. DELISH. Went here for lunch today and it was delectable - everything from the bread sticks to the lunch entrées. Why not five stars? While the service was good, it was a little slow for a business lunch, which can be tricky when you're tight on time. Fun tidbit - according to the restaurant's website, "Perbacco" is an Italian word to accentuate positive comments.

excerpts: Thanks Perbacco!
The FOOOOOD is GOOOOOD and The WINE is KILLER!
perbacco.author: Miguelito C.
perbacco.review: This place rocks! And doesn't rock the bank as one would suspect! The food is so, so, soooo good but the wine is so on! No paring needed here, you point and click! The service is very on! Right when you think, oh shit! Another snobby ass, wanna be joint meant to please the new yorker snob f#@k! You can stroll your a$$ in there and you are sure to find a lower life than you, but you will eat great food, drink very good wine, be treated very very well and rub elbows with the city's no so so pretentious prick! Get in there kick back, feel good, leave and get some booty from your girl, cuz it was a good night! Thanks Perbacco! The FOOOOOD is GOOOOOD and The WINE is KILLER!

excerpts: I went there for drinks one night - definitely try the Perbacco!
cocktail, a yummy blend of vodka, Amaretto and Meyer lemon.
It was a good scene for a Thursday night.
perbacco.author: Shannon L.
perbacco.review:
A nice addition to that Financial District.  I went there for drinks one night - definitely try the Perbacco! cocktail, a yummy blend of vodka, Amaretto and Meyer lemon.  It was a good scene for a Thursday night.  Not too crowded, not too noisy in the bar.  

Then, we were seated for dinner, and the dining area was a somewhat different experience.  So loud you almost couldn't hear across the table, although the food was fantastic. Try the pappardelle, it's great.  Would've been a five-star experience if I hadn't needed to shout and pantomime to my friends across the table to continue the conversation.

excerpts: Finally made it to dinner at Perbacco last night after wanting to go there for quite some time, and after hearing all the rave reviews.
I've come to Perbacco before for drinks, but now I am thinking that the inviting bar scene is a real dis-service to the restaurant scene.
The food highlights by far are the salami selection and the wine menu.
I'd come back anytime for a glass of wine and a nice salami appetizer plate - but I think I'll bring by top-dollar dinner budget to a quieter location where I can relax a bit more.
perbacco.author: Craig G.
perbacco.review:
I know I am the 390th person to review this place but I had to throw my hat into the ring. Finally made it to dinner at Perbacco last night after wanting to go there for quite some time, and after hearing all the rave reviews.

Upon arrival, I was partially turned off immediately because of the crowd. There was a crowd out front, a crowd around the reception desk, and a crowd in the bar. I opened the door, got a rush of hot air, the loud boom of a few hundred people talking in an echo-y room, then fought my way to the reception desk to check in for my reservation (this is 6pm on a Thursday).

Throughout the time I was there, the staff were all very nice and professional despite the stress of having a packed restaurant. The receptionist smiled and had her act together, the waiter was attentive and gave great suggestions, and everyone thanks you on the way out. No complaints over service.

The food was equally good. We started off with the chef's selection of Salami - and it was actually a very impressive spread of cured meats (all done in-house so they say). We also ordered the Red & Gold Beat salad which was fresh, and the Hamachi which was equally as fresh (but I am spoiled by being able to get fresh Hamachi anywhere in SF practically). For dinner I had the duck and it was cooked to perfection - very good. She had the Butternut Squash Lune, a little heavy on the butter but fresh and delicious. Desert - we ordered the Pistachio cake and it was soft and decadent.

SO WHY 3 STARS CRAIG?
The problem is the NOISE LEVEL. It is loud. I could barely carry on a conversation without shouting. I found myself rushing through the meal so I could get outside and out of the noise. I've come to Perbacco before for drinks, but now I am thinking that the inviting bar scene is a real dis-service to the restaurant scene.  The food highlights by far are the salami selection and the wine menu. I'd come back anytime for a glass of wine and a nice salami appetizer plate - but I think I'll bring by top-dollar dinner budget to a quieter location where I can relax a bit more.

excerpts: I've been meaning to try Perbacco for the past year or so and a coworker took me here today for lunch.
perbacco.author: Joe U.
perbacco.review:
I've been meaning to try Perbacco for the past year or so and a coworker took me here today for lunch.  

From the minute I stepped in, I felt like I was in swank New York eatery...soo cool inside. The bathroom is down in the basement, through tunnels and over train tracks; it's deep in there.
 
The food was awesome -- I had the market salad and the grilled hanger steak.  Hot, fresh and the meat was perfectly cooked.  She had the daily special which was fish, and really enjoyed it. Service was fast and friendly.  

The inside is really cool too with the brick and industrial feel.  I'll definitely come back and try their dinner menu.

excerpts: this is the definition of "Perbacco" and it's apt.
Last night I dined again, for maybe the fifth time, at Perbacco and for the third time I closed the place without even realizing it.
perbacco.author: Gary C.
perbacco.review:
"Good gracious, good heavens...expressions of surprise"...this is the definition of "Perbacco" and it's apt. Last night I dined again, for maybe the fifth time, at Perbacco and for the third time I closed the place without even realizing it. The poor staff...

We usually start at the bar with a cocktail. I'm partial to the Mandarino. If you hit the bar before 9pm its usually packed. It's a convivial joint and gets loud. The centerpiece at the bar is a meat slicer, but this isn't any old kitchen tool. This is a completely refurbished big red Berkel meat slicer from 1905. It is a beautifully designed piece of mechanical engineering and sets the stage for the (exceptional) salumi selection you'll find on the menu. Admiring the meat slicer and draining the Mandarino we were escorted upstairs to our table (I prefer sitting upstairs over the main floor...much quieter), seated and menu'ed.

I started with the Heirloom tomato salad (heirlooms are everywhere right now). I entree'd with the Liberty Farms Duck Breast. Around the table was the ricotta and spring garlic gnocchi, the lamb shank and more pasta. We ordered a bottle of light red...the conversation was so much fun that I just passed the ordering off to the sommelier who delivered a perfect choice and a very modest price. For dessert we shared gelati misti ( bitter-sweet chocolate /caramel with black sea salt /torrone), lemon -buttermilk panna cotta (strawberry compote /black pepper shortbread /mosto cotto) and warm polenta cake with olive oil gelato /rhubarb compote. All were fabulous...especially the salted caramel ice cream.

As we finished the desserts, we looked around and found ourselves the last to leave. A beautifully prepared meal, excellent service and a warm atmosphere led to a memorable evening with friends and great conversation. For an evening out with friends this is a hard place to beat. (4.5 stars)

excerpts: I've been to Perbacco three times in the last year.
Once last December, another time about a month ago, and a third time this past Friday.
We were extremely upset, since the whole point of going to Perbacco was to get prosciutto.
Happily, the manager managed to find us some prosciutto (despite their earlier protestations) and we were able to eat our fill.
We also shared the salumi plate and a bottle of wine.
We were looking for a particular type of wine - medium and full bodied, tannins, not too fruity and the sommalier
let us taste a number of different bottles before we settled on one.
Service was realy top notch, IMO.
Well, that's it, I LOVE Perbacco.
I give four stars for the food and the eminently reasonable prices, but an extra star for the service beyond the call of duty.
perbacco.author: Leah S.
perbacco.review:
I've been to Perbacco three times in the last year.  Once last December, another time about a month ago, and a third time this past Friday.  I have to say, I have never had a bad meal or had bad service at this place.

The first time around, my husband and I went for my birthday.  We had the salumi appetizer, w/c was very good - good variety and flavor.  I had a fish entree w/c was good, but the standout was my husband's shortrib entree.  So flavorful and rich without being overly greasy.  

The second time around, my hubby and I went w/ my sis and her hubby.  We also shared the salumi misti plate and the portions were very generous, and also had the local anchovy crudo, which was nice and briny but not too salty.  We also brought our own wine and ordered a bottle off the regular menu.  The sommalier was great, they were not snooty or condescending, which can sometimes happen when you bring your own wine (it helped I think that the wine we brought was unusual and not normally available to restaurants).  My hubby ordered the rabbit, which meh, I am not a fan of game, so I didn't taste it.  Apparently it was good, but I"ll take his word for it.  I had the roasted chicken w/c was absolutely luscious.  It was juicy and flavorful.  Yum.  I loved how attentive the service was, not too pushy and hovering, but always there whenever you needed them.

Last Friday, I went back w/ my girl friends, one of whom was desperately craving good prosciutto.  We tried to order the prosciutto, but apparently the restaurant was all out.  We were extremely upset, since the whole point of going to Perbacco was to get prosciutto.  Happily, the manager managed to find us some prosciutto (despite their earlier protestations) and we were able to eat our fill.  We also shared the salumi plate and a bottle of wine.  We were looking for a particular type of wine - medium and full bodied, tannins, not too fruity and the sommalier let us taste a number of different bottles before we settled on one.  Service was realy top notch, IMO.  It probably helped that we were four cute young gals.

Well, that's it, I LOVE Perbacco.  I give four stars for the food and the eminently reasonable prices, but an extra star for the service beyond the call of duty.

excerpts: Ive been here several times and Perbacco has yet to disappoint me.
I heart Perbacco
perbacco.author: Christian S.
perbacco.review:
OK - this place is the bomb. Ive been here several times and Perbacco has yet to disappoint me. I even think that this place is better than Delfina - yes - I said it..better than Delfina.

let me tell you why - 
-for one thing you dont have to wait two weeks for a reservation :)
-freshly made pastas - try the 5 hour pork sugo with tagliate or raviolis
-great appetizers - love the seared squid which melts in your mouth  and the breadsticks that accompany your food
-awesome entrees - fall of the bone beef short ribs..yum!
-tasty wine list - 
-complementary chocolates they give you after dessert.

I heart Perbacco

excerpts: For my recent 27th, my foodie Father suggested we make a reservation at Perbacco, having himself had a great meal there prior.
I hesitantly agreed but was soon thereafter reminded that way way back as a teeny tyke,  I professed to my parents that "it's so important to sample new products" which actually stuck as my motto.
In this case, Perbacco stood as the "new product" and I'm pleased to report, I'm quite glad I tried it.

From a vast and pleasing wine-list to delicious appetizers, entrees and great service, Perbacco proved to be not only a satisfying alternative to my usual birthday spot, but a delicious Italian restaurant worth coming back.
As this was my birthday and my pork craving on an all-time high, I found my perfect match in Perbacco's "porchetta" entree.
All I can say is HOLY PORCHETTA.
It was cooked perfectly, juicy and tender rather than swallowed in fat as is oven the case especially with a technique of pork using the belly.
Personally, as much as I love meat I can't handle the texture of fatty cuts nor can my stomach digest them.
So, I was incredibly pleased to be able to truly enjoy pork with the texture and flavor components I prefer in line.
I would most definitely return to Perbacco
perbacco.author: Lisa H.
perbacco.review:
I confess that I'm partial to celebrating my birthday at the same few select restaurants in San Francisco each year, with the guarantee of a fantastic meal. For my recent 27th, my foodie Father suggested we make a reservation at Perbacco, having himself had a great meal there prior. I hesitantly agreed but was soon thereafter reminded that way way back as a teeny tyke,  I professed to my parents that "it's so important to sample new products" which actually stuck as my motto. In this case, Perbacco stood as the "new product" and I'm pleased to report, I'm quite glad I tried it. From a vast and pleasing wine-list to delicious appetizers, entrees and great service, Perbacco proved to be not only a satisfying alternative to my usual birthday spot, but a delicious Italian restaurant worth coming back. 

As someone with dietary restrictions (gluten, no soy, spicy, fatty, creamy foods, limited dairy, no acidic, etc), eating out poses challenges that often a restaurant is not equipped to deal with. In this case, I bashfully explained to our server my particular restrictions and was pleasantly surprised at how immediately accommodating he was. To me, that set the tone for the meal and I knew I'd be able to fully enjoy my choices without feeling the need to settle. He pointed out menu selections that included wheat and even options I might want to avoid just in case. When our barrata and heirlume tomato appetizer came to the table topped with breadcrumbs he-apologetically-asked if I'd like my own small slice sans breadcrumbs. I, not wanting to be a hassle, declined but after insistence from my father and the waiter, gratefully obliged. Good move as I absolutely loved the fresh cheese and tomatoes, paired in perfect harmony. With my taste buds delightfully ignited I eagerly awaited the arrival of my main course. 

I consider myself a healthy eater, food-intolerance's aside, but every now and then I get a craving that I must satisfy. When my craving focuses on meat, or in this case, pork, nothing else will do and my mindset is to go big or don't bother. As this was my birthday and my pork craving on an all-time high, I found my perfect match in Perbacco's "porchetta" entree. All I can say is HOLY PORCHETTA. It was cooked perfectly, juicy and tender rather than swallowed in fat as is oven the case especially with a technique of pork using the belly. Personally, as much as I love meat I can't handle the texture of fatty cuts nor can my stomach digest them. So, I was incredibly pleased to be able to truly enjoy pork with the texture and flavor components I prefer in line. Finally, dessert of sorbet left a refreshing finishing touch to a great meal.  

I would most definitely return to Perbacco

excerpts: I would recommend skipping Perbacco and heading over to Barbacco.
I have never had a bad meal there.
perbacco.author: S. S.
perbacco.review: Just took a client here for dinner.  The waiter was very knowledgeable and the service was very good.  I started with the potato leek soup which was tasty and I really enjoyed the pinot noir we ordered.  My main course was a pasta with 5 hour cooked pork.  YUCK.  Seriously, this is the worst thing I have had at a restaurant in a long time. It was bland and seriously looked like dog food on the plate.  I say again, YUCK.  For desert I really enjoyed the salted carmel ice cream.  Hence the two star review - good service, good soup, great ice cream, and minus three stars for the worst pasta dish ever served at a restaurant.  I have to also say that the pasta was served overcooked, which to me was adding insult to injury.  I would recommend skipping Perbacco and heading over to Barbacco.  I have never had a bad meal there.
