perbacco.author: Tess R.
perbacco.review: Fabulous dinner, lovely private room, attentive staff, amazing food. It was truly a pleasure to work with the staff at Perbacco while planning our company dinner on May 18. Our guests loved the experience and, even more importantly, my bosses heaped me with compliments...

excerpts: After finishing a movie at the nearby Embacadero cinema, we went over to Perbacco for dinner.
After reading all the reviews, we ordered the Salame Nostrano for appetizer, delicious!
perbacco.author: Yan M.
perbacco.review:
After finishing a movie at the nearby Embacadero cinema, we went over to Perbacco for dinner. After reading all the reviews, we ordered the Salame Nostrano for appetizer, delicious! You also get breadsticks with pesto dip at the beginning.

For entree, I ordered the Pappardelle, braised short rib ragu and roasted chanterelles and bf had the Tajarin, Handcut Tagliatelle, 5 hr pork sugo and porcini mushrooms.
I really liked my pappardelle dish and bf's Tajarin was equally good with fine angel-hair-like pasta. Both were really flavorful and not too cheesy and pasta to sauce equation was excellent!

We loved the decor of the restaurant, very modern and yes good space. The bathrooms downstairs is cute and has lovely sinks. Maybe it was too cute that the couple next to us disappeared downstairs together when their entree arrived! (Hmmm....) Case of aphrodisiac?

To finish off the meal, we ordered the pistachio panna cotta with blood orange, it was VERY good. I love panna cotta and this restaurant serves up a great and smooth textured panna cotta! Excellent.

excerpts: Okay, so I didn't actually get to eat a full-on meal at Perbacco, so my rating is kind of arbitrary...however, I was lucky enough to get to join in on the tail end of my aunt's 53rd birthday dinner there!
I was going out with my aunt and uncle for after-dinner drinks, and they asked to me to meet them at Perbacco, but they weren't quite finished with their meal when I got there
, so they let me squeeze in with them at a booth
and I got to try my aunt's salmon dish and my uncle's pesto gnocchi!
Thanks to my experience at Perbacco, I learned about the concept of re-plating!
And, fyi, my aunt and uncle both really liked their food, which says a lot because they are both UBER-PICKY and sometimes quite hard to please...and they liked Perbacco,
so it must be really good :)
perbacco.author: Shannon R.
perbacco.review:
Okay, so I didn't actually get to eat a full-on meal at Perbacco, so my rating is kind of arbitrary...however, I was lucky enough to get to join in on the tail end of my aunt's 53rd birthday dinner there! 

I was going out with my aunt and uncle for after-dinner drinks, and they asked to me to meet them at Perbacco, but they weren't quite finished with their meal when I got there, so they let me squeeze in with them at a booth and I got to try my aunt's salmon dish and my uncle's pesto gnocchi! YUM! 

They had also saved some of their appetizers from the beginning of the meal for us to sample, so while they finished up dinner, their server was kind enough to have their leftovers re-plated, which were then brought out for my boyfriend and I to enjoy at the bar!

I thought this was a very nice service, to tell you the truth, I have never, in my life, thought to have anything I ordered at a restaurant "re-plated," to then revisit at a different juncture in the meal...! But then again, my aunt has been part of the fine dining circuit for far, far longer than I have, so I guess she just knows about these things!!! 

Thanks to my experience at Perbacco, I learned about the concept of re-plating! YESSSSS!!!!

And, fyi, my aunt and uncle both really liked their food, which says a lot because they are both UBER-PICKY and sometimes quite hard to please...and they liked Perbacco, so it must be really good :)

excerpts: I was so excited to try out Perbacco, and they did not disappoint.
Definitely try some of their homemade salumi...
the fennel salumi was absolutely delicious.
I had the monk fish which was excellent, and my boyfriend had the pork shoulder, which totally blew my dish out of the water.
The pork was so tender, it was like cutting into a stick of butter.
Their policy states that, if you cancel outside of 48 hours prior to your reservation, they will charge your credit card $25, and mail you a Perbacco gift card.
Well, I didn't cancel within 48 hours, and I told them I was just fine with being charged.
I just received a call from their management, who said that he wouldn't be charging me.
So fantastic...
The only downside to Perbacco is the noise...
it's a pretty open space, so conversations definitely reverberate throughout the restaurant, but it would never stop me from coming back.
Five enthusiastic stars!!!
perbacco.author: Brianne K.
perbacco.review:
I was so excited to try out Perbacco, and they did not disappoint.  Definitely try some of their homemade salumi...the fennel salumi was absolutely delicious. I had the monk fish which was excellent, and my boyfriend had the pork shoulder, which totally blew my dish out of the water. The pork was so tender, it was like cutting into a stick of butter. Their reservationists and management are incredible. I made a reservation for 10, which they were extremely helpful with, which I unfortunately had to cancel. excerpts: Perbacco in dialect means WOW!
I've been to Perbacco numerous times (my birthday dinner celebration, a co-worker luncheon, a stop-over for wine and salumi misti)
perbacco.author: Veritas V.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco in dialect means WOW! I love the brick lined walls and the soft overhead lights - giving the place a modern twist on Rustic Northern Cuisine.

I've been to Perbacco numerous times (my birthday dinner celebration, a co-worker luncheon, a stop-over for wine and salumi misti) always had a nice experience.  

My friend & I decided to stop by on a gorgeous Tuesday night without reservations and were immediately seated. NiCE.

For starter we shared the Vitello Tonnato - DELICIOUS.  Thinly sliced veal with a wonderful lemon tuna sauce.  The sauce is so delicate and the tuna (which you can not taste) gives the veal substance and enhance the sweetness of the slow roasted meat.  The arugula and capers cut the sweetness with a nice tangy finish.  I highly recommend trying it.  It's worth it!

We both ordered a pasta dish - tajarin (think il ragu' bologenese) and pansotti (ravioli).  Wonderful home made pastas topped off with a nice complementing sauce.

Of course, we washed it all down with a nice bottle of Barbera D'Alba - Andrea Oberto 2005.  Wonderful with pasta dishes.

As usually we skip dessert.  At the end of the meal, our server brought out 4 itsy-bitsy dessert amuse morsels - perugiana and torrone.  Perfect ending.

Service was nice.  Our guy is friendly but he tends to forget to fill our wine glasses.  The sommelier is knowledgeable.  Noise level is nice unless you are seated next to a loud-mouth drunken patron.

perbacco.author: Mike G.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco offering northern Italian cuisine opened in San Francisco in late October '06 and has by now ironed out most of the wrinkles many new restaurants face.  Combining historical elements (original brick wall dating from around 1914) with sleek, modern lines the ambience is both comfortable and appealing.  

Prices are reasonable for the Bay Area with small plates (half orders) and most appetizers in the $10-14 range.  It's nice to go with friends who enjoy sampling several dishes and ordering several half orders that can be shared.  

I started with a Rosmarino cocktail ($9) of Grey Goose vodka with lemon, rosemary simple syrup and apple brandy - sweet but good, served with a sprig of rosemary.  Consult with their Italian sommelier who knows his stuff and can assist you in selecting a wine to pair with your meal.  

We started out with a half order of the Salumni Misti ($18) which featured a variety of cured meats including mortadella and fennel salame.  We also sampled half orders of the Butternut Squash Mezzelune ($9) - delicious with sage browned butter and Castelmagno cheese - and the Tajarin ($10) handcut tagliatelle pasta with pork sugo and porcini mushrooms - very succulent and smooth with a orange zest addition which worked very well with this dish. 

Entrees for the most part are in the $20-29 range.   My party selected the Beef Short Ribs ($21) with celery root puree, and the Pork Shoulder ($19) with savoy cabbage and polenta.  I had the Pork with was so tender you didn't need a knife to cut it.  The flavor was good and the cabbage paired well with the meat.  Sadly, the polenta had absolutely no flavor whatsoever.  Considering the soupy texture and bland taste - this side was very disappointing.  

The chocolate tart ($8) and the trio of gelato ($7) - hazelnut, bitter-sweet chocolate, and pistachio were the perfect ending to a delightful meal.  

A few added notes -  portion sizes were a bit small so be aware.  Service could have been faster, but due mainly to the kitchen and not the servers themselves who were quite attentive.  

The acoustics of the warm and inviting interior when filled with people can make it challenging to hear your own conversation.  Ask for the 2nd level dining area, if available, or a table near the back where it may be more quiet.  

Parking may be a bit of a hassle in this area - Perbacco is next to the Tadich Grill and near Aqua - so either be open to walking a distance or go with the valet which is available.  

Finally, the restrooms, which leave a little to be desired, are on the basement level.  You can however take the stairs or an elevator.  Overall, rating the quality of the food, the flavor combinations and options available, the staff, and the interior design you will enjoy the experience of dining at Perbacco.

excerpts: We are regulars at Perbacco.
After a few unsuccessful attempts for waterfront restaurants on NYE, we decided to go to Perbacco for the 2nd nite in a row.
perbacco.author: Judy D.
perbacco.review:
We are regulars at Perbacco. After a few unsuccessful attempts for waterfront restaurants on NYE, we decided to go to Perbacco for the 2nd nite in a row. Walked in and got a table at the bar with no problem.

I had somethings I've not tried before. The pear/hazelnut/fennel salad was very good with a mild gorgonzola dressing. But what's really incredible was the crab gnnochi, first time on the menu. OMG, to die for. I hope they keep it on menu!

excerpts: The food, atmosphere, and service at Perbacco get a solid 4 stars.
Umberto earns the bump to 5.
perbacco.author: Jeff T.
perbacco.review:
I've been a few times for lunch, and the food has always been good and the service has always been nice.  I went yesterday and was pleased to see that the pork shoulder was back on the menu...  it was my previous favorite and was great this time as well.  The cabage and polenta that came with it were very good as well. 

A special thanks to the owner Umberto.  I met him when I was considering venues for the rehearsal dinner prior to my wedding.  Ultimately I went a different direction, but Umberto was the nicest, most professional person I dealt with at any of the 10+ SF restaurants I considered.  (The space is also great too, by the way.)

The food, atmosphere, and service at Perbacco get a solid 4 stars.  Umberto earns the bump to 5.

excerpts: I can't say enough good things about Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Danielle L.
perbacco.review:
I can't say enough good things about Perbacco. After wanting to go for sometime, we finally made it last night for a birthday celebration. 

I had booked online at Open Table and put in the remarks: birthday celebration so we'd love a good table. Now, I almost always ask for a good table but so far, I don't think anyone has actually read the notes! We arrived to a fantastic table with a handwritten "Happy Birthday" notecard. Wow. 

The food was excellent. The server, Michael, superb. He even got us a taxi at the end of the night! The wine delicious. And the bill, as someone else noted, not as bad as I imagined. It is pricey if you do it right but for a downtown restaurant, I felt there was a lot of value. 

We can't wait to return!

excerpts: I have to yelp about Perbacco.
Loved this new Italian place in downtown SF.
I took a chance on this new restaurant for a birthday dinner I was hosting.
My four guests and I arrived a bit on the early side.
While it was a bit noisy, we were escorted to a seating area near the bar where we were served a few delicious cocktails.
While we caught up over drinks, I had a chance to notice the surroundings.
The bar is complete with a real old-fashioned meat slicer - available to slice the fresh Italian prosciutto, salamis, etc..
I recommend Perbacco the next time you're looking for a special Italian night out!
perbacco.author: Deborah S.
perbacco.review:
I have to yelp about Perbacco. Loved this new Italian place in downtown SF. I took a chance on this new restaurant for a birthday dinner I was hosting. My four guests and I arrived a bit on the early side. While it was a bit noisy, we were escorted to a seating area near the bar where we were served a few delicious cocktails. While we caught up over drinks, I had a chance to notice the surroundings. The bar is complete with a real old-fashioned meat slicer - available to slice the fresh Italian prosciutto, salamis, etc.. We were shown to our seats and I immediately got into the spirit by ordering a bottle of the Drusian Prosecco and the 'salumi misti' (an assortment of the cured meats).

While we waited we munched on some deliciously thin and perfectly salted breadsticks which came with a pesto paste for dipping. For our mains, we ordered pasta, fish, and the short ribs as well as a number of the vegetable sides. Everything was delicious.

Dessert left a bit to be desired. I really enjoyed the chocolate tart, but not so much the lemon tart.

Overall, the service was enthusiastic but not overwhelming, the atmosphere was cheerful (although a bit loud) and the food was wonderful! I recommend Perbacco the next time you're looking for a special Italian night out!

Every single time I/we had a fantastic time.
Everything is really, realy good, very authentic and the menu is wide enough that everyone can enjoy this place.

excerpts: I had my birthday dinner at Perbacco the other night and it was great!
Their ravioli was so fresh and had a lot of flavor.
perbacco.author: Christa K.
perbacco.review:
I had my birthday dinner at Perbacco the other night and it was great!
Their ravioli was so fresh and had a lot of flavor. Beef tongue salad was also yummy. 

I had a roasted rabbit for my main dish...mmm it wasn't really my fave. The sauce was a little bit too strong for me...

Everything else was just great! Good service, good people, good wines too :) It's gonna be my new favorite Italian restaurant in SF for sure.

excerpts: As soon as you walk into Perbacco, you feel like you are walking into the lobby of the W Hotel.
Slightly industrial, minimalist looking.
perbacco.author: D N.
perbacco.review:
As soon as you walk into Perbacco, you feel like you are walking into the lobby of the W Hotel. Slightly industrial, minimalist looking. The men are wearing jackets, and the women are wearing black.  

This is the "power lunch" or "power dinner" kind of restaurant. I have no doubt that the group of stern looking men sitting next of us were discussing the possible merger of their 2 companies. 

The food is delicious. I did not get to order off the menu because we were guests of a very generous, philanthropic San Franciscan. In other words, I ate for free. And such an enjoyable meal it was.

I had the fritto misto (delicious), and the pear salad (good if you like sweet salads like Waldorf). I also had the duck with a copious side of brussel sprouts. This is just really good, high-quality Americana on a plate.

Cocktails are strong. The occassion demanded a dirty martini. It goes without saying that the rest of the night is a blur. Before the night faded to black, I made sure to clean off my plate.

excerpts: Perbacco is a sleek and cool Italian restaurant in San Francisco's Financial District, focusing on the flavor of Italy's Piemonte and Ligurian regions, with a tinge of French and Provencal tastes.
With all these diverse influences, Perbacco puts up a long and interesting menu, featuring house made salume selections, a crudo list, and a selection of interesting hand-made pastas.
I always appreciate a long-ass and interesting menu, and Perbacco doesn't disappoint.
Perbacco prides itself on its freshly made pasta, and this dish backs
all tha talk up: the fresh and tender tagliatelle went perfectly with the rich and meaty sugo, which had a delightfully earthy flavor derived from porcini mushrooms.
We finished with a cheese plate, picking from Perbacco's nice selection of artisan cheeses.
We settled on Bianco Sotto Bosco, a cow and goat milk cheese infused with truffles, and Caprino Di Riofrano, goat's milk cheese wrapped in chestnut leaf.
($12.00 for selection of two).
Perbacco's dining room is very sleek and contemporary, and those expecting some sort of homey regional Italian experience will be disappointed.

The place has the appearance of a restaurant tailor-made for power lunches and important networking dinners: in other words, don't come expecting a romantic environment or overwrought opera music on the sound system.
We will certainly return to Perbacco soon.
It's excellent and interesting regional Italian dining at surprisingly regional prices - there really isn't much not to love.
perbacco.author: faine g.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is a sleek and cool Italian restaurant in San Francisco's Financial District, focusing on the flavor of Italy's Piemonte and Ligurian regions, with a tinge of French and Provencal tastes. With all these diverse influences, Perbacco puts up a long and interesting menu, featuring house made salume selections, a crudo list, and a selection of interesting hand-made pastas. I always appreciate a long-ass and interesting menu, and Perbacco doesn't disappoint.



I am exceedingly fond of our West coast sardines so I couldn't resist sampling the house cured local sardines with salsa verde, celery heart, and marinated egg yolk ($7.00). These were served chilled and had a pronounced and distinctly sardine flavor: you love it or you do not, there is little in between. I found the egg yolks played nicely off the oily fish-ness of the sardines, and the salsa verde gave things a nice herbal flavor.



Next was the roasted red and gold beets with arugula, Castelmagno cheese, and white balsamic vinaigrette ($10.00). This was a simple but successful salad, melding two different varieties of meaty and slightly fruity beets with the peppery bite of arugula and the earthy flavor of a good strong cheese. I have had variants of this dish all over the place in California and this was a pretty worthy (and nicely sized) rendition - and a very attractive presentation to boot.



We flipped for the handcut tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo, porcini mushrooms ($16.00 entree size, $11.00 appetizer sized). Perbacco prides itself on its freshly made pasta, and this dish backs all tha talk up: the fresh and tender tagliatelle went perfectly with the rich and meaty sugo, which had a delightfully earthy flavor derived from porcini mushrooms. My mother enjoyed this so much that she had it for an appetizer and an entree, and I suppose that is a fitting testimonial.



My dad went for the Coniglio al civet with Devil's Gulch rabbit, spiced red wine sauce, otto file polenta, and crispy pancetta. This was a face-foward and distinctly wine flavored dish, and the combination of slightly gamey rabbit, powerfully flavored sauce, and crispy, porky pancetta was a successful one. I wish rabbit found its way onto more menus, Thumper-related sentiments be damned.



I selected the special Ligurian fish stew with lobster broth, mussels, fish, scallops, shrimp, and mussels. The meaty and decadent broth was spiced lightly with saffron and had a piquant flash of tomato: it reminded me rather of a highly refined cioppino. The seafood was fresh and perfectly cooked, bypassing seafood stew's common issues with overcooked and rubbery shellfish. It's a light dish, almost too elegant: I would have liked a bit more of that delicious broth.



The sleeper hit of the evening were the side of brown butter brussels sprouts with capers and parmigiano reggiano ($5.00). These charmers flavored the falling-apart tender sprouts with a powerful hit of capers, rich brown butter, and distinctly stinky parmigiano. The overall flavor was that of a decadently rich and interesting casserole, and these were pretty impossible to risk - although the actual flavor of the sprouts was a secondary player here.

For the dessert course, we tried the pistachio panna cotta ($8.00), a straight forward and satisfyingly firm pudding with a nutty, slightly perfumed pistachio flavor. This was not a fancy dish, but it was a good ending to a rich meal.



We finished with a cheese plate, picking from Perbacco's nice selection of artisan cheeses. We settled on Bianco Sotto Bosco, a cow and goat milk cheese infused with truffles, and Caprino Di Riofrano, goat's milk cheese wrapped in chestnut leaf. ($12.00 for selection of two). I am no cheese critic, but both cheeses were earthy and tasty (and it is very hard to make truffled cheese bad.)

Perbacco's dining room is very sleek and contemporary, and those expecting some sort of homey regional Italian experience will be disappointed. The place has the appearance of a restaurant tailor-made for power lunches and important networking dinners: in other words, don't come expecting a romantic environment or overwrought opera music on the sound system. The beautiful people are served by what seemed to be an engaging and well trained waitstaff: our server was friendly and knowledgeable, and our food came out with impressive speed and timing.

We will certainly return to Perbacco soon. It's excellent and interesting regional Italian dining at surprisingly regional prices - there really isn't much not to love.

excerpts: Overall, Perbacco is a welcome addition to the San Francisco landscape.
I would gladly go back if I am ever in the mood for an upscale Italian meal in a quiet setting.
I think Perbacco is great for both closing the deal with a big client and for a romantic dinner with that special someone.
perbacco.author: Yan G.
perbacco.review:
It's a tough place to open a restaurant: you're on the same block as Aqua and Tadich Grill.  I mean, the former is one of the premier restaurants in the City, and the other one ... umm ... has been in business since 1849.   It's an interesting location choice, especially given that the decor suggests more of a SoMa location.  Exposed brick, stainless steel, and art deco inspired logo reminded me of my dot com days.

It's not your grandma's Italian restaurant.  Instead of focaccia bread and olive oil, you have gourmet breadsticks and pesto dip; instead of generic plates and silverware, you have elegant table settings; instead of spaghetti with meatballs, you have something more gourmet; instead of uncle Mario who is also the host and a short order cook, you have a knowledgeable, pleasant waiter.

I started with a gold and red beets salad with greens and vinaigrette dressing.  Beets are beets, but I liked the presentation.  I only ordered beets because my dinner companion ordered the arugula salad that I really wanted.  Don't blame me for wanting to be original.

Then my entree came.  I opted for the risotto with veal.  The risotto was delicious, and veal was very tender.  Granted, my plate only had two tiny medallions of veal, carefully and delicately placed in the middle of the plate, but they were really, really good.

For dessert, I opted for the pear and almond tart served with Creme Anglaise.  The tart was very rich, and the almond paste was fantastic.  Creme Anglaise was a bit too tart for my taste (no pun intended).  It tasted a bit like sour cream and custard mixed together and left in the sun for a couple of days.  Not my favorite item.  My dinner companion, however, opted for a chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream, which was clearly a better choice.  

Oh, and don't forget to order the espresso.  The tiny cup alone is worth the money.  You can feel very European drinking the espresso, or you can feel like a giant just holding a tiny cup.

Overall, Perbacco is a welcome addition to the San Francisco landscape.  I would gladly go back if I am ever in the mood for an upscale Italian meal in a quiet setting.  I think Perbacco is great for both closing the deal with a big client and for a romantic dinner with that special someone.

excerpts: I am a stickler for good linens and cutlery,ery, and Perbacco gets an A on that level.
perbacco.author: .Hon H.
perbacco.review:
Well, it was OK - but nothing too exciting, which disappointed me, given the hype.  Seated promptly, drinks and bread brought quickly.  The breadsticks were deliciously crispy and served with a little ramekin of pesto.  I didn't try the foccacia that was also brought to the table - look kinda doughy.  We ordered right away since we had gotten word that it takes about 45 minutes to receive your food, and being on our lunch hour didn't have that much time to spare

I got the Ligurian tuna salad and my companion got the tortellini and English peas.  The food was brought really fast - almost too fast!  My salad was so pretty to look at - little nicoise olives scattered around the plate along with tiny tiny little green string beans, cherry tomatoes, capers and some hard boiled quail eggs.  Unfortunately, the tuna was way overcooked and had the consistency of chicken of the sea, and there were eggshells on my plate from the hard boiled eggs.  Not quite what I was expecting.  Still, it was kind of good due to the wonderful dressing.  Ron's tortellini were kind of a dull - even the presentation was dull.

The place is pretty cool, and if you've ever eaten at it's predecessor, the Gold Coast, you would never recognize it.  They've preserved the long wooden bar and brick walls, but that's about it.  Lots of light wood paneling, thin strips of mirrors at eye level that really open up the room, and fabulous lighting.  I am a stickler for good linens and cutlery,ery, and Perbacco gets an A on that level.

All in all, it was sort of OK - but not for the price.  I think I may  try again for dinner with a group of people so we can really sample the menu.

And it was TOO DAMN LOUD!

excerpts: My wife and I ate at Perbacco for Valentines day this year and overall we had a very wonderful experience.
We highly recommend Perbacco.
It's a great complement Aqua and Tadich which it neighbors and is a very well priced alternative with very high quality cuisine.
perbacco.author: Joshua J.
perbacco.review:
My wife and I ate at Perbacco for Valentines day this year and overall we had a very wonderful experience.  I won't go into any detail about the aesthetics other than to say that the place was visually appealing and very comfortable with plenty of space between tables.  

The service was very pleasant and we had a great waiter who always kept our glasses full.  There was a rather long lull between courses but probably a result of the kitchen and not the waiter.  Our server had great suggestions which we found to be very reliable.

The menu, printed daily, is very complete with something for virtually any palate.  I highly recommend the house cured salami's - while plenty to share between 2 people these meats are so good you'll probably need a second serving.

For our second course we shared the Tajarin which was unbelievable and it was clear why this was the waiters recommendation.  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the Pork Sugo w/Porcini was very rich.

For the entrees my wife had the Sea Bass which was good but unmemorable.  I had the Pork Chop w/Pomegranate condimento which was fantastic.  This was really a great entree which seemed to be the most popular choice that evening.

Dessert was also great.  I had a pear bread pudding which was perfectly done.  My wife had the parmigiano reggiano which was some of the best we've ever had.

We highly recommend Perbacco.  It's a great complement Aqua and Tadich which it neighbors and is a very well priced alternative with very high quality cuisine.

excerpts: Perbacco is a prime example of service!
The front of the house was very nice and helpful when we thought we had reservations but didn't.
We were seated upstairs and it was packed with all these business meetings/luncheons.
Our server knew the menu.
When my friend wanted wine, she was immediately tended to.
We shared Piasta Seared Local Squid and Frito Misto Rock Shrimp.
Flavorful and beautifully cooked explains those appetizers.
We each had a pasta dish: Tajarin, Pansoti, and the Pappardelle.
The noodles of the Tajarin were so fresh and I loved the handmade texture and look.
Its meat sauce was comforting and delicious.
The Pansoti was flavorful of herbs and just perfect with the cheese.
The Pappardelle was amazing, especially its shredded short rib.
Tender, juicy, scrumptious!
Any meat eater would love that dish.
Of course we had dessert: Bonet-Piemontese Expresso Custard and the Huckleberry and Meyer Lemon Semifreddi.
Two awesome, dessert scores!!
I'm not one for anything coffee flavored, but this custard was perfecto in every way.
The semifreddi was presented beautifully and just a wonderful fresher and touch to the end of our meal.
I want my husband to take me back here for sure.
perbacco.author: Kekumukula N.
perbacco.review:
I dined here for the very first time with two friends.  Perbacco is a prime example of service!  The front of the house was very nice and helpful when we thought we had reservations but didn't.  We were seated upstairs and it was packed with all these business meetings/luncheons.  Our server knew the menu.  When my friend wanted wine, she was immediately tended to.  
We shared Piasta Seared Local Squid and Frito Misto Rock Shrimp.  Flavorful and beautifully cooked explains those appetizers.  We each had a pasta dish: Tajarin, Pansoti, and the Pappardelle.  The noodles of the Tajarin were so fresh and I loved the handmade texture and look.  Its meat sauce was comforting and delicious.  The Pansoti was flavorful of herbs and just perfect with the cheese.  The Pappardelle was amazing, especially its shredded short rib.  Tender, juicy, scrumptious!  Any meat eater would love that dish.
Of course we had dessert: Bonet-Piemontese Expresso Custard and the Huckleberry and Meyer Lemon Semifreddi.  Two awesome, dessert scores!!!  I'm not one for anything coffee flavored, but this custard was perfecto in every way.  The semifreddi was presented beautifully and just a wonderful fresher and touch to the end of our meal.
I want my husband to take me back here for sure.

excerpts: Still, Perbacco comes dangerously close to the overpriced/under-impressive touristy feel that befalls downtown restaurants.
Everything about Perbacco was good, but nothing about it was really great.
Considering our tab came out to nearly $100 apiece (including a cocktail and half-bottle of wine), I'd probably save Perbacco for out-of-towners on an expense account.
It seems the perfect power lunching spot, but for a nice San Francisco dinner, you can definitely do better.
perbacco.author: Aaron L.
perbacco.review:
You know you live in a city that spoils your taste buds when a place like this only receives two stars. Still, Perbacco comes dangerously close to the overpriced/under-impressive touristy feel that befalls downtown restaurants. Everything about Perbacco was good, but nothing about it was really great. 

I arrived early for my early meal (5:45 pm), and was seated in a rather unfavorable seat right under the Muzak speaker. When I asked to be moved shortly thereafter, the hostess became irritated and said the more attractive section I was pointing to was "reserved for those with reservations," as if to say I didn't have one. (I did.) Still, I was moved to a slightly quieter--if more claustrophobic table--further in the back. It wasn't like they were really hurting for seats--this two-level place is rather large, despite its modest facade. But whatever. At least I could dine without K.T. Tunstall blaring in my ears.

The food arrived promptly and with a competent pacing. The introductory bread sticks we received were strangely greasy, although tasty. We opted to try the house-cured prosciutto, which was delicious, especially when paired with the bread sticks. I started with the sugo pasta (nice that they offer their pastas as small or large portions, btw). Was very good, but definitely not the best I'd ever had. The entrees that followed were equally tasty... and good, but not great. My seared tuna was a generous cut of fish, but sort of bland. My friend seemed a lot happier with his skate wing. Desserts came to nearly $10 apiece, and considering the non-stellar-ness of everything thus far, it was enough to make me decide that tuna and sugo had filled me up.

Considering our tab came out to nearly $100 apiece (including a cocktail and half-bottle of wine), I'd probably save Perbacco for out-of-towners on an expense account. It seems the perfect power lunching spot, but for a nice San Francisco dinner, you can definitely do better.

excerpts: Oh, and Perbacco also gets a thumbs up for their open kitchen area.
perbacco.author: Alexis M.
perbacco.review:
I went on a business lunch here.  The food was very good.  And it is in a great location relative to my office.  I didn't really care for the full length bedroom mirrors turned sideways that form a border around the restaurant walls or the cave type seating area under the upper seating area or the light fixtures.  

But all of this is pish posh.  The main thing here is good food for a good price in a great location.  The rest is all details.  Oh, and Perbacco also gets a thumbs up for their open kitchen area.  If you get the back table you can watch the action.  

If you want to get a group larger than 6 people in here, book more than a week ahead!

excerpts: I really wanted to like Perbacco and many people do, so certainly give them a try.
perbacco.author: Ed L.
perbacco.review:
Maybe more like "debacle" for us (couldn't resist the pun). We came here after having drinks a couple of dooors down at Aqua. Funny that the group that in front of us also was at Aqua for drinks. Apparently this was an omen of things to come. They arrived about 15mins before and after another 10mins the person in charge went up to the hostess and said cancel our reservation and this is the third time it's happened to me. OK, not us but... we we seated 15mins pass our reservation (happens, it's a Saturday night). We are taken upstairs and seated in a booth. Drafty and dark along the railing overlooking the main dining area and bar. We're moved one over. Still dark and a small book-light was supplied to help us read our menus.

Appetizers:
Tasting of Salame (good)
Prosciutto de San Danielle over melon (very good)
Raw seas scallops with tomato cruda, coriander oil and sea salt (fair-scallop taste lost in the oil)

Entrees:
Beef short ribs with chanterelle mushrooms/peas and mashed potatoes (1-Very good and one was cold and was changed to the Tajarin pasta and the other barely any sauce)
Tajarin pasta (tagliatelle noodles with pork sugo and porcini mushrooms (very good).

Once ordered, everything came very quickly. The entrees came right after we finished our appetizers. Even the replacement dish came quickly. Now an odd part. It's starting to empty out alittle and the service just about disappeared. They'd walk by but not check-in to clear the empty plates. Finally when cleared, the dessert menu came very late so we passed and went to Buena Vista for some Irish Coffee.

Granted, it's unfair to rate places on a 1st visit which is what many of the reviews are and I like to give the benefit of the doubt most of the time. That's what so nice about this site/forum, you can change the rating up or down with future visits.

I really wanted to like Perbacco and many people do, so certainly give them a try.

excerpts: still holds the top accolade but Perbacco might be able to kick her off ---- maybe..

:) 
- Agnolotti - pillows of tasty raviolis filled with veal.
YUM!!!!
perbacco.author: H. Q.
perbacco.review:
This place has become what Aqua was about 5 years ago. It is THE place for the power lunch.  Fi-Di folks left and right wining and dining and making the deal. 

Prices might be considered a little higher than most places within the Fi-Di but the quality of the food is quite excellent. I believe they are more liguarian style italian food.  As a chef had once told me, "to judge an italian restaurant, you have to try their pasta"  We'll get to that soon enough.

Appetizers:
- Fritto misto - crisp, delicate and not oily!  
- Salumi misti - housemade cured meats!  Need I say more than SALAME and PROSCUITTO! my oh my....
- Beet salad - absolute SUGAR bomb!  paired with arugula and light sprinking of cheese 

Pasta:
- Parpadelle with a short rib ragu: anyone who knows me knows my insane love and obsession with finding the best ragu in the world. Right now, my italian friend's "mama!" still holds the top accolade but Perbacco might be able to kick her off ---- maybe.. :) 
- Agnolotti - pillows of tasty raviolis filled with veal.  YUM!!!!
- Trofie - very fresh pesto and a pretty generous portion of pasta.  

Mains:
- Ligurian tuna salad - the italian style nicoise with a substantial piece of tuna seared on the outside and rare on the inside. 
- Grilled chicken breast - not the most spectacular of their menu but for a lighter option it is good.  Chicken is very moist, even for chicken breasts.  hehe.

Be prepared for a wait, especially without reservations... OR go early i.e. 11:30.  You might also be able to find some financial district eye candy - men in suits! (it totally does something for me!) :)

excerpts: I was the first of my party to arrive at Perbacco and headed to the bar for a glass of wine.
Seats were not available at the bar, somehow I managed to hang on to the wine in front of the doorway awkwardly until dinner time.
It was amazingly busy for a Tuesday night.
We had reservations for 8:00 pm and weren't seated until 8:30, but redemption was earned by a complementary platter of salumi misto and an explanation from whom I assumed to be the gm of the place.
The salumi misto was terrific
( I would have ordered it anyway).
perbacco.author: Uimuim B.
perbacco.review:
Slick, Modern, Hip and Great for people watching - investment bankers, executives and politician types... I was the first of my party to arrive at Perbacco and headed to the bar for a glass of wine.  Seats were not available at the bar, somehow I managed to hang on to the wine in front of the doorway awkwardly until dinner time.  It was amazingly busy for a Tuesday night.  We had reservations for 8:00 pm and weren't seated until 8:30, but redemption was earned by a complementary platter of salumi misto and an explanation from whom I assumed to be the gm of the place.  The salumi misto was terrific ( I would have ordered it anyway).  It instantly made me feel better.

The place was sleet with some exposed brick.  The front of the restaurant was rather narrow.  As you walk through the front door, you would never expect that it opens up to large dining area in the back.  I don't remember if the restaurant had white marble/stone walls, but as you enter the lower level to the restrooms, the walls were in white stone.

The food was decent.  My favorite, as you may have guessed, is the salumi.  My second favorite was the breadsticks with the pesto sauce.  We ordered the hamachi - big mistake - perhaps sushi at an Italian restaurant is not the most brilliant idea - it was on the fishy side.  My pork shoulder was good, but a little on the dry side and Hubby's sirloin  was slathered with blue cheese - which he thought was a pity -- good meat should not be covered with heavy cheese flavoring!

The wine list was predominantly Italy.  It was a great opportunity to try Italian wines in preparation for Hubby and my upcoming trip to Italy.

My recommendation would be to go there for drinks and appetizers (salumi).  Dinner would be okay - just because they try hard and the food is decent and the staff are genuinely nice.

excerpts: At Perbacco, I got my lime right after I asked.
perbacco.author: Candice B.
perbacco.review:
Went there for a business lunch with 6 other people.  Sleek interior, attentive and fast service.

I judge the service by requesting a slice of lime for my sparkling water.  If they forget, that's bad.  If I have ask twice, that's questionable.  At Perbacco, I got my lime right after I asked.  So points for that!

Most of us had the Organic Peach salad with arugula and almonds.  Nice pairing of juicy Peaches and crunchy almonds.  I decided to have the sole for entree which the waiter chose when I asked what he would recommend between the sole, swordfish and the duck.  It came in a big portion.  The sweet corn from the sole dish was very delicious.  Fish was well done, juicy, not too cooked.  But nothing special for a $20 dish. 

Desserts looked very pretty.  I didn't have any but everyone else seems to like theirs.  I had a cup of organic English Breakfast instead and that was satisfying to me. 

I am surprised that people liked the bread sticks there.  I thought they were very ordinary (I like bread sticks from Hog Island, actually).  

Overall, I enjoyed it as a free lunch.  But if I had to pay for it myself, I would've gone somewhere else.  Although it does seem to be a very popular lunch spot.  When we were leaving around 1:45pm, there were about half a dozen people waiting to be seated.

excerpts:
Cow Milk/Aged

Drinks
PERBACCO! -
perbacco.author: Alice C.
perbacco.review:
I love this place! I just want to say thank to the waitress that night for being great and helpful!! 

I was getting a happy hour together for clients and needed a table for 12ppl. The dinner tables were not available - apparently lots of xmas parties that night. BUT I was able to hold the front two tables which they usually don't let you.

The waitress with the awesome hair (sorry sweetie I forgot your name) was so nice to us even though we were rowdy (after a couple too many sippies) and explained the menu to us.

Appetizers:
Castelvetrano Olives
Salumi Misti
Fritto Misto
Medjool Dates Filled with Gorgonzola and Coppa

CHEESES - I love their cheeses! The girl was very knowledgable and explained all the cheeses - especially the bleu pointing the lightest to strongest taste:
Castelmagno Dop
Cave Mixed Milk Cheese
Rutulin Di Capra
Fresh Goat's Milk Cheese 
Testun Al Barolo
Mixed Milk Cheese 
Brescianella All'Aquavite
Cow's Milk Cheese
Parmigiano Reggiano
Cow Milk/Aged

Drinks
PERBACCO! - I love this signature drink! 
Mandarino - This is okay. I had more (3) of the Perbaccos

Desserts:
Olive Oil Panna Cotta
Pear and Almond Tart
Warm Hazelnut Cake
Warm Chocolate Souffle Cake
Gelati Misti

YUM YUM YUM.....Will definitely go again.

excerpts: Perbacco is your place.
Good place for business or informal meetings.
The place can get a little packed at times, so I always take a later lunch.
Salumi is a safe bet to start, pasta dishes are great, try the ravioli or gnocchi.
I've tried the sea bass once for dinner, fresh and tender
is all I can say.
I don't like the noise though
, it can get loud in that place, good for groups at night.
Service is a-ok.
Panna Cotta is a can't miss by the way and choco cake goes great with their espressos.
All in all, this place does food right, nothing really negative to say.
perbacco.author: Jon Z.
perbacco.review:
Tired of Subway or Bistro burger and looking to splurge a little for lunch?  Perbacco is your place.  Good place for business or informal meetings.  The place can get a little packed at times, so I always take a later lunch.  
Salumi is a safe bet to start, pasta dishes are great, try the ravioli or gnocchi.  I've tried the sea bass once for dinner, fresh and tender is all I can say.  
I don't like the noise though, it can get loud in that place, good for groups at night.  Service is a-ok.  Panna Cotta is a can't miss by the way and choco cake goes great with their espressos.  All in all, this place does food right, nothing really negative to say.

excerpts: I went to Perbacco to meet an old friend for dinner a few months ago.
Unfortunately, that pork chop probably wouldn't be enough to make me go back to Perbacco again.
perbacco.author: Ava S.
perbacco.review:
I went to Perbacco to meet an old friend for dinner a few months ago. Overall, I came out of the dinner with a lot less money in my pocket, and only semi-satisfied with the experience.

First of all, the interior is very sleek. Unfortunately, the tables are really close together. I kind of felt like I was eating dinner with the people next to us.

Secondly, the service is not as impressive as it should be. It was slow, and we didn't feel like our waiter was giving us an honest impression of the food. My dining companion asked if the appetizer salad was big enough to share. The waiter said no, it was very tiny. When it came out, it was massive!

The food overall was pretty good. I had a very delicious pork chop. Unfortunately, that pork chop probably wouldn't be enough to make me go back to Perbacco again.

excerpts: It was a birthday card from Perbacco
- I thought that was a very nice touch.
perbacco.author: erika n.
perbacco.review:
I celebrated my 30th birthday here w/my girlfriends and it did not disappoint.  Ambiance was great, service was superb.  I walked to the table and already there was a little card w/my name on it propped up in the center of the table.  It was a birthday card from Perbacco - I thought that was a very nice touch.  :)

the food:
yellowfin tuna w/watermelon, mint and pepper: this dish was so refreshing and delicious.  the sweetness of the watermelon was really accentuated by the sharpness of the mint and pepper.
salumi misti: the platter has everything you could want from salami to lardo to ciccioli (pork pate) - i especially enjoyed the pork pate on bread and the breadsticks.
pappardelle: wide ribbon pasta w/duck ragu - this was extremely flavorful and satisfying w/o being too filling, i would highly recommend it!
gelati: the burnt caramel gelato was to die for!  the sea salt tickles your tongue to bring out the sweetness of the caramel.

excerpts: My husband and I just had a terrific lunch at Perbacco.
The atmosphere was perfect.
I would love to go back to Perbacco, and if it were in Portland, it would become a favorite spot.
perbacco.author: Plumeria P.
perbacco.review:
My husband and I just had a terrific lunch at Perbacco. The atmosphere was perfect. "Casual elegance" gets overused, but this place embodies that description.

Excellent service. Water glasses were never empty and my napkin was neatly folded at the table when I got back from the restroom. 

The food was amazing. The bartlett pear salad with marcona almonds was exceptional. The fennel and brussel sprouts sides were super savory and the butternut squash ravioli was heavenly. Very rich though so I'm glad my husband I split that dish!

I would love to go back to Perbacco, and if it were in Portland, it would become a favorite spot.

excerpts: I had a wonderful experience at Perbacco!
perbacco.author: Cara D.
perbacco.review:
Mmmmm so yummy!  I had a wonderful experience at Perbacco!  The ambiance was great- super hip, but you don't have to be hip, can be casual or dressy and great for all occasions!

The burrata was phenomenal with heirloom tomatoes.  Just what I would expect for a top of the line Italian Restaurant.  I also got the ricotta gnocchi with  mushrooms and mushroom sauce and it was delicious!  The gnocchi was not heavy like other gnocchi but so fresh!  The mushrooms were also amazing too and the aroma was to die for.  

Also, I had to get dessert-- couldn't pass that up!  I got the chocolate dessert with a bunch of little testers of yummy chocolate.  I loved it all!  The only one complaint was that one of my little desserts was too bitter, and I love bitter chocolate.  Surprising.

Lastly, I really enjoyed the wine I had.  With the help of our waiter, we selected a delicious wine that complemented our meal!

All in all, this is a great experience with great food!  Defiantly check this place out!

excerpts: The service drags Perbacco down to 2 stars.
I knocked off early and went to wait for some friends.
I sat at the bar (alone).
perbacco.author: Lena J.
perbacco.review:
I had dinner on a slow weekday and left feeling underwhelmed and  cranky.  The food was generally very good - lovely hearty, meaty pasta's and a chocolate tart that I fell deeply in love with.  The space is mellow but feels impersonal.  

The service drags Perbacco down to 2 stars.  I knocked off early and went to wait for some friends.  I sat at the bar (alone).  While at the bar I asked for the wine list, asked to order wine, asked for water, asked for a dinner menu, asked a question on the menu, asked to order food, asked to order another glass of wine.  

Ouch!  That's a lot of asking when the staff to patron ration is 4:1.  When engaged, the staff was friendly and knowlegeable.  But mostly I was ignored (until I got the bill for $75, which come to think of it, I had to ask for).

excerpts: Perbacco is the place!
I feel like 4 stars isn't enough for Perbacco, but I am hesitant to give it 5.
I will most likely be going back sometime in the future!
perbacco.author: Elaine S.
perbacco.review:
Want to feel like you are on the east coast (brick wall inside), want a great atmosphere, want great service, and want great food? Perbacco is the place!

The ambiance was great, very cozy and upscale. They start off by giving you bread sticks w/ some pesto dip, then come and individually put bread on your bread plate. They were very prompt on filling the water glasses and towards the end of our dinner after I had said I didn't need any more water, the waiter came and filled it and said, "sorry, I hate seeing your glass empty." Now that's good service! Although our server was a little clumsy, he was very charming, attentive & cute too!

The first dish I ordered was a pear and endive salad, which I liked, but was not impressed by...maybe b/c it is such a common combination for a salad. My next course was the butternut squash ravioli, which I LOVED...although had a tiny bit too much oil on it. The dessert was AMAZING. I ordered the warm chocolate cake, which was really rich and was served with awesome hazelnut ice cream...I can still taste it in my mouth, YUM!

I feel like 4 stars isn't enough for Perbacco, but I am hesitant to give it 5. I will most likely be going back sometime in the future!

excerpts: all contribute to the continued success of Perbacco.
And it's a block from my office!
But honestly, I'm always impressed when the quality of food and service remains high no matter how packed the bar area gets.
My recommendations are the Minestrone soup, the Pappardelle, the white beans, and their signature cocktail The Perbacco.
Less formal than Aqua, less stuffy than Tadich, but more posh than beer and meatballs at Harrington's or Schroeder's around the corner, you can't go wrong with Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Marina Maven C.
perbacco.review:
There is a reason this place fills up both at lunch and after work.  Amazing food, good service, and top notch wine and cocktails all contribute to the continued success of Perbacco.  And it's a block from my office!   But honestly, I'm always impressed when the quality of food and service remains high no matter how packed the bar area gets.  The interior is sleek and maneuverable, even during peak crowd times.

My recommendations are the Minestrone soup, the Pappardelle, the white beans, and their signature cocktail The Perbacco.  If you're in a wine kind of mood, there are many good picks.  

Less formal than Aqua, less stuffy than Tadich, but more posh than beer and meatballs at Harrington's or Schroeder's around the corner, you can't go wrong with Perbacco.

excerpts: We really enjoyed Perbacco.
The atmosphere was very "classy" and fairly formal.
Service was spot on but friendly enough that it didn't seem overly formal.
We were fully ready to order quite a bit more than we did but our server suggested we share due to portion size.
The charcuterie selection was excellent, much more focused on raw sausages and pates than cured meats, which was a nice change.
Our server was right, the portions were large and we were able to share a an appetizer and a main after the large salumi selection.
The wine list is fairly large and our server gave us excellent direction on glasses and then a bottle.
Our only difficulty with the evening came when it was time to try to get a cab at the end of the night and basically none were to be found in the fairly empty financial district.
We had to wait a while, but obviously that has nothing to do with the restaurant.
Highly Recommended
perbacco.author: Benjamin B.
perbacco.review: We really enjoyed Perbacco. The atmosphere was very "classy" and fairly formal. Service was spot on but friendly enough that it didn't seem overly formal. We were fully ready to order quite a bit more than we did but our server suggested we share due to portion size. The charcuterie selection was excellent, much more focused on raw sausages and pates than cured meats, which was a nice change. Our server was right, the portions were large and we were able to share a an appetizer and a main after the large salumi selection. The wine list is fairly large and our server gave us excellent direction on glasses and then a bottle. Our only difficulty with the evening came when it was time to try to get a cab at the end of the night and basically none were to be found in the fairly empty financial district. We had to wait a while, but obviously that has nothing to do with the restaurant. Highly Recommended

excerpts: Let me start out by saying the food at Perbacco was very good.
perbacco.author: S V.
perbacco.review:
We came here in January without a reservation because the first place we had a reservation for had problems with the utility service, effectively shutting their kitchen down.  

Let me start out by saying the food at Perbacco was very good.  

However, all the other negatives led me to giving this place one star.  

First, this restaurant is LOUD.  We got a table right by the bar, which didn't help.  Could barely carry a conversation here.  Be sure to request a table away from this area if you go.  

Second, we got what was probably the newbie in the service staff.  While he was polite and efficient, he made the biggest mistake any server could make......by dropping utensils into my expensive Abboud dress shirt.  I realize it's an accident, but the restaurant did not do enough to offset the blunder.  Nothing was comped on our bill, even though the manager, Mr. Cirilli, came by, apologized, and handed me his business card and said he'd take care of the dry cleaning bill.

Third, to this day, I've yet to be reimbursed for the dry cleaning.  It's been over five weeks since I sent him the email with the attached receipt.

Three strikes and you're out!  I don't care how good the food is at this place.  I'll neither come back nor recommend this restaurant to anyone
I know because of the bad taste left in my mouth by its poor customer service.

excerpts: Perbacco is good value because it excels on the quality-price ratio.
The antipasti are creative and tasty.
The pasta is delightful.
Dessert was definitely worth ordering.
What's not to like?
Wine list is comprehensive.
Limited grappa selection
but I can't say that I crave grappa.
There are a decent number of Super Tuscans on the list.
perbacco.author: Koy T.
perbacco.review: Perbacco is good value because it excels on the quality-price ratio.  The antipasti are creative and tasty.  The pasta is delightful.  Dessert was definitely worth ordering.  What's not to like?  Wine list is comprehensive.  Limited grappa selection but I can't say that I crave grappa.  There are a decent number of Super Tuscans on the list.

excerpts: It's nothing that special, nor is this restaurant for that matter, but if you want a good meal and haven't tried Perbacco yet, there's really no reason why you shouldn't go.
perbacco.author: Philip W.
perbacco.review:
I'm not usually one for fancy meals (which should be painfully obvious by the fact that I'm calling this place a fancy meal), but I was pleasantly surprised when I came here for lunch.

I'm no food enthusiast.  To me, what goes in just ends up coming back out anyways.  But every so often I'm reminded that the entire process can be made much more pleasant if what goes down is smooth and well prepared.  Since I don't really have much in my palette to which I can compare the meal I had here, I'll just say that it was delicious, and that I left not a smudge on my plate.

What was truly intriguing about this place though was the bathroom downstairs.  I was confused looking for the mens' room until I realized that the individual booths/stalls/toilets sorta negates the need for separate bathrooms...at least I hope that was the correct conclusion.  Anyhow, if you get the chance to go, check it out.  It's nothing that special, nor is this restaurant for that matter, but if you want a good meal and haven't tried Perbacco yet, there's really no reason why you shouldn't go.

excerpts: the fish of the day (perbacco knows how to do their fish) was sea bass
i've shopped around all the places in sf with an ocd excel spread sheet of room charges, food prices etc...and perbacco won by a mile.
perbacco.author: Anh V.
perbacco.review:
co-hosted a lively baby shower in one of their private rooms.

with guidance from the lovely dining director, nicole:
we rented the smaller room which seats up to 18 people.  they put up a "gift" table for all of the fun prezzies and even had our theme printed on the menu.

corkage was 20$ a pop for our bubbles for toasting that we brought but they did pair some affordable wines with our entrees.

due to the large size, we had to have a set menu and it's a big task for a foodie to pare it down to only a couple of choices but i did...and here was our selection:

we had the egg raviolo - you cut into the pasta and a lovely soft egg ran out and blended with the sauce.  absolutely fantastic!  everyone was sopping up the sauce with bread.

the pear salad was light and perfect (i sampled it off the guest to my left) but i'm for all carbs, carbs, carbs!

the filet mignon was a giant block of tenderness that just melted in your mouth.  the potato gratin was heavy and creamy.  thank goodness i left the spanx at home and put on a roomy dress.

the fish of the day (perbacco knows how to do their fish) was sea bass - i didn't sample it so i can't attest to it but the ladies who did enjoyed it.

dessert was a warm chocolate cake with whole pieces of hazelnut tucked in.  we also had two cheese plates with a variety smooth and hard cheeses that were enjoyed with our coffees.

so if you have a special event...i've shopped around all the places in sf with an ocd excel spread sheet of room charges, food prices etc...and perbacco won by a mile.

excerpts: I heart Perbacco liking because of past memories of yummy lunches.
The food isn't super unique but always delicious and something about the place just gets to me, but again on a personal level.
perbacco.author: Jemma L.
perbacco.review: I heart Perbacco liking because of past memories of yummy lunches. The food isn't super unique but always delicious and something about the place just gets to me, but again on a personal level. =)

excerpts: Perbacco is a great choice for an upscale lunch date in the Financial District.
Perbacco is a solid 4 stars.
I plan to come for dinner soon, so look for an updated review.
perbacco.author: Kerry D.
perbacco.review:
The boss taking you out to lunch?  Dining on the company expense account?   Need to impress a client?  Does a friend owe you a favor?  Just trying to milk someone for all they're worth?  This is the place for you!  Perbacco is a great choice for an upscale lunch date in the Financial District.  

My former co-workers were sweet enough to treat me here on my last week of work.  I started off with the Market Salad and my coworkers had the Pear and Arugula.  I don't think they expected the salad to be JUST that....pear and arugula.  I think the waitress has experienced this reaction before, so she promptly brought over lettuce to add to the salad.  Nice of her, but strange....

For the main courses, we ordered the Herb Ricotta Gnocchi (this is NOT the kind of dish I usually order--but it was out of this world), Grilled Chicken Breast Battuta, and the Trofie.  Everything was delicious.  I will also note that we were on a little bit of a time crunch and the food was served in a timely manner (even though the place was jumpin').  

Perbacco is a solid 4 stars.  I plan to come for dinner soon, so look for an updated review.

excerpts: Perbacco is the perfect restaurant for any occasion.
It's sophiscated and classy for a business dinner.
It's intimate and not over the top romantic for a date.
It's also nice and not pretentious for a dinner out with the girls.
perbacco.author: Denise L.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is the perfect restaurant for any occasion. It's sophiscated and classy for a business dinner. It's intimate and not over the top romantic for a date. It's also nice and not pretentious for a dinner out with the girls. And that was just what I needed last night!

For my entree, I had the Tajarin: 5 hour pork sugo tagliatelle with porcini mushrooms. It was delicious! The pasta were so thin and freshly made. (looked like ramen) The pork sugo sauce with porcini mushrooms was amazing! The pork meat was so delicious, you could tell that they were cooking it for a long time. It was savory, but slightly sweet. I had a bite of my friend's pappardelle short ribs and that was very good. I was slightly jealous of her dish. My other friend had the duck risotto and it was very rich and heavenly. There was  a lot of duck meat in it too.

For dessert, we had the chocolate tart and squash crostata. The chocolate tart was pretty good. The crust was very flaky and it was filled with a thin layer of caramel and the chocolate was very smooth and almost pudding like. It came with a large scoop of whipped cream and sprinkles of hazelnuts. My favorite of the desserts was the squash crostata. When I first read the description, I was very intrigued by the use of squash in a dessert. Since I love being adventurous, I decided to give it a try. I'm SO glad I did! It looked like a piece of pie, but the crust was made more flaky and the filling was sweet squash. It also came with a side of pumpkin ice cream. It was such a unique combination of ingredients and I loved it!!

I would definitely recommend checking this place out if you're in the financial district. It's the perfect place to go for dinner after work!

excerpts: I love perbacco.
We eat here about once a month since I work only 2 blocks from the joint.
I can't tell you how much I love the hazelnut cookies and the braised pork shoulder with savoy cabbage.
It literally falls off the bone after being braised in milk and cooked for hours...
perbacco.author: Glory W.
perbacco.review:
I love perbacco. We eat here about once a month since I work only 2 blocks from the joint. I can't tell you how much I love the hazelnut cookies and the braised pork shoulder with savoy cabbage. It literally falls off the bone after being braised in milk and cooked for hours...YUMMMMMM....

That being said, the service can be a bit slow, so don't come here if you are in a rush. If you're in the mood to mellow out and take in the lovely decor while savoring your glass of italian wine, you're in the right place.

excerpts: I see a bright future for Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Shannon M.
perbacco.review:
I see a bright future for Perbacco.  I had the pleasure of dining here for the Slow Food Golden Glass dinner last Sunday and it was lovely. 

 We enjoyed two successive Primi courses, first of Louisiana Prawns over several bean varietals with arugula; and the next, a course of rabbit raviolis.  The Prawns were flavorful and tender and paired beautifully with the beans and arugula.  The raviolis were absolutely divine, perfectly cooked and had the most amazing gravy.  Secondi was a Roasted Pork over polenta that melted in your mouth.  It was braised in wine and milk, I assume for hours, because the meat was so tender you could cut it with your fork.  For dessert, we were presented a Meyer Lemon Semi-Freddo which was good but not spectacular.  The chocolate cupcake offering was, however, quite yummy.

All the courses were accompanied with lovely Italian wines and we enjoyed a explanation from the chef and winemakers on their craft, philosophy and approach.  In true Slow Food fashion, our dinner lasted several hours -- they way it should be.

excerpts: For someone who prefers a lighter lunch (e.g. salads and sandwiches), the menu offering for Perbacco can be a bit daunting as most of its food is on the heavy side.
perbacco.author: buggy b.
perbacco.review:
Situated across the street from our office, it's the business lunch of choice for most of my colleagues. Without reservations, it's best to be there right when they open (11:30 on weekdays) to secure any sort of seating. By noon, the place gets pretty packed and busy. 

For someone who prefers a lighter lunch (e.g. salads and sandwiches), the menu offering for Perbacco can be a bit daunting as most of its food is on the heavy side. I opted for the market salad (fresh ingredients with a tasty lemon vinaigrette) and gnocchi (too creamy and rich for my taste) - couldn't finish either one, and was a bit disheartened to turn down dessert because there just wasn't any room left in me (the pear bread pudding sounds so good!). 

Catering to the business crowd, one thing is certain - service is excellent. They are friendly and extremely knowledgeable. Definitely worth checking out.

excerpts: Its difficult to say anything bad about Perbacco.
Its specially difficult when you didn't pick up the tab.
The food was very good and the service was excellent.
perbacco.author: Abhi S.
perbacco.review:
Sometimes the best places are right under your nose. This doesn't mean that much since I am blessed with a large Punjabi one and it doesn't narrow the choices by much. 

Its difficult to say anything bad about Perbacco. Its specially difficult when you didn't pick up the tab.  The food was very good and the service was excellent. The gentleman that was waiting on our table was warm, classy and very helpful (I was tempted to call him sir on many occasions). 

The salumi is made in house and is excellent! This was followed by the local sea bass with golden chanterelle  and potato stew. 

The pasta selection could be more extensive and they don't have beer on tap - it probably isn't the right place to be drinking beer anyway.

excerpts: dinner at Perbacco.
Everything unrelated to the flavor of the food was pristine at Perbacco.
Service was excellent.

My fiancée and I arrived a bit early for our reservation and the host informed us that we could be seated immediately or we could have a drink at the bar and then go to our table whenever we were ready.
We choose the latter option and enjoyed a glass of wine at the bar.
Sadly, the "by the glass" wine list was a bit lacking not offering as many choices as you would expect from a place like Perbacco.
Once ready to dine, we were promptly seated at our table.
Perbacco has a very cool option where for $18 per person, the entire table can try three different pastas (risotto does not count as pasta for this purpose).

We tried: (1) the tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms; (2) the tortelli filled with wild nettles and toped with toasted hazelnuts; and (3) the gnocchi with duck ragu and chanterelles.
Out of the three, the gnocchi was by far the best.
The other two pastas, while cooked beautifully, lacked flavor.

The sauce accompanying the tortelli wasn't flavorful enough to cancel out the earthiness of the nettles (which, if you had nettles before, has a strong weed (think pests in your garden not the medicinal herb)  like flavor).
As for the tagliatelle, it needed some heat . . .
some flavor to make it sing .
however, in lacking that flavor dimension, it was fairly standard pasta with a braised meat sauce.
Good . . .
So, as you can see, I don't have anything scathing to say about Perbacco.
The ambiance, service, and execution of the food was exceptional.
The flavor, however, was lacking and that's what dropped the restaurant down a star for me.
The flavor of the food is what makes a restaurant stand out and Perbacco lacked that essential element.
Thus, for me, Perbaccao has been lowered to the level of just another good Italian restaurant in SF that doesn't do anything different or note-worthy.
perbacco.author: Oski B.
perbacco.review:
Having thoroughly enjoyed my  lunch at Barbacco it was time to move on to the main event . . . dinner at Perbacco.

Everything unrelated to the flavor of the food was pristine at Perbacco.  Service was excellent.  My fiancée and I arrived a bit early for our reservation and the host informed us that we could be seated immediately or we could have a drink at the bar and then go to our table whenever we were ready.  We choose the latter option and enjoyed a glass of wine at the bar.  Sadly, the "by the glass" wine list was a bit lacking not offering as many choices as you would expect from a place like Perbacco.  Once ready to dine, we were promptly seated at our table.  The staff was very accommodating - and there was no delay in getting our table because we choose to have a drink first.

To begin, we shared the roasted octopus (a favorite of mine that I order every time I see it on a menu) and the burrata with asparagus.  (For my lone follower, the octopus was good (cooked well) but not nearly as good as at Bottega.  It was far better than Kokkari's, however.)  Despite its proper preparation, the octopus lacked flavor and was overpowered by the lemon flavor of the grilled scallions (lemon that was already added to the dish in the kitchen).  The burrata was good but overall the dish was nothing special as the asparagus lacked flavor (definitely needed salt).  We ended the appetizer portion of our meal wishing that it had more punch . . . more flavor . . . but perhaps that's just our palate preference.

For an entree, my fiancee and I got the trio of pasta.  Perbacco has a very cool option where for $18 per person, the entire table can try three different pastas (risotto does not count as pasta for this purpose).  We tried: (1) the tagliatelle with 5 hour pork sugo and porcini mushrooms; (2) the tortelli filled with wild nettles and toped with toasted hazelnuts; and (3) the gnocchi with duck ragu and chanterelles.  Out of the three, the gnocchi was by far the best.  The other two pastas, while cooked beautifully, lacked flavor.  The sauce accompanying the tortelli wasn't flavorful enough to cancel out the earthiness of the nettles (which, if you had nettles before, has a strong weed (think pests in your garden not the medicinal herb)  like flavor).  As for the tagliatelle, it needed some heat . . . some flavor to make it sing . . . however, in lacking that flavor dimension, it was fairly standard pasta with a braised meat sauce.  Good . . . but something numerous other Italian restaurants with far less cache offer up.    

For dessert we got the chocolate gilato with espresso cookies.  It was good but exactly what you would expect it to be.  It is the same chocolate gilato you've had at many other places.  

So, as you can see, I don't have anything scathing to say about Perbacco.  The ambiance, service, and execution of the food was exceptional.  The flavor, however, was lacking and that's what dropped the restaurant down a star for me.  The flavor of the food is what makes a restaurant stand out and Perbacco lacked that essential element.  Thus, for me, Perbaccao has been lowered to the level of just another good Italian restaurant in SF that doesn't do anything different or note-worthy.

excerpts: Perbacco specializes in Italian food from Piemonte and Liguria...
There's not much to say, really, except that I recommend Perbacco.
It was very delicious, well prepared food served without pretension.
Easy parking on the week-end is a big plus.
Nice room, nice art on the walls.
Just plain delish.
I also recommend the book "Heat".
You will crave this kind of food after reading it, and since going to Babbo is not an option here, try Perbacco.
perbacco.author: Neile R.
perbacco.review:
My husband and I picked this place, last minute for a 10 pm dinner on our 6th wedding anniversary. I just read the book "Heat" (Bill Buford, about Mario Batali and Italian food) so I was craving Italian. Perbacco specializes in Italian food from Piemonte and Liguria...I think it's the same region of Batali's expertise.....cured meats, amazing stuffed pastas, unadulterated seafood (they have a crudo selection), and braised meat sauces.

There's not much to say, really, except that I recommend Perbacco. It was very delicious, well prepared food served without pretension. Easy parking on the week-end is a big plus. Nice room, nice art on the walls. Just plain delish. I also recommend the book "Heat". You will crave this kind of food after reading it, and since going to Babbo is not an option here, try Perbacco.

excerpts: I'm not sure where the skeptical ratings come from - we found Perbacco to be an excellent dining experience on all fronts.
perbacco.author: David F.
perbacco.review:
I'm not sure where the skeptical ratings come from - we found Perbacco to be an excellent dining experience on all fronts.  

Our course by course review is below - but to summarize for those in a hurry, an excellent meal in a warm, friendly environment. 

We made a last minute reservation via Open Table and were seated promptly.  Our server hit the perfect balance, setting a warm tone without ever being intrusive or elusive - and his recommendations and wine pairings were spot on.

We decided to go with 3 courses, and started with seasonal fare, the poached asparagus with 63 degree C egg and Reggiano Parmesan crema was a wonderful way to enjoy fresh "grass", and the salad mixing local stawberries, spring onion, argula, ricotta salata and condimento balsamico was nicely balanced.  

We followed with two different pastas (the offer half portions so you can enjoy them as a course or as a meal) - my wife enjoyed the Truffle-Herb Ricotta Gnocchi with roasted wild mushrooms and Parmigiano Reggiano - light pillows of wonderful flavor - and I was blown away by the rich yet light  Herb Angolotti filled with Roasted Rabbit in a truffled sugo d'arrosto - the chef again hit a perfect balance between rich flavor and lightness.

For our main courses, I savored every bite to the Piatto Norcino - featuring 4 distinct and perfectly spiced sausages over a bed of lentils with seasonal greens. A simple plate of peasant food, with flavors a noble would love - a wonderful dish.  My wife found the Coniglio al Civet - with 3 treatments of Devil's Gulch rabbit, a wonderful choice, The belly portion was  "rabbit bacon" and offered  crispy, flavorful goodness, complemented by generous portions of a braised leg over polenta,

For dessert, the seasonal Strawberry Semolina Cake and Goat Cheese Sorbet - yes, goat cheese, and yes it worked bee-you-tee-fully! - was a great finsh to the night.

For each course, I asked our waiter to offer wine pairings, and each Italian wine complemented the course perfectly at ~$10-$14 per glass. Total cost for 2 people, 6 dishes, 4 glasses of wine and dessert - $160.

excerpts: Impress your date or impress your clients with this Italian gem:  take them to Perbacco.
Yes it's pricey, but if you don't mind paying good prices for good food, check this place out.
Fresh pasta, bring on that awesome Italian wine list, have their homemade salami (try the appetizer Salumi Misti - mixed cured ham and meats dish).
For those that haven't been to Italy, remember one thing: the pasta is what you want to taste - the sauce should complement the pasta
-  Perbacco does this wonderfully.
For dessert, these are top notch:
Apple Crostata (apple tart-like), Gelato (3 different flavors with Sharfenberger bittersweet chocolate, pistachio and hazelnut), and my favorite the Meyer Lemon Semifreddo.
I don't want to write too much and spoil your tastebuds, just go and eat it up!
