excerpts: , I need a bathroom (which is the curse of death anywhere in SF) and Perbacco just looks convenient at this point.
perbacco.author: NaNa M.
perbacco.review:
God-dam I love Yelp mobile...I think it's changed my life. I now feel like some kind of fine dining superhero when I don't want to waste my money and time and I'm stuck on the outskirts somewhere unfamiliar.  Take for example a few Friday nights ago. My beau and I are heading off to go see a play in the city, yet we have to get off an an early station for an emergency situation *don't ask* and hence, we miss our play despite our long fruitful journey on BART.  So we're stuck in the financial district, I need a bathroom (which is the curse of death anywhere in SF) and Perbacco just looks convenient at this point.

We decided to just grab a glass of wine at their bar tables up front, but when I yelped the place and saw the great reviews, we decided to stay  for some appetizers. The antipasto plates coming out were making our mouths water, so our cool waitress recommended the chefs selection, which is basically whatever he feels like giving us. When the selection came out, we were told that they cure all the meats there and were told more about the specific region of Italy that the food originates from...I live for this stuff. To me, that whole engagement with your server makes the experience really special and our waitress was very attentive, knowledgeable and charming. My favorite standout for me was the pate' served with a kind of apricot compote-- the savory and the sweet together just pops on your tastebuds. 
I can only speak for the appetizers, drinks and the waitress- but I'll be back for entrees the next time around- but this time, intentionally.

excerpts: Opened by famed former Scala's chef, Steffan Terje, PerBacco specializes in Northern Tuscan food.
perbacco.author: Papandreou A.
perbacco.review:
Opened by famed former Scala's chef, Steffan Terje, PerBacco specializes in Northern Tuscan food.

They have done a wonderful job with the space.  Lots of different woods conspire to make a very timeless and comfortable feel.

Service was fantastic....our waiter was very attentive but not overbearing.

And the food...aaaaah!  Short rib pappardelle was spectacular.  The salumi selection was large and the taste incredible (Terje makes it himself).

I highly recommend this joint

excerpts: i think the best thing about perbacco is the service.
from the cute ladies who host, to the adorable italian waitress who took care of my mom and i, to the flirty, energetic and attentive bartenders.
perbacco.author: rachel p.
perbacco.review:
i think the best thing about perbacco is the service. from the cute ladies who host, to the adorable italian waitress who took care of my mom and i, to the flirty, energetic and attentive bartenders. i think the service here is WAY more memorable than the food is. 

at dinner w/ mom we shared a salad and each got our own pasta. i had something with truffle oil and rabbit, a dish that from the menu discription soudned like it would explode with flavor. instead it was a bit heavy and uninspired. i actually got tired of it about half-way thru! my mom found her pasta slightly disappointing as well. 

 i went again about a week ago and sat at the bar where we got to experience those uber-friendly bartenders. i could see how eating near these guys would get you excited about the food. they're terrific salesmen, and when you get treated nice like that it makes everything taste better. still tho, i was a lil underwhelmed with our apps and pasta dish. again, pretty good. but not great. not even really memorable. i ate it, i got full. i watched the bartenders swing maniacally back and forth between thirsty patrons with smiles and winks and all manner of flirtatiousness. i was entertained for sure, but not really satisfied. 

if the one thing people seem to rave about on reviews are the salami and cheese and cute bartenders, then you need to step it up a bit. nuff said.

excerpts: If Perbacco could accentuate the wonderful dinner menu-
it certainly can accomplish this through its extensive wine selection.
It is without a doubt why people come here-
PS- Making Perbacco your next lunch/dinner venue will certainly accentuate a positive outlook in your life!
Si-
La Dolce Vita!
perbacco.author: Arissa C.
perbacco.review:
If Perbacco could accentuate the wonderful dinner menu- it certainly can accomplish this through its extensive wine selection.  It is without a doubt why people come here- it is  to taste what is Italy- through its wine, food and service.

My friend and I decided to meet here for dinner- it was both our first time to dine here and was very much looking forward to celebrating a recent promotion!
For starter:
Tasting of Salame- Nostrano, Finocchiona, Finocchiona picante and sangunato. This was a wonderful selection of the finest salami I have ever tasted.  The Nostrano was tender and sweet dotted with peppercorns, the finocchiona (cinta senese) was rich and seasoned with fennel- accompanied with the spicy version for contrast.  The sanguinato "blood sausage" was suprisingly delicious- a tarty sweetness but not too rich.
The Fritto Misto- was crispy and light- the rock shrimp was fresh with the  addition of  green beans, olives, fennel and lemon rings -all suited the aioli lemon dipping sauce.
My friend ordered the Beef Short Rib Stracotto- an italian version of pot roast- deliciously flavored with carrots, peas and gremolata.
The Braised Lamb Shank was the best I've had in a while, it was stewed to perfection- meat almost falling off the bones- the reduced stew sauce was impeccably rich and bold- I highly recommend it!
None of this could not have been more accentuated  by the Avignonesi 50 & 50 Capannelle, 2000 Tuscan wine- rich tannins- fresh tartiness that when allowed to breathe revealed its layers of complexity.  From appetizers- they were lush plums, cherries, and chocolate.  By the main dish- they were ripening raisins, prunes and light tabacco...ahhhh wines do breathe :-) 
I really liked the modern feel to this place, the dusk lighting and Cezanne-esque Italian countryside paintings were nostalgically entertaining, the staff all uniformed in crisp white shirts- not only conveyed tidiness but knowledge and courteousness.

PS- Making Perbacco your next lunch/dinner venue will certainly accentuate a positive outlook in your life!  Si- La Dolce Vita!

perbacco.author: Marisa M.
perbacco.review:
We were coming up to SF to see Wicked and decided to hit up Perbacco for dinner before. 

WOW.

Although I was totally underwhelmed by their breadsticks and herb oil that comes out with the menu, the rest of our food was DELICIOUS! 

I would say that the service was 5+ stars...best I've ever had.

The food only gets 4 stars, but still excellent. I ordered the highly recommended Sea Bass. It was great. Perfectly cooked with a gorgeous and light warm salad of fennel and citrus under it. My husband had the herb gnocchi with mushrooms. YUMMMMMM. I have decided that I'll get the pasta when we come back. The couples sitting around us had pasta and it looked fantastic.

The portions were perfect. We also ordered the pistachio cake for dessert and it was by far the highlight of the meal. PERFECT!!!! I strongly recommend saving room for this.

excerpts: Perbacco in Italian means "by Bacchus," the Roman god of wine (and debauchery) - love the name.
I usually don't care too much for salumi, but Perbacco's exceeded my expectations.
Especially good were the sanguinato (blood sausage), mortadella and ciccioli (shredded pork pate).
Skip the pickled watermelon rind included with the salumi, it's pretty nasty.
I was equally impressed with the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted veal and cabbage.
The agnolotti is very similar to tortellini or ravioli.
We also tried the burrata cheese, which didn't have as creamy of an interior as I expected, and the tajarin (tagliatelle with pork sugo), which had a good texture but was a little bland.

Given the server's awesome picks on the first set of courses (he didn't recommend the burrata cheese or tajarin), we decided to go with his picks for the main courses (duck breast, ribeye steak, and devil's gulch rabbit).
While the rabbit and duck breast were not spectacular by any means, I would rather have those entrees than the charred ribeye I received.
All I tasted was ash.
perbacco.author: Keith C.
perbacco.review:
This perennial Open Table hotspot is one of the powerful trio of restaurants (including Aqua and Tadich Grill) on the strip of California St. between Front and Battery.  Perbacco in Italian means "by Bacchus," the Roman god of wine (and debauchery) - love the name.  With all this going for it, and the strong word of mouth, my expectations were high coming in.

Food:  2 stars.  Appetizers and pastas definitely outperform the disappointing entrees here.  Also, Michael Bauer loves the breadsticks, but there's nothing special about them.  We took the server's recommendation and tried the salumi misti (chef's selection), and were immediately wowed.  I usually don't care too much for salumi, but Perbacco's exceeded my expectations.  Especially good were the sanguinato (blood sausage), mortadella and ciccioli (shredded pork pate).  Skip the pickled watermelon rind included with the salumi, it's pretty nasty.  I was equally impressed with the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted veal and cabbage.  The agnolotti is very similar to tortellini or ravioli.  We also tried the burrata cheese, which didn't have as creamy of an interior as I expected, and the tajarin (tagliatelle with pork sugo), which had a good texture but was a little bland.  Given the server's awesome picks on the first set of courses (he didn't recommend the burrata cheese or tajarin), we decided to go with his picks for the main courses (duck breast, ribeye steak, and devil's gulch rabbit).  While the rabbit and duck breast were not spectacular by any means, I would rather have those entrees than the charred ribeye I received.  All I tasted was ash.  Dessert (fig leaf panna cotta) was decent, but not memorable.

Service:  3 stars.  Service was smooth, attentive, and extremely friendly....but I took my server's recommendation and had an ashtray for my main course, which is unforgivable.

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  There is a lot going on in this restaurant from a design point of view.  The design is quirky yet modern and sleek.  It's definitely a vast improvement over the Gold Coast (not to be confused with the Gold Club), which previously occupied this space.  Extra points for the wall mirrors perfectly angled for people-watching (and my, do the people look good).

Hits:   Salumi, agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vittelone and savoy cabbage.

Misses:  Grilled dry aged ribeye steak, extra-charred.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Delfina, Oliveto, Acquerello, Incanto

excerpts: Before today, I'd been to Perbacco once for a couple rounds of drinks with a co-worker.
So at that point I didn't really feel educated enough on this establishment to publish a review (even though my experience there was fantastic).
But today I came here for lunch, so I am now well versed enough with Perbacco to give a well-rounded review.

I'd like to preface this by saying that my 3-course lunches during the week are few and far between, so anytime that situation comes up is a treat, but my experience today surpassed any expectations in my mind.
We had a 1:30 reservation and were seated promptly after our arrival.
Our server was very attentive and gave us great suggestions when we were stuck deciding between menu items.
Everything sounded great, but we ended up getting the burrata mozzarella and gnocchi appetizers.
I'm almost certain the gnocchi was mad in house - it was so moist and perfect and delicious.
For my entree I got the seared halibut with a tomato sauce and fingerling potatoes.
My coworker got the sole which looked incredibly delicious as well.
For dessert, I'm a sucker for chocolate cake, so I got that which included hazlenuts, whipped cream, and caramel sauce.
Impeccable.
I also tried my lunchmate's gelati (caramel, chocolate, and pistachio) and, once again, delizioso!

Another thing I'd like to mention is that the space is really cool, there's an open kitchen at the back end of the restaurant, and as we were escorted to our table there was a table adorned with a beautiful spread of cheeses which completely whetted my appetite!
Overall great experience, highly recommended, and I hope to go back again soon!

perbacco.author: jennifer y.
perbacco.review:
mindblowing delicious food. 

just read Linda L.'s yelp for deets. i'm far too lazy to write and/or be "creative" aobut my enjoyable time at perbacco. 

after casting one cursory glance at the menu on their website, i knew i had to try this place, and let me tell you - i was not disappointed (except for the incongruous second floor decor - where are we? olive garden?!). 

went there for lunch, and it got bumpin' in no time. fabulous meal, shockingly good. any place that understands and values the beauty of celeriac is good in my book. everyone's entrees were incredible. and yes, the breadsticks are ALL that. probably the best beet salad i ever had, topped with this pungent, crumbly, intense cheese - castelmango. 

i bet their mozzarella di bufala is insane.
and check out the salumi selection - what would paul bertolli think?

in regards to the decor: yes, yes, it's all sleek, sex, and contemporary - i'm sure it enables the clueless financial district business power-trippers to feel good about themselves...it's pretty, but almost in an offputting sense. however, i won't complain b/c the food is wonderful. if a restaurant can pull off both looks AND substance, more power to it. 

wonder how long this huge enterprise can hold on to their mojo - serving lunch AND dinner to voracious crowds is a consuming undertaking.

excerpts: I've been awaiting a feast of Italian savories at the raved about Perbacco since it opened.
Delfina is one of my favorite restos
and I loved my Xmas overindulgence at A16.

perbacco.author: Candice L.
perbacco.review:
Le sigh. I've been awaiting a feast of Italian savories at the raved about Perbacco since it opened. Delfina is one of my favorite restos and I loved my Xmas overindulgence at A16. The dishes I tried at Perbacco were mostly good but the service approached awful.
We waited for 15 minutes at the bar for our 830 res; the place was absolutely full. Drinks at the bar were crisp; I had a greyhound for an extra dose of vitamin c during cold season. At the bar, you get to watch the crudo and salumi stations prepare their platters. 

We were seated downstairs in the low ceilinged nook that housed the kitchen at the Gold Coast. They've done a lot with the space, conversations were held at normal levels despite the crowd. As our entire table wanted to try as many items as possible, we opted for the small ($18) salumi misto. Our waitress pushed us to order the large ($30) but we were also ordering a crudo, 2 salads, and entrees, which sounded like a lot of food. The small platter ended up being more than sufficient with about 3 pieces each of prosciutto, mortadella, a few salumi, and a pork pate. Although I'm a sucker for cured meats and will go to extreme lengths for crocks of pate, nothing on the plate was craveworthy. Everything was good, but it lacked sparkle. 

Service issues became apparent as the crudo, radicchio salad, and pear, gorgonzola, and endive salad arrived. Our food runner would silently drop plates onto the crowded table with a complete lack of finesse. We were left holding plates and moving glasses out of the way as we waited for our waitress to return for the used items. It was definitely awkward, and there was no coordination between the bussers, food runners, waitress, etc. 

The crudo was very fresh and the portion was quite large especially compared to the tiny portion at the Slanted Door. The kitchen nicely split the basic radicchio salad with creamy garlic dressing. During the chaos of the starters our wine, a Piedmontese Roero Arneis, arrived. Interestingly, they pour the wine for you and whisk it away to a table at the center of the room. While this is usually fine with me, there was confusion throughout the night if our bottle had been finished or was merely hiding. A major complaint of mine was the wine service. For a 4-top eating a multi-course meal, they completely dropped the ball on our booze. We had friends from out of town visiting and it was impossible to get a second bottle despite trying to flag down our waitress, asking our food runner, and asking some other guy for it. I was shocked at how difficult it was to order the second bottle. By the time our waitress returned, half of our entrees had been eaten and some of our guests thought it was too late for another bottle. The manfriend and I ordered another 1/2 liter, but this aspect of the meal really bothered me. I like my beverages! 

After another round of musical plates when the entrees arrived, I was finally able to tuck into the lauded agnolotti dal plin, little pockets filled with a mlange of veal, sausage, and vegetables. It seems everywhere I turn these days, this newly chic pasta shape is receiving heaps of praise from food mags, bloggers, and critics.I liked it, but it did not illicit the same toe-curling need to lick my plate as the chicken and foie gras ravioli at Delfina or even the need to order another serving immediately afterward like the crab and toasty breadcrumb pasta at A16. The filling was balanced and savory, and I enjoyed the sheer wisps of savoy cabbage in the pool of browned roasted meat juices that coated the pasta. However, I expected thinner wrappers to ensure a maximum filling to noodle ratio.

I anticipated more from the Berkshire pork shoulder al latte. I cook a lot of pork roasts, carnitas, and other succulent cuts at home. I turned to the manfriend for his reaction, it was "yeah, it's okay." Some bites were on the dry side which is really odd for such a fatty cut that had been braised. He later reported that some bites were quite good, but it's pork shoulder, come on! The rest of the table was happy with their gorgonzola and nettle gnocchi and tuna mains. 

No space for dessert after all that. We asked the waitress to put $100 on the card and gave her $140 cash; equaling the total plus exactly 20% for tip despite the service issues. I did not take up any of the issues with the manager and give them a chance to correct them. It was so hard to get a 2nd bottle of wine and I had guests with me, so I thought it would be a big scene. When entertaining, you want things to go as smoothly as possible. Instead, what we got back was the full bill ($200) on the card and $140 cash had been taken for a tip. A 70% tip! WTF? No way, not after the wine debacle. We eventually got the bill corrected but she acted like it was someone else's fault. I'm not sure who would make that sort of mistake, as a 70% tip is unusual. Service issues bumped a 4 or 4.5 star meal was bumped down to a 3 star experience.

excerpts: Definitely look up Perbacco.
The feel at Perbacco is on the serious side given its location in the financial district.
Think
Aqua, One Market, Boulevard, but just a tad more causal.
The place is general bustling with the typical downtown business crowd.
They have a nice bar, where you can grab a drink and apps before sitting down for dinner.
The dinning room is a little bland, and can get a little bit noisy.
I have heard some very mixed things from friends on Perbacco, but I have to say everything we ordered was very good.
We started with a Salame plate that had four different preparations.
There was a blood salame, a fennel salame, and two others that I forget.
I liked all four
and I thought the portion side was more than generous.
Next we moved into some apps:
the steak tartar and the bresaola.
The tartar left something to be desired.
It was good, but not really all that special, and I have had much better tartar, so I would look to the bresaola if you want a meat as an app.
For those of you that have never tried Bresaola give it a whirl, it is basically air dried salted steak.
Yum.
It was thin as paper, but had amazing freshness and very concentrated meat flavors.
For entrees we ordered the Pappardelle with braised short rib ragu and the duck breast.
The pasta was delicious, made fresh and cooked perfectly.
The short rib ragu was a very nice touch adding a nice richness to the pasta without making it over the top.
The duck was also good, and I think some of best duck I have had in the city recently.
It was a breast, but came whole rather than the thinly sliced preparation you normally receive.
I felt this locked in the flavors better and created more rich earthy flavors that speak more to the heart of the food.
Very tasty and highly recommended.
Finally for desert we had a trio of gelatos.
All were really good, there was a chocolate flavor, a hazelnut and a pistachio.
Perbacco has a really solid list, specializing in Italian varietals.
Most of the regions (not just the popular ones) are represented in both whites and reds.
This is great for experimenting with some of the rarer Italian wines.
We ordered a bottle of the Paolo Scavino Barbera d Alba.
For $42 you can't go wrong.
This is one of the best producers in Piedmont, and for those that don't want to drop $150 on one of his Barolos this is a fantastic option.
Next we dipped into a 1997 Tignanello (which I brought).
The Som waived our corkage since I bought a bottle, which I thought was pretty cool.
As far as the wine goes, though, I would first choose what you want to eat and then ask them to suggest some wine options.
Ask for something out of the ordinary, there are some really fun things on the list.
I was impressed all around with Perbacco.
Definitely not a great date place or a place for a romantic dinner, but a really well done Italian restaurant with a good up beat crowd.
A must try in the financial district.

excerpts:
2nd time dining at Perbacco..
this was my second time dining at Perbacco, the first time for lunch this time for dinner.
We sat in the dining room in the back to the right, my least favorite part of the restaurant, the ceiling is low and it was about 85 degrees in there.
Way too hot to be enjoyable.
Our server, slow to greeting us almost like we had been forgotten.
She looked a little rough, like she had jsut gotten dressed and dragged herself to work, a little fluff of the hair and cold water on the face would've been nice.
So not the most attentive server, she seemed like she may have been on a cigarette break for mst of the evening.

The food:
we started with the salumi platter it was delicious, loved all the cured in house meat selection.
we also had the hamachi fennel crudo.
it had a such potential but fell short with the large amount of sea salt on top, whaaaa mouth full of saltiness, and the pool of olive oil on the plate was over kill.
Next the raddichio salad, the two types of raddichio nice but alas one was extremely bitter and the parmesan and croutins couldn't cut through that.
For pasta we shared the angiotti pasta first filled with veal sugo and nettle ricotta gnochi, both fantastic flavors, the gnochi was wonderful melted in your mouth, one drawback to both the dishes
were they were barely luke warm, chilled almost.
Had our server been around and not on her break
i would have sent it back.
unfortunatey she never reappeared till we were almost finished.
we also shared the braised short rib entree, it was also only luke warm but the parsnip puree i believe it was, maybe celery root, was steaming hot.
The flavors were very nice.
For dessert we shared the pistachio panna cotta and the trio of gelatos.
the pistachio panna cotta different to say the least
, it took a second to want to try it, the color kind of scares you away, it looks like and experiment more than a dessert.
it was a deep swamp green color, the flavor grew on me after a couple of bites and  i liked the compotes, blodd orange segments and kumquat compote.
the gelatos, great, but again there was this sea salt thing on the caramel flavor, slow down there big guy with all the extra salt.
a small amount to compliment would've been just fine, why'd ya have to go overboard and overkill.
Overall i would go back, the food has shown to be good and the pricing reasonable.
Hopefully you don't get the haggard server.

2nd time dining at Perbacco..
this was my second time dining at Perbacco, the first time for lunch this time for dinner. We sat in the dining room in the back to the right, my least favorite part of the restaurant, the ceiling is low and it was about 85 degrees in there. Way too hot to be enjoyable. 
Our server, slow to greeting us almost like we had been forgotten. She looked a little rough, like she had jsut gotten dressed and dragged herself to work, a little fluff of the hair and cold water on the face would've been nice. So not the most attentive server, she seemed like she may have been on a cigarette break for mst of the evening. 
The food:
we started with the salumi platter it was delicious, loved all the cured in house meat selection. we also had the hamachi fennel crudo. it had a such potential but fell short with the large amount of sea salt on top, whaaaa mouth full of saltiness, and the pool of olive oil on the plate was over kill. Next the raddichio salad, the two types of raddichio nice but alas one was extremely bitter and the parmesan and croutins couldn't cut through that.
For pasta we shared the angiotti pasta first filled with veal sugo and nettle ricotta gnochi, both fantastic flavors, the gnochi was wonderful melted in your mouth, one drawback to both the dishes were they were barely luke warm, chilled almost. Had our server been around and not on her break i would have sent it back. unfortunatey she never reappeared till we were almost finished. 
we also shared the braised short rib entree, it was also only luke warm but the parsnip puree i believe it was, maybe celery root, was steaming hot. The flavors were very nice.
For dessert we shared the pistachio panna cotta and the trio of gelatos. the pistachio panna cotta different to say the least, it took a second to want to try it, the color kind of scares you away, it looks like and experiment more than a dessert. it was a deep swamp green color, the flavor grew on me after a couple of bites and  i liked the compotes, blodd orange segments and kumquat compote.
the gelatos, great, but again there was this sea salt thing on the caramel flavor, slow down there big guy with all the extra salt. a small amount to compliment would've been just fine, why'd ya have to go overboard and overkill. Overall i would go back, the food has shown to be good and the pricing reasonable. Hopefully you don't get the haggard server.

excerpts: This was our first time to Perbacco and will not be the last.
perbacco.author: George C.
perbacco.review:
A great way to spend Friday night dinner out with 4.  This was our first time to Perbacco and will not be the last.  The dining room is modern and you could carry on a conversation with your table, but there was a general buzz (i.e. not a quiet dinner spot)

We sat at the bar waiting for friends to show up.  It's always nice to have bartenders that give you a chance to taste before you decide on a wine.  Also, watching them slice up their house cured meats made that a must try for dinner.

Dinner started with the Salumi Misti (house selection of cured meats) which also came with a great country style pate.

We then proceeded to split 4 appetizers:  I would definitely recommend the veal and tuna sauce (delicious, must try traditional dish).  The sardine dish we ordered was good, but a fairly small portion relative to the other dishes.

We actually decided not to have a main, instead splitting 3 pastas to save room for dessert.  The Tarjin (hand cut tagliatelle which is like a flat spaghetti) and papardelle were delicious.  

There was not a dish that we did not like.  One of the better restaurants we have tried recently and a two thumbs up.  I would be comfortable recommending this place to anyone.

excerpts:
3.5 stars

Perbacco and I have a complex relationship.
perbacco.author: Alex W.
perbacco.review:
3.5 stars

Perbacco and I have a complex relationship. On one hand, it's ingredients are fresh and local and taste awesome. Some of the individual dishes I've had there are best in category (see short ribs below). Yet, I've felt at times like I'm intaking food from a rail gun (see salumi plate below), or there's just an item that's off...

Bread and butter:
- Bread: for a high-caliber Italian place, your bread is passable, but it's nothing to write home about. It's not very chewy and tastes a bit dry. I think the density is the main issue--there's to much air and too many air pockets that make the bread not enjoyable on its own. However, it does soak in sauces well, and most of your meat and pasta dishes have sauces that are simply divine. This bread + shortrib sauce + my mouth = happiness. 

- Butter: high-five for room temperature butter, but needs salt. 

Appetizers:

- SALUMI MISTI - I ordered a small, and this could feed 4 people. It was pleasant and a nice snack with bread, but nothing stood out as being terribly distinctive. One of the salumi items tasted like raw, ground meat, which was slightly off-putting. I don't know if the issue is even with the plate--Italian cured meats are categorically inferior to Spanish Jamón ibérico. (As a plug, the BEST cured meat I've ever had is the 5-yr old ham from Brindisa in Borough Market, London; pretty good manchego and membrillo too)

- Goose salad (ordered to-go) - 5-slices of goose breast over some arugula for $22? Are you kidding me? Say hello to my little friend, the log of dining disappointments

Mains:

- PAPPARDELLE (WIDE PASTA RIBBONS / SLOW COOKED SHORT RIB RAGU / ROASTED CIPOLLINE / GRATED HORSERADISH) - wow, this was a solid pasta dish with really fresh homemade pasta and awesome short ribs on the inside. The technique was flawless and the texture was al-dente chewy and gorgeously umami-rich and buttery. Would suggest putting a touch more salt in the sauce. Only note on presentation is that it was a little messy and felt more like a home-cooked meal (which I'll take any day over wow-factor presentation at the expense of flavor)

- BEEF SHORT RIB STRACOTTO (ROOT VEGETABLE PASSATINA / CAVOLO NERO / HONEY GLAZED CIPOLLINE AND CARROTS) - this baby came out and my jaw dropped. I was literally mid-conversation with the guy next to me at the bar, and I just stopped talking while my mouth went into epileptic shock. The smell envelops your head in a cloud of charred meat, tobacco and browned butter flavors. I talked to the bartender and he mentioned that the meat cooks for a 3 hours at 120 degrees, making the entire piece of Niman Ranch boneless short rib fall apart as soon as you touch it. Fat and meat juices were so well distributed throughout the short rib that I hesitated every time I touche it with a fork. I just wanted to admire this (large) piece of short rib perfection. The purple, white and orange carrots and other baby winter root vegetables elevated the plating to a stratospheric level. I'm not kidding when I say this is perfect plate of food. I could have this once a week for the rest of my life, and I would be a happy camper. I cannot emphasize enough how good this particular dish is--of all the deliciously memorable dishes I've had in my lifetime, this easily ranks in the top 10. 

Desserts:

- MEYER LEMON PANNA COTTA (HUCKLEBERRY COMPOTE / ROSEMARY SHORTBREAD) - technically perfect preparation of panna cotta, though I wasn't 100% set on the compote. The compote's texture was a bit too stiff for this dish and tended to stick to my fork as I ate the panna cotta. 

In short: check this place out. It's a fun place to go with friends, prices are reasonable for the quality of food and service. The selection of Italian wines is off the charts and the short rib dish is the best preparation of short rib I've ever had in my life. P.s. $20 corkage!

excerpts: well, tonight, I felt that Perbacco was THAT place.
We were taking some clients out and was able to manage a large table in the upper room... literally in the back cave.
Our party came sporadically (i.e. not on time) and so we sorta ordered bits and pieces here and there.
The coppa di testa (warm pig head terrine) was really good... and even some of the naysayers at the table gave it a nod of approval.
The other appetizers were just okay (the hamachi crudo, scallops, fritto misto and one other dish that didn't quite make it down to my end of the table)
... ditto for the pasta....
tagliatelle with pork ragu, some ravioli dish were just 'Oh hum' at best.
Then my entree, the house made sausage, took the longest to prepare, yet once I took the first bite, the middle of it was cold...
so I had to ask to reheat the thing.
Desserts were not spectactular, even borderline flat...
we sampled five different dessert items and not one jumped out at you.
The ice cream sampler, the 'ugly' hazelnut cookies, the meyer lemon semifreddo...

Yes, but only after the hype has died down...
perbacco.author: Dale K.
perbacco.review:
You know those things where you're literally the last person on earth to try it, but you're still so tempted to go there nonetheless cause of all the great 'hype' that's been building it up???.... well, tonight, I felt that Perbacco was THAT place.  We were taking some clients out and was able to manage a large table in the upper room... literally in the back cave.  Our party came sporadically (i.e. not on time) and so we sorta ordered bits and pieces here and there.  The coppa di testa (warm pig head terrine) was really good... and even some of the naysayers at the table gave it a nod of approval.   The other appetizers were just okay (the hamachi crudo, scallops, fritto misto and one other dish that didn't quite make it down to my end of the table)... ditto for the pasta.... tagliatelle with pork ragu, some ravioli dish were just 'Oh hum' at best.  Then my entree, the house made sausage, took the longest to prepare, yet once I took the first bite, the middle of it was cold... so I had to ask to reheat the thing.   Desserts were not spectactular, even borderline flat... we sampled five different dessert items and not one jumped out at you.  The ice cream sampler, the 'ugly' hazelnut cookies, the meyer lemon semifreddo... I've had better elsewhere.

And the wine list... it's a large selection and mainly all Italian varietals... there were some Napa selection... and the price was very reasonable all around.

I guess the thing is... Italian cuisine is readily available and there plenty of good Italian eateries in the city that it's hard to find a place that just blows everything else out of the water.  I felt like this with Perbacco.  The food is good, but I know I was just buying/being influenced more by the recent hype of this place vs. a hole-in-the-wall joint that focuses on the beauties of their food.

Would I go back to Perbacco?  Yes, but only after the hype has died down...

excerpts: Perbacco definitely has one of the best charcuterie platters that I've had in the city (even slightly better than Incanto, who make there own salumi).
Get the chef's selection or assorted platter.
They also have a mortadella or salumi one
but if you get the selection, you get a little bit of everything.
They have loads of appetizers
but you can't leave without trying some of their handmade pastas.
They offer most of them in small or large plates if you just want to have a taste.
The papardelle and tagliatelle with pork sugo or short rib ragu were the best things on the menu!
The pork shoulder and short rib entrees are the highlights of the main courses.
I've gotten both and wasn't that impressed with the pork shoulder.
Although they say it is slow braised, it's not as tender as you'd expect.
The short rib is sooo delicious though!
Juicy, tender, and so flavorful.
perbacco.author: Josephine H.
perbacco.review:
I've been to this place a couple of times and had to give this restaurant another shot. There were just too many things on the menu that I wanted to try again. Perbacco definitely has one of the best charcuterie platters that I've had in the city (even slightly better than Incanto, who make there own salumi). Get the chef's selection or assorted platter. They also have a mortadella or salumi one but if you get the selection, you get a little bit of everything. They have loads of appetizers but you can't leave without trying some of their handmade pastas. They offer most of them in small or large plates if you just want to have a taste. The papardelle and tagliatelle with pork sugo or short rib ragu were the best things on the menu! The pork shoulder and short rib entrees are the highlights of the main courses. I've gotten both and wasn't that impressed with the pork shoulder. Although they say it is slow braised, it's not as tender as you'd expect. The short rib is sooo delicious though! Juicy, tender, and so flavorful. It comes with a celery root puree that you can sop up all the beef juices with.

Wine list is also fairly extensive and reasonable. Check with the sommelier though...not all the waiters appear to be too knowledgeable. The ambience of this place is great. It's got a rustic yet modern feel to it and filled with great energy. There is a long bar area in the front with some booths for casual dining, along with the full dining area in the back. This place is usually packed by 7 on any night so book ahead!

excerpts: Update after more than a year and countless meals at Perbacco (today is 7/24/08):
The menu is constantly evolving, so every time I eat at Perbacco
I get to try something new and yet just as wonderful as the last visit!
I suggested Perbacco to my company's Chief Operating Officer.
She LOVED it.
perbacco.author: Kandi K.
perbacco.review:
I went here with clients yesterday, and it surely impressed.  Rather than a light lunch, we all ordered 3 courses.  My appetizer was some kind of soft, sweet, mild, creamy cheese with black truffle "salsa" served with toasted bread  and arugula.  It was the perfect palate whetter.  Made me wonder what else was in store.  My main course was a ricotta-gnocci with some kind of asparagus sauce.  It was very simple, a beautiful color, and delicious.  To top off the meal I had the most exciting dessert--get this--polenta cake with olive oil gelato.  To finish off the plate, olive oil was drizzled around the plate along with a bright red rhubarb sauce.  It looked so much like tomato sauce that I was dying of curiosity about how it would taste.  I was very surprised at how well the flavors blended together in my mouth.  I can't stop thinking about my meal there and I can't wait to return!  I also swiped a spoonful of my colleague's apple/pear bread pudding, and it too was scrumptious.

Update after more than a year and countless meals at Perbacco (today is 7/24/08):

I recently had a watermelon salad with honey-olive vinegrette and marcona almonds and it was so refreshing!  The menu is constantly evolving, so every time I eat at Perbacco I get to try something new and yet just as wonderful as the last visit!  HOW DO THEY DO IT?!

1)  I brought some friends here.  They LOVED it.
2)  I brought some other clients here.  They LOVED it.
3)  I suggested Perbacco to my company's Chief Operating Officer.  She LOVED it.

excerpts: I was expecting to be blown away by Perbacco.

My mother even called me the night of and when I told her I was going to Perbacco, I could practically see her eyes lighting up.
"TELL ME HOW IT IS!!
she shouted (because isn't that what all parents do on the phone?
Perbacco must be the SHIT.
perbacco.author: Nicole R.
perbacco.review:
I was expecting to be blown away by Perbacco. The week preceding my night out to dine here, I had about five friends tell me how incredible it was. My mother even called me the night of and when I told her I was going to Perbacco, I could practically see her eyes lighting up. "TELL ME HOW IT IS!!" she shouted (because isn't that what all parents do on the phone? Think it is necessary to escalate their voice?)

GOD, I thought. Perbacco must be the SHIT.

Okay. It was fine. It was nice. It was GOOD. Solid. Yummy. Insert more decent adjectives here.

Was I blown away? Nah. Have I had better food for the price we paid? For sure. 

I'm very happy I tried it, but perhaps I wouldn't have been (slightly) disappointed if everyone I know thinks this place is heaven.

excerpts: Just had my birthday dinner at Perbacco and it was fantastic.
We had a 6:15 reservation but got there early due to the abundance of parking available in FiDi at that time.
perbacco.author: J. F.
perbacco.review:
Just had my birthday dinner at Perbacco and it was fantastic.  We had a 6:15 reservation but got there early due to the abundance of parking available in FiDi at that time.  Not having to circle block after block to find parking is always nice.

We were seated right and got water, bread sticks with salsa verde, butter and bread right away.  Michael, our FANTASTIC waiter, was available to answer any questions we had on the menu and provide some great suggestions on what to order.  He actually had suggestions as opposed to some waiters who end up listing out the whole menu as "their favorite".

We ended up picking:
l'arrogante (cocktail)
salumi misti
local green asparagus salad / peppercress / herb vinaigrette / olive oil zabaglione
pappardelle / slow-cooked short rib ragu / parmigiano reggiano
alaskan halibut / asparagus & leek poached in chervil cream / shaved purple asparagus
wild chocolate gelato / salted toffee

The food was so delicious.  Well seasoned, salted, and balanced.  It's given me some inspirations on additional ways to prep asparagus.  We were also able to purchase 0.25 lb of the coppa al barbera to take home.  (Michael, if you are reading this...  Thanks for helping us make this happen and pls also thank the chef for us.)

And now I am happy, well-fed, totally stuffed, and in possession of 0.25 lb of coppa to nibble on for the rest of the night.  :D

excerpts: I had been to Perbacco before and it was excellent.

Try the signature Perbacco drink- thank you to Mike-
he is a GREAT server, and should be recognized for his ability to make the customer happy!

excerpts: At Perbacco, the price does not equate to the quality or taste that should be expected.
So Sorry Charlie.
perbacco.author: Manton R.
perbacco.review: Ok, I've been to a lot of fancy shmancy restaurants and this one is probably one of the worst.  The food is OVERPRICED for the quality.  Also, the service is horrible.  The venue is nice and appealing to the eye BUT it's very crowded.  I've been there twice and each time I was sitting less than 1 foot away from another couple.  The food takes FOREVER to arrive and the quality of the food is equivalent to a Black Angus restaurant.  Don't get me wrong, I like Black Angus, but you get what you paid for when you eat at Black Angus.  At Perbacco, the price does not equate to the quality or taste that should be expected.  So Sorry Charlie.

excerpts: The people at Perbacco were so accommodating, they got us a high chair and then a regular chair for a baby seat (although it's not really a baby place, I do not recommend for them), and a table that was a bit quieter upstairs as opposed to one downstairs.
Also, because we shared everything, they divided the pastas for us and put it onto plates for each of us.
Great attentive service!
They kept on picking up the scarf my sister could not keep on the back of her chair, refilled water, etc.
perbacco.author: Alison K.
perbacco.review:
Delicious!  

Nduja salumi: spreadable and spicy!  Not your typical salumi, which the waiter was kind enough to warn of us, although we ordered it anyway.  The consistency is like stickier pate.  Also, they give you a generous portion of it, and there were three of us.  

Seared squid: cooked to perfection :) 

Burrata cheese salad: the burrata cheese melts in your mouth, the tomatoes firm and ripe, everything is well seasoned.  

Beet salad: we pretty much order beets whenever we can, this was good, but if you had to choose, I'd go with the burrata.  Nice big slices of golden and red beets, again well seasoned.  

Tajarin pasta: cheesy, meaty, thin pasta.  Yum!  

paparadelle: THE HIGHLIGHT.  Nice short rib meat, big belts of pasta ... all I can really think to say is NOM NOM NOM.

Brown butter cake: it was good, but not my favorite.  If you are a chocolate fiend (I am not), I think you would enjoy this more than me, because of the chocolate ganache they place on top. 

The people at Perbacco were so accommodating, they got us a high chair and then a regular chair for a baby seat (although it's not really a baby place, I do not recommend for them), and a table that was a bit quieter upstairs as opposed to one downstairs.  Also, because we shared everything, they divided the pastas for us and put it onto plates for each of us.  Great attentive service!  They kept on picking up the scarf my sister could not keep on the back of her chair, refilled water, etc. All of that for about 120, tip and tax included, is not bad! 

Am definitely coming back and would recommend to friends!!

excerpts: In my honest opinion, and I dine out A LOT, Perbacco is, hands down, THE best restaurant in San Francisco.
Tonight was my fifth or sixth time dining at Perbacco
AND it was my 33rd birthday.
My boyfriend and I were seated in minutes and I was greeted by a personal birthday card from the staff.
Amazingly nice touch!
We ordered the fritto misto, the pear gorganzola salad and the spinach, hen egg and cheese ravioli as appetizers and practically licked the plates clean!
For entrees, I had the scallops and my boyfriend had the sea bass.
Again, we licked our plates clean.
For dessert was the warm, delicious apple bread pudding which was TO DIE for.
An added b-day touch were some sweet and delicous cookies, on the house!
So awesome!!
Onto the service.
In my 5 or 6 times coming here, the service has been nothing short of exceptional!
Very attentive, friendly staff.
If you need to get up from the table, your napkin will be folded within 5 or 6 seconds of you leaving.
The wine list is extensive, and the staff is very knowledgable about perfect pairings with your dish.
I cannot recommend this place enough.
I've read other reviews that claim this place is noisy and small, but i've never had that experience.
It is simply, the best.
I am a committed and loyal customer and look forward to dining there again very soon!
Thanks, Perbacco for your exquisite service and amazingly delicious food.

excerpts: I've already been critical of its neighbor, Aqua, so while I'm at it, why don't I take on Perbacco as well?
As with Aqua, I've been on countless business meals at Perbacco since it opened, and still fail to understand what the fuss is all about.
Yes, this is a nice, convenient place for a client lunch if you're in the Financial District, so it certainly serves a useful purpose in that regard.
But for the most part, the menu is thoroughly average.
I've been there at least 6 times in the past year and change, and can't remember a single aspect of any meal, which has to tell you something, beyond just the fact that I have a poor memory.

excerpts: Everyone loves Perbacco, and that's for a reason
: It is a great restaurant.
Not cheap; hard to get into to, but the food is wonderful; the service is excellent and the setting is very pleasant.
We had a corner table in the back, and they did not rush us.
We were there almost 2 hours at lunch, eating slowly, talking, etc.
They brought us our food as we wanted it, not as the chef want to prepare it.
Lots of info about the dishes here on Yelp, so I won't repeat it.
I doubt there is a less than super dish on the menu.
Wine list is extensive, but focused on out of US wines, so the local selection is a little slim.
But the staff were knowledgeable about the wine and helped us make a good selection.
It's a real winner.

excerpts:
Perbacco

Loved this place.
perbacco.author: maria a.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco

Loved this place.  Service was excellent, knowledgeable and very friendly (our waiter told us stories of the guy they keep in the basement making the grissini placed on the table instead of bread, with a nice salsa cruda - AWESOME grissini - we went thru 3 plates of those in the first 10 minutes.  i lived in Italy for 5 months and never had better).  very crowded and noisy, but a beautiful, airy space.  But because it's so noisy, and huge, it feels a tad impersonal, not warm and cozy.  Ehh, that's a nit that doesn't need picking

Here's what 3 of us ate last night:  Brandacujun --- salt cod/potato gratin/crostini - perfect balance of warm potato with crunchy browned top and salty cod; mozzarella di bufala/black truffle condimento/arugula/grilled pilone (a type of bread) - SOOOO GOOD.  So creamy soft, like melting jack cheese, but not warm, with the truffle and arugula, on the nicely charred bread - very heady; Coppa di testa - warm pig's head terrine!!  like rillettes, chopped up and then spread very thin into two disks, had a sweet, almost clove-y, cinnamon-y taste; this was a wow, and even tho my friend was put off by the fact it was pig's head, he loved it; carne cruda of vitallone/black truffle condimento/crostini - raw cute little baby veal (i have to get over this, i ate veal all over Italy - you almost can't get grown-up cow there!) of course was yummy, almost like the texture of ahi tuna tartare; fritto misto of rock shrimp/green beans/olives/meyer lemon/fennel/lemon aioli - very nice, light batter, olives were a nice tart touch in a rich dish like this; pappardelle/braised short rib ragu/roasted chanterelles - another rich dish - slow cooked, meaty, dark sauce, mixed in with big flat homemade noodles; fijian (!) swordfish/fingerling potatoes/chanterelles - better than the pappardelle even - tender and dense and flavorful.  dessert was a sort of chocolate tart with carmelized hazelnuts and some kind of polenta cake/vanilla ice cream/fruit coulis/with more carmelized hazelnuts - have to say dessert was a disappointment to me, but i'm not a huge dessert person.  my two companions liked it.  i thought the polenta cake was heavy (tho the waiter described it as light) and flavorless, and the chocolate thing was a bit dry, and hazelnuts are my least favorite nut.

But i have to say, overall, YUM.  We shared everything and were completely, painfully stuffed.  We also had three bottles of prosecco, and our bill total was something like $210 before tip.  Then onto Aqua for 3 glasses of wine.  Too much is never enough.

excerpts: I was really looking forward to eating at Perbacco and had brought along some of my fellow foodies who had also heard great things about the restaurant.
We asked several questions, and she left to give us a few minutes to decide - which in the land of Perbacco is more like 15 minutes.
My friends ordered the Perbacco cocktail, wanted another, but were never given the chance to order another.
Perbacco is a good place to go sit at the bar for drinks and apps.
If you want to sit down for a meal - go to A16.
The menus are strangely similar, but the service at A16 is FAR better, the food is consistently good and the prices are well worth it.
perbacco.author: Rachelle P.
perbacco.review:
I was really looking forward to eating at Perbacco and had brought along some of my fellow foodies who had also heard great things about the restaurant. 

We had reservations and were seated right away, thank you opentable.com. Once our waitress took our drink orders, it was at least another 10-15 minutes before she came back with the drinks. We asked several questions, and she left to give us a few minutes to decide - which in the land of Perbacco is more like 15 minutes. Based on her recommendations, we had the following:

Apps - the burrato cheese with heirloom tomatoes on filone bread was ridiculously delicious. Literally ridiculous. The hamachi was also good, but the gnocchi overwhelmingly tasted like asparagus and wasn't good at all. And I generally love gnocchi.

Main course - the pork loin was delicious and moist. The duck was surprisingly lean and much lighter than duck I had before - also very good. My dish was unfortunately a major disappointment. I ordered the beef short ribs based on the server's rave reviews and received about 10 ounces of beef fat with 2 ounces of gritty meat. This was surrounded by a sea of peas, one of the few vegetables I despise, and a couple of carrots and potatoes. 

Dessert - Since the service was so, so slow, we passed. 

Drinks - I had prosecco and ordered a second glass which never came. But the first glass was very good. My friends ordered the Perbacco cocktail, wanted another, but were never given the chance to order another.

The food is generally good, but not consistent. Our server was friendly and sensitive to my food allergies, but seemed overwhelmed with too many tables. From start to finish, it took almost two and half hours for a two course meal. Simply too slow.

Perbacco is a good place to go sit at the bar for drinks and apps. If you want to sit down for a meal - go to A16. The menus are strangely similar, but the service at A16 is FAR better, the food is consistently good and the prices are well worth it.

excerpts: My wife and I ate at Perbacco earlier this week.
The service was great and the ambiance was very nice -- the place felt very alive, but not overly crowded.
We were both very happy with our starters -- Lisa had panzanella and I had burrata and tomatoes.
Their charcuterie looks amazing -- would love to go back even if just for that.
My entree, seared halibut in a tomato, fish stock sauce was excellent.
Cooked perfectly and very flavorful.
Lisa had yellowfin tuna, which wasn't quite as impressive.
Bit tough, but that's always my complaint with yellowfin.
Highlight of the night was the wine.
Sommelier recommended an excellent bottle of Veneto that I'll be looking for in stores, but will no doubt never find.
Guess we'll have to return to Perbacco!

We had a four-course menu with perfect portion sizes.
My favorite dish was the pesto flavored pasta with small asparagus cuts.
I've never had such tender noodles; they were clearly homemade.
I also loved the seared scallops with a mushroom sauce - I wish I had looked at the menu more closely so I could remember the other outstanding components of the sauce.
The berry crumble dessert was tasty, but I so wanted to order one of the other decadent Italian desserts off the menu.
If I ever have the chance to dine at Perbacco again, I think I'll have to order two desserts after hearing others' rave reviews!
Overall, Perbacco was a memorable and satisfying dining experience.
perbacco.author: Alison T.
perbacco.review: I had a wonderful evening here during my recent business trip to the city.  Our group had two tables set aside in a secluded area that was pretty stark and had poor lighting, so we missed out on the chic decor of the main dining area.  Other than this fact, Perbacco was great.  We had a four-course menu with perfect portion sizes.  My favorite dish was the pesto flavored pasta with small asparagus cuts.  I've never had such tender noodles; they were clearly homemade.  I also loved the seared scallops with a mushroom sauce - I wish I had looked at the menu more closely so I could remember the other outstanding components of the sauce. excerpts: It was impossible to get into Perbacco right after it opened..which may explain some of the bad reviews.
A new restaurant is often overwhelmed, while the staff is still being trained.
You should not expect perfection if you go in the first few weeks.
I had an opportunity to eat at Perbacco family style - four people sharing almost everything on the menu - after the post opening rush.

I found:
1)
The food was excellent.
Not exquisite, but it is not intended to be Campton Place or the Fifth Floor.
All of it very tasty and well presented.
Nothing pretentious or overly composed.
The foods have a slight rustic element, which I find pleasant.
The service non memorable, which means just fine.
I only remember bad service.
perbacco.author: Otto S.
perbacco.review:
It is what it is, an excellent choice for downtown dining. With Terje gone from Scala, San Francisco lost a great chef in downtown dining options. As for a downtown restaurant without the extras offered by a French Laundry, it's as good as you get or would want.

It was impossible to get into Perbacco right after it opened..which may explain some of the bad reviews. A new restaurant is often overwhelmed, while the staff is still being trained. You should not expect perfection if you go in the first few weeks. We didn't even try. 

I had an opportunity to eat at Perbacco family style - four people sharing almost everything on the menu - after the post opening rush. I found:
1) The food was excellent. Not exquisite, but it is not intended to be Campton Place or the Fifth Floor. All of it very tasty and well presented.
Nothing pretentious or overly composed. The foods have a slight rustic element, which I find pleasant.
2) The service non memorable, which means just fine. I only remember bad service.
3) The bill acceptable. 

The only unfortunate thing is that it is located in a nest of similarly priced restaurants which offer excellent food: Acqua, Palio and others, leaving those of us working closer to the Downtown Centre with Scala, Kuletto or the Grand Cafe, all of which have slipped considerably in the past year, or Lark Creek Steak - which is excellent, but you don't always want to eat that hearty.

This was my first time eating there
and I was very happy with the food!
Service was excellent.
Tons of stuff on the menu that I want to try
so we are going back, yes yes!
perbacco.author: Mar D.
perbacco.review: Just had my birthday dinner at Perbacco last week. This was my first time eating there and I was very happy with the food! Service was excellent. Tons of stuff on the menu that I want to try so we are going back, yes yes!

excerpts: The atmosphere at Perbacco IS NOT sexy.
This is a place that is managed pretty well, with the "general" riding herd on the tables, making sure that everyone is happy.
We had a staff "miss" when my order was the wrong entree.
The staff member dropped both plates, and when I brought it to the staff's attention, only my plate was removed, leaving my wife to eat alone.
This lasted about a minute...
the general walked by our table, looked, went immediately to our waiter who removed her plate.
Within 10 minutes both orders were delivered with an apology.
The food was first rate.
The desserts were fantastic.
My wonderfully beautiful spousal unit had the Dolcetto Sabajon...
wow.
Pears in a white wine sabajon that was exquisitely peaked.
I had the Chocolate Tart....fantastic but second-best!
This is a family style restaurant with large seating areas and a large bar in the Financial District.
It's a great place for dinner after work, or a family event.
Wonderful.
But don't go here expecting a romantic or intimate atmosphere....unless one of the light bulbs go out in a corner.

I went last December and most recently last week.
Both times the service bordered on gaudy.

perbacco.author: Tiger P.
perbacco.review:
I have mixed feeling about Perbacco. I went last December and most recently last week. Both times the service bordered on gaudy. I can't think of a better word. When the waiter read the specials he sounded like the Fonz.....no he reminded me Joey Buttafuaco. The first time I went we had a horribly obnoxious Italian lady who wouldn't leave us alone. She even lined up our glasses on the table to make it "prettier" interrupting our conversation. This time the waiter took my wine glass when it was empty (we still had a half bottle of wine!) and didn't come back. (I mean why would you take the wine glass away if you've still got a bottle of wine??)

Other than that the food is pretty good. Not blow your mind fantastic, but good. Started with the hamachi and cicioli. Main entrees were the seared duck breast and duck pappardelle. All reasonably good. Their salumi plate is their specialty and is good as well. Had the pear tart for dessert, crust was soggy, tasted greasy. I remember their chocolate dessert being better.

I think this place is great for having a glass of prosecco and some appetizers on your lunch break or on a  nice business lunch, but I wouldn't go out of my way there for dinner....better just to go to Aqua next door.

excerpts: I'll give Perbacco 4 stars.
perbacco.author: Mark K.
perbacco.review: Started with the roasted octopus (w/ saffron poached potato, meyer lemon vinaigrette, and salsa verde) - not bad.  For my main course, had the beef short rib stracotto (w/ root vegetable puree, roasted cipolline, and baby turnips) - as the name would suggest, it's tender and they did a great job with this one.  Pleasant dining experience and I would come back, so I'll give Perbacco 4 stars.

excerpts: Perbacco is my go-to restaurant.
I've been here multiple times, and each time I've left 100% satisfied.
The pastas are warm, loving plates, but you don't feel like you could have made it at home.
The servers are always friendly and well-informed.
I've never been disappointed in a suggestion they made.
perbacco.author: Susan Y.
perbacco.review: Perbacco is my go-to restaurant. I've been here multiple times, and each time I've left 100% satisfied. The pastas are warm, loving plates, but you don't feel like you could have made it at home. The servers are always friendly and well-informed. I've never been disappointed in a suggestion they made.

excerpts: So we definitely had a great time at Perbacco, but did experience some misses with the quail and with the service.
perbacco.author: Tim L.
perbacco.review: 3.5 stars.  7 of us came here for dinner on Saturday night.  Overall, the food was great.  We ordered the salumi and it was an awesome way to start the meal.  I had the hamachi crudo which was excellent, but my wife's tagliatelle with 5 hr pork sugo was ridiculously flavorful.  I also got to taste a small bite of the roasted octopus and that was well cooked and not at all rubbery or tasteless.  For entrees, I devoured my short rib (braised short rib with bone marrow crust?!  what's not to like?).  However, my wife and I felt her quail filled with foie was somewhat mushy; I'd expect the foie to be soft, but the quail really didn't have a nice consistency to it.  I also was expecting the dish to be awesome, but it was kinda bland.  Lastly, our orders kept getting messed up all night.  The right orders came to our table, but the waiters kept giving the wrong dishes to the wrong diner.  They even gave my Fernet Branca to my wife!  Place is definitely popular on a Saturday night and loud, but we had a nice round table in the back on the second floor.  So we definitely had a great time at Perbacco, but did experience some misses with the quail and with the service.

excerpts: My second outing to Perbacco was for dinner, this time with 13 co-workers.
This time we were seated downstairs.
I was surprised by the seating arrangement.
One side of the table was along the booth-like wall.
That meant that those of us in the center on that side were completely trapped there.
I don't know if there was a heater under the seat or what, but everyone on that side was sweating when we left.
It was so damn hot (and I only had a sip of wine!)
We had 8 different bottles of wine on our table - 4 white and 4 red.
I was really impressed by the service in this respect.
The waiters poured the wine throughout the evening and gave us as many different glasses for it as we wanted.
The service overall was much better at dinner than it was at lunch.
I was very disappointed to find rolls as the dinner bread.
I really wanted that focaccia again!
For dinner I had the spring garlic gnocchi with asparagus sauce.
It was really, really yummy.
I would definitely order that dish again.
perbacco.author: Squirrel L.
perbacco.review:
I hadn't been here before, but ended up going twice last week.  The first occasion was a lunch to celebrate a few co-workers' birthdays.  We were seated upstairs on the mezzanine, which was quite chilly when we arrived.  The service was pretty slow considering that people are usually in a bigger rush at lunchtime.  I started with a golden & red beets appetizer, which was yummy and refreshing.  For the main course, I had the Ligurian style pesto, which was freshly made pasta, pesto, potatoes, and green beans.  My fiance's family makes this dish, so I was very excited to see this on the menu.  It was tasty, but a little too salty.  Lunch was accompanied by an unbelievably good focaccia.  I could have eaten baskets full of it.  I'm generally not super excited about bread, but this stuff was amazing!

My second outing to Perbacco was for dinner, this time with 13 co-workers.  This time we were seated downstairs.  I was surprised by the seating arrangement.  One side of the table was along the booth-like wall.  That meant that those of us in the center on that side were completely trapped there.  I don't know if there was a heater under the seat or what, but everyone on that side was sweating when we left.  It was so damn hot (and I only had a sip of wine!)  We had 8 different bottles of wine on our table - 4 white and 4 red.  I was really impressed by the service in this respect.  The waiters poured the wine throughout the evening and gave us as many different glasses for it as we wanted.  The service overall was much better at dinner than it was at lunch.  I was very disappointed to find rolls as the dinner bread.  I really wanted that focaccia again!  For dinner I had the spring garlic gnocchi with asparagus sauce.  It was really, really yummy.  I would definitely order that dish again.  I had some dessert this time too - lemon panna cotta - super delicious!

While I think they have some atmospheric problems in here, the food is just fabulous.  I will definitely return again soon.

excerpts: Perbacco holds to European service standards:
perbacco.author: Dennis H.
perbacco.review:
UPDATE - 3/25/08:

I had lunch here with a friend today and we couldn't have enjoyed ourselves -- and the food -- more.  We'd asked for a secluded table and got one.  The table was far enough apart from our neighbors so that we -- honestly -- didn't even know they were there.  I had an exquisite soup of the day -- asparagus puree with pancetta on top -- and couldn't pass up the mushroom risotto (I never can).  

Perbacco holds to European service standards:  servers are efficient and courteous but not overbearing or overly-familiar, and best of all, they don't hover.  

Lunch was so good that we didn't even have room for dessert, but I'll definitely be back.  Thanks, Umberto!

excerpts: Perbacco was excellent yet again.
We both ordered the tajarin, and my client loved it.
perbacco.author: Kimberly Q.
perbacco.review: Went in for lunch a couple of days ago with a client.  Perbacco was excellent yet again.  We both ordered the tajarin, and my client loved it.

The fantastic cocktail

perbacco.author: Ritch G.
perbacco.review:
I've been to Perbacco twice now - first time I had a very good meal, the second time everything I had previously enjoyed was gone from the menu (no pesto in a restaurant that claims to "introduce ... the full range of flavors... of Liguria"!?)  The fantastic cocktail I'd had on my first visit was also gone.

Still, high quality food, but not cheap.  You can get Italian food that's just as good for a lot less money, but you're paying for the big designy space.

excerpts: I've been to Perbacco many times and aside from my most recent visit the experiences rated 3-5 stars.
Unfortunately this week's visit rated 2 stars.
We sat in a booth in the bar area (generally my favorite location) and ordered lots of small plates and a lovely bottle of wine for a bill that totalled about $230.
My BF got mushroom risotto with pancetta (that's how it was described in the menu).
What arrived was mushroom risotto with two large (3"x3") slabs of what seemed to be raw pork belly/fat on top.
The risotto had no pork or meat flavor to it - it was good, but there was no connection to the weird "topper".
My BF and I are by no means vegetarians and neither are we squeamish - especially him, not at all -
and we both found the "meat" to be truly disgusting.

When our very perky server checked on us, we expressed disappointment/concern and her response was "yeah, usually the pancetta is small, cooked and within the risotto, but I guess the chef wanted to something a little edgier tonight".
And then she giggled and popped away.
"Edgier"?
Raw, large slabs of light pink fat?
How about "grosser"?.
It was so revolting that neither of us could eat anything else - my veal tartare was untouched as a result.
My complaint was not as much with the food - there some things that I/
we don't like -
so be it - no big deal.

But the fact that the server did not seem at all concerned that we didn't like it, that she didn't notice or care that we stopped eating and didn't touch large plates of food after it arrived, that she didn't even ask "was there something wrong with the tartare?" or when we expressed dissatisfaction with the risotto "can I bring you something else?
" etc etc - you get what I mean...
We were having a large, fairly expensive meal at a very nice, upscale restaurant and our server was either clueless and/or completely insensitive to our satisfaction.
Extremely disappointing - the experience will seriously make me question whether to go back, which is too bad.

The place is pretty, the food is often tasty and the wine list is very special - largely Italian, which I don't know well at all, but the sommeliers are extremely helpful - they have always helped me find things I like (which is no small challenge) - they are truly great.
But this dinner was far from pleasant - bummer.

No privacy in the main dining room, though, the tables are so closely arranged your fellow diners' conversation can easily be overhearad.

it still isnt all that cheap, and although the food we had wasnt bad, it didnt deserve the rep we had heard.
between 5 people we had quite  bit of food.

excerpts: I highly recommend Perbacco!!
perbacco.author: Jennifer D.
perbacco.review: We had our celebratory wedding dinner here last Friday.  We had 17 people and reserved the Barolo Room.  The room was absolutely perfect.  Our server was so friendly and helpful and fun.  The food was some of the best I've ever eaten.  We asked the restaurant for help with our preselected wine and it was wonderful.  The overall experience was more than I could have hoped for.  Our guests cannot stop raving about how great everything was.  I highly recommend Perbacco!!

excerpts: but Perbacco is an exception.
It's absolutely fantastic in terms of food, service, and ambiance.
Would highly recommend.
perbacco.author: Sydney L.
perbacco.review: It's rare I go to a restaurant more than once in San Francisco (there are too many to try!) but Perbacco is an exception. It's absolutely fantastic in terms of food, service, and ambiance. Would highly recommend.

excerpts: I have been to Perbacco twice for lunch and have really like the atmosphere.
The service is solid also.
The food is good but not spectacular.
I had pasta both times; it was well prepared but nothing exceptional.
perbacco.author: Peter H.
perbacco.review:
I have been to Perbacco twice for lunch and have really like the atmosphere.  The service is solid also.  The food is good but not spectacular.  I had pasta both times; it was well prepared but nothing exceptional.  This is a perfectly good place for a business lunch or whatever, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there.

SFD

excerpts: So, is Perbacco's food magnificent?
Probably not by our twisted standards, but it is very good.
What makes this place great, though, is the overall experience.
In a previous life, I worked in restaurants and one axiom is that great service can make up for not-so-great food, but great food will not make up for bad service.
At Perbacco you get good food, but you also get great service (and usually with an accent).
I have always felt very taken care of and very appreciated as a patron here.
You get the full-on dining experience.
You pay for that experience, true, but all-in-all, I think you get a nice return on that investment.
perbacco.author: Don B.
perbacco.review: We are more than a little spoiled here in The City. What we consider mediocre is probably magnificent elsewhere and our magnificent is orgasmic almost anywhere else. So, is Perbacco's food magnificent? Probably not by our twisted standards, but it is very good. What makes this place great, though, is the overall experience. In a previous life, I worked in restaurants and one axiom is that great service can make up for not-so-great food, but great food will not make up for bad service. At Perbacco you get good food, but you also get great service (and usually with an accent). I have always felt very taken care of and very appreciated as a patron here. You get the full-on dining experience. You pay for that experience, true, but all-in-all, I think you get a nice return on that investment.

excerpts: I was a little embarrassed to send a dish back, but it's obvious that the staff at Perbacco really want each customer to leave happy, and we certainly did.
Both our server and the sommelier were friendly and helpful.
I would definitely go back.
perbacco.author: Michelle A.
perbacco.review: Went here last night for dinner.  The high points included the cocktails, the salumi platter, and the duck.  The not-so-high points included the rabbit (overcooked) and the salad with hazelnuts (boring). The service really sets this place apart.  I told the server that I thought the rabbit was overcooked, and he immediately whisked it off the table, the sommelier instantly appeared with a plate of gnocchi so I would have something to eat while my husband ate his pasta, and then they brought us the duck to share after we finished the pasta and gnocchi.  I was a little embarrassed to send a dish back, but it's obvious that the staff at Perbacco really want each customer to leave happy, and we certainly did.  Both our server and the sommelier were friendly and helpful.  I would definitely go back.

excerpts: Look, Perbacco isn't a horrible restaurant - it's just doesn't live up to the hype stirred up by the hyperventilating foodie crowd.
perbacco.author: Lulu C.
perbacco.review: I had high expectations, but was somewhat disappointed.  First of all, the service is amazing and is a nice treat.  Too bad what they bring to the table doesn't match professional friendly service.  I had the mushroom risotto. Sure, they had another fancy name for it, but get real, it was mushroom risotto...and it was very over salted.  Mushrooms have an earthiness that stands on its own, no need to muck it up by shoveling heaps of salt in the dish.  I had also ordered a beet salad, but it was so uninspiring that I forget many of the details surrounding it.   Look, Perbacco isn't a horrible restaurant - it's just doesn't live up to the hype stirred up by the hyperventilating foodie crowd.

excerpts: I have been to Perbacco twice and really enjoyed the food both times.
I especially like the short ribs, the tagliatelle and the caramel/ sea salt gelato.
Service is very helpful and not snooty.
The atmosphere is a little bland for my taste.
A good place to impress the in-laws!
perbacco.author: Melissa K.
perbacco.review: I have been to Perbacco twice and really enjoyed the food both times.  I especially like the short ribs, the tagliatelle and the caramel/ sea salt gelato.  Service is very helpful and not snooty.  The atmosphere is a little bland for my taste.  A good place to impress the in-laws!

Food was great...definitely try the burnt caramel & sea salt gelato if you can.  Great!  :-)  We will be eating at Perbacco again!

excerpts: I highly recommend Perbacco to you.
perbacco.author: Tom B.
perbacco.review: I dined with my friend on Monday, March 22 & we had a spectacular meal.  Despite the energy and noise of the dining room, we were able to have a romantic dinner.  Offering wine by the glass selections in two glass 250ml decanters is a great idea and helped us pair wines to our courses.  We enjoyed the arugula & strawberry salad, seafood risotto, rabbit ravioli (angolotti), Piedmontese blood sausage, cheese & dessert.  The food was delicious & portions were large enough despite the fact we split everything.  We enjoyed a glass each of Franciacorta  brut, a muller-thurgau from Alto Adige, a 375ml bottle of Barolo & a 20 year tawny from Taylor-Fladgate.  Service was impeccable; quiet, omnipresent & knowledgeable.  The speed and efficiency of the kitchen given the quality of the food is incredible.  I highly recommend Perbacco to you.

excerpts: Perbacco staff were accommodating and kind.

The food came out quickly (not too quickly) and perfectly prepared for all guests.
