I will go back again and again.

excerpts: I was looking forward to perbacco as I heard so many great things, but sadly I won't be returning.
perbacco.author: Lisa P.
perbacco.review: Four stars?? Really?  The salami plate needed some time hanging from the ceiling, 4 out of the 5 were more like mushy salami pate.  A mixed green salad was as boring as anything. Two pastas to avoid-bolognese out of a can plopped on dry egg noodles. Blech.  Gnocchi, soft and light, with salty brothy sauce with rubbery mushrooms. Very disappointing in the height of mushroom season. Truffle meals start nov 9, but after asking twice, no go for lunchtime truffles only 3 hours away from dinner. Our waiter did not move things in the right direction.  I was looking forward to perbacco as I heard so many great things, but sadly I won't be returning.

excerpts: If you go to Perbacco try to reserve a table on the ground floor as the upstairs was a bit drab and had an odd odor.
perbacco.author: Ben M.
perbacco.review: I had high expectations for this place and in the end the experience fell a bit short.  I ordered the "signature" dish which was some sort of short rib pasta and while it was certainly good it wasn't very interesting and I found myself bored with it half way through.  That paired with a mealy heirloom tomato salad and my impression of the food simply was not great.  However, the prices were fair and the service was very good.  If you go to Perbacco try to reserve a table on the ground floor as the upstairs was a bit drab and had an odd odor.

excerpts: Perbacco is, hands down, my favorite restaurant.
I've never had a bad dish at Perbacco, and I almost hate talking to people about it because I don't want it to get any more crowded than it is!
But the staff is so nice and friendly, I have to give them their due.
Go to Perbacco, you won't be disappointed.
perbacco.author: Tim H.
perbacco.review:
Perbacco is, hands down, my favorite restaurant. Here are just a few reasons:

1. Scallop crudo with pomegranate, mint, and olive oil. Completely luscious. My mouth waters just thinking about it. I would come for this alone. 

2. Warm, professional staff that are perfectly attentive, make recommendations, then leave you to your meal. 

3. Rich, delicious stewed meats with handmade pasta, like the agnolotti with rabbit and truffle. 

4. Gooey in the middle, warm and crusty on the outside, pistachio cake. 

5. The Notte Picante, a spicy cocktail special. A gimlet with a twist. 

I've never had a bad dish at Perbacco, and I almost hate talking to people about it because I don't want it to get any more crowded than it is! But the staff is so nice and friendly, I have to give them their due. Go to Perbacco, you won't be disappointed.

excerpts: I had read sample Perbacco menus and reviews, saw that it was heavy on the meat, esp.
processed meats,
so I wasn't expecting much.
There were 2 entree choices for our party - either filet mignon or scallops - and I picked the latter.
What came out was as follows: bread sticks - nice, but I'm not a stick fan.
There was some sort of tasty dip, perhaps a chimichurri, to dip them into, and that gave them a little flavor.
Next, real bread.
Delicious, soft with a good crust, and fresh butter.
The salad was mixed greens - arugula, radicchio, and endive.
Tiny granules of salt and pepper sparkled on the tongue - a nice effect, but sprinkled a little too generously for my taste.
I would have preferred more vinegar in the vinaigrette.
The scallops were huge and perfectly cooked - charred on each side of the "coin" and soft in the middle.
The sauce was a demiglace or reduction, scattered with corn kernels, sauteed slices of wild mushroom, and little nubbins of something else - perhaps fennel.
So good
I had to sop it up with my bread.
Dessert was divine panna cotta with a mixed berry sauce.
I don't know whose Pinot Gris I had, but
I'm sure it had no effect on my judgment
I'll be back soon to try the other dishes.
Gotta introduce this place to my hub.

perfect.

There it is so soft and served very simply w/salt and olive oil on great toasted bread.  I thought the Perbacco version was an interesting combo (with the red pepper) but the cheese itself was on the tougher side and the bread it came with was just not up to snuff.   The appetizer that was incredible was the albacore crudo.  OMG.  Explosion of flavor and nice kick of salt.  I will be back for this.  I had the papardelle in short rib sauce.  I thought it was great.  Warm and rich on a rainy night.  perfect.  Then we ordered the chocolate mouse cake or something like that and it was disappointing.  I didn't care for it.  Kinda dry and just nothing special.  We also got the "ugly" piedmont cookies and those were GREAT.  I wanted a dozen to go.  We sat up on the balcony.  We all enjoyed ourselves and although every dish didn't hit, I will be very glad to go back for a cocktail and more crudo.

UPDATE:  Ate a late lunch here today and it was stellar.  the arugula salad w/fennel, orange and marcona almonds was perfect.  also had the pansotti in brown butter.  very good, but had better in italy.  had the radish greens too and they were perfect - tender and flavorful.  then dessert.  oh.  my.  god.  had the carmel bonet (new on the menu) w/apricot compote and carmel sauce.  had it with a glass of vin santo and it was absolutely perfect.  incredible.  just amazing.  once again, giving it 4 out of 5 stars.  service was very very good - relaxed and personal.  of course it was an odd hour and not many other diners, but still just great hostess, waiter and owner, were very attentive.

excerpts: not that i'm a huge fan of frisson, but that drink was so amazing it is still making me weak in the knees days later, and perbacco was such a downer... i almost got in a fight with my boyfriend because everything was so NOT good
too bad perbacco didn't have anything to do with that, or they might have gotten another star.
perbacco.author: eva g.
perbacco.review:
talk about a disappointment... this was one of those dinners when i really wished we had stayed and eaten at the first place where we had drinks. an UNbelievably good passionfruit caiparinha at frisson! not that i'm a huge fan of frisson, but that drink was so amazing it is still making me weak in the knees days later, and perbacco was such a downer... i almost got in a fight with my boyfriend because everything was so NOT good - i had to take it out on somebody.

to start off with, we were seated along the side in the back behind one of the huge columns. now clearly the columns are structural, i know, but if you have these huge things blocking half the people's view in the restaurant... don't you want them to look nice?!  The wood paneling is cut poorly, the edges don't meet, the stainless steel corner gaurds don't come up to the top, and then they just secured it all with huge bolts right through the finish wood. it looks like a job someone's drunk uncle would do in cheap basement redesign. and it is directly at eye level! soooo shoddy! i realize it's not about the food, but it's like the age-old clean bathroom theory... if a place can't get those small details right, what's going on in the kitchen?

my cocktail was terrible (frisson ruined me)... way too sweet with no flavor but vodka and sugar with a sugar rim. and some sugar. oh, and did i mention it had sugar? first thing they tell us is that there's no more burrata which is the one thing i really wanted. watercress salad was fine. watercress and ricotta salata with o+v. maybe .50cents worth of product on the plate for $9.00. what is that, like a 450% mark up? 

then we tried to order wine but i am not knowledgeable about italian wines and these are far and away the bulk of what they have. the sommelier came over, but he had such a thick accent i really could not follow what he was saying. granted that was my problem, so i just got a glass of cab (and the waitress did nicely swap it for my unpalatable cocktail.) but it would really help to have the wine menu broken up into some categories like "big reds", "dry whites", etc.

for dinner i had risotto which was also just fine. nothing exciting or out of the ordinary in any way, shape or form. the risotto i had a few months back at chez spencer... that was extraordinary! my bf ordered rabbit or something (probably the real reason i was pissed at him - how can  you sit down and order thumper's cousin with your vegetarian girlfriend?) anyway, she brought one dish and after he took a couple bites she comes back and said she ordered him the wrong thing. she takes the plate and leaves him with nothing while we wait for his main dish. i've worked in a lot of restaurants, and usually it's polite if it's your fuck up to just let the customer enjoy what you brought them while their correct dish is cooked. it's not like someone else was going to be able to eat it after my boyfriend already started it. and of course i was finished by the time his came. and no, we did not even get a free scoop of gelato for that.

we did order 2 desserts - i always like to give a place a chance up until the very end. the panna cotta was not very good - it was not nearly as rich or nicely tectured as many in the city ( it is as chic as molten chocolate cake at this point), though it did have a good cookie with it. the coffee custard w/ chocolate crust was quite good, but the best part of the meal was certainly the sambucca. too bad perbacco didn't have anything to do with that, or they might have gotten another star.

excerpts: What can I add that over 700 reviewers haven't already stated?  Not much other than to say that dinner last night at Perbacco was lovely!
The food was awesome and service was across the board attentive and gracious right from the front of the house to our server!
We were a party of three and requested a table upstairs and that is exactly what we received.
We started with three appetizers:  the AVIOLO FILLED WITH TRUFFLED RICOTTA, the FRITTO MISTO OF ROCK SHRIMP, and ROASTED D"ANJOU PEAR SALAD.
The Aviolo was my absolute favorite.
The Fritto Misto was very light - perhaps a few too many fried olives for my liking.
For our main entree, we shared three pastas ($18 per person for the entire table).

We had the RABATÒN (TRUFFLE-HERB RICOTTA GNOCCHI / ROASTED MUSHROOM SUGO), the PACCHERI (LARGE PASTA TUBES with ALBACORE TUNA RAGU / TOMATO / CAPERS / CHILI PEPPER), and my usual favorite, the PAPPARDELLE with SHORT RIB RAGU.
My absolute favorite last night was the pasta with tuna.
I thought the portions were quite ample as well.
I probably would have preferred that we had the option to have the food served family style as opposed to pre-divided into three piles on a long rectangular plate.
I think it would have been a bit warmer.
Also, as a person who now lives and works in the Peninsula, I loved the $10 valet parking as parking is impossible in the FIDI.
Even lukewarm, the pastas were delicious.
Sad to say we skipped dessert and coffee as we were stuffed!
I really can't wait to go back again
and I definitely want/need to check out Barbacco next door.

excerpts: Let me frame this - if I had walked in off the street and didnt know anything about Perbacco, I might have been surprised.
But, ranking with the heavy hitters in SF ?
No way.
First off, the space sucks.
Its noisy, crowded adn gives one the feel of a conference center and the smell of rank carpet.
They sat us on the second floor under an exit sign.
Since my wife refused to glow green all night we were given another table 10 feet away.
Not much of an improvement.
Secondly, the service was abyssmal.
I lost count of the times my mind drifte to 'where the hell is our waiter' and I had to flag someone down more than thrice to get some attention.
He would leave in mid sentence to handle something else, not to mention forgetting whole portions of our order.
I'm not even going to go into his limited knowledge of the menu ( where he had to return to the kitchen three times to get questions answered )
- it was pretty pathetic for a ranked restaurant.
The food for the most part was mediocre - traditional plates done in an American style with little surprise or panache.
The sea-bass was soggy, the paperdelle dry and the sugo sugary like a chinese to go.
The one savior was the older gentleman who acted as Sommellier - he reco'd some very interesting wines, and they turned out to be the highlite of the evening.
Overall, would not go back.
There are too many other restaurants that have to earn their clientelle.
Sayonara Perbacco.

Perbacco has quite the flair of fine dining in decor and in clientèle.
The first thing that struck me was the monastic expressions on the faces of the wait staff.
Our server only cracked a smile, which all of us rated as 'fake' when we were presented with the bill.
We had to ask for the bread, although the server walked around us several times to make sure that the plates of the folks next to us were filled.
We tried a variety of appetizers (beets, shrimp, squid, cheese & tomato) and main courses (meatballs, sea bass and  chicken).
All of them were good, but none really stood out as great.
Everyone was 'stuffed' by the end and we only tried the Hazelnut cookies which were very good.
I had never come across such a lite and airy cookie that had a chewy and pleasant texture.
If the hype and the prices were lower, I would have given this a better rating.

excerpts: I really enjoyed my  dinner at Perbacco.
We arrived a little early and had a drink at the bar.
The bar is insanely loud.
Noise doesn't normally bother me much but the bar was really, really loud.
Once we were seated the dining room was much more comfortable and much easier to have a conversation.
The wine list has many nice selections and our waiter was able to help us select a great wine.
We tried the salami plate which had four interesting selections and we both enjoyed them all.
The waiter recommended the roasted octupus appetizer and it was unique and
really my favorite thing we tried.
We also had the anglotti with rabbit ragout, it was tasty
but I wouldn't order it again
and finally we had the pork chop which was cooked to perfection
but the butternut squash it was served with had little flavor.
Overall it was good, our server was trying hard but disappeared for great lengths of time but the excellent busboy made up for his lack of attention.
One odd thing about the wine service, he showed us the wine bottle and then left to open it in the waiter station.
He came back with and explained that they always do that because Italian wines are often difficult to open.
It was a rather strange way to serve the wine but we survived.

excerpts: Perbacco shines with cooking that spotlights the Piemonte region and elements from Liguria and Provence.
The slow roasted veal appetizer with lemon and albacore tuna sauce is so tender and tasty, they should seriously make giant sandwiches out of that stuff.
While I thought about having the Salumi Misti, house cured meats and salami - after all, it is #18 on 7x7's list of places to try before you die -
I opted for the squid which was also impressively tender and nicely accented with lemon and red chili flakes.
The folks here make their own pasta daily, and you can taste the freshness in dishes such as the roasted rabbit agnolotti.
The Subrich, or Piemontese meatballs, were perfectly prepared, not too dense or mushy, with a rich and savory spiced red wine jus offset by slightly sweet apples and potato puree.
Don't forget dessert.

They have a lot of chocolatey and nutty decadence on the menu, but they also have interesting items like citrus and vanilla infused rice pudding with a caramel crust, a cross between rice pudding and creme brulee.
At noon, the suit set converges upon this place, so be sure to have reservations.

perbacco.author: Molly T.
perbacco.review:
I had heard a lot about this new Italian place in the financial district and the opportunity to try it out presented itself.  I was taking several co-workers out to dinner so I was a little nervous about trying a new place, but am I glad we went!  
The food was fantastic.  We had way to many dishes to list them all. There were six of us so we split a few different appetizers, which were all delicious.  Almost all of us had a different entree, but everyone loved what they ordered.  And dessert!  Again, we all split a few desserts and I highly HIGHLY recommend the chocolate tart.  It's amazing.  That was our favorite dessert.  
The staff was very nice.  We never waited too long for anything, nor did we feel rushed.  The tables weren't too close together.  I can't stand it when it feels like you are eating dinner with the strangers next to you.  I didn't ever feel like any one conversation was overpowering and I'm pretty sure our group was OK.  The mezzanine was a cool place to be seated.  We didn't have a drink at the bar, but it looked fun and the place was pretty crowded when we left (it was a Thursday  night).
The only negative, and it's not really that bad, is that the menu is a bit pretentious, even for San Francisco.  There are a lot of fancy food words and you sort of find yourself looking for things you recognize (e.g. does that mean it's a chicken dish??)  But once you get past that it was a great dining experience and I would definitely go back.  I even sent my boss and my CEO to dinner there the other night and they thought it was great!
Overall, Perbacco is a wonderful new addition to the dining options in San Francisco.

excerpts: We dined at Perbacco 8:30PM thursday night.
High ceilings, brick wall, and large space.
Good downtown vibe.
We had a couple of glasses of the Barbera which was tasty.
Service was great.
Next table over, lady forgot her reading glasses so the waiter came back with a case of reading glasses for her to choose from.
The other next table over another waiter picks up dinner napkin from floor and spends the time to fold it ever so nicely in a upside down V
so it would stand up on the table before the customer returned from the bathroom.
Our appetizer, octopus salad, came out promptly.
First time I had octopus that wasn't slightly rubbery.
Surprisingly it was soooo soft.
Yummy.
My favorite part was the pasta sampling.
Incredible home made pastas:
Tajina  with the 5 hour pork sugo, pappardelle with shredded short ribs, and gnocchi stuffed with Ricotta.
I absolutely loved their pastas.
My favorite from the sampling was the gnocchi and Mr. ShiverMeTimber's fave was the tajina.
Gnocchi was light in texture.
I'm not sure how to describe but it was scrumptious.
We had the halibut which I couldn't finish because I was stuffed.
Mr. P said that it was very good as he helped himself to mine.
Next time I hope there's room for dessert or a cheese plate.
Great dinner!

excerpts: With 473 reviews, nobody needs my 2 cents about Perbacco.
But since I walked 4 hours to get there for dinner tonight, I might as well chime in.
True, I did not take the most direct route.

Starting at the Ferry Bldg, I walked up the Embarcadero, through Fisherman's Wharf and Fort Mason, up Chestnut St. to the Presidio, climbed the spectacular Lyon Street Steps, and headed out Sacramento St. to Presidio.
Then back along California to Divisidero and down Divis to Castro, where I thought I'd check out Gay Pride weekend.
Things were in preparation, but nothing had really started yet.
It seemed like there was better planning than in the past:  plenty of porta-potties everywhere around Dolores Park, scene of the Dyke Festival.
( I remember eating at Delfina a few years ago during that celebration when the restaurant was beseiged by revellers from the street wanting to use the restroom.
One particularly agressive young woman, when denied access stomped out yelling
"Delfina hates lesbians!")
So I continued down 18th St, left on Valencia to Market, down Market and finally wound up at Perbacco on California St.
Of course, I could have just walked the 2 or 3 blocks from the Ferry Bl.
but that would have been too boring.

I ordered two small pasta plates, the agnolotti dal plin filled with roasted vitelloni and savoy cabbage, followed by the tajarine:  handcut very thin tagliatelli in a brilliant saffron color with pork sugo.
Both dishes were a bit similar (the vitelloni and sugo were not that far apart) but each was quite good, with deep, complex flavors, more on the refined than the rustic side.
My glass of Barbera d'Alba was superb and complemented both dishes.
So that was it--a bit anticlimactic after the four hour trek, perhaps.
In terms of pure enjoyment, I got more out of the custard- filled bombolloni I bought from Boriana's at the Ferry Building, or the In 'N'
Out burger
I indulged in at Fisherman's Wharf.
Most interesting to me was how each Italian restaurant attracts such a different clientelle.
Perbacco was filled with downtown types--jaded older patrons spinkled with a few young professionals, all very buttoned up.
A16, by contrast, attacts the young Marina yuppie crowd, whereas Delfina, which requires a trek to the Mission, is filled with a diverse, vibrant mix of everything,

excerpts: perbacco is perfect for upscale tapas.
with the modern, woodsy design, its no wonder corporate 9-5ers flock to this place.
perbacco.author: Anthro Food E.
perbacco.review: perbacco is perfect for upscale tapas.  with the modern, woodsy design, its no wonder corporate 9-5ers flock to this place.  i really loved the non-alcoholic drink called limonata salata, which is basically a salty lemonade.  sheer genius!  the salt cod and potato gratin is genius too!  a bit salty so be sure to eat in small doses. the olive plate was good, but nothing special.  the salumi misit (all of the above) is highly recommended if youre into cured meats.  overall, this was a good experience.  the waitstaff was very attentive no matter how crazy it got during happy hour. also, if you would rather have an entree rather than go the tapas route, i would recommend the parpadelle ragu in wine sauce.  everything about it will make you speechless!  the risotto w/ duck confit was good, but not great.  the duck confit was spectacular because it really melted in my mouth, and unfortunately i cant say the same for the risotto.  it was runny and not thick/creamy as it shouldve been. the large mushrooms in the risotto seemed large and intimidating for such a delicate, yet rich dish...

excerpts: To drink, I started with the Aloe and Goodbye cocktail, an unusual combination that felt like a risky order, but turned out to be nicely refreshing.
And for my main, I split the Raviora and the Quail with my SO - the raviora is a MUST.
Meyer lemon + ricotta cheese and mint is an incredible combination.
The quail is no slouch either, with a crispy exterior, delicate interior, and perfectly paired mushrooms on the side.
Suffice it to say, I will be back.
aloe and goodbye.author: Megan B.
aloe and goodbye.review: I had an amazing experience at Perbacco. It's been hyped up for me (and I've been to its sister restaurant Barbacco), but it totally lived up to expectations. I was with a group of six and everyone enjoyed the food and service tremendously. We had a couple of appetizers between us, including the octopus, which was perfectly cooked (i.e. not rubbery at all); the burrata, which was perfectly creamy and paired with delightful asparagus; and a beet salad, which was tasty. To drink, I started with the Aloe and Goodbye cocktail, an unusual combination that felt like a risky order, but turned out to be nicely refreshing. And for my main, I split the Raviora and the Quail with my SO - the raviora is a MUST. Meyer lemon + ricotta cheese and mint is an incredible combination. The quail is no slouch either, with a crispy exterior, delicate interior, and perfectly paired mushrooms on the side. Suffice it to say, I will be back.

excerpts: I also enjoyed the minted southside which was refreshing and wasn't overly sweet.
minted southside.author: Charlene E.
minted southside.review:
Highly recommend the tajarin pasta and I would definitely return for this dish alone. 

The tajarin is must if you're a mushroom fan. The pork and porcini mushroom sauce was so tasty and creamy. The pasta had just the right texture/chewiness. My fiancé ordered the pappardelle pasta which was good as well but paled in comparison to the tajarin pasta. Their roasted octopus appetizer paired well with the arugula and beans. I also enjoyed the minted southside which was refreshing and wasn't overly sweet. 

Our server was attentive and made thoughtful suggestions throughout our meal. I wouldn't hesitate to return for my next pasta craving.

excerpts: Went here again for happy hour this week for the same items as my first time after I told a coworker about the limonata.
DELISH!
I tried their limonata scozzese as I've never tried a drink that had cucumber.
It was very delicious and of course, refreshing in the sense that it had cucumber and was something new to try.
We also tried the fritto misto, which had fried green olives that I really liked.
Generally, I think green olives are too salty for me
but with it being fried, it made it less salty but a slight tanginess that I liked.
Happy hour", (as the prices are not the norm of happy hour) was a great experience, which makes me want to come back to try the dinner menu.

limonata.review:
Went here again for happy hour this week for the same items as my first time after I told a coworker about the limonata. DELISH! Makes it even better now that I know they are quite consistent in service and yummie food.

Previous visit: I went there for a quick drink after work Friday and refreshingly enough, it was not overly packed like most of the area's bars/restaurants.    Not sure if that is a good thing or not, but I appreciated not having to push through a crowd or have to wait to order my drink.  I tried their limonata scozzese as I've never tried a drink that had cucumber.  It was very delicious and of course, refreshing in the sense that it had cucumber and was something new to try.  We also tried the fritto misto, which had fried green olives that I really liked.  Generally, I think green olives are too salty for me but with it being fried, it made it less salty but a slight tanginess that I liked.  "Happy hour", (as the prices are not the norm of happy hour) was a great experience, which makes me want to come back to try the dinner menu.

excerpts: My husband enjoyed some extremely well made Limonata Scozzeses by bartender Steve (his own creation!).
It was so nice and relaxing at the bar drinking some really good drinks, we decided to order some apps.
We went with the olives and the parmesian cheese plate.
Both were delicious.
The parm comes with bread, a wine reduction sauce and some other sauces and marcona almonds.
The olives are a meal themselves.
The ambience is great- comfortable but downtown trendy.
We were there on a Friday night and it wasn't too packed, but it was definitely full.
They could've used some music, but other than that, it was nice to sit back and enjoy the surroundings.
I will definitely be back!
Big props to the bartenders.
They make amazing drinks!
limonata.author: Maral P.
limonata.review: This place is awesome!  My husband and I decided to check this place out because we'd heard good things about it and we happened to be in the area.  We had already eaten so we decided to sit at the bar and get some drinks.  They have a great Italian wine selection plus other wines that aren't on the menu (if you tell the bartender what you like, s/he will be able to pick something out for you if there isn't something on the menu that you are interested in).  I started out with a nice glass of Chardonnay, but eventually made my way to a really nice Barbera and an outstanding Montepulciano based on the bartender's recommendation.  My husband enjoyed some extremely well made Limonata Scozzeses by bartender Steve (his own creation!).  It was so nice and relaxing at the bar drinking some really good drinks, we decided to order some apps.  We went with the olives and the parmesian cheese plate.  Both were delicious.  The parm comes with bread, a wine reduction sauce and some other sauces and marcona almonds.  The olives are a meal themselves.  The ambience is great- comfortable but downtown trendy.  We were there on a Friday night and it wasn't too packed, but it was definitely full.   They could've used some music, but other than that, it was nice to sit back and enjoy the surroundings.  I will definitely be back!  Big props to the bartenders.   They make amazing drinks!
